regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) â€“ Material scope

description.brief_summary: Specifies when the Regulation applies to processing of personal data and lists categories of processing that are excluded from its scope, including activities outside Union law, certain Member State activities under TEU Title V, purely personal/household activities, and processing by competent authorities for criminal law enforcement/public security purposes.
description.detailed_explanation: This section sets the material scope by defining covered processing operations and explicit exclusions. Covered processing includes (i) processing of personal data "wholly or partly by automated means" and (ii) non-automated processing of personal data that "form part of a filing system or are intended to form part of a filing system." The section then provides a closed list of exclusions where the Regulation "does not apply" to processing of personal data: (a) processing "in the course of an activity which falls outside the scope of Union law"; (b) processing "by the Member States when carrying out activities which fall within the scope of Chapter 2 of Title V of the TEU"; (c) processing "by a natural person in the course of a purely personal or household activity"; and (d) processing "by competent authorities" for specified criminal justice and public security purposes (prevention, investigation, detection, prosecution of criminal offences; execution of criminal penalties; safeguarding against and prevention of threats to public security). The section also clarifies that for processing by Union institutions/bodies/offices/agencies, a different instrument applies (Regulation (EC) No 45/2001), and that this instrument and other applicable Union legal acts for such processing "shall be adapted to the principles and rules of this Regulation" in accordance with Article 98. Finally, it states the Regulation is "without prejudice" to Directive 2000/31/EC, particularly intermediary service provider liability rules in Articles 12â€“15 of that Directive.
description.purpose: To delineate precisely which personal data processing activities fall under the Regulation and to prevent misapplication to excluded domains (e.g., household activities, certain state security/law enforcement activities, and EU institutions governed by a separate regime).
description.legislative_intent: To ensure consistent application to relevant personal data processing while respecting limits of Union competence, preserving specific regimes for Member State security activities and law enforcement, and maintaining the e-commerce intermediary liability framework.

what_it_covers: Processing of personal data wholly or partly by automated means (quote: "processing of personal data wholly or partly by automated means")
Processing other than by automated means of personal data that form part of a filing system (quote: "processing other than by automated means of personal data which form part of a filing system")
Processing other than by automated means of personal data intended to form part of a filing system (quote: "or are intended to form part of a filing system")

target_entities: Controllers and processors conducting covered processing of personal data (implied by applicability to processing activities)
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Within the scope of Union law for covered processing activities (explicitly excludes activities outside Union law).

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing of personal data in the course of an activity outside the scope of Union law (quote: "in the course of an activity which falls outside the scope of Union law")

Processing by Member States when carrying out activities within Chapter 2 of Title V TEU (quote: "by the Member States when carrying out activities which fall within the scope of Chapter 2 of Title V of the TEU")
Processing by a natural person in the course of a purely personal or household activity (quote: "by a natural person in the course of a purely personal or household activity")

Processing by competent authorities for criminal law enforcement and related public security purposes (quote: "by competent authorities for the purposes of the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of criminal offences or the execution of criminal penalties, including the safeguarding against and the prevention of threats to public security")

Processing of personal data by Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies is governed by Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 rather than this Regulation (quote: "For the processing of personal data by the Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies, Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 applies")

mandatory_obligations: Apply the Regulation to covered processing activities: automated processing of personal data and non-automated processing in/for a filing system (quote: "This Regulation applies to...")
For processing by Union institutions/bodies/offices/agencies: apply Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 (quote: "Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 applies")

Adapt Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 and other Union legal acts applicable to EU-institution processing to the principles and rules of this Regulation in accordance with Article 98 (quote: "shall be adapted to the principles and rules of this Regulation in accordance with Article 98")
prohibited_actions: Do not apply this Regulation to excluded processing categories (quote: "This Regulation does not apply to the processing of personal data: (a)... (d)...")
conditional_requirements: If processing is non-automated, the Regulation applies only where the personal data form part of a filing system or are intended to form part of a filing system (quote: "processing other than by automated means ... which form part of a filing system or are intended to form part of a filing system")
If processing is conducted by competent authorities for specified criminal justice/public security purposes, this Regulation does not apply (quote: "by competent authorities for the purposes of...")
If processing is by a natural person and purely personal/household, this Regulation does not apply (quote: "by a natural person in the course of a purely personal or household activity")

If processing is by Member States within Chapter 2 Title V TEU activities, this Regulation does not apply (quote: "by the Member States when carrying out activities which fall within the scope of Chapter 2 of Title V of the TEU")
If processing occurs in the course of an activity outside Union law, this Regulation does not apply (quote: "falls outside the scope of Union law")

Application is without prejudice to Directive 2000/31/EC, particularly intermediary liability rules (quote: "shall be without prejudice to the application of Directive 2000/31/EC, in particular of the liability rules of intermediary service providers in Articles 12 to 15")

general_restrictions: Material limitation: the Regulationâ€™s applicability is restricted to automated processing and certain non-automated processing linked to filing systems (quote: "wholly or partly by automated means"; "form part of a filing system or are intended to form part of a filing system")
data_restrictions: Non-automated processing is only within scope when connected to a filing system (quote: "form part of a filing system or are intended to form part of a filing system")
operational_restrictions: Excluded operational contexts: activities outside Union law; certain Member State TEU Title V activities; personal/household activities; competent authority criminal justice/public security processing (quotes as listed in exclusions)
technical_restrictions: Automated means trigger applicability (quote: "wholly or partly by automated means")
geographic_restrictions: Exclusion tied to Union competence (quote: "outside the scope of Union law")

general_exceptions: Activities outside the scope of Union law (quote: "falls outside the scope of Union law")
Member State activities within Chapter 2 of Title V TEU (quote: "within the scope of Chapter 2 of Title V of the TEU")
Purely personal or household activity by a natural person (quote: "purely personal or household activity")

Processing by competent authorities for criminal offences/criminal penalties/public security threat prevention (quote: "prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of criminal offences or the execution of criminal penalties, including the safeguarding against and the prevention of threats to public security")
conditional_exemptions: Non-automated processing not connected to a filing system is outside scope by implication (since only filing-system-related non-automated processing is covered)
public_interest_exceptions: Competent authority processing for criminal justice and public security purposes is excluded (quote: "including the safeguarding against and the prevention of threats to public security")

organizational_measures: Scope assessment: organizations must classify processing as automated/non-automated and determine whether non-automated processing is part of or intended for a filing system to decide applicability (derived directly from applicability criteria stated).

related_articles: Article 98 (adaptation clause referenced: "in accordance with Article 98")
complementary_regulations: Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 (EU institutions processing regime)
Directive 2000/31/EC (E-Commerce Directive), Articles 12â€“15 (intermediary liability rules)

implementation_steps: Inventory processing operations and tag each as automated vs non-automated.
For non-automated processing, determine whether the personal data are part of a filing system or intended to be included in one; if not, treat as out of scope for this Regulation.
Identify whether any processing is performed by a natural person purely for personal/household purposes; if so, treat as excluded.

Identify whether any processing is performed by competent authorities for criminal justice/public security purposes; if so, treat as excluded from this Regulation (and assess applicable alternative regime separately).
For EU institutions/bodies/offices/agencies processing, apply Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 and track any required adaptation under Article 98.
When assessing online intermediary activities, ensure compliance analysis also considers Directive 2000/31/EC Articles 12â€“15 because this Regulation does not override them ("without prejudice").
common_violations: Applying the Regulation to purely personal/household processing when it is excluded.
Failing to recognize that non-automated processing not linked to a filing system is outside scope.
Ignoring the separate legal regime for EU institutions (Regulation (EC) No 45/2001).
Assuming this Regulation overrides intermediary liability rules under Directive 2000/31/EC despite the 'without prejudice' clause.
best_practices: Maintain a documented scope determination for each processing activity (in-scope vs excluded) based on the explicit criteria and exclusions in this section.
Create decision rules for identifying 'competent authority' criminal justice/public security processing and routing it to the correct legal framework.
compliance_checklist: Is the processing of personal data wholly or partly automated?
If non-automated, is it part of or intended to be part of a filing system?
Is the activity outside the scope of Union law?
Is the processing by a Member State within Chapter 2 Title V TEU activities?
Is the processing by a natural person purely personal/household?
Is the processing by competent authorities for criminal offences/criminal penalties/public security threats?
Is the processing by EU institutions/bodies/offices/agencies (triggering Regulation (EC) No 45/2001)?
Does the activity implicate intermediary service provider liability rules under Directive 2000/31/EC Articles 12â€“15?

key_definitions.processing wholly or partly by automated: Processing of personal data carried out entirely or partially using automated methods (quote: "wholly or partly by automated means").
key_definitions.non-automated processing within scope: Non-automated processing is within scope only when the personal data "form part of a filing system or are intended to form part of a filing system".
key_definitions.excluded personal/household processing: Processing "by a natural person in the course of a purely personal or household activity" is excluded.
key_definitions.excluded competent authority processing: Processing "by competent authorities" for criminal justice purposes and public security threat prevention is excluded (quote: "prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of criminal offences or the execution of criminal penalties, including the safeguarding against and the prevention of threats to public security").

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 (EU institutions personal data processing regime) â€“ applicability and adaptation clause (as referenced in this section)

description.brief_summary: Establishes that EU institutions/bodies/offices/agencies are governed by Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 for their personal data processing, and mandates adaptation of that regime and other applicable Union legal acts to align with the principles and rules of this Regulation via Article 98.
description.detailed_explanation: The section contains two actionable statements about Regulation (EC) No 45/2001: (1) an applicability rule allocating EU-institution processing to Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 (quote: "For the processing of personal data by the Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies, Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 applies."); and (2) an adaptation requirement (quote: "Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 and other Union legal acts applicable to such processing of personal data shall be adapted to the principles and rules of this Regulation in accordance with Article 98."). No further operational requirements of Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 are detailed in this section beyond these allocation/alignment rules.
description.purpose: To clarify the governing legal instrument for EU institutionsâ€™ processing and ensure alignment of that instrument with the principles and rules of this Regulation.
description.legislative_intent: To avoid regulatory gaps or conflicts for EU institutions and to harmonize EU-institution data protection rules with the broader Regulationâ€™s principles.

what_it_covers: Processing of personal data by Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies (quote: "by the Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies")

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: EU-level institutions and entities.

what_it_does_not_cover: Non-EU-institution processing (not allocated to Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 by this clause).

mandatory_obligations: Apply Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 to processing of personal data by Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies (quote: "Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 applies")

Adapt Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 and other applicable Union legal acts to the principles and rules of this Regulation in accordance with Article 98 (quote: "shall be adapted to the principles and rules of this Regulation in accordance with Article 98")
prohibited_actions: Do not treat this Regulation as the governing instrument for EU institutionsâ€™ processing where Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 applies (implied by the allocation statement).
conditional_requirements: The applicability and adaptation obligations are triggered specifically "For the processing of personal data by the Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies" (quote).

general_restrictions: Regulatory allocation restriction: EU institutionsâ€™ processing is carved out to a separate regulation (quote: "Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 applies").

organizational_measures: Governance mapping: EU institutions should map processing activities to Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 as the applicable instrument (derived from the explicit applicability statement).

Legal alignment management: track and implement adaptations required under Article 98 to align Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 and other applicable acts with this Regulationâ€™s principles and rules (quote: "shall be adapted...").

complementary_regulations: The Regulation containing this section (material scope clause)

implementation_steps: If you are an EU institution/body/office/agency, treat Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 as the primary compliance framework for personal data processing.
Monitor and implement any adaptations mandated under Article 98 to align applicable EU-institution processing rules with this Regulationâ€™s principles.
common_violations: Applying the wrong legal instrument to EU-institution processing (using this Regulation instead of Regulation (EC) No 45/2001).
Failing to operationalize required adaptations under Article 98.
best_practices: Maintain a legal register identifying which processing operations fall under Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 vs this Regulation.
compliance_checklist: Are you a Union institution/body/office/agency processing personal data?
If yes, is Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 applied as the governing instrument?
Are you tracking required adaptations under Article 98?

key_definitions.Union institutions, bodies, offices and: EU-level entities identified as subject to Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 for their personal data processing (quote: "Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies").

regulations.regulation_name: Directive 2000/31/EC (E-Commerce Directive) â€“ Intermediary service provider liability rules (Articles 12 to 15) (non-prejudice clause as referenced in this section)

description.brief_summary: States that this Regulation does not prejudice the application of Directive 2000/31/EC, particularly the intermediary service provider liability rules in Articles 12â€“15.
description.detailed_explanation: The section contains a conflict/priority rule: "This Regulation shall be without prejudice to the application of Directive 2000/31/EC, in particular of the liability rules of intermediary service providers in Articles 12 to 15 of that Directive." This is an actionable interpretive requirement for compliance: when both instruments are relevant, organizations must ensure that obligations under this Regulation are implemented in a way that does not override or negate the continued application of the E-Commerce Directiveâ€™s intermediary liability framework (Articles 12â€“15). The section does not reproduce the substantive content of Articles 12â€“15; it only preserves their application.
description.purpose: To preserve the continued applicability of the E-Commerce Directiveâ€™s intermediary liability rules alongside this Regulation.
description.legislative_intent: To avoid unintended alteration of intermediary liability safe harbours and related rules by the data protection regime.

what_it_covers: Application/interaction rule between this Regulation and Directive 2000/31/EC (quote: "without prejudice to the application of Directive 2000/31/EC")
Specific emphasis on intermediary service provider liability rules in Articles 12â€“15 (quote: "in particular of the liability rules of intermediary service providers in Articles 12 to 15")

target_entities: Entities subject to this Regulation whose activities also implicate Directive 2000/31/EC intermediary liability rules

what_it_does_not_cover: Substantive requirements of Directive 2000/31/EC Articles 12â€“15 are not detailed in this section (only preserved).

mandatory_obligations: Ensure application of this Regulation does not prejudice the application of Directive 2000/31/EC (quote: "shall be without prejudice to the application of Directive 2000/31/EC")

Specifically preserve the application of intermediary service provider liability rules in Articles 12â€“15 of Directive 2000/31/EC (quote: "in particular of the liability rules of intermediary service providers in Articles 12 to 15")
prohibited_actions: Do not interpret or implement this Regulation in a way that disapplies or undermines Directive 2000/31/EC, especially Articles 12â€“15 (derived from "without prejudice").
conditional_requirements: Applies where Directive 2000/31/EC is relevant to the activity (implied by the preservation clause).

general_restrictions: Interpretation restriction: this Regulation cannot be used to negate the application of Directive 2000/31/EC (quote: "without prejudice").

organizational_measures: Legal interoperability assessment: where intermediary services are involved, confirm that compliance measures under this Regulation are designed and documented so they do not conflict with or displace Directive 2000/31/EC Articles 12â€“15 (derived from the non-prejudice clause).

complementary_regulations: The Regulation containing this section (material scope clause)

implementation_steps: Identify whether your services qualify as intermediary services potentially covered by Directive 2000/31/EC Articles 12â€“15.
When implementing measures under this Regulation, validate that they do not alter the applicability of the intermediary liability rules preserved by the non-prejudice clause.
common_violations: Assuming data protection obligations automatically override intermediary liability safe harbours despite the explicit 'without prejudice' clause.
best_practices: Maintain a cross-regulatory mapping for online services showing how compliance under this Regulation coexists with Directive 2000/31/EC Articles 12â€“15.
compliance_checklist: Do any of our services fall under intermediary service provider categories relevant to Directive 2000/31/EC?
Have we ensured our implementation of this Regulation does not prejudice the application of Directive 2000/31/EC, especially Articles 12â€“15?

key_definitions.without prejudice: A legal preservation clause meaning the application of this Regulation must not affect the application of Directive 2000/31/EC (quote: "shall be without prejudice to the application of Directive 2000/31/EC").

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 3 Territorial scope

applicable_regions: EU Member States (via Member State law where applicable by public international law)

description.brief_summary: Establishes when the GDPR applies based on the location/establishment of the controller or processor and the location of the data subjects, including extraterritorial reach for offering goods/services to, or monitoring, individuals in the Union.
description.detailed_explanation: This section sets out three independent jurisdictional hooks for applicability. (1) If processing occurs "in the context of the activities of an establishment" of a controller or processor in the Union, the Regulation applies regardless of where the processing physically takes place. (2) If a controller/processor is not established in the Union, the Regulation still applies when it processes personal data of data subjects who are in the Union, provided the processing is related to either offering goods or services to those data subjects in the Union (payment not required) or monitoring their behaviour insofar as the behaviour takes place within the Union. (3) The Regulation also applies to processing by a controller not established in the Union when the controller is located in a place where Member State law applies by virtue of public international law.
description.purpose: To define the territorial reach of the Regulation and prevent avoidance of EU data protection rules through offshore processing or non-EU establishment when targeting or monitoring individuals in the Union.
description.legislative_intent: To ensure consistent protection of personal data for individuals in the Union and to subject relevant processing activities to EU rules based on establishment, targeting, monitoring, or applicability of Member State law under public international law.

what_it_covers: Processing of personal data
Processing in the context of activities of an EU establishment of a controller or processor
Processing by non-EU controllers/processors of personal data of data subjects who are in the Union when related to offering goods/services to them
Processing by non-EU controllers/processors of personal data of data subjects who are in the Union when related to monitoring their behaviour within the Union
Processing by a non-EU controller in a place where Member State law applies by virtue of public international law

entity_types: Any organization acting as controller or processor
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies to (i) controllers/processors with an establishment in the Union; (ii) controllers/processors not established in the Union when targeting or monitoring data subjects in the Union; (iii) controllers not established in the Union but located where Member State law applies by virtue of public international law.

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing not in the context of activities of an EU establishment (for hook 1)
Processing by non-EU controllers/processors that is not related to offering goods/services to data subjects in the Union and not related to monitoring behaviour within the Union (for hook 2)
Monitoring of behaviour outside the Union (to the extent the behaviour does not take place within the Union, for hook 2(b))

mandatory_obligations: Applicability rule (EU establishment): The Regulation applies to "the processing of personal data in the context of the activities of an establishment of a controller or a processor in the Union, regardless of whether the processing takes place in the Union or not."

Applicability rule (non-EU targeting/monitoring): The Regulation applies to "the processing of personal data of data subjects who are in the Union by a controller or processor not established in the Union" where the processing activities are related to either offering goods/services to such data subjects in the Union or monitoring their behaviour within the Union.

Applicability rule (public international law): The Regulation applies to "the processing of personal data by a controller not established in the Union, but in a place where Member State law applies by virtue of public international law."
conditional_requirements: Condition for extraterritorial application to non-EU entities: processing must involve "personal data of data subjects who are in the Union" AND be related to at least one of the following: (a) "the offering of goods or services" to such data subjects in the Union ("irrespective of whether a payment of the data subject is required"), or (b) "the monitoring of their behaviour" insofar as the behaviour takes place within the Union.

Condition for EU-establishment hook: processing must be "in the context of the activities" of an establishment of a controller or processor in the Union; physical location of processing is irrelevant ("regardless of whether the processing takes place in the Union or not").
Condition for public-international-law hook: controller is not established in the Union but is in a place where "Member State law applies by virtue of public international law."

general_restrictions: Territorial limitation for monitoring hook: monitoring is only relevant "as far as their behaviour takes place within the Union."
geographic_restrictions: EU establishment hook applies irrespective of processing location: "regardless of whether the processing takes place in the Union or not."
Non-EU targeting/monitoring hook is limited to data subjects "who are in the Union" and to behaviour monitored "within the Union."
Public international law hook depends on Member State law applicability by virtue of public international law.

conditional_exemptions: Non-EU entities are not within scope under the targeting/monitoring hook if their processing is not related to offering goods/services to data subjects in the Union and not related to monitoring behaviour within the Union.

implementation_steps: Determine whether the organization has an "establishment" in the Union and whether processing is "in the context of the activities" of that establishment.

If not established in the Union, assess whether any processing involves personal data of data subjects "who are in the Union" and whether processing is related to (a) offering goods/services to them in the Union (payment irrelevant) or (b) monitoring behaviour within the Union.
Assess whether the organization is located in a place where Member State law applies by virtue of public international law (e.g., certain diplomatic/territorial contexts), triggering applicability.
common_violations: Assuming GDPR does not apply because processing infrastructure is outside the Union despite EU establishment context (contrary to "regardless of whether the processing takes place in the Union or not").

Assuming GDPR does not apply to a non-EU entity while offering goods/services to individuals in the Union because no payment is taken (contrary to "irrespective of whether a payment ... is required").
Ignoring GDPR applicability when monitoring behaviour of individuals in the Union (e.g., tracking) where the behaviour takes place within the Union.
best_practices: Map establishments and business activities in the Union to determine whether processing is in the context of those activities.
For non-EU entities, document whether goods/services are offered to individuals in the Union and whether behavioural monitoring occurs within the Union.
Maintain a jurisdictional applicability assessment as part of privacy governance.
compliance_checklist: Do we have an establishment in the Union (controller or processor)?
Is the processing conducted in the context of the activities of that EU establishment?
If not established in the Union: are we processing personal data of data subjects who are in the Union?
If yes: is the processing related to offering goods/services to those data subjects in the Union (payment irrelevant)?
If yes: is the processing related to monitoring behaviour, and does the behaviour take place within the Union?
Are we in a place where Member State law applies by virtue of public international law?

key_definitions.in the context of the activities of an e: Trigger for applicability where processing is linked to the activities of a controller/processor establishment in the Union (exact phrase: "in the context of the activities of an establishment of a controller or a processor in the Union").
key_definitions.regardless of whether the processing tak: Clarifies that physical location of processing does not limit applicability when the EU-establishment context is met.
key_definitions.data subjects who are in the Union: Condition for extraterritorial applicability to non-EU controllers/processors (exact phrase: "data subjects who are in the Union").
key_definitions.offering of goods or services: A scope trigger for non-EU controllers/processors when related to offering goods/services to data subjects in the Union (exact phrase: "the offering of goods or services, irrespective of whether a payment of the data subject is required").
key_definitions.monitoring of behaviour: A scope trigger for non-EU controllers/processors when related to monitoring behaviour, limited to behaviour within the Union (exact phrase: "the monitoring of their behaviour as far as their behaviour takes place within the Union").
key_definitions.Member State law applies by virtue of pu: A scope trigger applying GDPR to a non-EU controller located where Member State law applies due to public international law (exact phrase: "in a place where Member State law applies by virtue of public international law").

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 4 Definitions

description.brief_summary: Defines core GDPR terms that set legal thresholds and criteria for when GDPR obligations apply and how key concepts must be interpreted.
description.detailed_explanation: The section establishes binding definitions used throughout the Regulation. These definitions function as compliance criteria by determining (i) what constitutes personal data and processing; (ii) when processing is automated and/or includes specific operations; (iii) what qualifies as restriction of processing and profiling; (iv) when processing qualifies as pseudonymisation and the conditions required (separation of additional information and technical/organisational measures); (v) what constitutes a filing system; (vi) who is a controller or processor and how controller designation may be set by Union/Member State law; (vii) who is a recipient and the carve-out for public authorities receiving data in a particular inquiry; (viii) what constitutes consent and the required characteristics (freely given, specific, informed, unambiguous, statement or clear affirmative action); (ix) what constitutes a personal data breach; (x) definitions of special categories-related data types (genetic, biometric, health); (xi) how to determine main establishment for controllers/processors with multiple EU establishments; (xii) what constitutes a representative and the requirement of written designation pursuant to Article 27; (xiii) enterprise/group of undertakings; (xiv) binding corporate rules as internal policies for transfers within a group; (xv) supervisory authority and supervisory authority concerned; (xvi) cross-border processing tests; (xvii) relevant and reasoned objection criteria; (xviii) information society service by reference to Directive (EU) 2015/1535; and (xix) international organisation.
description.purpose: To provide uniform, legally certain meanings for key terms so that GDPR obligations are applied consistently across Member States and by controllers/processors.
description.legislative_intent: To harmonize interpretation and enforcement by defining triggers, roles, and thresholds (e.g., identifiability, cross-border processing, consent validity) that determine applicability of substantive GDPR duties.

what_it_covers: Definition of 'personal data' and identifiability criteria
Definition of 'processing' including enumerated operations
Definition of 'restriction of processing' as marking stored data to limit future processing
Definition of 'profiling' as automated processing to evaluate/predict personal aspects
Definition and conditions for 'pseudonymisation'
Definition of 'filing system'
Role definitions: controller, processor, recipient, third party, representative
Definition of 'consent' validity characteristics
Definition of 'personal data breach'
Definitions of genetic data, biometric data, data concerning health
Criteria for determining 'main establishment' for controllers/processors
Definitions relevant to governance: supervisory authority, supervisory authority concerned, cross-border processing, relevant and reasoned objection
Definition of information society service (by reference)
Definition of international organisation

entity_types: Natural persons acting as controllers/processors where applicable
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies in the context of the Regulation; includes criteria for entities with establishments in more than one Member State and representatives established in the Union.

what_it_does_not_cover: No standalone procedural obligations, deadlines, or penalty rules are set in this definitions section beyond definitional criteria and embedded conditions/carve-outs.

mandatory_obligations: Pseudonymisation condition: additional information must be kept separately and subject to technical and organisational measures to ensure non-attribution. Exact quote: "provided that such additional information is kept separately and is subject to technical and organisational measures to ensure that the personal data are not attributed to an identified or identifiable natural person".
Representative designation must be in writing (where applicable under Article 27). Exact quote: "designated by the controller or processor in writing pursuant to Article 27".

Public authority recipient carve-out condition: where public authorities receive personal data in the framework of a particular inquiry in accordance with Union or Member State law, they are not regarded as recipients; their processing must comply with applicable data protection rules according to the purposes of processing. Exact quote: "shall not be regarded as recipients; the processing of those data by those public authorities shall be in compliance with the applicable data protection rules according to the purposes of the processing".
conditional_requirements: Main establishment (controller) determination is conditional: central administration is main establishment unless decisions on purposes/means are taken in another EU establishment and that establishment has power to implement them; then that decision-making establishment is main establishment. Exact quote: "unless the decisions on the purposes and means ... are taken in another establishment ... and the latter establishment has the power to have such decisions implemented".

Main establishment (processor) determination is conditional: central administration is main establishment; if no central administration in the Union, main establishment is where main processing activities take place to the extent the processor is subject to specific obligations under the Regulation. Exact quote: "if the processor has no central administration in the Union, the establishment ... where the main processing activities ... take place to the extent that the processor is subject to specific obligations under this Regulation".

Cross-border processing classification is conditional on either (a) multi-establishment context in more than one Member State, or (b) single establishment processing that substantially affects or is likely to substantially affect data subjects in more than one Member State.

Supervisory authority concerned status is conditional on one of three triggers: establishment in that Member State; data subjects residing there substantially affected/likely affected; or complaint lodged with that authority.
documentation_requirements: Written designation of representative (where Article 27 applies).

general_restrictions: Restriction of processing is defined as limiting future processing by marking stored personal data. Exact quote: "the marking of stored personal data with the aim of limiting their processing in the future".
data_restrictions: Pseudonymisation requires separation of additional information and protective measures to prevent attribution to an identified/identifiable person.
technical_restrictions: Pseudonymisation requires "technical and organisational measures" to ensure non-attribution (specific measures not enumerated here).
geographic_restrictions: Representative must be "established in the Union".
Main establishment criteria are tied to establishments "in the Union" and Member State locations.

conditional_exemptions: Recipient definition carve-out: public authorities receiving personal data in the framework of a particular inquiry in accordance with Union or Member State law are not regarded as recipients.
public_interest_exceptions: Public authority inquiry carve-out within the 'recipient' definition (limited to receipt in a particular inquiry under Union/Member State law).

technical_measures: For pseudonymisation: implement measures ensuring personal data cannot be attributed to a specific data subject without additional information, and ensure additional information is kept separately.
organizational_measures: For pseudonymisation: organizational separation controls for additional information.
For representative: ensure written designation instrument exists where Article 27 applies.
security_measures: Personal data breach is defined as a security breach leading to accidental/unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorized disclosure of, or access to, personal data (used to trigger incident response duties elsewhere in the Regulation).

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authority (independent public authority established by a Member State pursuant to Article 51).
enforcement_mechanisms: Definition of 'supervisory authority concerned' establishes when an authority is involved in oversight (establishment, affected residents, or complaint).
Definition of 'relevant and reasoned objection' sets criteria for objections in the cooperation/consistency mechanism (procedural details elsewhere).

complementary_regulations: Directive (EU) 2015/1535 Article 1(1)(b) (definition of information society service) (referenced)

implementation_steps: Classify data as 'personal data' if it relates to an identified/identifiable natural person, including indirect identification via identifiers (name, ID number, location data, online identifier) or identity factors.
Treat a broad set of operations as 'processing' (collection through destruction), including non-automated processing.

If claiming 'pseudonymisation', ensure (1) re-identification requires additional information, (2) additional information is kept separately, and (3) technical and organisational measures prevent attribution.
Determine controller vs processor roles based on who determines purposes and means (controller) vs who processes on behalf of controller (processor).
When disclosing data, determine whether the receiving party is a 'recipient'; apply the public authority inquiry carve-out where conditions are met.
Validate consent against the defined elements: freely given, specific, informed, unambiguous, and expressed by statement or clear affirmative action.
Classify incidents as 'personal data breach' if they involve accidental/unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorized disclosure, or access to personal data.

For multi-Member-State operations, assess whether processing is 'cross-border processing' and identify 'main establishment' using the decision-making/power-to-implement test (controller) or main processing activities test (processor).
Where Article 27 applies, ensure the representative is established in the Union and designated in writing.
common_violations: Treating data as non-personal despite indirect identifiability (e.g., online identifiers, location data).
Assuming pseudonymisation without separating additional information or without adequate technical/organisational measures.
Relying on implied consent or inactivity (not a clear affirmative action) contrary to the consent definition.
Misclassifying controller/processor roles, leading to incorrect allocation of GDPR duties.
Incorrectly treating public authorities as 'recipients' (or incorrectly applying the inquiry carve-out without meeting its conditions).
Misidentifying main establishment, affecting lead supervisory authority determination.
best_practices: Maintain a role-mapping analysis documenting who determines purposes/means for each processing activity.
Document pseudonymisation architecture: separation controls, access controls, key management, and organizational segregation.
Design consent capture mechanisms that require an affirmative action and record the specific, informed choice presented.
Implement incident classification playbooks aligned to the personal data breach definition.
For cross-border operations, document decision-making locus and implementation authority to support main establishment determination.
compliance_checklist: Identifiability assessment includes direct and indirect identifiers (name, ID number, location data, online identifier, identity factors).
Processing inventory includes all operations listed (collection, storage, use, disclosure, restriction, erasure, destruction) including non-automated.
Pseudonymisation: additional information kept separately + technical/organisational measures in place.
Representative (if applicable): established in the Union + designated in writing.
Recipient classification includes public authority inquiry carve-out conditions and ensures subsequent processing complies with applicable data protection rules by purpose.
Consent mechanism meets freely given, specific, informed, unambiguous, affirmative action criteria.
Breach definition mapped to security incident categories (CIA impacts and unauthorized disclosure/access).
Main establishment documented for controller/processor with multi-Member-State establishments.
Cross-border processing determination documented (multi-establishment or substantial effect in multiple Member States).

key_definitions.personal data: â€œany information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person (â€˜data subjectâ€™); an identifiable natural person is one who can be identified, directly or indirectly, in particular by reference to an identifier such as a name, an identification number, location data, an online identifier or to one or more factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that natural personâ€
key_definitions.processing: â€œany operation or set of operations which is performed on personal data or on sets of personal data, whether or not by automated means, such as collection, recording, organisation, structuring, storage, adaptation or alteration, retrieval, consultation, use, disclosure by transmission, dissemination or otherwise making available, alignment or combination, restriction, erasure or destructionâ€
key_definitions.restriction of processing: â€œthe marking of stored personal data with the aim of limiting their processing in the futureâ€
key_definitions.profiling: â€œany form of automated processing of personal data consisting of the use of personal data to evaluate certain personal aspects relating to a natural person, in particular to analyse or predict aspects concerning that natural person's performance at work, economic situation, health, personal preferences, interests, reliability, behaviour, location or movementsâ€
key_definitions.pseudonymisation: â€œthe processing of personal data in such a manner that the personal data can no longer be attributed to a specific data subject without the use of additional information, provided that such additional information is kept separately and is subject to technical and organisational measures to ensure that the personal data are not attributed to an identified or identifiable natural personâ€
key_definitions.filing system: â€œany structured set of personal data which are accessible according to specific criteria, whether centralised, decentralised or dispersed on a functional or geographical basisâ€
key_definitions.controller: â€œthe natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data; where the purposes and means of such processing are determined by Union or Member State law, the controller or the specific criteria for its nomination may be provided for by Union or Member State lawâ€
key_definitions.processor: â€œa natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which processes personal data on behalf of the controllerâ€
key_definitions.recipient: â€œa natural or legal person, public authority, agency or another body, to which the personal data are disclosed, whether a third party or notâ€ with carve-out: public authorities receiving data â€œin the framework of a particular inquiry in accordance with Union or Member State law shall not be regarded as recipients; the processing of those data by those public authorities shall be in compliance with the applicable data protection rules according to the purposes of the processingâ€
key_definitions.third party: â€œa natural or legal person, public authority, agency or body other than the data subject, controller, processor and persons who, under the direct authority of the controller or processor, are authorised to process personal dataâ€
key_definitions.consent: â€œany freely given, specific, informed and unambiguous indication of the data subject's wishes by which he or she, by a statement or by a clear affirmative action, signifies agreement to the processing of personal data relating to him or herâ€
key_definitions.personal data breach: â€œa breach of security leading to the accidental or unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorised disclosure of, or access to, personal data transmitted, stored or otherwise processedâ€
key_definitions.genetic data: â€œpersonal data relating to the inherited or acquired genetic characteristics of a natural person which give unique information about the physiology or the health of that natural person and which result, in particular, from an analysis of a biological sample from the natural person in questionâ€
key_definitions.biometric data: â€œpersonal data resulting from specific technical processing relating to the physical, physiological or behavioural characteristics of a natural person, which allow or confirm the unique identification of that natural person, such as facial images or dactyloscopic dataâ€
key_definitions.data concerning health: â€œpersonal data related to the physical or mental health of a natural person, including the provision of health care services, which reveal information about his or her health statusâ€
key_definitions.main establishment: Controller: central administration in the Union unless decisions on purposes/means are taken in another EU establishment with power to implement; Processor: central administration in the Union or, if none, the EU establishment where main processing activities take place to the extent subject to specific obligations under the Regulation
key_definitions.representative: â€œa natural or legal person established in the Union who, designated by the controller or processor in writing pursuant to Article 27, represents the controller or processor with regard to their respective obligations under this Regulationâ€
key_definitions.enterprise: â€œa natural or legal person engaged in an economic activity, irrespective of its legal form, including partnerships or associations regularly engaged in an economic activityâ€
key_definitions.group of undertakings: â€œa controlling undertaking and its controlled undertakingsâ€
key_definitions.binding corporate rules: â€œpersonal data protection policies which are adhered to by a controller or processor established on the territory of a Member State for transfers or a set of transfers of personal data to a controller or processor in one or more third countries within a group of undertakings, or group of enterprises engaged in a joint economic activityâ€
key_definitions.supervisory authority: â€œan independent public authority which is established by a Member State pursuant to Article 51â€
key_definitions.supervisory authority concerned: A supervisory authority concerned because: (a) controller/processor established in its Member State; (b) data subjects residing there substantially affected/likely affected; or (c) a complaint lodged with it
key_definitions.cross-border processing: Either (a) processing in context of activities of establishments in more than one Member State where controller/processor is established in more than one Member State; or (b) processing in context of a single EU establishment that substantially affects or is likely to substantially affect data subjects in more than one Member State
key_definitions.relevant and reasoned objection: â€œan objection to a draft decision ... which clearly demonstrates the significance of the risks posed by the draft decision as regards the fundamental rights and freedoms of data subjects and, where applicable, the free flow of personal data within the Unionâ€
key_definitions.information society service: â€œa service as defined in point (b) of Article 1(1) of Directive (EU) 2015/1535â€
key_definitions.international organisation: â€œan organisation and its subordinate bodies governed by public international law, or any other body which is set up by, or on the basis of, an agreement between two or more countriesâ€

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Principles relating to processing of personal data (Article 5)

applicable_regions: European Economic Area (via incorporation into EEA law)

description.brief_summary: Establishes mandatory principles for processing personal data and requires controllers to be responsible for and able to demonstrate compliance with those principles.
description.detailed_explanation: The section mandates that personal data processing must comply with a set of core principles: (a) lawfulness, fairness, and transparency; (b) purpose limitation, including a specific rule that certain further processing for archiving in the public interest, scientific or historical research, or statistical purposes is not considered incompatible when aligned with Article 89(1); (c) data minimisation (adequate, relevant, limited to necessity); (d) accuracy, including an affirmative duty to take every reasonable step to erase or rectify inaccurate data without delay; (e) storage limitation, including a conditional allowance to store longer when processing is solely for archiving/research/statistics under Article 89(1) and subject to appropriate technical and organisational measures safeguarding data subject rights and freedoms; and (f) integrity and confidentiality, requiring appropriate security including protection against unauthorised/unlawful processing and accidental loss/destruction/damage using appropriate technical or organisational measures. It also imposes an accountability obligation: the controller must be responsible for compliance with these principles and must be able to demonstrate such compliance.
description.purpose: To ensure personal data is processed responsibly, proportionately, securely, and in a way that protects individuals, while enabling limited compatible further processing for public-interest archiving and research/statistics under safeguards.
description.legislative_intent: To set baseline, enforceable processing standards across the EU and to shift compliance from a purely substantive duty to a demonstrable, evidence-based accountability model for controllers.

what_it_covers: Processing of personal data
Collection of personal data for specified purposes
Further processing and compatibility assessment
Data quality management (accuracy and updating)
Retention and storage practices
Security of processing (technical and organisational measures)
Controller accountability and demonstrability of compliance

entity_types: Any entity acting as a controller

what_it_does_not_cover: Non-personal data (not addressed in this section)
Specific lawful bases, transparency notice contents, or detailed security controls (not specified here beyond principle-level requirements)
Processor-specific obligations (not specified here)

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Process personal data lawfully, fairly, and transparently in relation to the data subject.
mandatory_obligations.how: Ensure processing meets the three cumulative criteria: lawfulness, fairness, transparency.
mandatory_obligations.quote: â€œprocessed lawfully, fairly and in a transparent manner in relation to the data subjectâ€

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Collect personal data for specified, explicit, and legitimate purposes.
mandatory_obligations.how: Define purposes at collection that are specified, explicit, and legitimate.
mandatory_obligations.quote: â€œcollected for specified, explicit and legitimate purposesâ€

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Ensure personal data are adequate, relevant, and limited to what is necessary for the purposes of processing (data minimisation).
mandatory_obligations.how: Limit data fields and processing scope to necessity relative to stated purposes.
mandatory_obligations.quote: â€œadequate, relevant and limited to what is necessary in relation to the purposes for which they are processedâ€

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Ensure personal data are accurate and, where necessary, kept up to date.
mandatory_obligations.how: Implement processes to maintain accuracy and update data when needed.
mandatory_obligations.quote: â€œaccurate and, where necessary, kept up to dateâ€

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Take every reasonable step to ensure inaccurate personal data are erased or rectified without delay, considering the purposes of processing.
mandatory_obligations.how: Establish and execute correction/erasure workflows; apply a reasonableness standard; act without delay; assess inaccuracy in light of processing purposes.
mandatory_obligations.quote: â€œevery reasonable step must be taken to ensure that personal data that are inaccurate, having regard to the purposes for which they are processed, are erased or rectified without delayâ€

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Keep personal data in a form permitting identification of data subjects for no longer than necessary for the purposes for which the data are processed (storage limitation).
mandatory_obligations.how: Define and enforce retention periods tied to processing purposes; limit identifiability duration.
mandatory_obligations.quote: â€œkept in a form which permits identification of data subjects for no longer than is necessary for the purposes for which the personal data are processedâ€

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Process personal data in a manner ensuring appropriate security, including protection against unauthorised or unlawful processing and against accidental loss, destruction, or damage, using appropriate technical or organisational measures.
mandatory_obligations.how: Implement security controls (technical and/or organisational) proportionate to ensure appropriate security and specified protections.
mandatory_obligations.quote: â€œprocessed in a manner that ensures appropriate security of the personal data, including protection against unauthorised or unlawful processing and against accidental loss, destruction or damage, using appropriate technical or organisational measuresâ€

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Be responsible for compliance with the principles and be able to demonstrate compliance (accountability).
mandatory_obligations.how: Maintain evidence and governance demonstrating adherence to all principles in paragraph 1.
mandatory_obligations.quote: â€œThe controller shall be responsible for, and be able to demonstrate compliance with, paragraph 1â€

prohibited_actions.prohibition: Do not further process personal data in a manner incompatible with the purposes for which they were collected.
prohibited_actions.quote: â€œnot further processed in a manner that is incompatible with those purposesâ€

prohibited_actions.prohibition: Do not retain identifiable personal data longer than necessary for the purposes for which they are processed (subject to stated exceptions).
prohibited_actions.quote: â€œfor no longer than is necessary for the purposes for which the personal data are processedâ€

conditional_requirements.condition: If further processing is for archiving purposes in the public interest, scientific or historical research purposes, or statistical purposes
conditional_requirements.requirement: Such further processing shall not be considered incompatible with the initial purposes, provided it is â€œin accordance with Article 89(1)â€.
conditional_requirements.quote: â€œfurther processing for archiving purposes in the public interest, scientific or historical research purposes or statistical purposes shall, in accordance with Article 89(1), not be considered to be incompatible with the initial purposesâ€

conditional_requirements.condition: If personal data are stored for longer periods than necessary for the original purposes
conditional_requirements.requirement: Longer storage is permitted only insofar as the data will be processed solely for archiving in the public interest, scientific or historical research, or statistical purposes in accordance with Article 89(1), and subject to implementation of appropriate technical and organisational measures required by the Regulation to safeguard rights and freedoms.
conditional_requirements.quote: â€œpersonal data may be stored for longer periods insofar as the personal data will be processed solely for archiving purposes in the public interest, scientific or historical research purposes or statistical purposes in accordance with Article 89(1) subject to implementation of the appropriate technical and organisational measures required by this Regulation in order to safeguard the rights and freedoms of the data subjectâ€

conditional_requirements.condition: Where necessary to meet the accuracy principle
conditional_requirements.requirement: Personal data must be kept up to date where necessary.
conditional_requirements.quote: â€œand, where necessary, kept up to dateâ€

documentation_requirements.requirement: Maintain evidence sufficient to demonstrate compliance with all principles in paragraph 1 (accountability).
documentation_requirements.quote: â€œbe able to demonstrate compliance with, paragraph 1â€

timeline_requirements.applies_to: Erasure or rectification of inaccurate personal data (after considering processing purposes and taking every reasonable step).
timeline_requirements.quote: â€œerased or rectified without delayâ€

timeline_requirements.applies_to: Keeping personal data in identifiable form relative to processing purposes (subject to stated longer-storage conditions).
timeline_requirements.quote: â€œfor no longer than is necessaryâ€

general_restrictions: Processing must meet cumulative principles (lawfulness, fairness, transparency; purpose limitation; minimisation; accuracy; storage limitation; integrity/confidentiality).
data_restrictions: Collection limited to specified, explicit, legitimate purposes.
Further processing restricted to compatibility with initial purposes, with a defined carve-out for archiving/research/statistics under Article 89(1).
Data must be limited to what is necessary (minimisation).
Data must be accurate and updated where necessary; inaccurate data must be erased/rectified without delay.
Identifiable retention limited to necessity, with conditional longer retention for archiving/research/statistics under safeguards.
operational_restrictions: Controllers must implement processes to ensure and evidence compliance (accountability).
technical_restrictions: Security must include protection against unauthorised or unlawful processing and accidental loss/destruction/damage using appropriate technical measures (as applicable).

individual_rights: Implied protection of â€œrights and freedoms of the data subjectâ€ through required safeguards for longer storage/archiving/research/statistics processing (no specific right-exercise procedure stated in this section).

conditional_exemptions: Further processing for archiving in the public interest, scientific or historical research, or statistical purposes is treated as not incompatible with initial purposes when in accordance with Article 89(1).

Longer storage than otherwise necessary is permitted when processing is solely for archiving in the public interest, scientific or historical research, or statistical purposes in accordance with Article 89(1) and subject to appropriate technical and organisational measures safeguarding data subject rights and freedoms.
public_interest_exceptions: Archiving purposes in the public interest (as a condition enabling compatibility and longer storage, subject to Article 89(1) and safeguards).

technical_measures: Implement â€œappropriate technical ... measuresâ€ to safeguard rights and freedoms of the data subject when storing longer for archiving/research/statistics under Article 89(1).
Implement technical measures to ensure â€œappropriate securityâ€ including protection against unauthorised/unlawful processing and accidental loss/destruction/damage.
organizational_measures: Implement â€œappropriate ... organisational measuresâ€ to safeguard rights and freedoms of the data subject when storing longer for archiving/research/statistics under Article 89(1).
Adopt organisational measures to ensure lawful, fair, transparent processing; purpose specification; minimisation; accuracy management; retention governance; and accountability evidence.
security_measures: Protection against â€œunauthorised or unlawful processingâ€.
Protection against â€œaccidental loss, destruction or damageâ€.
Use of â€œappropriate technical or organisational measuresâ€ to achieve appropriate security.
audit_requirements: Ability to demonstrate compliance implies readiness for supervisory authority review/inspection, though no explicit audit procedure is stated in this section.

related_articles: GDPR Article 89(1) (referenced for archiving/research/statistics safeguards and compatibility)

implementation_steps: Define and document specified, explicit, legitimate purposes for each processing activity.
Assess and document compatibility before any further processing; if relying on archiving/research/statistics compatibility, ensure alignment with Article 89(1) safeguards.
Apply data minimisation by limiting collection fields, access, and processing scope to necessity per purpose.
Implement data quality controls (validation, periodic review, update mechanisms) and a correction/erasure workflow to act â€œwithout delayâ€ on inaccuracies.

Set retention schedules tied to purposes; ensure deletion/anonymisation or restriction of identifiability when no longer necessary; if retaining longer for archiving/research/statistics, ensure processing is solely for those purposes and implement appropriate technical/organisational safeguards.
Implement security controls to prevent unauthorised/unlawful processing and accidental loss/destruction/damage; document the measures as part of accountability.
Maintain evidence demonstrating compliance with each principle (policies, records, decisions, controls).
common_violations: Collecting data beyond what is necessary for stated purposes (minimisation failure).
Repurposing data for new uses without compatibility assessment or without meeting the Article 89(1) conditions for archiving/research/statistics.
Keeping identifiable data indefinitely or without purpose-based retention limits.
Failing to correct or delete inaccurate data promptly.
Insufficient security measures leading to unauthorised processing or accidental loss/damage.
Inability to demonstrate compliance (lack of documentation/evidence).
best_practices: Purpose statements mapped to processing activities and data categories.
Retention schedules with automated deletion or de-identification controls.
Data accuracy SLAs and ticketing for rectification/erasure requests and internal corrections.
Security-by-design with access controls, encryption where appropriate, backups, and incident prevention controls.
Accountability pack: policies, DPIAs where relevant, records of processing, training logs (if used), and periodic compliance reviews.
compliance_checklist: Lawfulness/fairness/transparency: documented basis and transparent communications (principle-level requirement stated here).
Purpose limitation: purposes specified/explicit/legitimate; further processing compatibility assessed; Article 89(1) reliance documented where applicable.
Minimisation: data collected/used limited to necessity per purpose.
Accuracy: update mechanisms; reasonable steps; rectification/erasure without delay for inaccuracies.
Storage limitation: retention limits; identifiability limited; longer storage only under sole archiving/research/statistics processing with Article 89(1) safeguards and appropriate measures.
Integrity/confidentiality: appropriate technical/organisational security measures addressing unauthorised/unlawful processing and accidental loss/destruction/damage.
Accountability: evidence demonstrating compliance with all principles.

key_definitions.lawfulness, fairness and transparency: Processing must be â€œprocessed lawfully, fairly and in a transparent manner in relation to the data subjectâ€.
key_definitions.purpose limitation: Personal data must be â€œcollected for specified, explicit and legitimate purposesâ€ and â€œnot further processed in a manner that is incompatible with those purposesâ€, with a stated compatibility rule for certain archiving/research/statistics further processing under Article 89(1).
key_definitions.data minimisation: Personal data must be â€œadequate, relevant and limited to what is necessary in relation to the purposes for which they are processedâ€.
key_definitions.accuracy: Personal data must be â€œaccurate and, where necessary, kept up to dateâ€; and â€œevery reasonable step must be takenâ€ to erase or rectify inaccurate data â€œwithout delayâ€.
key_definitions.storage limitation: Personal data must be â€œkept in a form which permits identification of data subjects for no longer than is necessaryâ€ for processing purposes, with conditional longer storage for sole archiving/research/statistics processing under Article 89(1) and safeguards.
key_definitions.integrity and confidentiality: Personal data must be processed ensuring â€œappropriate security ... including protection against unauthorised or unlawful processing and against accidental loss, destruction or damage, using appropriate technical or organisational measuresâ€.
key_definitions.accountability: â€œThe controller shall be responsible for, and be able to demonstrate compliance with, paragraph 1â€.

regulations.source_section: ## Principles relating to processing of personal data

regulations.regulation_name: Directive (EU) 2015/1535 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 9 September 2015 laying down a procedure for the provision of information in the field of technical regulations and of rules on Information Society services

description.brief_summary: This section contains only a bibliographic footnote citation to Directive (EU) 2015/1535 and does not state any actionable requirements from that Directive.
description.detailed_explanation: The text includes a footnote referencing Directive (EU) 2015/1535 with its title and Official Journal citation. No procedural steps, obligations, prohibitions, timelines, or compliance criteria from the Directive are described in this section; therefore, no extractable regulatory requirements are present here beyond the fact of the reference.

what_it_does_not_cover: No Directive (EU) 2015/1535 requirements are detailed in this section.

regulations.source_section: ## Principles relating to processing of personal data

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 6 (Lawfulness of processing)

applicable_regions: European Economic Area (via incorporation into EEA law)

description.brief_summary: Defines when processing of personal data is lawful by listing the permissible legal bases and sets conditions for further processing compatibility and for legal bases grounded in Union or Member State law.
description.detailed_explanation: This section establishes that processing of personal data is lawful only if at least one enumerated legal basis applies. It lists six lawful bases: consent for specific purposes; necessity for contract performance or pre-contract steps requested by the data subject; necessity for compliance with a legal obligation; necessity to protect vital interests; necessity for a public interest task or exercise of official authority; and necessity for legitimate interests of the controller/third party subject to an overriding-rights test, with heightened emphasis where the data subject is a child. It further prohibits public authorities from relying on the legitimate interests basis when processing is carried out in the performance of their tasks. For processing based on legal obligation or public task/official authority, it requires that the legal basis be laid down in Union or Member State law and that the purpose be determined in that legal basis (or be necessary for the public task/authority). It allows Union/Member State law to include specific provisions adapting GDPR application (e.g., types of data, data subjects, disclosures, purpose limitation, storage periods, operations/procedures, and measures ensuring lawful and fair processing) and requires such law to meet an objective of public interest and be proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued. Finally, it imposes a mandatory compatibility assessment for further processing for a new purpose when that further processing is not based on consent or on qualifying Union/Member State law meeting Article 23(1) safeguards; the controller must consider specified factors (link between purposes, context/relationship, nature of data including special categories/criminal data, consequences, and safeguards such as encryption/pseudonymisation).
description.purpose: To ensure personal data processing occurs only under recognized lawful bases and to constrain repurposing of data by requiring compatibility analysis and appropriate legal grounding, especially for public authority processing and processing mandated by law.
description.legislative_intent: To harmonize lawful processing criteria across the EU, protect individualsâ€™ fundamental rights and freedoms, and provide legal certainty for controllers while enabling necessary processing for contracts, legal obligations, public tasks, and legitimate interests subject to safeguards.

what_it_covers: Determination of lawful basis for processing personal data
Processing necessary for contracts and pre-contract steps
Processing necessary for legal obligations
Processing necessary to protect vital interests
Processing for public interest tasks/official authority
Processing based on legitimate interests and balancing test
Limits on public authorities using legitimate interests for task-related processing
Member State ability to specify rules for processing under legal obligation/public task bases
Requirements for legal bases in Union/Member State law and purpose determination
Compatibility assessment for further processing for a new purpose
Consideration of safeguards such as encryption/pseudonymisation in compatibility assessment

target_entities: Third parties whose legitimate interests may be relied upon (via controller reliance)
Member States (legislative role for specifying provisions)
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities subject to GDPR territorial scope; this section itself does not specify territorial criteria.

what_it_does_not_cover: This excerpt does not specify penalties, supervisory authority procedures, or detailed consent conditions (handled elsewhere in GDPR).

mandatory_obligations: Controllers must ensure processing is lawful only if and to the extent that at least one lawful basis applies. Quote: "Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies:"

If relying on consent, the controller must ensure the data subject has given consent "for one or more specific purposes". Quote: "the data subject has given consent to the processing of his or her personal data for one or more specific purposes"

If relying on contract necessity, processing must be "necessary for the performance of a contract" or "to take steps at the request of the data subject prior to entering into a contract". Quote: "processing is necessary for the performance of a contract... or in order to take steps at the request of the data subject prior to entering into a contract"

If relying on legal obligation, processing must be "necessary for compliance with a legal obligation to which the controller is subject". Quote: "processing is necessary for compliance with a legal obligation to which the controller is subject"

If relying on vital interests, processing must be "necessary in order to protect the vital interests of the data subject or of another natural person". Quote: "processing is necessary in order to protect the vital interests..."

If relying on public task/official authority, processing must be "necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority vested in the controller". Quote: "processing is necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority vested in the controller"

If relying on legitimate interests, processing must be "necessary" for those interests and must pass an overriding-rights test. Quote: "processing is necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests... except where such interests are overridden by the interests or fundamental rights and freedoms of the data subject"
When assessing legitimate interests, controllers must give particular protection where the data subject is a child. Quote: "in particular where the data subject is a child"

For processing under legal obligation (Art. 6(1)(c)) and public task/official authority (Art. 6(1)(e)), the legal basis must be laid down by Union law or Member State law to which the controller is subject. Quote: "The basis for the processing referred to in point (c) and (e)... shall be laid down by: (a) Union law; or (b) Member State law to which the controller is subject."

For processing under Art. 6(1)(c) and (e), the purpose must be determined in the legal basis, or (for (e)) be necessary for the public task/official authority. Quote: "The purpose of the processing shall be determined in that legal basis or, as regards the processing referred to in point (e)... shall be necessary for the performance of a task..."

Union/Member State law underpinning Art. 6(1)(c) and (e) must meet an objective of public interest and be proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued. Quote: "The Union or the Member State law shall meet an objective of public interest and be proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued."

Where further processing for a new purpose is not based on consent or on qualifying Union/Member State law (as described), the controller must assess compatibility by taking into account specified factors. Quote: "the controller shall, in order to ascertain whether processing for another purpose is compatible... take into account, inter alia:" followed by factors (a)-(e).

In the compatibility assessment, the controller must consider: (a) link between original and new purposes; (b) context of collection and relationship; (c) nature of data including whether Article 9 special categories or Article 10 criminal data; (d) possible consequences; (e) existence of appropriate safeguards such as encryption or pseudonymisation. Quotes: (a) "any link between the purposes..."; (b) "the context... in particular regarding the relationship..."; (c) "the nature... in particular whether special categories... pursuant to Article 9... or... criminal convictions and offences... pursuant to Article 10"; (d) "the possible consequences..."; (e) "the existence of appropriate safeguards, which may include encryption or pseudonymisation."
prohibited_actions: Processing must not occur unless at least one lawful basis applies (implicit prohibition). Quote: "Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies"

Public authorities must not rely on the legitimate interests basis for processing carried out in the performance of their tasks. Quote: "Point (f) of the first subparagraph shall not apply to processing carried out by public authorities in the performance of their tasks."
conditional_requirements: Legitimate interests basis applies only if the controller/third party interests are not overridden by the data subjectâ€™s interests or fundamental rights and freedoms requiring protection. Quote: "except where such interests are overridden..."
Heightened consideration for children under legitimate interests balancing. Quote: "in particular where the data subject is a child"
