Member States may maintain or introduce more specific provisions to adapt application of GDPR rules for processing under Art. 6(1)(c) and (e), including determining more precise processing requirements and measures to ensure lawful and fair processing, including for Chapter IX situations. Quote: "Member States may maintain or introduce more specific provisions... by determining more precisely specific requirements for the processing and other measures to ensure lawful and fair processing..."

Further processing compatibility assessment is required only when the new-purpose processing is not based on consent and not based on qualifying Union/Member State law that is a necessary and proportionate measure in a democratic society to safeguard Article 23(1) objectives. Quote: "Where the processing for a purpose other than that for which the personal data have been collected is not based on the data subject's consent or on a Union or Member State law which constitutes a necessary and proportionate measure in a democratic society to safeguard the objectives referred to in Article 23(1)..."

general_restrictions: Lawfulness is limited to the enumerated bases; processing is lawful only "if and to the extent" a basis applies (necessity/extent limitation). Quote: "only if and to the extent"

Legitimate interests basis is restricted by an overriding-rights test and special sensitivity for children. Quote: "except where such interests are overridden... in particular where the data subject is a child"
data_restrictions: Compatibility assessment must consider whether special categories of data (Article 9) or criminal convictions/offences data (Article 10) are involved. Quote: "in particular whether special categories... pursuant to Article 9... or... criminal convictions and offences... pursuant to Article 10"
operational_restrictions: Public authorities cannot use legitimate interests for task-related processing. Quote: "shall not apply to processing carried out by public authorities in the performance of their tasks"

Further processing for a new purpose is constrained by a mandatory compatibility assessment unless based on consent or qualifying law. Quote: "the controller shall... take into account" factors (a)-(e).
technical_restrictions: Appropriate safeguards may include encryption or pseudonymisation (not mandated in all cases, but explicitly identified as safeguards to consider). Quote: "appropriate safeguards, which may include encryption or pseudonymisation"

individual_rights: Implied protection of the data subjectâ€™s "fundamental rights and freedoms" through the legitimate interests overriding test. Quote: "fundamental rights and freedoms of the data subject which require protection of personal data"
organizational_rights: Controllers may rely on legitimate interests as a lawful basis subject to conditions (except public authorities for task processing). Quote: "legitimate interests pursued by the controller or by a third party"

conditional_exemptions: Public authority exception to legitimate interests: legitimate interests basis does not apply to processing by public authorities in performance of their tasks. Quote: "shall not apply"
legitimate_interest_exceptions: Legitimate interests basis is unavailable where overridden by the data subjectâ€™s interests/rights/freedoms, particularly for children. Quote: "except where such interests are overridden... in particular where the data subject is a child"
public_interest_exceptions: Processing may be lawful when necessary for a public interest task or official authority vested in the controller. Quote: "necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority"

technical_measures: Consider implementing encryption and/or pseudonymisation as appropriate safeguards in the context of further processing compatibility. Quote: "appropriate safeguards, which may include encryption or pseudonymisation"
organizational_measures: Establish a process to select and document an applicable lawful basis before processing (implied by the requirement that processing is lawful only if a basis applies). Quote anchor: "Processing shall be lawful only if..."

Implement a structured compatibility assessment procedure for further processing not based on consent or qualifying law, ensuring consideration of factors (a)-(e). Quote anchor: "the controller shall... take into account"
security_measures: Safeguards for further processing may include encryption or pseudonymisation. Quote: "may include encryption or pseudonymisation"

related_articles: GDPR Article 9 (special categories of personal data) (referenced)
GDPR Article 10 (personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences) (referenced)
complementary_regulations: Union law and Member State law establishing legal bases for processing under Article 6(1)(c) and (e) (as applicable)

implementation_steps: Map each processing activity to at least one lawful basis under points (a)-(f) and ensure processing is limited to what is necessary for that basis ("to the extent").
For legitimate interests, perform and retain a balancing assessment addressing overriding rights/freedoms and special consideration where children are involved.

For public authorities, ensure task-related processing does not rely on legitimate interests; use an alternative lawful basis (e.g., public task/official authority or legal obligation) where applicable.
For processing under legal obligation/public task, identify the specific Union/Member State legal instrument that lays down the basis and verify that the purpose is determined/necessary as required.

When planning further processing for a new purpose, determine whether it is based on consent or qualifying law; if not, conduct a compatibility assessment considering factors (a)-(e) and evaluate safeguards such as encryption/pseudonymisation.
common_violations: Processing without selecting a valid lawful basis or relying on multiple bases without necessity alignment.
Using legitimate interests where the data subjectâ€™s rights override the controllerâ€™s interests, or failing to account for children.
Public authorities relying on legitimate interests for task-related processing.
Further processing for a new purpose without conducting the required compatibility assessment.
Ignoring the nature of data (special categories/criminal data) when assessing compatibility.
best_practices: Maintain a lawful-basis register per processing purpose and ensure purpose specificity for consent-based processing.
Standardize compatibility assessments with a checklist aligned to factors (a)-(e) and include a safeguards evaluation section.
For (c)/(e) processing, maintain a legal basis library linking processing operations to the relevant Union/Member State provisions and stated purposes.
compliance_checklist: Is there at least one applicable lawful basis (a)-(f) for each processing purpose?
If consent is used, is it tied to "one or more specific purposes"?
If contract basis is used, is processing necessary for contract performance or requested pre-contract steps?
If legal obligation/public task basis is used, is the basis laid down in Union/Member State law and is the purpose determined/necessary as required?
If legitimate interests is used, has an overriding-rights test been performed, with special attention to children?
If the controller is a public authority, is legitimate interests avoided for task-related processing?
For further processing for a new purpose, if not based on consent or qualifying law, has compatibility been assessed using factors (a)-(e)?
Have appropriate safeguards (e.g., encryption/pseudonymisation) been considered/implemented where relevant?

key_definitions.lawful basis: One of the grounds listed in points (a)-(f) that must apply for processing to be lawful.
key_definitions.legitimate interests balancing: The requirement that legitimate interests processing is permitted only where those interests are not overridden by the data subjectâ€™s interests or fundamental rights and freedoms requiring protection of personal data.
key_definitions.compatibility assessment (further proces: The controllerâ€™s evaluation of whether a new processing purpose is compatible with the original collection purpose by considering factors (a)-(e) when the new processing is not based on consent or qualifying law.

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 7 (Conditions for consent)

applicable_regions: European Economic Area (via incorporation into EEA law)

description.brief_summary: Establishes mandatory conditions for obtaining, presenting, documenting, and withdrawing consent, and provides criteria for assessing whether consent is freely given.
description.detailed_explanation: The provision imposes concrete obligations on controllers when relying on consent as the lawful basis for processing. Controllers must be able to prove that valid consent was obtained. Consent requests embedded in broader written declarations must be clearly separated and presented in an intelligible, accessible manner using clear language; any infringing parts of such declarations are not binding. Data subjects must be able to withdraw consent at any time, must be informed of that right before consenting, and withdrawal must be as easy as giving consent; withdrawal does not retroactively invalidate processing that was lawful before withdrawal. In evaluating whether consent is freely given, decision-makers must give 'utmost account' to whether contract performance or service provision is made conditional on consent to processing that is not necessary for that contract.
description.purpose: To ensure consent is a genuine, informed, freely given, and controllable choice for individuals, and to prevent coercive or opaque consent practices while enabling accountability.
description.legislative_intent: To operationalize consent as a reliable lawful basis by requiring demonstrability, clarity, separability, and easy withdrawal, and by discouraging bundling consent with contracts for unnecessary processing.

what_it_covers: Processing of personal data where the lawful basis is consent
How consent requests must be presented in written declarations that also address other matters
Controller accountability to demonstrate consent
Data subject withdrawal of consent and related information duties
Assessment criteria for whether consent is freely given in contractual/service contexts

entity_types: Any entity acting as a controller
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies within GDPR territorial scope; not specified in this section.

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing based on lawful bases other than consent (not addressed in this section)
Specific consent requirements for children or special categories (not addressed in this section)

mandatory_obligations.requirement: Controller must be able to demonstrate that the data subject has consented.
mandatory_obligations.condition: Where processing is based on consent
mandatory_obligations.exact_quote: â€œWhere processing is based on consent, the controller shall be able to demonstrate that the data subject has consented to processing of his or her personal data.â€

mandatory_obligations.requirement: Consent request must be clearly distinguishable from other matters when included in a written declaration covering other matters.
mandatory_obligations.actor: Controller (as the party presenting the request for consent)
mandatory_obligations.condition: If consent is given in the context of a written declaration which also concerns other matters
mandatory_obligations.exact_quote: â€œthe request for consent shall be presented in a manner which is clearly distinguishable from the other mattersâ€

mandatory_obligations.requirement: Consent request must be in an intelligible and easily accessible form.
mandatory_obligations.condition: If consent is given in the context of a written declaration which also concerns other matters
mandatory_obligations.exact_quote: â€œin an intelligible and easily accessible formâ€

mandatory_obligations.requirement: Consent request must use clear and plain language.
mandatory_obligations.condition: If consent is given in the context of a written declaration which also concerns other matters
mandatory_obligations.exact_quote: â€œusing clear and plain language.â€

mandatory_obligations.requirement: Prior to giving consent, the data subject must be informed of the right to withdraw consent.
mandatory_obligations.actor: Controller (as the party responsible for informing prior to consent collection)
mandatory_obligations.condition: Before consent is given
mandatory_obligations.exact_quote: â€œPrior to giving consent, the data subject shall be informed thereof.â€

mandatory_obligations.requirement: Withdrawal must be as easy as giving consent.
mandatory_obligations.condition: Where consent is relied upon and withdrawal is exercised
mandatory_obligations.exact_quote: â€œIt shall be as easy to withdraw as to give consent.â€

mandatory_obligations.requirement: In assessing whether consent is freely given, utmost account must be taken of whether contract performance/service provision is conditional on consent to unnecessary processing.
mandatory_obligations.actor: Assessor of consent validity (controller and/or supervisory authority/court in practice; not specified here)
mandatory_obligations.condition: When assessing whether consent is freely given
mandatory_obligations.exact_quote: â€œWhen assessing whether consent is freely given, utmost account shall be taken of whether, inter alia, the performance of a contract, including the provision of a service, is conditional on consent to the processing of personal data that is not necessary for the performance of that contract.â€

prohibited_actions.prohibition: Treat infringing parts of a written declaration as binding.
prohibited_actions.actor: Controller and any party seeking to rely on the declaration
prohibited_actions.condition: Where a part of the declaration constitutes an infringement of the Regulation
prohibited_actions.exact_quote: â€œAny part of such a declaration which constitutes an infringement of this Regulation shall not be binding.â€

requirements_triggered: Controller must be able to demonstrate consent

conditional_requirements.trigger: Consent is given in the context of a written declaration which also concerns other matters
requirements_triggered: Consent request must be clearly distinguishable
Consent request must be intelligible and easily accessible
Consent request must use clear and plain language
Infringing parts of the declaration are not binding

conditional_requirements.trigger: Data subject is asked to give consent
requirements_triggered: Data subject must be informed prior to giving consent that consent can be withdrawn at any time
Withdrawal must be possible at any time
Withdrawal must be as easy as giving consent
Withdrawal does not affect lawfulness of prior processing based on consent

conditional_requirements.trigger: Assessing whether consent is freely given
requirements_triggered: Give utmost account to conditionality of contract/service on consent to unnecessary processing

documentation_requirements.document_or_record: Evidence/records sufficient to demonstrate that the data subject consented
documentation_requirements.exact_quote: â€œthe controller shall be able to demonstrate that the data subject has consentedâ€

timeline_requirements.exact_quote: â€œThe data subject shall have the right to withdraw his or her consent at any time.â€

timeline_requirements.applies_to: Informing the data subject about the right to withdraw
timeline_requirements.exact_quote: â€œPrior to giving consent, the data subject shall be informed thereof.â€

general_restrictions.restriction: Consent requests cannot be bundled indistinguishably with other matters in a written declaration; they must be clearly distinguishable and presented clearly.
general_restrictions.exact_quote: â€œclearly distinguishable from the other matters, in an intelligible and easily accessible form, using clear and plain language.â€

general_restrictions.restriction: Contract/service provision conditionality on consent to unnecessary processing is a key negative factor in determining whether consent is freely given.
general_restrictions.exact_quote: â€œutmost account shall be taken of whether... the performance of a contract... is conditional on consent to the processing... that is not necessary for the performance of that contract.â€

data_restrictions.restriction: Discourages/limits reliance on consent where processing is not necessary for contract performance but is made a condition for the contract/service.
data_restrictions.exact_quote: â€œconditional on consent to the processing of personal data that is not necessary for the performance of that contract.â€

operational_restrictions.restriction: Controllers must implement withdrawal mechanisms that are no harder than the consent mechanism.
operational_restrictions.exact_quote: â€œIt shall be as easy to withdraw as to give consent.â€

individual_rights.right: Right to withdraw consent at any time
individual_rights.exact_quote: â€œThe data subject shall have the right to withdraw his or her consent at any time.â€

how_to_exercise_rights.process_requirement: Withdrawal must be as easy as giving consent (i.e., the controller must provide an accessible withdrawal method).
how_to_exercise_rights.exact_quote: â€œIt shall be as easy to withdraw as to give consent.â€

technical_measures.measure: Provide user-facing mechanisms enabling withdrawal that are as easy as the consent capture mechanism.
technical_measures.source_quote: â€œIt shall be as easy to withdraw as to give consent.â€

organizational_measures.measure: Maintain processes and governance to demonstrate consent (accountability).
organizational_measures.source_quote: â€œthe controller shall be able to demonstrate that the data subject has consentedâ€

organizational_measures.measure: Design consent request templates/forms so consent is clearly distinguishable, intelligible, accessible, and in clear/plain language when bundled with other matters.
organizational_measures.source_quote: â€œclearly distinguishable... intelligible and easily accessible... clear and plain language.â€

organizational_measures.measure: Ensure pre-consent notices include information that consent can be withdrawn at any time.
organizational_measures.source_quote: â€œPrior to giving consent, the data subject shall be informed thereof.â€

organizational_measures.measure: Include a consent-freedom assessment step, especially where contract/service is tied to consent for non-necessary processing.
organizational_measures.source_quote: â€œutmost account shall be taken of whether... [contract] is conditional on consent... not necessaryâ€

implementation_steps: Implement consent logging/recordkeeping sufficient to demonstrate that the data subject consented to the specific processing.
If consent is requested within a broader written declaration, separate the consent request visually/structurally so it is clearly distinguishable from other matters.
Ensure consent language is clear and plain, and the consent request is intelligible and easily accessible (e.g., not hidden in dense terms).
Provide a withdrawal method that is no more difficult than the method used to give consent (symmetry of effort).
Before collecting consent, inform the data subject that consent can be withdrawn at any time and that withdrawal does not affect prior lawful processing.
Assess whether consent is freely given, giving significant weight to whether access to a contract/service is conditioned on consenting to unnecessary processing.
common_violations: Inability to produce evidence that consent was obtained for the processing.
Bundling consent into general terms without making it clearly distinguishable.
Using complex, legalistic, or unclear language for consent requests.
Making withdrawal difficult (e.g., requiring phone calls or multiple steps) compared to giving consent (e.g., one click).
Failing to inform individuals before consent that they can withdraw at any time.
Conditioning a contract/service on consent to processing that is not necessary for the contract, undermining the 'freely given' nature of consent.
best_practices: Use layered notices and clear toggles/checkboxes for consent that are separate from other acknowledgments.
Provide a simple, persistent withdrawal option (e.g., account settings toggle or unsubscribe link) matching the ease of initial consent.
Document consent context (what was presented, when, how, and for what processing) to support demonstrability.
compliance_checklist: Can the controller demonstrate consent for each consent-based processing activity?
If consent is embedded in a broader written declaration, is the consent request clearly distinguishable?
Is the consent request intelligible and easily accessible?
Is the consent request written in clear and plain language?
Is the data subject informed before consenting that consent can be withdrawn at any time?
Is withdrawing consent as easy as giving consent?
Does withdrawal avoid retroactively affecting the lawfulness of prior consent-based processing (i.e., processes reflect non-retroactivity)?
When consent is tied to a contract/service, is there an assessment of whether the processing is necessary for the contract and whether consent is freely given?

keywords: as easy to withdraw as to give

key_definitions.withdrawal of consent: The act by which the data subject revokes previously given consent; per this section it may occur 'at any time' and 'shall not affect the lawfulness of processing based on consent before its withdrawal.'
key_definitions.freely given: A validity condition for consent; assessment must take 'utmost account' of whether contract/service performance is conditional on consent to processing that is not necessary for the contract.

regulations.regulation_id: GDPR Article 8 (Conditions applicable to child's consent in relation to information society services)
regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 8: Conditions applicable to child's consent in relation to information society services

industry_sectors: Any provider of information society services offered directly to children

description.brief_summary: Establishes when processing based on consent is lawful for information society services offered directly to children, setting an age threshold and requiring parental consent/authorization below that threshold, plus a controller duty to make reasonable efforts to verify parental involvement.
description.detailed_explanation: This provision applies only where the lawful basis is consent under Article 6(1)(a) and the context is the offer of information society services directly to a child. It sets a default rule that a child can provide valid consent at age 16 or older. If the child is under 16, processing is lawful only if and to the extent that consent is given or authorized by the holder of parental responsibility. Member States may legislate a lower age for these purposes, but the lower age cannot be below 13. Controllers must make reasonable efforts to verify that consent is given or authorized by the holder of parental responsibility, taking into account available technology. The rule explicitly does not affect Member Statesâ€™ general contract law concerning children (e.g., validity, formation, or effect of a contract involving a child).
description.purpose: To provide enhanced protection for children in the digital environment by ensuring that consent-based processing for online services offered directly to children is subject to age thresholds and parental involvement for younger children, and by requiring verification efforts by controllers.
description.legislative_intent: To harmonize baseline protections across the EU for childrenâ€™s consent in online services while allowing limited national flexibility (age floor 13) and ensuring controllers implement practical verification measures without overriding national contract law rules relating to minors.

what_it_covers: Processing of personal data of a child
Processing relying on consent as the lawful basis (Article 6(1)(a))
Offer of information society services directly to a child
Verification of parental consent/authorization where required
Member State legislative discretion to set a lower child-consent age (not below 13)

entity_types: Any entity acting as a controller offering information society services directly to children and relying on consent
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies within EU Member States; Member State law may set the applicable age between 13 and 16 for these purposes.

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing not based on consent under Article 6(1)(a) (not addressed in this section)
Effects on Member Statesâ€™ general contract law regarding children (explicitly not affected)

mandatory_obligations: Ensure that, where consent is the lawful basis under Article 6(1)(a) and an information society service is offered directly to a child, processing is lawful only under the age/consent conditions stated in this article.

Where the child is below the applicable age threshold (default 16 unless Member State law sets lower age not below 13), ensure processing is lawful "only if and to the extent that consent is given or authorised by the holder of parental responsibility over the child."

In cases requiring parental consent/authorization, the controller "shall make reasonable efforts to verify" that consent is given or authorised by the holder of parental responsibility, "taking into consideration available technology."
prohibited_actions: Do not treat consent as a lawful basis for processing a childâ€™s personal data in the covered context if the child is below the applicable age threshold and parental consent/authorization is not obtained.

Do not process beyond the scope permitted by parental consent/authorization where the child is below the applicable age threshold (implied by "only if and to the extent that" parental consent/authorization exists).

conditional_requirements.condition: Where point (a) of Article 6(1) applies (consent is the lawful basis), and the processing relates to the offer of information society services directly to a child
conditional_requirements.requirement: Processing is lawful where the child is at least 16 years old (default rule).
conditional_requirements.quote: "the processing of the personal data of a child shall be lawful where the child is at least 16 years old."

conditional_requirements.condition: Child is below 16 years old (or below the lower age set by Member State law, provided it is not below 13)
conditional_requirements.requirement: Processing is lawful only if and to the extent that consent is given or authorised by the holder of parental responsibility over the child.
conditional_requirements.quote: "Where the child is below the age of 16 years, such processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that consent is given or authorised by the holder of parental responsibility over the child."

conditional_requirements.condition: Member State chooses to legislate a lower age threshold for child consent for these purposes
conditional_requirements.requirement: The lower age must not be below 13 years.
conditional_requirements.quote: "Member States may provide by law for a lower age for those purposes provided that such lower age is not below 13 years."

conditional_requirements.condition: Parental consent/authorization is required (child below applicable age threshold)
conditional_requirements.requirement: Controller must make reasonable efforts to verify parental consent/authorization, considering available technology.
conditional_requirements.quote: "The controller shall make reasonable efforts to verify in such cases that consent is given or authorised by the holder of parental responsibility over the child, taking into consideration available technology."

conditional_requirements.condition: Interaction with Member State contract law involving children
conditional_requirements.requirement: This article does not affect general contract law of Member States (e.g., validity, formation, effect of a contract in relation to a child).
conditional_requirements.quote: "Paragraph 1 shall not affect the general contract law of Member States such as the rules on the validity, formation or effect of a contract in relation to a child."

documentation_requirements: Maintain evidence sufficient to demonstrate that consent was obtained from the child (if at/above applicable age) or given/authorised by the holder of parental responsibility (if below applicable age), consistent with the need to verify parental consent/authorization (specific record types not specified in this section).
timeline_requirements: Age threshold applies at the time consent is relied upon for processing in the context described (no explicit deadlines stated).

general_restrictions: Consent-based processing for information society services offered directly to a child is restricted by age thresholds and parental responsibility requirements.
data_restrictions: For children below the applicable age threshold, processing is limited to what is covered by parental consent/authorization ("only if and to the extent that").
operational_restrictions: Controllers must implement a process to verify parental consent/authorization when required.
technical_restrictions: Verification efforts must take into consideration available technology (specific technologies not mandated).
geographic_restrictions: Member States may set different age thresholds by law within the permitted range (13â€“16), creating jurisdiction-specific operational requirements.

individual_rights: Implied ability for a child aged at least 16 (or the lower age set by Member State law, not below 13) to provide valid consent for the covered processing context.
Implied role for the holder of parental responsibility to give or authorize consent for children below the applicable age threshold.
organizational_rights: Member States have discretion to legislate a lower age threshold for child consent for these purposes, subject to the minimum age of 13.
how_to_exercise_rights: Child provides consent if at/above applicable age threshold; if below, the holder of parental responsibility gives or authorizes consent (procedural details not specified in this section).

general_exceptions: This article applies only where Article 6(1)(a) (consent) is the lawful basis and the service is an information society service offered directly to a child; other lawful bases or contexts are not addressed here.
conditional_exemptions: Paragraph 1 does not affect Member Statesâ€™ general contract law regarding children (validity, formation, effect of contracts).

technical_measures: Implement age-gating or age-assessment mechanisms sufficient to apply the correct consent pathway (specific method not mandated in this section).
Implement mechanisms to support verification of parental consent/authorization, calibrated to what is reasonable and considering available technology (specific method not mandated in this section).
organizational_measures: Establish consent collection workflows distinguishing: (i) children at/above applicable age threshold; (ii) children below threshold requiring parental consent/authorization.
Establish procedures defining what constitutes "reasonable efforts" to verify parental responsibility consent/authorization, taking into account available technology.

complementary_regulations: Member State laws setting a lower age threshold for child consent for these purposes (13â€“16) (referenced but not specified)

implementation_steps: Determine whether the processing relies on consent under Article 6(1)(a) and whether the service is an information society service offered directly to a child.
Identify the applicable age threshold in each relevant Member State (default 16 unless lowered by national law, but not below 13).
Implement a consent flow that: (a) accepts the childâ€™s consent if the child is at/above the applicable age; (b) requires parental consent/authorization if below.
Implement and document "reasonable efforts" to verify parental consent/authorization, selecting methods appropriate to available technology and risk.
common_violations: Relying on a childâ€™s consent below the applicable age threshold without obtaining parental consent/authorization.
Failing to perform reasonable verification of parental consent/authorization when required.
Applying a uniform age threshold across the EU without accounting for Member State laws that set a lower age (13â€“16).
Processing beyond the scope covered by parental consent/authorization (contrary to "only if and to the extent that").
best_practices: Maintain jurisdiction-specific configuration for the child-consent age threshold (13â€“16) based on Member State law.
Use proportionate verification methods aligned with "reasonable efforts" and document the rationale for the chosen approach considering available technology.
compliance_checklist: Is the lawful basis for the processing consent under Article 6(1)(a)?
Is the service an information society service offered directly to a child?
What is the applicable age threshold in the relevant Member State (16 default; may be lower but not below 13)?
If the child is below the applicable age threshold, is consent given or authorized by the holder of parental responsibility?
Have reasonable efforts been made to verify parental consent/authorization, considering available technology?
Is processing limited to the extent covered by the obtained consent/authorization?

regulations.source_section: ## Conditions applicable to child's consent in relation to information society services

regulations.regulation_id: GDPR Article 9 (Processing of special categories of personal data)
regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 9: Processing of special categories of personal data

description.brief_summary: Prohibits processing of special categories of personal data unless a listed exception applies, and imposes additional secrecy/safeguard conditions for certain health-related processing; allows Member States to impose further conditions for genetic, biometric, and health data.
description.detailed_explanation: This section establishes a default rule that processing of specified special categories of personal data is prohibited. It then provides a closed list of legal bases/conditions under which the prohibition is lifted, including explicit consent, employment/social protection law authorization with safeguards, vital interests where consent cannot be given, limited not-for-profit processing with safeguards and non-disclosure without consent, data manifestly made public by the data subject, legal claims/courts, substantial public interest with proportionality and safeguards, medical/health/social care purposes under law or contract with a health professional subject to safeguards, public health reasons under law with specific measures including professional secrecy, and archiving/research/statistics under Article 89(1) with proportionality and safeguards. It further requires that processing for the medical/health purposes in point (h) be performed by or under responsibility of a professional bound by secrecy (or another person bound by secrecy) under Union/Member State law or competent-body rules. Finally, it permits Member States to maintain or introduce additional conditions/limitations for genetic data, biometric data, or health data.
description.purpose: To provide heightened protection for sensitive personal data by prohibiting processing by default and allowing it only under strict, enumerated conditions with safeguards.
description.legislative_intent: To reduce risks of discrimination and harm from misuse of sensitive data while enabling necessary processing for defined societal, legal, employment, medical, public health, and research purposes under safeguards.

what_it_covers: Processing of personal data revealing racial or ethnic origin
Processing of personal data revealing political opinions
Processing of personal data revealing religious or philosophical beliefs
Processing of personal data revealing trade union membership
Processing of genetic data
Processing of biometric data for the purpose of uniquely identifying a natural person
Processing of data concerning health
Processing of data concerning a natural person's sex life
Processing of data concerning a natural person's sexual orientation
Processing for employment/social security/social protection purposes where authorized
Processing by not-for-profit bodies with political/philosophical/religious/trade union aims under conditions
Processing for legal claims and courts acting judicially
Processing for substantial public interest under law with safeguards

Processing for preventive/occupational medicine, working capacity assessment, diagnosis, care/treatment, and health/social care system management under law/contract with health professional and secrecy safeguards
Processing for public health interests (e.g., cross-border threats; quality/safety of care, medicinal products, medical devices) under law with safeguards including professional secrecy
Processing for archiving in the public interest, scientific/historical research, or statistical purposes in accordance with Article 89(1) under law with safeguards

target_entities: Processors (indirectly, where acting on behalf of controllers)
Not-for-profit bodies (foundations, associations, other not-for-profit bodies) with specified aims
Health professionals and persons under their responsibility
Member State legislators/regulators (ability to add conditions)
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies within EU/Member State legal frameworks; several exceptions require a basis in Union or Member State law.

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing of non-special-category personal data (not addressed in this section)
Biometric data not processed 'for the purpose of uniquely identifying a natural person' (not explicitly included in the listed prohibition as quoted)

mandatory_obligations: Apply a default prohibition: "Processing of personal data revealing racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, or trade union membership, and the processing of genetic data, biometric data for the purpose of uniquely identifying a natural person, data concerning health or data concerning a natural person's sex life or sexual orientation shall be prohibited."
Only process special categories if at least one enumerated condition applies (points (a)â€“(j)).

For employment/social security/social protection processing under point (b), ensure it is "authorised by Union or Member State law or a collective agreement pursuant to Member State law" and that such instrument provides "appropriate safeguards for the fundamental rights and the interests of the data subject."

For not-for-profit processing under point (d), ensure processing is carried out "in the course of its legitimate activities" and "with appropriate safeguards"; ensure it "relates solely" to members/former members or persons with regular contact in connection with its purposes; ensure data "are not disclosed outside that body without the consent of the data subjects."

For substantial public interest processing under point (g), ensure there is a basis in Union/Member State law that "shall be proportionate to the aim pursued, respect the essence of the right to data protection and provide for suitable and specific measures to safeguard the fundamental rights and the interests of the data subject."

For medical/health/social care processing under point (h), ensure it is based on Union/Member State law or "pursuant to contract with a health professional" and is "subject to the conditions and safeguards referred to in paragraph 3."

For public health processing under point (i), ensure it is based on Union/Member State law that "provides for suitable and specific measures to safeguard the rights and freedoms of the data subject, in particular professional secrecy."

For archiving/research/statistics under point (j), ensure it is "in accordance with Article 89(1)" and based on Union/Member State law that is proportionate, respects the essence of the right to data protection, and provides suitable and specific safeguarding measures.

For processing under point (h), ensure paragraph 3 secrecy condition is met: special category data "may be processed for the purposes referred to in point (h)" only when processed "by or under the responsibility of a professional" subject to professional secrecy under Union/Member State law or competent-body rules, or by another person also subject to an obligation of secrecy under such law/rules.
prohibited_actions: Process special categories of personal data unless an exception applies (general prohibition).
Under point (d), disclose personal data outside the not-for-profit body without the data subjects' consent.

conditional_requirements.condition: Explicit consent exception (point (a))
conditional_requirements.requirement: Processing is permitted if "the data subject has given explicit consent to the processing of those personal data for one or more specified purposes".
conditional_requirements.limitation: This does not apply "where Union or Member State law provide that the prohibition referred to in paragraph 1 may not be lifted by the data subject".

conditional_requirements.condition: Employment/social security/social protection (point (b))
conditional_requirements.requirement: Processing must be "necessary" for carrying out obligations/exercising specific rights of controller or data subject in employment and social security/social protection law, and must be authorized by Union/Member State law or qualifying collective agreement with appropriate safeguards.

conditional_requirements.condition: Vital interests (point (c))
conditional_requirements.requirement: Processing must be "necessary" to protect vital interests of the data subject or another natural person, and the data subject must be "physically or legally incapable of giving consent".

conditional_requirements.condition: Not-for-profit bodies (point (d))
conditional_requirements.requirement: Processing must be in course of legitimate activities, with appropriate safeguards, relate solely to members/former members or regular contacts, and no disclosure outside without consent.

conditional_requirements.condition: Manifestly made public (point (e))
conditional_requirements.requirement: Processing is permitted where it "relates to personal data which are manifestly made public by the data subject".

conditional_requirements.condition: Legal claims/courts (point (f))
conditional_requirements.requirement: Processing must be "necessary" for establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims, or occur "whenever courts are acting in their judicial capacity".

conditional_requirements.condition: Substantial public interest (point (g))
conditional_requirements.requirement: Processing must be "necessary" for reasons of substantial public interest, based on Union/Member State law meeting proportionality/essence/safeguards criteria.

conditional_requirements.condition: Preventive/occupational medicine and health/social care (point (h) + paragraph 3)
conditional_requirements.requirement: Processing must be "necessary" for listed medical/health purposes; must be based on Union/Member State law or contract with a health professional; and must be performed by/under responsibility of a secrecy-bound professional (or another secrecy-bound person).

conditional_requirements.condition: Public health (point (i))
conditional_requirements.requirement: Processing must be "necessary" for public interest in public health (examples given), based on Union/Member State law with suitable and specific measures safeguarding rights/freedoms, particularly professional secrecy.

conditional_requirements.condition: Archiving/research/statistics (point (j))
conditional_requirements.requirement: Processing must be "necessary" for archiving in public interest, scientific/historical research, or statistical purposes; must be in accordance with Article 89(1); and based on Union/Member State law meeting proportionality/essence/safeguards criteria.

conditional_requirements.condition: Member State additional conditions (paragraph 4)
conditional_requirements.requirement: Member States "may maintain or introduce further conditions, including limitations" for processing of genetic data, biometric data, or health data.

general_restrictions: Default ban on processing special categories of personal data unless a listed exception applies.
data_restrictions: Special categories listed are restricted: racial/ethnic origin; political opinions; religious/philosophical beliefs; trade union membership; genetic data; biometric data for unique identification; health data; sex life; sexual orientation.
operational_restrictions: Not-for-profit bodies must limit processing scope to members/former members/regular contacts and must not disclose outside without consent.
Medical/health processing under point (h) must be carried out by/under responsibility of secrecy-bound professionals or secrecy-bound persons.
geographic_restrictions: Several exceptions require a basis in Union or Member State law; Member States may impose additional conditions/limitations for genetic/biometric/health data.

individual_rights: Implied protection right via prohibition and safeguard requirements (no standalone procedural right described in this section).
Right to control disclosure outside a not-for-profit body under point (d) via consent requirement for disclosure.
organizational_rights: Not-for-profit bodies may process within legitimate activities under strict conditions (point (d)).
Controllers may process special categories when one of the enumerated exceptions applies.
how_to_exercise_rights: Provide explicit consent for specified purposes (point (a)) where legally permitted.
Withhold consent to prevent disclosure outside a not-for-profit body (point (d)).

general_exceptions: The prohibition "shall not apply" if one of points (a)â€“(j) applies.
conditional_exemptions: Explicit consent for specified purposes (a), subject to Union/Member State law that may prevent lifting the prohibition.
Employment/social security/social protection necessity with legal/collective agreement authorization and safeguards (b).
Vital interests where consent cannot be given (c).
Not-for-profit legitimate activities with safeguards and non-disclosure without consent (d).
Data manifestly made public by the data subject (e).
Legal claims or courts acting judicially (f).
Substantial public interest under proportionate law with safeguards (g).
Medical/health/social care purposes under law/contract with health professional and secrecy safeguards (h + paragraph 3).
Public health interest under law with suitable/specific measures, particularly professional secrecy (i).
Archiving/research/statistics under Article 89(1) and proportionate law with safeguards (j).
public_interest_exceptions: Substantial public interest (g) under Union/Member State law with proportionality and safeguards.
Public interest in the area of public health (i) under Union/Member State law with suitable/specific measures, particularly professional secrecy.
Archiving in the public interest (j) under Article 89(1) and Union/Member State law with safeguards.

organizational_measures: Implement decision logic to ensure special category processing occurs only under an applicable exception (a)â€“(j).
Where relying on (b), ensure applicable law/collective agreement authorization is identified and that appropriate safeguards are implemented as required by that instrument.

Where relying on (d), implement governance to ensure processing is limited to eligible individuals (members/former members/regular contacts), conducted with appropriate safeguards, and prevent external disclosure absent consent.
Where relying on (g), (i), or (j), identify and comply with the specific Union/Member State law basis and its required suitable/specific safeguarding measures.
security_measures: Where required by applicable Union/Member State law under (g), (i), (j), implement "suitable and specific measures" safeguarding fundamental rights/interests/rights and freedoms; for (i) explicitly includes measures ensuring "professional secrecy".

complementary_regulations: Union or Member State laws authorizing processing under points (b), (g), (h), (i), (j)
Collective agreements pursuant to Member State law (point (b))
Rules established by national competent bodies regarding professional secrecy (paragraph 3)

implementation_steps: Classify data to detect whether it falls within the listed special categories (racial/ethnic origin, political opinions, religious/philosophical beliefs, trade union membership, genetic, biometric for unique identification, health, sex life, sexual orientation).
Block processing of such data by default unless a documented exception (a)â€“(j) is selected and validated.

If using explicit consent (a), ensure consent is explicit and tied to one or more specified purposes; verify whether Union/Member State law disallows lifting the prohibition by consent for the relevant context.

If using employment/social protection basis (b), map the specific obligation/right and confirm authorization in Union/Member State law or qualifying collective agreement; implement the required safeguards.
If using vital interests (c), confirm necessity and document incapacity to consent.
If using not-for-profit basis (d), restrict datasets to members/former members/regular contacts; implement non-disclosure controls; obtain consent before any external disclosure.
If using legal claims/courts (f), confirm necessity for claims or that courts act judicially.

If using substantial public interest (g), identify the enabling law and implement its suitable/specific safeguarding measures; confirm proportionality and respect for the essence of the right to data protection as required by the law.
If using medical/health basis (h), ensure processing is by/under responsibility of secrecy-bound professionals (paragraph 3) and that the legal/contractual basis and safeguards are in place.
If using public health basis (i), ensure enabling law includes suitable/specific measures, particularly professional secrecy, and implement them.
If using archiving/research/statistics (j), ensure compliance with Article 89(1) and enabling law safeguards.
common_violations: Processing special category data without fitting within any exception (a)â€“(j).
Relying on consent where Union/Member State law does not allow lifting the prohibition by consent.
Not-for-profit bodies disclosing data outside the organization without obtaining data subject consent.
Health-related processing under (h) performed without professional secrecy obligations or outside responsibility of a secrecy-bound professional.
Invoking public interest bases (g), (i), or (j) without a specific Union/Member State law basis and without implementing the required suitable/specific safeguards.
best_practices: Maintain a controlled register of special-category processing activities mapped to the specific exception (a)â€“(j) and the corresponding legal basis (Union/Member State law/collective agreement/contract).
Implement access controls and confidentiality commitments aligned with professional secrecy requirements for health processing.
For not-for-profit processing, implement strict membership/relationship validation and outbound disclosure prevention controls.
compliance_checklist: Is the data within the listed special categories?
If yes, which exception (a)â€“(j) is relied upon, and is it necessary for that purpose?
If relying on (a), is consent explicit and purpose-specific, and is consent legally capable of lifting the prohibition in this context?
If relying on (b), is there Union/Member State law or qualifying collective agreement authorization and appropriate safeguards?
If relying on (d), is processing limited to members/former members/regular contacts, with appropriate safeguards, and no external disclosure without consent?
If relying on (g)/(i)/(j), is there a specific Union/Member State law basis and are suitable/specific safeguarding measures implemented (including professional secrecy for (i))?
If relying on (h), is processing by/under responsibility of a secrecy-bound professional (or secrecy-bound person) and are required safeguards applied?
Have Member State additional conditions/limitations for genetic/biometric/health data been checked and applied (paragraph 4)?

key_definitions.special_categories_of_personal_data: As listed in the prohibition: personal data revealing racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, trade union membership; genetic data; biometric data for uniquely identifying a natural person; data concerning health; data concerning a natural person's sex life or sexual orientation.
key_definitions.biometric_data_for_unique_identification: Biometric data processed "for the purpose of uniquely identifying a natural person" (as the condition stated in the prohibition).
key_definitions.explicit_consent: Consent that is "explicit" and given "for one or more specified purposes" (as stated in point (a)).
key_definitions.professional_secrecy: An "obligation of professional secrecy" under Union or Member State law or rules established by national competent bodies (paragraph 3), and highlighted as a key safeguard for public health processing (point (i)).

regulations.source_section: ## Processing of special categories of personal data

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 10 (Processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences)

applicable_regions: EEA (via incorporation into EEA law, where applicable)

sub_domains: Safeguards for data subject rights and freedoms
industry_sectors: All sectors processing criminal conviction/offence data (e.g., employers, background screening, financial services, security services, online platforms, public sector)

description.brief_summary: Criminal conviction/offence data (and related security measures) may be processed only under official authority control or where authorized by EU/Member State law with appropriate safeguards; comprehensive criminal conviction registers must be kept only under official authority control.
description.detailed_explanation: This provision imposes heightened conditions on processing personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences or related security measures. It restricts such processing to two permitted governance/legal pathways: (1) processing carried out 'only under the control of official authority'; or (2) processing that is 'authorised by Union or Member State law' and that law must 'provid[e] for appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of data subjects.' In addition, it imposes a specific rule for 'any comprehensive register of criminal convictions': it 'shall be kept only under the control of official authority.' The section also states that the processing referenced is 'based on Article 6(1)', indicating that even where a lawful basis under Article 6(1) exists, these additional Article 10 conditions must still be satisfied for criminal conviction/offence data.
description.purpose: To limit and tightly govern the processing of criminal conviction and offence data due to its sensitivity and potential for significant harm, discrimination, or unfair treatment, ensuring strong public oversight or explicit legal authorization with safeguards.
description.legislative_intent: To ensure that criminal conviction/offence data is not processed freely by private actors solely on general lawful bases, but instead is subject to official authority control or explicit legislative authorization with safeguards, and to reserve comprehensive conviction registers to official authority control.

what_it_covers: Processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions
Processing of personal data relating to criminal offences
Processing of personal data relating to 'related security measures'
Keeping/maintaining 'any comprehensive register of criminal convictions'
Processing that is 'based on Article 6(1)' (i.e., processing relying on a lawful basis under GDPR Article 6(1))

target_entities: Processors (to the extent they process on behalf of controllers under the controllerâ€™s governance and legal authorization)
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities subject to GDPR territorial scope (not specified in the provided text).

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing of other categories of personal data not relating to criminal convictions/offences or related security measures (not addressed in this section).

mandatory_obligations: Ensure that 'Processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences or related security measures based on Article 6(1) shall be carried out only under the control of official authority' OR meet the alternative authorization condition described in the same sentence. (Quote: "shall be carried out only under the control of official authority or when the processing is authorised by Union or Member State law providing for appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of data subjects.")

Where relying on authorization by law, ensure the processing is 'authorised by Union or Member State law' and that such law 'provid[es] for appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of data subjects.' (Quote: "authorised by Union or Member State law providing for appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of data subjects")

Ensure that 'Any comprehensive register of criminal convictions shall be kept only under the control of official authority.' (Quote: "Any comprehensive register of criminal convictions shall be kept only under the control of official authority.")
prohibited_actions: Do not process personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences or related security measures (where based on Article 6(1)) unless it is under official authority control or authorized by Union/Member State law with appropriate safeguards. (Implied prohibition from 'shall be carried out only...')
Do not keep a comprehensive register of criminal convictions unless it is under the control of official authority. (Implied prohibition from 'shall be kept only...')
conditional_requirements: If processing is not under the control of official authority, it is permitted only 'when the processing is authorised by Union or Member State law' AND that law provides 'appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of data subjects.'
If an organization maintains a 'comprehensive register of criminal convictions', it must be kept only under official authority control (no alternative pathway is stated for comprehensive registers).

general_restrictions: Processing is restricted to official authority control or explicit legal authorization with safeguards. (Quote: "shall be carried out only under the control of official authority or when the processing is authorised by Union or Member State law providing for appropriate safeguards")
Comprehensive criminal conviction registers are restricted to official authority control only. (Quote: "shall be kept only under the control of official authority")
data_restrictions: Applies specifically to 'personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences or related security measures'.
operational_restrictions: Private-sector processing operations involving criminal conviction/offence data must be structured either under official authority control or grounded in a specific Union/Member State legal authorization with safeguards.

individual_rights: Right to have processing subject to 'appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of data subjects' where processing is authorized by Union/Member State law. (Quote: "appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of data subjects")

conditional_exemptions: Processing may occur without being under official authority control only if it is authorized by Union or Member State law that provides appropriate safeguards. (This is an alternative condition rather than an exemption.)

organizational_measures: Establish governance to ensure processing is either conducted under official authority control or is demonstrably authorized by applicable Union/Member State law with appropriate safeguards.
For any activity that could constitute a 'comprehensive register of criminal convictions', ensure operational control rests with an official authority.
security_measures: Where processing is authorized by law, ensure 'appropriate safeguards' are in place for data subject rights and freedoms (specific safeguards are not enumerated in the provided text).

related_articles: GDPR Article 6(1) (lawfulness of processing) (referenced in the text as the basis over which Article 10 imposes additional conditions)
complementary_regulations: Union or Member State law authorizing such processing and providing appropriate safeguards (not specified in the provided text).

implementation_steps: Identify whether any processing involves 'personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences or related security measures.'
Confirm the intended lawful basis under GDPR Article 6(1) and then apply the additional Article 10 gatekeeping conditions.

Determine whether processing is 'under the control of official authority'; if not, identify the specific Union/Member State law that authorizes the processing and verify it provides 'appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of data subjects.'

Assess whether any dataset/system constitutes a 'comprehensive register of criminal convictions'; if yes, ensure it is kept only under official authority control (or discontinue/avoid maintaining such a register).
common_violations: Processing criminal conviction/offence data in the private sector relying only on a general Article 6(1) lawful basis without official authority control or explicit legal authorization with safeguards.
Maintaining a broad/internal database that functions as a comprehensive criminal conviction register without official authority control.
best_practices: Maintain a legal basis mapping that flags criminal conviction/offence data as requiring Article 10 conditions in addition to Article 6(1).
Document the specific Union/Member State legal authorization relied upon and the safeguards it requires/implements (even though documentation is not explicitly required in the provided text).
Minimize collection and avoid building comprehensive conviction registers unless operating under official authority control.
compliance_checklist: Does the processing involve criminal convictions/offences or related security measures?
Is the processing under official authority control? If not, is there a specific Union/Member State law authorizing it?
Does the authorizing law provide appropriate safeguards for data subject rights and freedoms?
Is any comprehensive register of criminal convictions being kept? If yes, is it kept only under official authority control?

key_definitions.personal data relating to criminal convi: Not defined in the provided text; refers to personal data about an individual's criminal convictions and offences.
key_definitions.related security measures: Not defined in the provided text; refers to security measures connected to criminal convictions/offences.
key_definitions.under the control of official authority: Not defined in the provided text; indicates oversight/control by a public/official authority.
key_definitions.comprehensive register of criminal convi: Not defined in the provided text; indicates a broad/complete register/database of criminal convictions.

regulations.source_section: ## Processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 11: Processing which does not require identification

applicable_regions: European Economic Area (as incorporated into EEA law)

description.brief_summary: Where a controllerâ€™s processing purposes do not require (or no longer require) identifying individuals, the controller is not required to keep or obtain extra information solely to identify individuals for GDPR compliance; if the controller can demonstrate it cannot identify the data subject, it must inform the data subject if possible, and certain rights (Articles 15â€“20) do not apply unless the data subject provides additional information enabling identification.
description.detailed_explanation: Article 11 establishes a limitation on controllersâ€™ obligations to identify data subjects. First, it removes any obligation to maintain, acquire, or process additional information solely to identify a data subject when identification is not needed for the controllerâ€™s processing purposes. Second, it provides a conditional mechanism affecting the applicability of certain data subject rights: if the controller can demonstrate it is not in a position to identify the data subject in the circumstances described in paragraph 1, the controller must inform the data subject accordingly (if possible). In that situation, the rights in Articles 15 to 20 do not apply, except where the data subject provides additional information that enables identification for the purpose of exercising those rights.
description.purpose: To prevent forcing controllers to collect or retain additional identifying data solely to respond to GDPR compliance obligations when the processing does not require identification, while still allowing rights to be exercised if the data subject provides information enabling identification.
description.legislative_intent: To balance data minimization and practical feasibility with the protection of data subject rights, ensuring controllers are not incentivized to increase identifiability merely to comply, but preserving rights where identification becomes possible.

what_it_covers: Controller processing of personal data where identification of the data subject is not required for the processing purposes
Controller decisions about whether to maintain, acquire, or process additional identifying information solely for GDPR compliance
Controller handling of data subject rights requests under Articles 15â€“20 when the controller cannot identify the requester
Controller communications to data subjects about inability to identify (where possible)

entity_types: Any organization acting as a controller
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Controllers subject to GDPR territorial scope (not specified in this section).

what_it_does_not_cover: Situations where the controllerâ€™s purposes require identification of the data subject (Article 11(1) condition not met)
Rights outside Articles 15â€“20 (this section only limits applicability of Articles 15â€“20 under specified conditions)

mandatory_obligations: When the controller is able to demonstrate that it is not in a position to identify the data subject (in cases referred to in paragraph 1), the controller must inform the data subject accordingly, if possible. (Quote: "the controller shall inform the data subject accordingly, if possible.")
prohibited_actions: A controller must not be required (i.e., is not obliged) to maintain, acquire, or process additional information solely to identify the data subject for the sole purpose of complying with the GDPR, where identification is not or no longer required for the processing purposes. (Quote: "the controller shall not be obliged to maintain, acquire or process additional information in order to identify the data subject for the sole purpose of complying with this Regulation.")
conditional_requirements: Condition for non-obligation: applies only "If the purposes for which a controller processes personal data do not or do no longer require the identification of a data subject by the controller" (Article 11(1)).

Condition for informing the data subject: applies "Where, in cases referred to in paragraph 1 of this Article, the controller is able to demonstrate that it is not in a position to identify the data subject" (Article 11(2)); then the controller must inform the data subject accordingly, "if possible".

Condition limiting rights applicability: "In such cases, Articles 15 to 20 shall not apply" (Article 11(2))â€”i.e., when the controller can demonstrate it cannot identify the data subject in the Article 11(1) scenario.

Exception to rights limitation: Articles 15â€“20 apply "except where the data subject, for the purpose of exercising his or her rights under those articles, provides additional information enabling his or her identification." (Article 11(2)).
documentation_requirements: The controller must be able to demonstrate it is not in a position to identify the data subject in the relevant cases. (Quote: "the controller is able to demonstrate that it is not in a position to identify the data subject")
reporting_requirements: Notification/communication to the data subject about inability to identify, if possible. (Quote: "shall inform the data subject accordingly, if possible")
timeline_requirements: No explicit deadlines are stated in this section for informing the data subject or for handling rights requests.

general_restrictions: Controllers are not required to take additional steps to identify a data subject solely for GDPR compliance when identification is not needed for processing purposes.
data_restrictions: Restriction against maintaining, acquiring, or processing additional identifying information solely to identify the data subject for compliance purposes in the Article 11(1) scenario.
operational_restrictions: Limitation on the applicability of Articles 15â€“20 in the specified non-identification scenario, unless the data subject provides additional identifying information.

individual_rights: Conditional ability to exercise rights under Articles 15â€“20 by providing additional information enabling identification when the controller cannot otherwise identify the data subject. (Quote: "except where the data subject... provides additional information enabling his or her identification")
organizational_rights: Controllers have the ability to refrain from maintaining/acquiring/processing additional identifying information solely for GDPR compliance when identification is not required for processing purposes. (Quote: "shall not be obliged")

Controllers may treat Articles 15â€“20 as not applicable in the specified scenario where they can demonstrate inability to identify, unless the data subject provides additional identifying information. (Quote: "Articles 15 to 20 shall not apply except where...")
how_to_exercise_rights: If the controller cannot identify the data subject, the data subject may provide additional information enabling identification for the purpose of exercising rights under Articles 15â€“20.

general_exceptions: Articles 15â€“20 do not apply in the specified scenario where the controller can demonstrate it cannot identify the data subject. (Quote: "Articles 15 to 20 shall not apply")
conditional_exemptions: The non-obligation to identify applies only when the controllerâ€™s processing purposes do not or no longer require identification. (Quote: "do not or do no longer require the identification")
The duty to inform the data subject is qualified by feasibility: "if possible."

organizational_measures: Implement a process to assess and document whether processing purposes require identification of data subjects (to determine applicability of Article 11(1)).

Implement a process to evaluate and document whether the controller is "in a position to identify" a data subject in the context of a rights request, and to support the required demonstration under Article 11(2).
Implement a communication mechanism to inform the data subject that identification is not possible, where feasible ("if possible").
Implement a procedure to accept and use additional information provided by the data subject to enable identification for exercising Articles 15â€“20 rights.

related_articles: GDPR Articles 15â€“20 (data subject rights referenced as conditionally inapplicable/applicable)

implementation_steps: Determine whether each processing activityâ€™s purposes require identification of data subjects; if not, avoid collecting/retaining extra identifiers solely for GDPR compliance.
When receiving a rights request, assess whether the requester can be identified with information already held; if not, document the basis for inability to identify.
If the controller can demonstrate inability to identify, inform the data subject accordingly where feasible.
If the data subject provides additional information enabling identification, process the request under Articles 15â€“20 using that information.
common_violations: Collecting or retaining additional identifying information solely to be able to respond to GDPR obligations when identification is not required for the processing purposes.
Failing to inform the data subject (where possible) that the controller cannot identify them after determining and being able to demonstrate inability to identify.
Incorrectly refusing to apply Articles 15â€“20 even after the data subject provides additional information enabling identification.
best_practices: Maintain clear internal criteria for when identification is required for processing purposes versus when it is not.
Keep a documented rationale and evidence supporting any claim that the controller is not in a position to identify a data subject.
Provide a clear channel for data subjects to submit additional information to enable identification when exercising Articles 15â€“20 rights.
compliance_checklist: Processing purposes assessed: identification required? (yes/no) documented.
No additional identifying data collected solely for GDPR compliance where Article 11(1) applies.
Ability/inability to identify data subject assessed and demonstrable evidence retained.
Data subject informed of inability to identify where feasible.
Procedure exists to accept additional information from data subject and then apply Articles 15â€“20.

key_definitions.controller: Not defined in this section (term used as the responsible party).
key_definitions.data subject: Not defined in this section (individual whose personal data are processed).
key_definitions.additional information: Information provided or obtained to enable identification of the data subject; only referenced, not defined.
key_definitions.not in a position to identify: A state where the controller cannot identify the data subject; requires the controller to be able to demonstrate this, but no criteria are specified in this section.

regulations.source_section: ## Processing which does not require identification

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 12: Transparent information, communication and modalities for the exercise of the rights of the data subject

applicable_regions: European Economic Area (as incorporated by EEA mechanisms where applicable)

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data (public and private)

description.brief_summary: Imposes detailed procedural and transparency requirements on controllers for providing GDPR information and handling data subject rights requests, including format, language, timelines, free-of-charge principle, conditions for fees/refusal, identity verification, and optional standardized icons.
description.detailed_explanation: The provision requires controllers to implement appropriate measures to deliver GDPR information (Articles 13 and 14) and communications/actions related to data subject rights (Articles 15â€“22) and personal data breach communications (Article 34) in a manner that is concise, transparent, intelligible, and easily accessible, using clear and plain language, with special emphasis on child-directed information. It establishes permissible delivery channels (written or other means including electronic; oral upon request with identity proven). It mandates facilitation of rights exercise and limits refusal to act, particularly where Article 11(2) applies, unless the controller can demonstrate inability to identify the data subject. It sets strict response deadlines (without undue delay and within one month), allows a defined extension (up to two additional months) based on complexity/number of requests, and requires timely notice of extension with reasons. It requires electronic responses where requests are made electronically, where possible, unless the data subject requests otherwise. If no action is taken, the controller must notify the data subject within one month with reasons and inform them of complaint and judicial remedy options. It establishes that information/communications/actions under specified articles must be free of charge, with a narrow exception for manifestly unfounded or excessive requests (especially repetitive), allowing either a reasonable fee (administrative costs-based) or refusal; the controller bears the burden of demonstrating the request is manifestly unfounded/excessive. It permits controllers to request additional information to confirm identity where there are reasonable doubts (without prejudice to Article 11). It allows combining Articles 13/14 information with standardized icons to provide a meaningful overview, and requires machine-readability when icons are presented electronically. It empowers the Commission to adopt delegated acts (per Article 92) to determine icon information and procedures.
description.purpose: To ensure data subjects can effectively understand and exercise their GDPR rights through standardized, accessible, timely, and fair communications and request-handling procedures.
description.legislative_intent: To operationalize transparency and rights effectiveness by mandating clear communication standards, predictable timelines, safeguards against abusive requests, and mechanisms (including icons) that improve comprehension and accessibility.

what_it_covers: Providing information referred to in GDPR Articles 13 and 14
Communications under GDPR Articles 15 to 22 and 34 relating to processing
Modalities for exercising data subject rights (Articles 15â€“22)
Controller response timelines and extension rules for rights requests
Controller obligations when refusing or not acting on a request
Charging fees or refusing requests that are manifestly unfounded or excessive
Identity verification and requests for additional identity information
Use of standardized icons for Articles 13/14 information and machine-readability requirements
Commission delegated acts on icon content and procedures

entity_types: Any organization acting as a controller under GDPR
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies to controllers subject to GDPR territorial scope (not detailed in this section).

what_it_does_not_cover: Processor-specific obligations (not specified here)
Substantive content of Articles 13, 14, 15â€“22, or 34 beyond the procedural handling and communication modalities described here
Penalties and fine amounts (not stated in this section)

mandatory_obligations: Controller must take "appropriate measures" to provide required information and communications to the data subject meeting specified quality and accessibility standards.
