Quote: "The controller shall take appropriate measures to provide any information referred to in Articles 13 and 14 and any communication under Articles 15 to 22 and 34... in a concise, transparent, intelligible and easily accessible form, using clear and plain language".
Special consideration for children. Quote: "in particular for any information addressed specifically to a child".
Provide information "in writing, or by other means, including, where appropriate, by electronic means."

Provide information orally when requested by the data subject, provided identity is proven by other means. Quote: "When requested by the data subject, the information may be provided orally, provided that the identity of the data subject is proven by other means."
Controller must facilitate exercise of data subject rights under Articles 15 to 22. Quote: "The controller shall facilitate the exercise of data subject rights under Articles 15 to 22."

In Article 11(2) cases, controller must not refuse to act on a request to exercise rights under Articles 15â€“22 unless it demonstrates inability to identify the data subject. Quote: "the controller shall not refuse to act... unless the controller demonstrates that it is not in a position to identify the data subject."
Controller must provide information on action taken on a request under Articles 15â€“22 "without undue delay" and "in any event within one month of receipt of the request."

If extending the response period, controller must inform the data subject of the extension within one month of receipt and provide reasons. Quote: "The controller shall inform the data subject of any such extension within one month of receipt of the request, together with the reasons for the delay."

If request is made by electronic means, provide information by electronic means where possible unless otherwise requested. Quote: "Where the data subject makes the request by electronic form means, the information shall be provided by electronic means where possible, unless otherwise requested by the data subject."

If controller does not take action, it must inform the data subject without delay and at the latest within one month of receipt, including reasons and information about complaint/judicial remedy. Quote: "the controller shall inform the data subject without delay and at the latest within one month... of the reasons for not taking action and on the possibility of lodging a complaint with a supervisory authority and seeking a judicial remedy."
Information under Articles 13 and 14 and communications/actions under Articles 15â€“22 and 34 must be provided free of charge. Quote: "shall be provided free of charge."

Where charging a fee or refusing due to manifestly unfounded/excessive requests, controller bears burden of demonstrating that character. Quote: "The controller shall bear the burden of demonstrating the manifestly unfounded or excessive character of the request."

Where controller has reasonable doubts about identity, it may request additional information necessary to confirm identity. Quote: "the controller may request the provision of additional information necessary to confirm the identity of the data subject."
If standardized icons are presented electronically, they must be machine-readable. Quote: "Where the icons are presented electronically they shall be machine-readable."
prohibited_actions: Controller must not refuse to act on a data subject request to exercise rights under Articles 15â€“22 in Article 11(2) cases unless it can demonstrate inability to identify the data subject. Quote: "shall not refuse to act... unless... demonstrates that it is not in a position to identify the data subject."

Controller must not charge for information/communications/actions under Articles 13, 14, 15â€“22, and 34 except under the manifestly unfounded/excessive request conditions described. Quote: "shall be provided free of charge" (subject to the stated exception).
conditional_requirements: Oral provision is permitted only if requested by the data subject and identity is proven by other means. Quote: "may be provided orally, provided that the identity... is proven by other means."

Response deadline extension is permitted only "where necessary" and considering "the complexity and number of the requests"; maximum extension is two further months. Quote: "may be extended by two further months where necessary, taking into account the complexity and number of the requests."

Electronic response modality applies when the request is made by electronic means and electronic provision is possible, unless the data subject requests otherwise. Quote: "shall be provided by electronic means where possible, unless otherwise requested".

Fee charging or refusal is permitted only where requests are "manifestly unfounded or excessive, in particular because of their repetitive character"; fee must be "reasonable" and consider administrative costs. Quote: "charge a reasonable fee taking into account the administrative costs".

Additional identity information may be requested only where the controller has "reasonable doubts" concerning identity and only to the extent "necessary" to confirm identity. Quote: "reasonable doubts" and "necessary to confirm".

Standardised icons may be used in combination with Articles 13/14 information to provide a meaningful overview; machine-readability is mandatory only when icons are presented electronically. Quote: "may be provided in combination" and "Where the icons are presented electronically they shall be machine-readable."
documentation_requirements: Maintain capability to demonstrate inability to identify the data subject when refusing to act in Article 11(2) contexts (implied by the requirement to "demonstrate"; specific record types not specified).
Maintain evidence supporting classification of a request as "manifestly unfounded or excessive" (implied by burden of proof; specific record types not specified).

Provide reasons for delay when extending deadlines and reasons for not taking action when refusing (these reasons must be communicated; internal documentation not explicitly mandated but is practically necessary).
reporting_requirements: Notify the data subject of action taken on requests under Articles 15â€“22 within required timelines.
Notify the data subject of any deadline extension within one month of receipt, including reasons for delay.
Notify the data subject when not taking action, including reasons and information about complaint to supervisory authority and judicial remedy.
timeline_requirements: Provide information on action taken on a request under Articles 15â€“22: "without undue delay" and "in any event within one month of receipt of the request."
Permitted extension: up to "two further months" where necessary based on complexity/number of requests.
Extension notice deadline: inform the data subject "within one month of receipt of the request" with reasons.
If not taking action: inform the data subject "without delay" and "at the latest within one month of receipt of the request".

general_restrictions: Communications must meet quality standards: "concise, transparent, intelligible and easily accessible" and use "clear and plain language".
Fee charging/refusal is restricted to "manifestly unfounded or excessive" requests; controller must justify this classification.
Identity verification requests are restricted to situations of "reasonable doubts" and limited to information "necessary" to confirm identity.
data_restrictions: Additional identity data may be collected/required only as necessary to confirm identity when reasonable doubts exist (data minimization implied by "necessary" limitation within this section).
operational_restrictions: Controller must organize processes to meet one-month response deadlines and manage extensions with timely notices.
Controller must provide electronic responses where possible when requests are made electronically, unless the data subject requests otherwise.
technical_restrictions: If standardized icons are presented electronically, they must be "machine-readable".

individual_rights: Right to receive information and communications in a concise, transparent, intelligible, easily accessible form using clear and plain language (as a modality supporting GDPR rights).
Right to request oral provision of information, subject to identity verification. Quote: "When requested... may be provided orally".
Right to be informed of action taken on rights requests within specified timelines.
Right to be informed of deadline extensions and reasons for delay.
Right to be informed of reasons for inaction and of the possibility of lodging a complaint with a supervisory authority and seeking a judicial remedy.
Right to receive required information/communications/actions free of charge, subject to the manifestly unfounded/excessive exception.
organizational_rights: Right (permission) for controllers to charge a reasonable fee or refuse to act when requests are manifestly unfounded or excessive, subject to burden of proof.
Right (permission) for controllers to request additional information necessary to confirm identity when there are reasonable doubts.
how_to_exercise_rights: Data subject submits requests under Articles 15â€“22; if submitted electronically, response should be electronic where possible unless otherwise requested.
Data subject may request oral provision of information; controller may require identity to be proven by other means.

conditional_exemptions: Free-of-charge principle exception: where requests are "manifestly unfounded or excessive" (especially repetitive), controller may charge a reasonable fee or refuse to act.
Facilitation/refusal limitation exception in Article 11(2) context: controller may refuse to act only if it demonstrates it cannot identify the data subject.

technical_measures: Support electronic provision of information/communications where appropriate and where possible when requests are made electronically.
If using standardized icons electronically, implement machine-readable icon presentation.
organizational_measures: Implement procedures to provide Articles 13/14 information and Articles 15â€“22/34 communications in required form and language standards.
Implement child-appropriate communication practices for information addressed specifically to a child.
Implement request intake, tracking, and response workflows to meet one-month deadline and manage permissible extensions with timely notices and reasons.
Implement a process to assess whether requests are manifestly unfounded or excessive (including repetitive) and to document justification (burden of proof).
Implement a process for handling non-action decisions, including mandatory notices about reasons and complaint/judicial remedy options.
Implement identity verification procedures, including escalation to request additional information only when reasonable doubts exist.
security_measures: Identity verification implies secure handling of identity evidence and additional information requested (specific security controls not stated in this section).
training_requirements: Staff handling data subject requests should be trained to apply timelines, extension rules, free-of-charge principle, and identity verification thresholds (training not explicitly mandated in this section; operationally implied).
audit_requirements: Ability to demonstrate (i) inability to identify data subject when refusing in Article 11(2) cases and (ii) manifestly unfounded/excessive nature of requests when charging/refusing (audit not explicitly mandated; demonstrability required).

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authority (referenced as complaint recipient); specific authority names not provided in this section.
enforcement_mechanisms: Data subject complaint to a supervisory authority (explicitly referenced).
Judicial remedy sought by the data subject (explicitly referenced).

related_articles: GDPR Articles 13 and 14 (information to be provided)
GDPR Articles 15 to 22 (data subject rights requests and communications/actions)
GDPR Article 34 (communication of a personal data breach to the data subject)
GDPR Article 11(2) (limitations where identification is not required/possible; referenced for refusal constraints)
GDPR Article 11 (general reference: "Without prejudice to Article 11" for identity doubts)
GDPR Article 92 (delegated acts procedure for Commission empowerment)

implementation_steps: Create standardized templates for Articles 13/14 notices and Articles 15â€“22/34 communications that meet: concise, transparent, intelligible, easily accessible, clear and plain language.
Implement child-friendly versions of notices where services are directed to or information is addressed specifically to children.
Set up a request management system to log receipt date, channel (electronic/non-electronic), identity verification status, and deadlines (1 month; possible +2 months).
Define criteria and internal approval for invoking extensions (complexity/number of requests) and generate extension notices with reasons within one month of receipt.
Ensure capability to respond electronically when requests are submitted electronically, unless the requester asks otherwise.

Define a decision framework for 'manifestly unfounded or excessive' requests (including repetitive requests), including calculation method for 'reasonable fee' based on administrative costs and documentation to meet burden of proof.
Define a refusal/no-action workflow that triggers mandatory notice including: reasons, complaint option to supervisory authority, and judicial remedy option, within one month.
Implement identity verification steps and escalation to request additional information only when reasonable doubts exist; limit requested information to what is necessary.
If using standardized icons, ensure electronic icons are machine-readable and align with any Commission delegated acts adopted under Article 92.
common_violations: Using complex or legalistic language that is not 'clear and plain' or failing to make information easily accessible.
Missing the one-month response deadline or failing to provide extension notice with reasons within one month.
Providing non-electronic responses to electronically submitted requests without justification or contrary to the data subjectâ€™s preference.
Charging fees by default or without demonstrating the request is manifestly unfounded or excessive.
Refusing to act in Article 11(2) contexts without demonstrating inability to identify the data subject.
Requesting excessive identity information without 'reasonable doubts' or beyond what is necessary.
Failing to inform data subjects of complaint and judicial remedy options when not taking action.
Providing electronic standardized icons that are not machine-readable.
best_practices: Use layered notices and plain-language summaries to meet conciseness and intelligibility requirements.
Maintain SLA timers and automated reminders for the one-month deadline and extension notice deadline.
Keep a documented rationale and evidence pack for any 'manifestly unfounded or excessive' determination.
Adopt a risk-based identity verification approach with minimal additional data collection.
compliance_checklist: Information/communications are concise, transparent, intelligible, easily accessible, and in clear/plain language.
Child-directed information is specifically adapted for children where applicable.
Information is available in writing and via appropriate electronic means; oral provision available upon request with identity proven.
Processes facilitate exercise of rights under Articles 15â€“22.
Responses provided without undue delay and within one month of receipt.
If extended, extension is necessary (complexity/number) and limited to +2 months; extension notice with reasons sent within one month of receipt.
Electronic requests receive electronic responses where possible unless the data subject requests otherwise.
If no action is taken, notice sent without delay and within one month, including reasons and complaint/judicial remedy options.
No fees charged unless request is manifestly unfounded/excessive; any fee is reasonable and based on administrative costs; controller can prove the request is manifestly unfounded/excessive.
Additional identity information requested only when reasonable doubts exist and limited to what is necessary.
If standardized icons are used electronically, they are machine-readable.

key_definitions.controller: Not defined in this section (GDPR-defined term).
key_definitions.data subject: Not defined in this section (GDPR-defined term).
key_definitions.manifestly unfounded or excessive: Not defined in this section; described as including, "in particular because of their repetitive character".
key_definitions.reasonable doubts concerning identity: Not defined in this section; threshold condition allowing request for additional information.
key_definitions.standardised icons: Not defined in this section; permitted as a means to provide a meaningful overview of intended processing; must be machine-readable if presented electronically.

regulations.source_section: ## Transparent information, communication and modalities for the exercise of the rights of the data subject

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 13: Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

applicable_regions: European Economic Area (as implemented by EEA states)

description.brief_summary: Requires controllers to provide specified information to data subjects when collecting personal data directly from them, at the time of collection, with additional disclosures to ensure fair and transparent processing and additional notice before further processing for a new purpose, subject to an exception where the data subject already has the information.
description.detailed_explanation: This section imposes a direct, time-bound obligation on the controller to provide a set of transparency disclosures whenever personal data are collected from the data subject. The disclosures are split into (i) core identity/contact and processing-purpose/legal-basis information, plus conditional disclosures about legitimate interests, recipients, and international transfers; and (ii) additional information necessary to ensure fair and transparent processing, including retention period/criteria, rights information, consent withdrawal (where consent is the legal basis), complaint rights, whether provision is statutory/contractual/necessary for contract and consequences of non-provision, and information about automated decision-making/profiling including logic, significance, and consequences. If the controller intends to further process the data for a different purpose, the controller must provide notice of the new purpose and relevant further information before that further processing. The obligations do not apply where and insofar as the data subject already has the information.
description.purpose: To ensure transparency and enable data subjects to understand and exercise control over how their personal data are processed, including understanding lawful bases, recipients, transfers, retention, rights, and automated decision-making impacts.
description.legislative_intent: To operationalize fair and transparent processing by mandating standardized, timely disclosures at collection and before repurposing, reducing information asymmetry between controllers and data subjects.

what_it_covers: Collection of personal data directly from the data subject
Provision of privacy information/notice at the time personal data are obtained
Disclosure of controller identity and contact details (and representative where applicable)
Disclosure of DPO contact details where applicable
Disclosure of purposes and legal basis for processing
Disclosure of legitimate interests where processing relies on GDPR Article 6(1)(f)
Disclosure of recipients/categories of recipients
Disclosure of intended international transfers and transfer mechanism/adequacy/safeguards and how to obtain a copy
Disclosure of retention period or criteria
Disclosure of data subject rights (access, rectification, erasure, restriction, objection, portability)
Disclosure of consent withdrawal right where processing relies on GDPR Article 6(1)(a) or Article 9(2)(a)
Disclosure of right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority
Disclosure of whether provision is statutory/contractual/necessary for contract; whether obliged; consequences of failure
Disclosure of automated decision-making/profiling under GDPR Article 22(1) and (4), including logic, significance, and consequences
Additional notice obligations prior to further processing for a new purpose
Exception where the data subject already has the information

entity_types: Any entity acting as a controller under GDPR

what_it_does_not_cover: Situations where personal data are not collected from the data subject (not addressed in this section)
Cases where and insofar as the data subject already has the information (explicit exception)

mandatory_obligations: Provide the required information to the data subject "at the time when personal data are obtained" when personal data relating to a data subject are collected from the data subject. (Quote: "the controller shall, at the time when personal data are obtained, provide the data subject with all of the following information")

Provide identity and contact details of the controller and, where applicable, of the controllerâ€™s representative. (Quote: "the identity and the contact details of the controller and, where applicable, of the controller's representative")
Provide contact details of the data protection officer, where applicable. (Quote: "the contact details of the data protection officer, where applicable")

Provide the purposes of the processing and the legal basis for the processing. (Quote: "the purposes of the processing for which the personal data are intended as well as the legal basis for the processing")
Provide the recipients or categories of recipients of the personal data, if any. (Quote: "the recipients or categories of recipients of the personal data, if any")

Provide additional information necessary to ensure fair and transparent processing at the time personal data are obtained. (Quote: "provide the data subject with the following further information necessary to ensure fair and transparent processing")

Provide the period for which the personal data will be stored, or if not possible, the criteria used to determine that period. (Quote: "the period for which the personal data will be stored, or if that is not possible, the criteria used to determine that period")

Inform the data subject of the existence of rights: access, rectification, erasure, restriction, objection, and data portability. (Quote: "the existence of the right to request from the controller access to and rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing ... or to object ... as well as the right to data portability")
Inform the data subject of the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority. (Quote: "the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority")

Inform whether provision of personal data is a statutory or contractual requirement, or necessary to enter into a contract; whether the data subject is obliged to provide; and the possible consequences of failure to provide. (Quote: "whether the provision of personal data is a statutory or contractual requirement, or a requirement necessary to enter into a contract, as well as whether the data subject is obliged to provide the personal data and of the possible consequences of failure to provide such data")

Inform the existence of automated decision-making, including profiling, referred to in Article 22(1) and (4) and, at least in those cases, provide meaningful information about the logic involved, as well as the significance and envisaged consequences for the data subject. (Quote: "the existence of automated decision-making, including profiling... and, at least in those cases, meaningful information about the logic involved, as well as the significance and the envisaged consequences")

Where the controller intends to further process personal data for a purpose other than that for which it was collected, provide the data subject prior to that further processing with information on the other purpose and any relevant further information as referred to in paragraph 2. (Quote: "shall provide the data subject prior to that further processing with information on that other purpose and with any relevant further information")
prohibited_actions: Do not omit required disclosures when collecting personal data from the data subject, unless the exception applies (data subject already has the information).

conditional_requirements.condition: Where applicable (controller has a representative)
conditional_requirements.requirement: Provide identity and contact details of the controllerâ€™s representative.
conditional_requirements.quote: â€œand, where applicable, of the controller's representativeâ€

conditional_requirements.condition: Where applicable (a data protection officer exists/has been designated)
conditional_requirements.requirement: Provide contact details of the data protection officer.
conditional_requirements.quote: â€œthe contact details of the data protection officer, where applicableâ€

conditional_requirements.condition: Where processing is based on point (f) of Article 6(1) (legitimate interests)
conditional_requirements.requirement: Provide the legitimate interests pursued by the controller or by a third party.
conditional_requirements.quote: â€œwhere the processing is based on point (f) of Article 6(1), the legitimate interests pursued by the controller or by a third partyâ€

conditional_requirements.condition: If there are recipients
conditional_requirements.requirement: Provide the recipients or categories of recipients of the personal data.
conditional_requirements.quote: â€œthe recipients or categories of recipients of the personal data, if anyâ€

conditional_requirements.condition: Where applicable (controller intends to transfer personal data to a third country or international organisation)
conditional_requirements.requirement: Disclose the fact of intended transfer and whether an adequacy decision exists; or for transfers under Article 46 or 47 or the second subparagraph of Article 49(1), reference appropriate/suitable safeguards and the means to obtain a copy or where made available.
conditional_requirements.quote: â€œwhere applicable, the fact that the controller intends to transfer personal data to a third country or international organisation and the existence or absence of an adequacy decision by the Commission, or in the case of transfers referred to in Article 46 or 47, or the second subparagraph of Article 49(1), reference to the appropriate or suitable safeguards and the means by which to obtain a copy of them or where they have been made available.â€

conditional_requirements.condition: If it is not possible to state the storage period
conditional_requirements.requirement: Provide the criteria used to determine the storage period.
conditional_requirements.quote: â€œor if that is not possible, the criteria used to determine that periodâ€

conditional_requirements.condition: Where processing is based on point (a) of Article 6(1) (consent) or point (a) of Article 9(2) (explicit consent for special categories)
conditional_requirements.requirement: Inform about the right to withdraw consent at any time, and that withdrawal does not affect lawfulness of processing before withdrawal.
conditional_requirements.quote: â€œthe existence of the right to withdraw consent at any time, without affecting the lawfulness of processing based on consent before its withdrawalâ€

conditional_requirements.condition: Where automated decision-making including profiling referred to in Article 22(1) and (4) exists
conditional_requirements.requirement: Provide meaningful information about the logic involved and the significance and envisaged consequences for the data subject (at least in those cases).
conditional_requirements.quote: â€œand, at least in those cases, meaningful information about the logic involved, as well as the significance and the envisaged consequences of such processing for the data subject.â€

conditional_requirements.condition: Where controller intends further processing for a new purpose
conditional_requirements.requirement: Before further processing, provide information on the other purpose and any relevant further information as referred to in paragraph 2.
conditional_requirements.quote: â€œshall provide the data subject prior to that further processing with information on that other purpose and with any relevant further information as referred to in paragraph 2.â€

documentation_requirements: Maintain/prepare the content of disclosures sufficient to provide: identity/contact details; DPO contact; purposes and legal basis; legitimate interests (if applicable); recipients/categories; transfer details and safeguards/copy access; retention period/criteria; rights information; consent withdrawal information (if applicable); complaint right; statutory/contractual requirement and consequences; automated decision-making logic/significance/consequences (if applicable).
reporting_requirements: Provide information to the data subject (a form of notice/communication) at specified times; no external authority reporting is specified in this section.

timeline_requirements.trigger: When personal data are obtained from the data subject
timeline_requirements.deadline: At the time when personal data are obtained
timeline_requirements.quote: â€œat the time when personal data are obtainedâ€

timeline_requirements.trigger: Before further processing for a new purpose
timeline_requirements.quote: â€œprior to that further processingâ€

general_restrictions: Further processing for a new purpose is restricted by a prior-notice requirement: the controller must inform the data subject of the other purpose and relevant further information before proceeding.
data_restrictions: International transfers require transparency restrictions: if transfers are intended, the controller must disclose adequacy decision status or safeguards and how to obtain a copy/where available.
operational_restrictions: Collection workflows must incorporate delivery of required disclosures at the time of collection; repurposing workflows must incorporate pre-processing notice.
technical_restrictions: Automated decision-making/profiling requires provision of meaningful information about logic, significance, and consequences (information transparency constraint on such systems).
geographic_restrictions: Transfers to third countries/international organisations trigger additional disclosure requirements regarding adequacy decisions and safeguards.

individual_rights: Right to request access to personal data
Right to rectification
Right to erasure
Right to restriction of processing
Right to object to processing
Right to data portability
Right to withdraw consent at any time (where processing is based on consent under Article 6(1)(a) or Article 9(2)(a))
Right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority
how_to_exercise_rights: The controller must inform the data subject of the existence of these rights; specific procedures for exercising them are not detailed in this section.

general_exceptions.exception: Paragraphs 1, 2 and 3 do not apply where and insofar as the data subject already has the information.
general_exceptions.quote: â€œParagraphs 1, 2 and 3 shall not apply where and insofar as the data subject already has the information.â€

conditional_exemptions: Disclosures marked "where applicable" or "if any" are not required unless the condition is met (representative; DPO; recipients; intended transfers).

technical_measures: Implement notice delivery mechanisms at data collection points (e.g., web forms, apps, call scripts) to ensure disclosures are provided at the time data are obtained.

For automated decision-making/profiling, implement capability to generate and present â€œmeaningful information about the logic involvedâ€ and the â€œsignificanceâ€ and â€œenvisaged consequencesâ€ to the data subject.
organizational_measures: Establish and maintain a privacy notice content standard covering all required disclosure elements.
Create procedures to identify the lawful basis used per purpose and ensure it is disclosed.
Create procedures to identify when Article 6(1)(f) is used and document/communicate the legitimate interests pursued.
Create procedures to identify recipients/categories and keep disclosures current.

Create procedures to identify international transfers and the applicable transfer mechanism (adequacy decision vs. safeguards under Articles 46/47/49(1) second subparagraph) and provide access to safeguard copies or locations.
Create procedures to define and disclose retention periods or criteria.
Create procedures to handle purpose changes (further processing) and ensure pre-processing notice is delivered with the new purpose and relevant paragraph 2 information.
Create a check to determine whether the data subject already has the information to rely on the exception only â€œwhere and insofar asâ€ applicable.
training_requirements: Train staff involved in data collection and customer interactions to provide required disclosures at the time of collection and to recognize when additional disclosures apply (legitimate interests, transfers, automated decision-making, consent withdrawal).
audit_requirements: Periodically review collection channels to verify required disclosures are presented at the correct time and include all required elements, including conditional elements when triggered.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authority (GDPR data protection authority) (referenced via the data subjectâ€™s right to lodge a complaint).
enforcement_mechanisms: Complaints by data subjects to a supervisory authority (explicitly referenced).

related_articles: GDPR Article 9(2)(a) (explicit consent for special categories) (referenced)

implementation_steps: At every direct collection point, present a privacy notice containing: controller identity/contact; representative (if applicable); DPO contact (if applicable); purposes and legal basis; legitimate interests (if Article 6(1)(f)); recipients/categories (if any); transfer intentions and adequacy/safeguards and how to obtain copies (if applicable).

Include additional transparency items: retention period/criteria; rights list (access, rectification, erasure, restriction, objection, portability); consent withdrawal right (if consent basis under Article 6(1)(a) or 9(2)(a)); complaint right; whether data provision is statutory/contractual/necessary for contract and consequences; automated decision-making/profiling info (if applicable) including logic, significance, consequences.
Before any further processing for a new purpose, issue an updated notice describing the new purpose and any relevant paragraph 2 information.
Implement a control to avoid duplicative notices only where and insofar as the data subject already has the information.
common_violations: Failing to provide the notice at the time of collection (e.g., after submission).
Stating purposes but omitting the legal basis.
Using legitimate interests but failing to disclose the legitimate interests pursued.
Failing to disclose recipients/categories of recipients where they exist.
Failing to disclose intended international transfers or failing to state adequacy decision status/safeguards and how to obtain a copy.
Providing a retention statement without a period or criteria.
Omitting one or more rights (e.g., portability or objection).
Using consent but failing to disclose the right to withdraw consent and the non-retroactive effect.
Failing to disclose complaint right.
Failing to explain whether data provision is required and consequences of non-provision.
Using automated decision-making/profiling but failing to provide meaningful logic information and significance/consequences.
Changing purposes (further processing) without providing prior notice of the new purpose.
best_practices: Use layered notices: concise just-in-time notice at collection with links to full details, ensuring all required elements are accessible at the time data are obtained.
Maintain a mapping of purposes to lawful bases and ensure notices are updated when processing changes.
Maintain a transfer register and a standard disclosure module describing adequacy/safeguards and how to obtain copies.
For automated decision-making, prepare standardized explanations of model logic at an appropriate level of abstraction and user-facing impact statements.
compliance_checklist: Notice delivered at the time personal data are obtained
Controller identity and contact details included
Representative identity/contact included where applicable
DPO contact details included where applicable
Purposes and legal basis included
Legitimate interests included where Article 6(1)(f) is used
Recipients/categories included if any
International transfer intention disclosed where applicable
Adequacy decision existence/absence disclosed where applicable
If relying on Articles 46/47/49(1) second subparagraph, safeguards referenced and copy access/location provided
Retention period stated or criteria provided
Rights list included (access, rectification, erasure, restriction, objection, portability)
Consent withdrawal right included where consent is the basis (Article 6(1)(a) or 9(2)(a))
Complaint right included
Statutory/contractual/contract-necessity and obligation/consequences disclosed
Automated decision-making/profiling existence disclosed where applicable
Meaningful logic info plus significance and envisaged consequences provided where Article 22(1)/(4) applies
If further processing for a new purpose occurs, prior notice of new purpose and relevant paragraph 2 info provided
Exception applied only where and insofar as the data subject already has the information

regulations.source_section: ## Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 14: Information to be provided where personal data have not been obtained from the data subject

applicable_regions: European Economic Area (via incorporation into EEA law)

description.brief_summary: Requires controllers to provide specified transparency information to data subjects when personal data are obtained indirectly, within defined time limits, with additional notice for further processing, and provides limited exceptions.
description.detailed_explanation: This provision imposes a mandatory notice regime on controllers that collect personal data from sources other than the data subject. The controller must provide a defined set of baseline information (identity, DPO contact, purposes/legal basis, categories, recipients, and transfer information) and additional information needed for fair and transparent processing (storage period/criteria, legitimate interests where applicable, rights information, consent withdrawal where applicable, complaint right, source of data, and automated decision-making/profiling details). The notice must be delivered within a reasonable period and no later than one month after obtaining the data, or earlier depending on first communication or first disclosure. If the controller intends to further process for a new purpose, it must inform the data subject prior to that further processing. The obligations do not apply in enumerated circumstances (already has information; impossible/disproportionate effort with safeguards and protective measures; obtaining/disclosure laid down by law with protective measures; or confidentiality/professional secrecy obligations).
description.purpose: To ensure transparency and fairness for individuals whose personal data are collected indirectly, enabling them to understand and exercise their rights and to be informed about processing, recipients, transfers, and decision-making.
description.legislative_intent: To operationalize the GDPR principles of transparency and fairness by mandating timely, content-specific notices for indirect collection scenarios, while allowing narrowly tailored exceptions where notice is impracticable or conflicts with legal secrecy or statutory collection/disclosure regimes.

what_it_covers: Situations where a controller has obtained personal data from a source other than the data subject
Provision of information/notice to the data subject about the processing
Timing rules for providing the notice
Additional notice obligations for further processing for a new purpose
Exceptions to the notice obligation and required protective measures in certain exception cases

entity_types: Any organization acting as a controller under GDPR
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Controllers subject to GDPR (not specified in this excerpt).

what_it_does_not_cover: Direct collection from the data subject (covered by a different GDPR provision, not detailed here)
Any requirements not explicitly listed in this section

mandatory_obligations: Provide the data subject with the information listed in Article 14(1) when personal data have not been obtained from the data subject. Quote: "Where personal data have not been obtained from the data subject, the controller shall provide the data subject with the following information:"

Provide the data subject with the additional information listed in Article 14(2) necessary to ensure fair and transparent processing. Quote: "In addition to the information referred to in paragraph 1, the controller shall provide the data subject with the following information necessary to ensure fair and transparent processing"

Provide the Article 14(1) and 14(2) information within the applicable time limit under Article 14(3) (reasonable period, no later than one month; or at first communication; or at first disclosure, depending on circumstances). Quote: "The controller shall provide the information referred to in paragraphs 1 and 2:" followed by timing points (a)-(c).

If intending to further process for a purpose other than that for which the personal data were obtained, provide the data subject prior to that further processing with information on the other purpose and any relevant further information as referred to in Article 14(2). Quote: "the controller shall provide the data subject prior to that further processing with information on that other purpose and with any relevant further information as referred to in paragraph 2."

In cases where providing information is impossible or would involve disproportionate effort (especially for archiving in the public interest, scientific/historical research, or statistical purposes), take appropriate measures to protect the data subjectâ€™s rights, freedoms, and legitimate interests, including making the information publicly available. Quote: "In such cases the controller shall take appropriate measures to protect the data subject's rights and freedoms and legitimate interests, including making the information publicly available"
prohibited_actions: Do not omit required Article 14 information unless an Article 14(5) exception applies (implicit prohibition derived from mandatory 'shall provide' language and enumerated non-application cases).

conditional_requirements.condition: Where applicable, controller has a representative
conditional_requirements.requirement: Provide identity and contact details of the controller's representative. Quote: "the identity and the contact details of the controller and, where applicable, of the controller's representative"

conditional_requirements.condition: Where applicable, a data protection officer exists/has been designated
conditional_requirements.requirement: Provide contact details of the data protection officer. Quote: "the contact details of the data protection officer, where applicable"

conditional_requirements.condition: If there are recipients or categories of recipients
conditional_requirements.requirement: Provide the recipients or categories of recipients. Quote: "the recipients or categories of recipients of the personal data, if any"

conditional_requirements.condition: Where applicable, controller intends to transfer personal data to a recipient in a third country or international organisation
conditional_requirements.requirement: Inform about the intended transfer and the existence or absence of an adequacy decision by the Commission; or for transfers under Article 46 or 47 or the second subparagraph of Article 49(1), reference appropriate/suitable safeguards and how to obtain a copy or where made available. Quote: "where applicable, that the controller intends to transfer personal data to a recipient in a third country or international organisation and the existence or absence of an adequacy decision by the Commission, or in the case of transfers referred to in Article 46 or 47, or the second subparagraph of Article 49(1), reference to the appropriate or suitable safeguards and the means to obtain a copy of them or where they have been made available."

conditional_requirements.condition: If the period for which personal data will be stored cannot be stated
conditional_requirements.requirement: Provide the criteria used to determine that period. Quote: "the period for which the personal data will be stored, or if that is not possible, the criteria used to determine that period"

conditional_requirements.condition: Where processing is based on Article 6(1)(f)
conditional_requirements.requirement: Provide the legitimate interests pursued by the controller or by a third party. Quote: "where the processing is based on point (f) of Article 6(1), the legitimate interests pursued by the controller or by a third party"

conditional_requirements.condition: Where processing is based on Article 6(1)(a) or Article 9(2)(a)
conditional_requirements.requirement: Inform about the right to withdraw consent at any time, without affecting lawfulness before withdrawal. Quote: "the existence of the right to withdraw consent at any time, without affecting the lawfulness of processing based on consent before its withdrawal"

conditional_requirements.condition: If applicable, data originated from publicly accessible sources
conditional_requirements.requirement: Inform whether it came from publicly accessible sources. Quote: "from which source the personal data originate, and if applicable, whether it came from publicly accessible sources"

conditional_requirements.condition: Where automated decision-making, including profiling, referred to in Article 22(1) and (4) exists
conditional_requirements.requirement: Provide meaningful information about the logic involved and the significance and envisaged consequences for the data subject. Quote: "meaningful information about the logic involved, as well as the significance and the envisaged consequences of such processing for the data subject"

conditional_requirements.condition: Timingâ€”general indirect collection scenario
conditional_requirements.requirement: Provide information "within a reasonable period after obtaining the personal data, but at the latest within one month" considering specific circumstances. Quote: "within a reasonable period after obtaining the personal data, but at the latest within one month, having regard to the specific circumstances"

conditional_requirements.condition: Timingâ€”personal data to be used for communication with the data subject
conditional_requirements.requirement: Provide information "at the latest at the time of the first communication". Quote: "if the personal data are to be used for communication with the data subject, at the latest at the time of the first communication"

conditional_requirements.condition: Timingâ€”disclosure to another recipient is envisaged
conditional_requirements.requirement: Provide information "at the latest when the personal data are first disclosed". Quote: "if a disclosure to another recipient is envisaged, at the latest when the personal data are first disclosed"

documentation_requirements: Maintain or be able to provide a copy of appropriate/suitable safeguards for certain international transfers, or indicate where they have been made available (implied by obligation to provide 'means to obtain a copy' or location of availability). Quote: "the means to obtain a copy of them or where they have been made available"
reporting_requirements: Provide notice/information to the data subject (a form of notification obligation) as specified in Article 14(1)-(4).

timeline_requirements.deadline: Within a reasonable period, but no later than one month
timeline_requirements.quote: "within a reasonable period after obtaining the personal data, but at the latest within one month"

timeline_requirements.trigger: If personal data will be used to communicate with the data subject
timeline_requirements.deadline: At the latest at the time of first communication
timeline_requirements.quote: "at the latest at the time of the first communication"

timeline_requirements.trigger: If disclosure to another recipient is envisaged
timeline_requirements.deadline: At the latest when the personal data are first disclosed
timeline_requirements.quote: "at the latest when the personal data are first disclosed"

timeline_requirements.trigger: Before further processing for a new purpose
timeline_requirements.quote: "prior to that further processing"

general_restrictions: Notice obligation is limited by enumerated non-application cases in Article 14(5) (i.e., controller is not required to provide information where and insofar as an exception applies). Quote: "Paragraphs 1 to 4 shall not apply where and insofar as:"
data_restrictions: Where personal data must remain confidential due to professional secrecy obligations regulated by Union or Member State law (including statutory secrecy), the notice obligations do not apply where and insofar as that confidentiality requirement applies. Quote: "where the personal data must remain confidential subject to an obligation of professional secrecy"
operational_restrictions: If providing information would render impossible or seriously impair the achievement of objectives of certain processing (archiving in public interest, scientific/historical research, statistical), the notice obligation may be limited, but protective measures must be taken. Quote: "likely to render impossible or seriously impair the achievement of the objectives of that processing"
geographic_restrictions: Transfers to third countries/international organisations trigger specific disclosure content about adequacy decisions or safeguards. Quote: "transfer personal data to a recipient in a third country or international organisation"

individual_rights: Right to request access to personal data. Quote: "the right to request from the controller access"
Right to rectification. Quote: "and rectification"
Right to erasure. Quote: "or erasure of personal data"
Right to restriction of processing. Quote: "or restriction of processing"
Right to object to processing. Quote: "and to object to processing"
Right to data portability. Quote: "as well as the right to data portability"

Right to withdraw consent at any time (where processing is based on consent under Article 6(1)(a) or Article 9(2)(a)), without affecting prior lawfulness. Quote: "the existence of the right to withdraw consent at any time, without affecting the lawfulness of processing based on consent before its withdrawal"
Right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority. Quote: "the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority"
how_to_exercise_rights: The controller must inform the data subject of the existence of the rights listed (access, rectification, erasure, restriction, objection, portability) and the complaint right; the section does not specify procedural steps beyond the obligation to provide this information.

general_exceptions.exception: Data subject already has the information
general_exceptions.scope_limit: Applies "where and insofar as" the data subject already has the information
general_exceptions.quote: "the data subject already has the information"

general_exceptions.exception: Provision of information proves impossible or would involve a disproportionate effort
general_exceptions.scope_limit: Applies "where and insofar as" provision is impossible or disproportionate; highlighted particularly for archiving in the public interest, scientific/historical research, or statistical purposes, subject to Article 89(1) conditions and safeguards; also where the obligation is likely to render impossible or seriously impair objectives of processing
general_exceptions.quote: "the provision of such information proves impossible or would involve a disproportionate effort"

general_exceptions.exception: Obtaining or disclosure is expressly laid down by Union or Member State law
general_exceptions.scope_limit: Controller must be subject to that law and the law must provide appropriate measures to protect the data subjectâ€™s legitimate interests
general_exceptions.quote: "obtaining or disclosure is expressly laid down by Union or Member State law to which the controller is subject and which provides appropriate measures to protect the data subject's legitimate interests"

general_exceptions.scope_limit: Where personal data must remain confidential subject to professional secrecy obligations regulated by Union or Member State law, including statutory secrecy
general_exceptions.quote: "where the personal data must remain confidential subject to an obligation of professional secrecy regulated by Union or Member State law, including a statutory obligation of secrecy"

conditional_exemptions.exemption_case: Impossibility/disproportionate effort (including certain public interest/research/statistical processing)
conditions: Processing for archiving purposes in the public interest, scientific or historical research purposes or statistical purposes
Subject to the conditions and safeguards referred to in Article 89(1)
Or where the obligation is likely to render impossible or seriously impair achievement of objectives
conditional_exemptions.controller_duty_if_exempt: Take appropriate measures to protect rights/freedoms/legitimate interests, including making the information publicly available
quotes: "in particular for processing for archiving purposes in the public interest, scientific or historical research purposes or statistical purposes"
"subject to the conditions and safeguards referred to in Article 89(1)"
"In such cases the controller shall take appropriate measures ... including making the information publicly available"

public_interest_exceptions: A specific exception pathway exists for archiving in the public interest and certain research/statistical processing where notice is impossible/disproportionate or would impair objectives, subject to Article 89(1) safeguards and additional protective measures (including public availability of information).

technical_measures: If relying on the impossibility/disproportionate effort exception, implement a method to make the information publicly available (e.g., publication mechanism), as explicitly listed as an example protective measure. Quote: "including making the information publicly available"
organizational_measures: Establish and operate a process to deliver Article 14 notices for indirect collection, ensuring inclusion of all required content items and meeting the applicable timing trigger (one month / first communication / first disclosure).

Establish a process to assess and document whether an Article 14(5) exception applies "where and insofar as" and, where using the disproportionate effort/impossibility exception, to implement appropriate protective measures.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authority (referenced as complaint recipient); specific enforcement bodies and sanctions are not stated in this excerpt.
enforcement_mechanisms: Data subject complaints to a supervisory authority (explicitly referenced as a right).

complementary_regulations: Union or Member State laws expressly laying down obtaining or disclosure with appropriate measures to protect legitimate interests (as referenced in the exception).

implementation_steps: Identify all indirect collection data flows (data brokers, public sources, affiliates, third-party partners, lead lists, enrichment providers).

For each flow, prepare an Article 14 notice template containing all Article 14(1) and 14(2) elements, with conditional modules (legitimate interests, consent withdrawal, transfers, automated decision-making).
Implement a timing control to ensure notice is sent: (i) within one month of obtaining the data, or (ii) at first communication, or (iii) at first disclosureâ€”whichever is triggered by the scenario.

If planning further processing for a new purpose, implement a pre-change notice step to inform the data subject of the new purpose and relevant additional Article 14(2) information before the new processing begins.

Create an exception assessment workflow for Article 14(5) and, if using the disproportionate effort/impossibility exception, implement protective measures (including public posting of the information) and ensure Article 89(1) safeguards are met where relevant.
common_violations: Failing to provide notice within one month of indirect collection.
Providing incomplete notice (e.g., omitting data categories, source, storage period/criteria, or transfer safeguards/adequacy information).
Not providing meaningful information about logic/significance/consequences for automated decision-making/profiling when applicable.
Relying on 'disproportionate effort' without implementing protective measures such as making information publicly available.
Further processing for a new purpose without providing prior notice of the new purpose.
best_practices: Use layered notices that still include all mandatory elements, with clear links to safeguards copies/locations for international transfers.
Maintain a mapping of sources and whether they are publicly accessible to accurately satisfy the source disclosure requirement.
Align retention disclosures with actual retention schedules and provide criteria where exact periods cannot be stated.
compliance_checklist: Identity and contact details of controller provided
Representative identity/contact provided where applicable
DPO contact details provided where applicable
Purposes and legal basis provided
Categories of personal data provided
Recipients/categories of recipients provided (if any)
Third-country/international transfer intention disclosed where applicable
Adequacy decision existence/absence disclosed where applicable
If relying on Article 46/47/49(1) safeguards: safeguards referenced and copy/availability method provided
Storage period or criteria provided
Legitimate interests provided where Article 6(1)(f) applies
Rights (access/rectification/erasure/restriction/objection/portability) disclosed
Consent withdrawal right disclosed where Article 6(1)(a) or 9(2)(a) applies
Complaint right disclosed
Source of data disclosed; publicly accessible source status disclosed if applicable
Automated decision-making/profiling existence disclosed; logic/significance/consequences provided where applicable
Timing met: within one month / first communication / first disclosure as applicable
Further processing for new purpose: prior notice provided
If exception relied upon: exception fits 'where and insofar as'; and if disproportionate effort/impossible: protective measures taken including public availability

key_definitions.adequacy decision: Existence or absence of an adequacy decision by the Commission must be communicated where applicable for intended transfers to a third country or international organisation (definition not provided in this excerpt).
key_definitions.appropriate or suitable safeguards: For transfers referred to in Articles 46 or 47, or the second subparagraph of Article 49(1), the controller must reference the safeguards and provide means to obtain a copy or where made available (definition not provided in this excerpt).

regulations.source_section: ## Information to be provided where personal data have not been obtained from the data subject

regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2016/679) â€” Article 15 (Right of access by the data subject)

applicable_regions: European Economic Area (as incorporated by EEA states)

description.brief_summary: Requires controllers to provide data subjects with confirmation of processing and access to their personal data, along with specified contextual information about the processing, and to provide a copy of the data undergoing processing subject to limitations protecting othersâ€™ rights and freedoms.
description.detailed_explanation: This section sets out a structured access right. Upon request, the controller must (i) confirm whether personal data concerning the data subject are being processed; and if so (ii) provide access to the personal data and a defined set of information about the processing (purposes, categories, recipients, storage period/criteria, related rights, complaint right, source where not collected from the data subject, and information about automated decision-making including profiling with meaningful logic and consequences). Where transfers to third countries or international organisations occur, the data subject must be informed of the appropriate safeguards used for the transfer (by reference to Article 46). The controller must provide a copy of the personal data undergoing processing; may charge a reasonable administrative-cost-based fee for additional copies; and must provide the information in a commonly used electronic form when the request is made electronically unless the data subject requests otherwise. The right to obtain a copy must be implemented so it does not adversely affect the rights and freedoms of others.
description.purpose: To enable individuals to understand and verify how their personal data are processed, to support the exercise of other rights (e.g., rectification, erasure, restriction, objection), and to promote transparency and accountability in personal data processing.
description.legislative_intent: To provide an actionable, standardized mechanism for individuals to obtain both their data and essential processing context, including transfer safeguards and automated decision-making transparency, while balancing this access against the rights and freedoms of other persons.

what_it_covers: Requests by a data subject for confirmation whether their personal data are processed
Access to personal data concerning the data subject
Provision of specified processing information items (purposes, categories, recipients, retention, rights, complaint, source, automated decision-making details)
Information about safeguards for transfers to third countries/international organisations
Provision of a copy of personal data undergoing processing
Format of response for electronic requests
Fees for additional copies
Limitation to protect rights and freedoms of others

entity_types: Any organization acting as a controller

what_it_does_not_cover: No explicit exclusions are stated in this section; limitation is stated regarding not adversely affecting othersâ€™ rights and freedoms.

mandatory_obligations: Provide confirmation of processing: "The data subject shall have the right to obtain from the controller confirmation as to whether or not personal data concerning him or her are being processed".
If processing occurs, provide access to the personal data: "and, where that is the case, access to the personal data".

Where transfers occur, inform about safeguards: "Where personal data are transferred to a third country or to an international organisation, the data subject shall have the right to be informed of the appropriate safeguards pursuant to Article 46 relating to the transfer."
Provide a copy: "The controller shall provide a copy of the personal data undergoing processing."

If request is electronic, provide in commonly used electronic form unless otherwise requested: "Where the data subject makes the request by electronic means, and unless otherwise requested by the data subject, the information shall be provided in a commonly used electronic form."
Ensure copy right does not adversely affect others: "The right to obtain a copy referred to in paragraph 3 shall not adversely affect the rights and freedoms of others."
prohibited_actions: Do not provide a copy in a manner that adversely affects othersâ€™ rights and freedoms: "shall not adversely affect the rights and freedoms of others."
conditional_requirements: Access and information items (a)â€“(h) are required "where that is the case" (i.e., where personal data concerning the data subject are being processed).
Retention information must be provided "where possible" as an envisaged period; "if not possible" then provide "the criteria used to determine that period".
Recipient disclosure must include recipients or categories of recipients, with emphasis "in particular" on recipients in third countries or international organisations.
Source information is required only "where the personal data are not collected from the data subject" and is limited to "any available information" as to source.

Automated decision-making details are required where such processing exists; and "at least in those cases" referred to in Article 22(1) and (4), provide meaningful information about logic, significance, and envisaged consequences.
Transfer safeguard information is required only "Where personal data are transferred to a third country or to an international organisation".
Fees are permitted only for "any further copies" beyond the initial copy and must be "reasonable" and "based on administrative costs".
Electronic form requirement applies only "Where the data subject makes the request by electronic means" and is overridden if "otherwise requested by the data subject".
documentation_requirements: No explicit internal recordkeeping/documentation duty is stated in this section; obligations are framed as information to be provided to the data subject.
reporting_requirements: Provide information to the data subject as specified in items (a)â€“(h) and paragraph 2; this is a disclosure/response obligation rather than reporting to an authority.
timeline_requirements: No response deadline is specified in this section.

general_restrictions: Limitation on copy right: "shall not adversely affect the rights and freedoms of others."
data_restrictions: Copy provision must be constrained to avoid adverse impact on othersâ€™ rights and freedoms (implies redaction/segregation may be necessary, but the section states only the limitation).
operational_restrictions: Charging fees is restricted to additional copies and must be reasonable and administrative-cost-based.
technical_restrictions: If request is made electronically, provide information "in a commonly used electronic form" unless the data subject requests otherwise.
geographic_restrictions: Special informational requirement is triggered for transfers to "a third country" or "an international organisation" (cross-border context).

individual_rights: Right to obtain confirmation whether personal data concerning the data subject are being processed.
Right to access the personal data (where processing occurs).

Right to receive specified information about processing: purposes; categories; recipients/categories (including third-country/international recipients); retention period or criteria; existence of rights to rectification/erasure/restriction/objection; right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority; source information where data not collected from the data subject; and information about automated decision-making including profiling (logic, significance, consequences at least in Article 22 cases).
Right to be informed of appropriate safeguards for third-country/international organisation transfers pursuant to Article 46.
Right to obtain a copy of personal data undergoing processing.
Right (by implication of the format rule) to request a non-electronic or different format even when the request is made electronically: "unless otherwise requested by the data subject".
organizational_rights: Controller may charge a reasonable fee based on administrative costs for further copies beyond the first: "the controller may charge a reasonable fee based on administrative costs."
how_to_exercise_rights: Submit an access request to the controller; if made "by electronic means" the response should be in a commonly used electronic form unless the data subject requests otherwise.

general_exceptions: No broad exception to the access right is stated; a limitation is stated to protect othersâ€™ rights and freedoms.
conditional_exemptions: Source disclosure is limited to "any available information" where data were not collected from the data subject.
Retention disclosure may be provided as criteria rather than a specific period if the period is "not possible" to provide.

technical_measures: Capability to deliver responses in a "commonly used electronic form" for electronically submitted requests (unless the data subject requests otherwise).
organizational_measures: Process to (1) confirm processing status, (2) compile and provide the required information items (a)â€“(h), (3) provide transfer safeguard information when applicable, and (4) produce a copy of personal data undergoing processing.
Process to assess and mitigate impact on "rights and freedoms of others" when providing copies (e.g., review/redaction workflow), as required by the limitation.
security_measures: No explicit security controls are stated in this section.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authority (as referenced: "the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority")
enforcement_mechanisms: Complaint mechanism: data subject may lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority.

related_articles: GDPR Article 22(1) and (4) (automated decision-making, including profiling) (referenced)

implementation_steps: Implement an intake workflow for access requests that determines whether personal data concerning the requester are processed and generates a confirmation response.

If processing exists, compile and provide: purposes; categories; recipients/categories (including third-country/international recipients); retention period or criteria; existence of rights (rectification/erasure/restriction/objection); complaint right; source (if not collected from the data subject); and automated decision-making/profiling information (logic, significance, consequences at least for Article 22 cases).
If transfers to third countries/international organisations occur, include information on the "appropriate safeguards pursuant to Article 46" used for the transfer.
Provide an initial copy of the personal data undergoing processing; track additional copy requests and, if charging, calculate a "reasonable fee" limited to "administrative costs".
For electronically submitted requests, default to a "commonly used electronic form" unless the data subject requests another format.
Review the copy package to ensure it "shall not adversely affect the rights and freedoms of others" (e.g., identify third-party data and apply appropriate measures).
common_violations: Failing to provide one or more required information items (a)â€“(h) when granting access.
Omitting recipient information, especially disclosures to third countries or international organisations.
Providing no retention period and no criteria when a specific period cannot be provided.
Failing to provide source information when data were not collected from the data subject (where available).
Failing to provide meaningful information about logic, significance, and consequences for automated decision-making/profiling (at least in Article 22 cases).
Failing to inform about appropriate safeguards for third-country/international transfers when such transfers occur.
Charging for the first copy or charging an unreasonable fee not based on administrative costs for additional copies.
Providing an electronic response in an uncommon/proprietary format despite an electronic request and no contrary request by the data subject.
Disclosing information in a way that adversely affects othersâ€™ rights and freedoms.
best_practices: Use standardized templates that enumerate items (a)â€“(h) to ensure completeness.
Maintain a mapping of processing purposes, categories, recipients, retention rules, transfer mechanisms/safeguards, and automated decision-making logic to support accurate responses.
Adopt a third-party rights review step to apply the limitation protecting othersâ€™ rights and freedoms.
compliance_checklist: Confirm whether personal data concerning the requester are processed.
If yes, provide access to the personal data.
Provide purposes of processing.
Provide categories of personal data concerned.
Provide recipients or categories of recipients (including third-country/international recipients where applicable).
Provide envisaged storage period or, if not possible, criteria used to determine it.
Inform about existence of rights to rectification, erasure, restriction, and objection.
Inform about right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority.
If data not collected from the data subject, provide any available source information.
If automated decision-making/profiling exists, provide meaningful logic information and significance/consequences (at least for Article 22(1)/(4) cases).
If transfers to third countries/international organisations occur, inform about appropriate safeguards pursuant to Article 46.
Provide a copy of the personal data undergoing processing.
If additional copies requested, ensure any fee is reasonable and based on administrative costs.
If request made electronically, provide information in a commonly used electronic form unless otherwise requested.
Ensure providing the copy does not adversely affect the rights and freedoms of others.

key_definitions.controller: Not defined in this section (term used as the entity from whom the data subject obtains confirmation/access and who provides copies).
key_definitions.data subject: Not defined in this section (term used as the individual whose personal data are concerned and who exercises the access right).
key_definitions.personal data: Not defined in this section (term used as the data concerning the data subject).
key_definitions.recipients: Not defined in this section; referenced as entities to whom personal data have been or will be disclosed, including recipients in third countries or international organisations.
key_definitions.automated decision-making, including pro: Not defined in this section; referenced as processing referred to in Article 22(1) and (4) requiring meaningful information about logic, significance, and envisaged consequences at least in those cases.
key_definitions.appropriate safeguards pursuant to Artic: Not defined in this section; referenced as safeguards relating to transfers to third countries or international organisations about which the data subject has a right to be informed.
key_definitions.commonly used electronic form: Not defined in this section; required response format for electronically made requests unless otherwise requested by the data subject.
key_definitions.reasonable fee based on administrative c: Not defined in this section; permitted charge for further copies requested by the data subject.

regulations.source_section: ## Right of access by the data subject

description.brief_summary: Requires controllers to rectify inaccurate personal data concerning a data subject without undue delay and to complete incomplete personal data, considering the purposes of processing, including by allowing a supplementary statement.
description.detailed_explanation: This section creates an enforceable right for the data subject against the controller. The controller must act "without undue delay" to correct (rectify) personal data that is inaccurate and relates to the requesting data subject. Additionally, where personal data is incomplete, the data subject has the right to have it completed. The completion must be assessed "taking into account the purposes of the processing," meaning completeness is evaluated relative to why the data is processed. The section explicitly recognizes that completion may be achieved "including by means of providing a supplementary statement," i.e., adding an additional statement to the record to complete context or missing elements rather than only overwriting existing data.
description.purpose: To ensure personal data held/used by controllers is accurate and appropriately complete for the purposes for which it is processed, and to provide individuals a mechanism to correct or complete their data.
description.legislative_intent: To operationalize data accuracy and fairness by giving individuals a direct right to demand correction/completion and by imposing a prompt-response obligation on controllers.

what_it_covers: Rectification (correction) of inaccurate personal data
Completion of incomplete personal data
Use of supplementary statements to complete data
Controller response timing obligation ("without undue delay")

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Controllers subject to EU/EEA data protection regime (not further specified in the provided text).

what_it_does_not_cover: Processor-specific obligations (not mentioned in the provided text)
Specific procedural steps for submitting/handling requests (not specified in the provided text)
Explicit exceptions/limitations (none stated in the provided text)

mandatory_obligations: Controller must provide the data subject the ability to obtain rectification of inaccurate personal data concerning him or her. Quote: "The data subject shall have the right to obtain from the controller ... the rectification of inaccurate personal data concerning him or her."
Controller must rectify inaccurate personal data "without undue delay" once rectification is to be provided. Quote: "without undue delay".

Controller must enable completion of incomplete personal data, taking into account the purposes of processing. Quote: "Taking into account the purposes of the processing, the data subject shall have the right to have incomplete personal data completed".

Controller must allow completion "including by means of providing a supplementary statement" (i.e., completion can be achieved by adding a supplementary statement). Quote: "including by means of providing a supplementary statement."
prohibited_actions: Imposing undue delay in rectifying inaccurate personal data (implied prohibition from the obligation to act "without undue delay").
conditional_requirements: Completion obligation is conditioned by the purposes of processing; completeness must be assessed relative to processing purposes. Quote: "Taking into account the purposes of the processing".
timeline_requirements: Rectification must occur "without undue delay." Quote: "without undue delay".

general_restrictions: Timeliness constraint on the controller: rectification must not be delayed beyond what is undue. Quote: "without undue delay".
