data_restrictions: Rectification right is limited to "inaccurate personal data" and completion right to "incomplete personal data" concerning the data subject. Quotes: "inaccurate personal data"; "incomplete personal data"; "concerning him or her".

individual_rights: Right to obtain from the controller the rectification of inaccurate personal data concerning the data subject. Quote: "The data subject shall have the right to obtain from the controller ... the rectification of inaccurate personal data concerning him or her."
Right to have incomplete personal data completed, taking into account the purposes of processing. Quote: "the data subject shall have the right to have incomplete personal data completed".
Right to complete data by providing a supplementary statement. Quote: "including by means of providing a supplementary statement."
how_to_exercise_rights: By obtaining rectification/completion "from the controller" (no further procedure specified in the provided text). Quote: "obtain from the controller".

organizational_measures: Implement an operational capability to correct inaccurate personal data and to complete incomplete personal data upon data subject request, including the ability to append supplementary statements (specific measures not detailed in the provided text).

implementation_steps: Provide a channel for data subjects to request correction/completion of their personal data (procedure not specified in the provided text).
Establish internal workflows to assess whether data is inaccurate or incomplete and to execute rectification/completion promptly to meet the "without undue delay" requirement.
Support completion via adding a supplementary statement where appropriate, rather than only overwriting existing records.
common_violations: Delaying rectification beyond what is justified (violating "without undue delay").
Refusing to complete incomplete data when completion is necessary in light of the purposes of processing.
Failing to allow a supplementary statement as a means to complete data.
best_practices: Define internal service-level targets to operationalize "without undue delay" (exact timeframe not provided in the text).
Maintain mechanisms to append supplementary statements to records to preserve context while completing data.
compliance_checklist: Can the controller correct inaccurate personal data concerning a data subject upon request?
Is rectification performed without undue delay?
Can the controller complete incomplete personal data in a manner aligned with the purposes of processing?
Is there a capability to complete data by adding a supplementary statement?

key_definitions.data subject: The individual to whom the personal data relates (term used but not defined in the provided text).
key_definitions.controller: The entity from whom the data subject obtains rectification/completion (term used but not defined in the provided text).
key_definitions.rectification: Correction of inaccurate personal data (concept stated but not defined in the provided text).
key_definitions.without undue delay: A requirement to act promptly without unjustified delay (phrase used but not quantified in the provided text).
key_definitions.supplementary statement: An additional statement provided to complete incomplete personal data (term used but not further defined in the provided text).

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 17 Right to erasure (â€˜right to be forgottenâ€™)

applicable_regions: EEA (via incorporation into EEA law, where applicable)

description.brief_summary: Establishes a data subjectâ€™s right to obtain erasure of personal data without undue delay and imposes corresponding controller obligations, including downstream notification steps when data has been made public, subject to enumerated necessity-based exceptions.
description.detailed_explanation: The provision creates (1) an individual right: the data subject may obtain from the controller the erasure of personal data concerning them "without undue delay"; and (2) a controller duty: the controller must erase personal data "without undue delay" when at least one listed ground applies. The grounds include necessity no longer existing, consent withdrawal with no alternative legal basis, successful objection under Article 21, unlawful processing, compliance with a legal obligation to erase under Union/Member State law, and collection in relation to information society services to a child (Article 8(1) reference). Where the controller has made the data public and must erase under paragraph 1, the controller must take "reasonable steps" (including technical measures), considering available technology and implementation cost, to inform other controllers processing the data that the data subject requested erasure of links/copies/replications. The right and obligations in paragraphs 1 and 2 are limited: they do not apply "to the extent that processing is necessary" for specified purposes (freedom of expression/information; legal obligation/public interest task/official authority; public health public interest; archiving/research/statistics under Article 89(1) where erasure would make objectives impossible/seriously impaired; and legal claims).
description.purpose: To give individuals control over their personal data by enabling deletion when continued processing is unjustified, while balancing competing rights and public interests through necessity-based exceptions.
description.legislative_intent: To operationalize a strong, actionable erasure right (including in online/public contexts) and to ensure controllers act promptly, while preserving processing needed for fundamental rights (expression), legal/public functions, public health, research/archiving/statistics, and legal claims.

what_it_covers: Handling of data subject requests for erasure
Controller decision-making on whether erasure grounds apply
Execution of erasure of personal data
Additional steps when personal data has been made public (downstream notification to other controllers)
Assessment and application of exceptions where processing remains necessary

entity_types: Any entity acting as a controller under GDPR
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Controllers subject to GDPR (not further specified in this excerpt).

what_it_does_not_cover: Situations where processing remains necessary under the listed exceptions (applies only "to the extent" of necessity).

mandatory_obligations: Controller must erase personal data "without undue delay" when one of the listed grounds applies. Quote: "the controller shall have the obligation to erase personal data without undue delay where one of the following grounds applies".

Controller must provide erasure to the data subject "without undue delay" when grounds apply. Quote: "The data subject shall have the right to obtain from the controller the erasure of personal data concerning him or her without undue delay".

If the controller has made the personal data public and is obliged to erase under paragraph 1, the controller must take reasonable steps (including technical measures) to inform other controllers processing the data about the erasure request regarding links/copies/replications. Quote: "shall take reasonable steps, including technical measures, to inform controllers which are processing the personal data that the data subject has requested the erasure by such controllers of any links to, or copy or replication of, those personal data."
prohibited_actions: Implied prohibition: continuing to process/retain personal data when an erasure ground applies and no exception applies (because the controller is obliged to erase).
conditional_requirements: Erasure obligation applies when at least one ground is met:
Ground (a): erase when "the personal data are no longer necessary in relation to the purposes for which they were collected or otherwise processed".
Ground (b): erase when "the data subject withdraws consent" and processing is based on Article 6(1)(a) or Article 9(2)(a) "and where there is no other legal ground for the processing".
Ground (c): erase when the data subject objects under Article 21(1) and "there are no overriding legitimate grounds for the processing", or objects under Article 21(2).
Ground (d): erase when "the personal data have been unlawfully processed".
Ground (e): erase when "the personal data have to be erased for compliance with a legal obligation in Union or Member State law to which the controller is subject".
Ground (f): erase when "the personal data have been collected in relation to the offer of information society services referred to in Article 8(1)".

Public-data downstream notification duty applies only if BOTH conditions are met: (i) controller "has made the personal data public" AND (ii) controller "is obliged pursuant to paragraph 1 to erase the personal data".
When taking steps to inform other controllers, the controller must consider proportionality factors. Quote: "taking account of available technology and the cost of implementation".

Exceptions: paragraphs 1 and 2 do not apply only "to the extent that processing is necessary" for the listed purposes (meaning partial application is required where only some processing is necessary).
reporting_requirements: Notification-type requirement (not to a regulator, but to other controllers): where applicable, the controller must inform other controllers processing the data about the erasure request for links/copies/replications.
timeline_requirements: "without undue delay" for both granting the right (responding by erasing) and fulfilling the controllerâ€™s erasure obligation.

general_restrictions: Erasure right and corresponding obligations are limited where processing is necessary for enumerated purposes; the limitation is scoped "to the extent" of necessity.
data_restrictions: When an erasure ground applies and no exception applies, personal data concerning the data subject must be erased (i.e., not retained).
Where data was made public, the controller must address not only its own copies but also facilitate removal of "any links to, or copy or replication" by informing other controllers.
operational_restrictions: Controllers must implement processes to evaluate grounds and exceptions and to execute erasure promptly.
Controllers that made data public must operationalize outreach/notification to other controllers, constrained by technology and cost considerations.
technical_restrictions: Reasonable steps "including technical measures" are required to inform other controllers when data has been made public and must be erased.

individual_rights: Right to obtain from the controller the erasure of personal data concerning the data subject "without undue delay" when grounds apply.
how_to_exercise_rights: Data subject makes a request to the controller for erasure; the controller must assess whether one of the grounds applies and whether any exception applies, then erase without undue delay where required. (The excerpt explicitly references that the data subject "has requested the erasure" in the public-data scenario.)

general_exceptions: Paragraphs 1 and 2 do not apply "to the extent that processing is necessary" for the listed purposes.
conditional_exemptions: Freedom of expression and information. Quote: "for exercising the right of freedom of expression and information".

Legal obligation / public interest task / official authority. Quote: "for compliance with a legal obligation which requires processing by Union or Member State law to which the controller is subject or for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority vested in the controller".
Public health public interest. Quote: "for reasons of public interest in the area of public health in accordance with points (h) and (i) of Article 9(2) as well as Article 9(3)".

Archiving/research/statistics under Article 89(1) where erasure would undermine objectives. Quote: "for archiving purposes in the public interest, scientific or historical research purposes or statistical purposes in accordance with Article 89(1) in so far as the right referred to in paragraph 1 is likely to render impossible or seriously impair the achievement of the objectives of that processing".
Legal claims. Quote: "for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims".
legitimate_interest_exceptions: In the objection scenario under Article 21(1), erasure is not required if there are "overriding legitimate grounds for the processing" (i.e., the ground for erasure in 1(c) is not met).
public_interest_exceptions: Performance of a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority vested in the controller.
Public interest in the area of public health (per referenced Article 9(2)(h) and (i) and Article 9(3)).
Archiving purposes in the public interest; scientific or historical research; statistical purposes (Article 89(1) conditions).

technical_measures: Where applicable, implement "technical measures" as part of "reasonable steps" to inform other controllers processing the personal data about the erasure request relating to "any links to, or copy or replication".
organizational_measures: Establish procedures to (i) receive and action erasure requests, (ii) assess whether any of the grounds (a)-(f) apply, (iii) assess whether any exception applies "to the extent" processing is necessary, and (iv) execute erasure without undue delay.
Where the controller made data public, establish a process to identify and contact/inform other controllers processing the data, calibrated to available technology and cost of implementation.

related_articles: Article 6(1)(a) (consent as legal basis) â€” referenced in ground (b)
Article 9(2)(a) (explicit consent for special categories) â€” referenced in ground (b)
Article 21(1) and Article 21(2) (right to object) â€” referenced in ground (c)
Article 8(1) (conditions applicable to child's consent in relation to information society services) â€” referenced in ground (f)
Article 9(2)(h) and Article 9(2)(i) and Article 9(3) (public health-related conditions) â€” referenced in exception (c)
Article 89(1) (safeguards and derogations for archiving/research/statistics) â€” referenced in exception (d)
complementary_regulations: Union or Member State law imposing a legal obligation to erase (referenced in ground (e))
Union or Member State law requiring processing (referenced in exception (b))

implementation_steps: Implement an erasure request intake channel and identity verification process (not specified in excerpt, but necessary to operationalize the right; details not provided here).

Create decision logic mapping each ground (a)-(f) to internal triggers (e.g., purpose no longer necessary; consent withdrawal; objection handling; unlawful processing determination; legal obligation to erase; child information society services context).
Define and enforce a workflow to erase personal data "without undue delay" once a ground applies and no exception applies.

If personal data was made public, implement a process to take "reasonable steps" (including technical measures) to notify other controllers processing the data about the erasure request for links/copies/replications, considering available technology and cost.
Implement an exception assessment step to determine whether processing remains necessary for any of the listed purposes and limit non-erasure accordingly (apply only "to the extent" necessary).
common_violations: Failing to erase personal data without undue delay after a valid ground is met.
Rejecting erasure requests without assessing whether an exception applies only "to the extent" processing is necessary (overbroad refusal).
Failing to take reasonable steps to inform other controllers after making data public and being obliged to erase.
Continuing processing based on consent after consent withdrawal where no other legal ground exists.
best_practices: Maintain a mapping of processing activities to purposes to support the "no longer necessary" assessment.
Maintain records of legal bases to quickly determine whether an alternative legal ground exists after consent withdrawal (the excerpt requires "no other legal ground").
Use scalable technical measures (e.g., standardized notices, APIs/automated notifications where feasible) to satisfy the "reasonable steps" requirement, calibrated to technology and cost.
compliance_checklist: Can the controller erase personal data concerning a data subject without undue delay when any ground (a)-(f) applies?
Does the controller assess whether there is "no other legal ground" when consent is withdrawn?
Does the controller handle objections under Article 21(1) by assessing "overriding legitimate grounds" and under Article 21(2) accordingly?
Does the controller have a process to identify and remediate unlawful processing via erasure where required?
Does the controller identify legal obligations in Union/Member State law requiring erasure and execute erasure accordingly?

If the controller made data public, does it take reasonable steps (including technical measures) to inform other controllers about erasure requests for links/copies/replications, considering technology and cost?

Does the controller apply exceptions only "to the extent" processing is necessary for the listed purposes (expression, legal obligation/public task, public health, archiving/research/statistics, legal claims)?

key_definitions.without undue delay: Not defined in the excerpt; used as the required timeliness standard for erasure and related obligations.
key_definitions.controller: Not defined in the excerpt; referenced as the entity obligated to erase and to inform other controllers.
key_definitions.made public: Not defined in the excerpt; triggers the additional duty to take reasonable steps to inform other controllers.
key_definitions.reasonable steps: Not defined in the excerpt; must be determined by considering "available technology" and "the cost of implementation" and includes technical measures.
key_definitions.overriding legitimate grounds: Not defined in the excerpt; referenced as the condition that can defeat erasure following an objection under Article 21(1).
key_definitions.to the extent that processing is necessa: Limits the non-applicability of paragraphs 1 and 2 to only the necessary processing for the listed exception purposes.

regulations.source_section: ## Right to erasure (â€˜right to be forgottenâ€™)

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 18 (Right to restriction of processing)

applicable_regions: European Economic Area (via incorporation into EEA law)

description.brief_summary: Requires controllers to restrict processing upon request when specified conditions apply, limits what processing may occur during restriction, and obliges controllers to notify the data subject before lifting the restriction.
description.detailed_explanation: This provision creates an enforceable right for a data subject to require a controller to place a limitation on processing of the data subjectâ€™s personal data in defined circumstances. When restriction applies, the default permitted operation is storage; any further processing is prohibited unless it falls within a closed list of exceptions (consent, legal claims, protection of othersâ€™ rights, or important public interest of the Union or a Member State). Additionally, once restriction has been granted, the controller must provide advance notice to the data subject before removing (lifting) the restriction.
description.purpose: To provide a safeguard short of erasure that protects individuals while disputes (e.g., accuracy, lawfulness, objection balancing) are resolved or while data is needed for legal claims.
description.legislative_intent: To ensure individuals can temporarily halt active use of their personal data without necessarily deleting it, and to constrain controllers from continuing substantive processing while key issues are pending.

what_it_covers: Requests by data subjects to restrict processing
Controller decision-making on restriction triggers
Permissible processing activities during restriction
Notification to data subjects before lifting restriction

entity_types: Any entity acting as a controller under GDPR
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Controllers subject to GDPR territorial scope (not specified in this section).

what_it_does_not_cover: Specific procedural steps for submitting requests (not specified here)
Specific time limits for responding to restriction requests (not specified here)
Processor-specific duties (not specified here)

mandatory_obligations: Controller must grant restriction of processing when at least one of the listed conditions applies. Quote: "The data subject shall have the right to obtain from the controller restriction of processing where one of the following applies:"

During restriction, controller must limit processing to storage except where an enumerated exception applies. Quote: "Where processing has been restricted under paragraph 1, such personal data shall, with the exception of storage, only be processed..."

Controller must inform the data subject before lifting the restriction. Quote: "A data subject who has obtained restriction of processing pursuant to paragraph 1 shall be informed by the controller before the restriction of processing is lifted."
prohibited_actions: Controller must not process restricted personal data beyond storage unless one of the specified exceptions applies. Quote: "...with the exception of storage, only be processed with the data subject's consent or..."

conditional_requirements.condition: Accuracy contested by the data subject
conditional_requirements.requirement: Restriction must be available "for a period enabling the controller to verify the accuracy of the personal data."
conditional_requirements.quote: (a) "the accuracy of the personal data is contested by the data subject, for a period enabling the controller to verify the accuracy of the personal data;"

conditional_requirements.condition: Processing is unlawful AND the data subject opposes erasure and requests restriction instead
conditional_requirements.requirement: Restriction must be granted as an alternative to erasure when the data subject chooses restriction.
conditional_requirements.quote: (b) "the processing is unlawful and the data subject opposes the erasure of the personal data and requests the restriction of their use instead;"

conditional_requirements.condition: Controller no longer needs the personal data for processing purposes BUT the data subject requires it for legal claims
conditional_requirements.requirement: Restriction must be granted to preserve data for "the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims."
conditional_requirements.quote: (c) "the controller no longer needs the personal data for the purposes of the processing, but they are required by the data subject for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims;"

conditional_requirements.condition: Data subject has objected under Article 21(1) and balancing is pending
conditional_requirements.requirement: Restriction must apply "pending the verification whether the legitimate grounds of the controller override those of the data subject."
conditional_requirements.quote: (d) "the data subject has objected to processing pursuant to Article 21(1) pending the verification whether the legitimate grounds of the controller override those of the data subject."

conditional_requirements.condition: Processing is restricted under paragraph 1
conditional_requirements.requirement: Any processing beyond storage is permitted only under the listed bases: consent; legal claims; protection of rights of another person; important public interest of the Union or a Member State.
conditional_requirements.quote: Paragraph 2: "...only be processed with the data subject's consent or for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims or for the protection of the rights of another natural or legal person or for reasons of important public interest of the Union or of a Member State."

conditional_requirements.condition: Controller intends to lift restriction previously obtained by the data subject
conditional_requirements.requirement: Controller must inform the data subject before lifting.
conditional_requirements.quote: Paragraph 3: "...shall be informed by the controller before the restriction of processing is lifted."

reporting_requirements: Notification to the data subject before lifting restriction (individual notice obligation).

timeline_requirements.time_requirement: Restriction applies "for a period enabling the controller to verify the accuracy" (duration tied to verification period; no fixed number of days stated).
timeline_requirements.quote: (a) "for a period enabling the controller to verify the accuracy of the personal data"

timeline_requirements.time_requirement: Restriction applies while verification of overriding legitimate grounds is pending.
timeline_requirements.quote: (d) "pending the verification whether the legitimate grounds of the controller override those of the data subject"

timeline_requirements.time_requirement: Notice must be provided before lifting (advance notice; no minimum lead time stated).
timeline_requirements.quote: Paragraph 3: "shall be informed... before the restriction... is lifted"

general_restrictions: When restriction is in place, processing is limited; storage is the default permitted operation.
data_restrictions: Restricted personal data may not be processed (beyond storage) unless one of the enumerated exceptions applies.
operational_restrictions: Controller operations using the restricted data (e.g., use, disclosure, analysis) must cease unless justified by consent, legal claims, protection of othersâ€™ rights, or important public interest.
geographic_restrictions: Important public interest exception may be based on "the Union or of a Member State" (ties permissible processing to EU/Member State public interest reasons).

individual_rights.right: Right to obtain restriction of processing from the controller
conditions: Accuracy contested (during verification period)
Unlawful processing where the data subject opposes erasure and requests restriction instead
Controller no longer needs data but data subject needs it for legal claims
Objection under Article 21(1) pending balancing verification
quotes: Paragraph 1: "The data subject shall have the right to obtain from the controller restriction of processing where one of the following applies:"

individual_rights.right: Right to be informed before restriction is lifted
quotes: Paragraph 3: "...shall be informed by the controller before the restriction of processing is lifted."

how_to_exercise_rights: Data subject contests accuracy, opposes erasure and requests restriction, asserts need for legal claims, or objects under Article 21(1) (submission mechanics not specified in this section).

conditional_exemptions.exception: Processing beyond storage is allowed with the data subjectâ€™s consent.
conditional_exemptions.quote: Paragraph 2: "...only be processed with the data subject's consent..."

conditional_exemptions.exception: Processing beyond storage is allowed for "the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims".
conditional_exemptions.quote: Paragraph 2: "...or for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims..."

conditional_exemptions.exception: Processing beyond storage is allowed "for the protection of the rights of another natural or legal person".
conditional_exemptions.quote: Paragraph 2: "...or for the protection of the rights of another natural or legal person..."

conditional_exemptions.exception: Processing beyond storage is allowed "for reasons of important public interest of the Union or of a Member State".
conditional_exemptions.quote: Paragraph 2: "...or for reasons of important public interest of the Union or of a Member State."

legitimate_interest_exceptions: Restriction may be triggered pending verification of controllerâ€™s "legitimate grounds" overriding the data subjectâ€™s grounds following an Article 21(1) objection (the balancing concept is referenced; the detailed test is not set out here).
public_interest_exceptions: Processing beyond storage during restriction is permitted for "important public interest of the Union or of a Member State."

organizational_measures: Implement a process to receive and assess restriction requests against the four listed triggers.
Implement controls to ensure restricted data is not processed beyond storage unless an exception applies.
Implement a notification step to inform the data subject before lifting restriction.

related_articles: GDPR Article 21(1) (referenced as the basis for objection triggering restriction under paragraph 1(d))

implementation_steps: Create an intake channel for restriction requests and a decision workflow mapping to conditions (a)â€“(d).
When restriction is applied, flag the data in systems to enforce 'storage-only' by default.
Define and document approval paths for the four permitted processing exceptions during restriction (consent, legal claims, protection of othersâ€™ rights, important public interest).
Before removing a restriction flag, send notice to the data subject and record that notice was sent.
common_violations: Continuing to use restricted data for routine business purposes (e.g., marketing/analytics) without fitting an exception.
Lifting restriction without informing the data subject beforehand.
Failing to apply restriction while accuracy verification or Article 21(1) balancing is pending.
best_practices: Maintain a 'restriction status' attribute per record and enforce it across downstream systems.
Log the legal basis used for any processing beyond storage during restriction.
compliance_checklist: Can the organization identify and apply restriction triggers (a)â€“(d)?
Is restricted data technically/operationally limited to storage by default?
Are exceptions during restriction limited to the four listed bases and documented per event?
Is the data subject notified before restriction is lifted?

key_definitions.restriction of processing: A limitation placed by the controller such that, except for storage, the personal data is only processed under the enumerated exceptions in paragraph 2.
key_definitions.storage: Retention/keeping of personal data, explicitly permitted even when processing is restricted (as the default exception).
key_definitions.legal claims: Claims for which personal data may be processed during restriction for the "establishment, exercise or defence" of those claims.

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 19 (Notification obligation regarding rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing)

applicable_regions: European Economic Area (as incorporated into EEA law)

description.brief_summary: Requires controllers to notify recipients of personal data about rectification, erasure, or restriction actions taken, subject to an impossibility or disproportionate effort exception, and to provide the data subject with information about those recipients upon request.
description.detailed_explanation: This provision creates two linked obligations for the controller when it has disclosed personal data to recipients and subsequently performs a rectification, erasure, or restriction of processing under specified GDPR rights provisions. First, the controller must communicate the fact of the rectification/erasure/restriction to each recipient to whom the personal data were disclosed. Second, the controller must inform the data subject about the recipients (i.e., identify the recipients) if the data subject requests that information. The duty to communicate to recipients is not absolute: it does not apply where communicating to each recipient is impossible or would involve disproportionate effort. The section ties the triggering actions to those carried out in accordance with GDPR Article 16 (rectification), Article 17(1) (erasure), and Article 18 (restriction of processing).
description.purpose: To ensure downstream recipients who received disclosed personal data are made aware of changes (rectification), deletion (erasure), or limitations (restriction) so they can align their processing and records accordingly, thereby making the data subject rights effective beyond the original controller.
description.legislative_intent: To operationalize data subject rights by extending their practical effect to third parties who received the data, while balancing feasibility through an exception where notification is impossible or disproportionately burdensome.

what_it_covers: Controller communications to recipients following rectification of personal data
Controller communications to recipients following erasure of personal data
Controller communications to recipients following restriction of processing
Providing the data subject with information about recipients upon request
Situations where personal data have been disclosed to recipients

entity_types: Any organization acting as a controller under GDPR
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Controllers subject to GDPR territorial scope (not specified in this section).

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing activities where no disclosure to recipients has occurred (no recipients to notify)
Actions other than rectification, erasure under Article 17(1), or restriction under Article 18 (not specified as triggers in this section)

mandatory_obligations: The controller must communicate any rectification of personal data carried out in accordance with Article 16 to each recipient to whom the personal data have been disclosed, unless an exception applies. Quote: "The controller shall communicate any rectification ... carried out in accordance with Article 16 ... to each recipient to whom the personal data have been disclosed".

The controller must communicate any erasure of personal data carried out in accordance with Article 17(1) to each recipient to whom the personal data have been disclosed, unless an exception applies. Quote: "The controller shall communicate any ... erasure of personal data ... carried out in accordance with ... Article 17(1) ... to each recipient to whom the personal data have been disclosed".

The controller must communicate any restriction of processing carried out in accordance with Article 18 to each recipient to whom the personal data have been disclosed, unless an exception applies. Quote: "The controller shall communicate any ... restriction of processing ... carried out in accordance with ... Article 18 to each recipient to whom the personal data have been disclosed".

If the data subject requests it, the controller must inform the data subject about the recipients to whom the personal data have been disclosed (in the context of the above communications). Quote: "The controller shall inform the data subject about those recipients if the data subject requests it."
prohibited_actions: Failing to communicate rectification/erasure/restriction to each recipient when it is neither impossible nor disproportionately effortful (implied by the mandatory 'shall' obligation).
conditional_requirements: The obligation to communicate to each recipient applies unless communicating "proves impossible". Quote: "unless this proves impossible".
The obligation to communicate to each recipient does not apply where it "involves disproportionate effort". Quote: "or involves disproportionate effort".
The obligation to inform the data subject about recipients is triggered only if the data subject requests it. Quote: "if the data subject requests it".
reporting_requirements: Recipient notification requirement: communicate rectification/erasure/restriction to each recipient (a form of notification/communication obligation).
Data subject information requirement: provide information about recipients to the data subject upon request.
timeline_requirements: No explicit deadline or timeframe is stated in this section for communicating to recipients or informing the data subject.

general_restrictions: The controllerâ€™s duty to notify recipients is limited by feasibility: it is not required where notification is impossible or would involve disproportionate effort.
data_restrictions: Where restriction of processing is carried out under Article 18, the controller must communicate that restriction to recipients (so recipients can apply corresponding limitations).
operational_restrictions: Controllers must maintain the operational capability to identify recipients to whom data were disclosed and to communicate updates to them, except where impossible or disproportionate.

individual_rights: Right to be informed about recipients of disclosed personal data (in the context of rectification/erasure/restriction communications) upon request. Quote: "The controller shall inform the data subject about those recipients if the data subject requests it."
how_to_exercise_rights: The data subject exercises the right by requesting information about the recipients; upon such request, the controller must provide the information. Quote: "if the data subject requests it".

general_exceptions: Recipient communication is not required where it "proves impossible". Quote: "unless this proves impossible".
Recipient communication is not required where it "involves disproportionate effort". Quote: "or involves disproportionate effort".
conditional_exemptions: The controller is exempt from communicating to each recipient only to the extent the controller can substantiate impossibility or disproportionate effort (the section states the conditions but does not specify evidentiary standards).

technical_measures: Ability to track disclosures to recipients and link them to specific data subjects/records to enable targeted communications (implied by the obligation to notify "each recipient" and to inform the data subject about "those recipients").
organizational_measures: Procedures to execute and log recipient communications following rectification/erasure/restriction actions under Articles 16, 17(1), and 18.
Process to respond to data subject requests for information about recipients.

implementation_steps: Identify whether the controller has disclosed the affected personal data to any recipients.
When rectification/erasure/restriction is carried out under Articles 16, 17(1), or 18, prepare a communication to each identified recipient describing the rectification/erasure/restriction.

Send the communication to each recipient unless doing so is impossible or would involve disproportionate effort; if relying on an exception, determine and record the basis internally (recordkeeping not mandated in this section).
Maintain an accessible list of recipients for each disclosure so that, if the data subject requests it, the controller can inform the data subject about those recipients.
common_violations: Not notifying all recipients after rectification/erasure/restriction when notification is feasible.
Inability to identify recipients due to inadequate disclosure tracking, leading to failure to inform the data subject upon request.
Overbroad reliance on 'disproportionate effort' without a concrete assessment (assessment criteria not specified in this section).
best_practices: Maintain a disclosure register mapping data subjects/records to recipients to enable prompt and complete communications.
Standardize templates and workflows for recipient notifications for rectification, erasure, and restriction events.
Define internal criteria for assessing 'impossible' and 'disproportionate effort' and apply consistently.
compliance_checklist: Process exists to detect when rectification/erasure/restriction has been carried out under Articles 16, 17(1), or 18.
Recipients of disclosed personal data can be identified for the affected data.
Mechanism exists to communicate the rectification/erasure/restriction to each recipient.
Procedure exists to handle and respond to data subject requests for information about recipients.
Exception handling exists for cases where notification is impossible or disproportionate.

regulations.source_section: ## Notification obligation regarding rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing

regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2016/679) â€” Article 20 (Right to data portability)

applicable_regions: European Economic Area (as incorporated into EEA law)

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data within GDPR scope

description.brief_summary: Establishes a data subjectâ€™s right to receive personal data they provided to a controller in a structured, commonly used, machine-readable format and to transmit it to another controller without hindrance, subject to specific legal and technical conditions and limitations.
description.detailed_explanation: The provision grants data subjects a portability right over personal data concerning them that they have provided to a controller. The controller must enable the data subject to receive such data in a "structured, commonly used and machine-readable format" and to transmit those data to another controller "without hindrance" from the original controller, but only where the processing is based on consent (Article 6(1)(a) or Article 9(2)(a)) or contract (Article 6(1)(b)) and where the processing is carried out by automated means. Additionally, when exercising this right, the data subject has the right to have the personal data transmitted directly from one controller to another where technically feasible. The right is limited: it is without prejudice to Article 17, does not apply to processing necessary for tasks carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority vested in the controller, and must not adversely affect the rights and freedoms of others.
description.purpose: To enhance individual control over personal data and facilitate switching between services by enabling reuse and transfer of personal data across controllers.
description.legislative_intent: To reduce lock-in and promote user autonomy and competition by requiring interoperable, usable data export/transfer mechanisms while balancing other rights and public-interest processing needs.

what_it_covers: Providing the data subject with personal data concerning them that they have provided to a controller
Providing such data in a structured, commonly used, machine-readable format
Enabling transmission of those data to another controller without hindrance
Direct controller-to-controller transmission where technically feasible
Limitations relating to Article 17, public interest/official authority tasks, and third-party rights and freedoms

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities acting as controllers within GDPR territorial scope

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing that is not based on consent (Article 6(1)(a) or Article 9(2)(a)) or contract (Article 6(1)(b))
Processing that is not carried out by automated means
Processing necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority vested in the controller

mandatory_obligations: Provide the data subject the right to receive the personal data concerning them, which they have provided to a controller, "in a structured, commonly used and machine-readable format" (Quote: "The data subject shall have the right to receive the personal data concerning him or her, which he or she has provided to a controller, in a structured, commonly used and machine-readable format").

Enable the data subject to transmit those data to another controller "without hindrance" from the controller to which the personal data have been provided, where the applicability conditions are met (Quote: "and have the right to transmit those data to another controller without hindrance from the controller to which the personal data have been provided").

Where technically feasible, enable the data subject to have the personal data transmitted directly from one controller to another when exercising the right (Quote: "the data subject shall have the right to have the personal data transmitted directly from one controller to another, where technically feasible").

Ensure the exercise of the right does not adversely affect the rights and freedoms of others (Quote: "The right referred to in paragraph 1 shall not adversely affect the rights and freedoms of others").
prohibited_actions: Do not place "hindrance" in the way of the data subject transmitting the data to another controller when the conditions for portability are met (derived from Quote: "without hindrance").

Do not apply the portability right to processing necessary for public interest tasks or official authority (Quote: "That right shall not apply to processing necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority vested in the controller").
Do not allow the exercise of portability to adversely affect othersâ€™ rights and freedoms (Quote: "shall not adversely affect the rights and freedoms of others").
conditional_requirements: Portability applies only where: (a) processing is based on consent pursuant to Article 6(1)(a) or Article 9(2)(a), or on a contract pursuant to Article 6(1)(b); and (b) processing is carried out by automated means (Quote: "where: (a) the processing is based on consent... or on a contract...; and (b) the processing is carried out by automated means").
Direct controller-to-controller transmission is required only "where technically feasible" (Quote: "where technically feasible").
Exercise of the right is "without prejudice to Article 17" (Quote: "shall be without prejudice to Article 17").

general_restrictions: The portability right is limited by and must be exercised "without prejudice to Article 17" (Quote: "shall be without prejudice to Article 17").

The portability right "shall not apply" to certain public interest/official authority processing (Quote: "shall not apply to processing necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority vested in the controller").
The portability right must not adversely affect othersâ€™ rights and freedoms (Quote: "shall not adversely affect the rights and freedoms of others").
data_restrictions: Applies to "personal data concerning" the data subject "which he or she has provided to a controller" (Quote: "personal data concerning him or her, which he or she has provided to a controller").
operational_restrictions: Controller must not hinder transmission to another controller when conditions are met (Quote: "without hindrance").
technical_restrictions: Data must be provided in a "structured, commonly used and machine-readable format" (Quote: "structured, commonly used and machine-readable format").
Direct transmission obligation is limited to what is "technically feasible" (Quote: "where technically feasible").
Right applies only where processing is "carried out by automated means" (Quote: "carried out by automated means").

individual_rights: Right to receive personal data concerning the data subject, which the data subject has provided to a controller, in a structured, commonly used and machine-readable format (Quote: "shall have the right to receive...").

Right to transmit those data to another controller without hindrance from the original controller, where conditions are met (Quote: "have the right to transmit those data to another controller without hindrance...").
Right to have the personal data transmitted directly from one controller to another, where technically feasible (Quote: "shall have the right to have the personal data transmitted directly...").
how_to_exercise_rights: Exercise is framed as the data subject receiving data in the specified format and transmitting it to another controller; additionally, the data subject may request direct controller-to-controller transmission where technically feasible (Quotes: "receive... in a structured, commonly used and machine-readable format"; "transmit those data to another controller"; "transmitted directly from one controller to another, where technically feasible").

general_exceptions: The right does not apply unless the processing is based on consent (Article 6(1)(a) or Article 9(2)(a)) or contract (Article 6(1)(b)) and is carried out by automated means (Quote: "where: (a)...; and (b)...").
conditional_exemptions: Direct transmission between controllers is only required "where technically feasible" (Quote: "where technically feasible").
public_interest_exceptions: The right "shall not apply" to processing necessary for a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority vested in the controller (Quote: "shall not apply to processing necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority vested in the controller").

technical_measures: Implement export/provision capability that outputs the relevant personal data in a "structured, commonly used and machine-readable format" (Quote: "structured, commonly used and machine-readable format").
Implement capability to transmit data to another controller without hindrance when conditions are met (Quote: "transmit those data to another controller without hindrance").
Where technically feasible, implement secure direct controller-to-controller transmission mechanism (Quote: "transmitted directly from one controller to another, where technically feasible").
Ensure technical design prevents adverse impact on othersâ€™ rights and freedoms when fulfilling portability requests (Quote: "shall not adversely affect the rights and freedoms of others").
organizational_measures: Establish procedures to assess whether a portability request meets the legal basis condition (consent/contract) and automated processing condition (Quotes: "processing is based on consent... or on a contract"; "processing is carried out by automated means").
Establish procedures to assess and document technical feasibility for direct controller-to-controller transmission (Quote: "where technically feasible").
Establish procedures to evaluate and mitigate potential adverse effects on the rights and freedoms of others when responding (Quote: "shall not adversely affect the rights and freedoms of others").

Establish procedures to identify and exclude requests relating to processing necessary for public interest/official authority tasks (Quote: "shall not apply to processing necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority vested in the controller").

related_articles: GDPR Article 9(2)(a) (explicit consent for special categories) (referenced condition)

implementation_steps: Identify datasets that qualify as "personal data concerning" the data subject and "which he or she has provided" to the controller.
Implement an export function producing a "structured, commonly used and machine-readable format".
Implement a process to verify the request meets both conditions: (1) consent/contract legal basis and (2) automated processing.
Provide a transmission pathway enabling the data subject to transmit the exported data to another controller "without hindrance".
Offer direct controller-to-controller transfer when requested and when "technically feasible".
Screen requests to ensure the portability right is not applied to processing necessary for public interest/official authority tasks.
Assess whether fulfilling the request could adversely affect othersâ€™ rights and freedoms and apply safeguards accordingly.
common_violations: Refusing portability even though processing is based on consent/contract and carried out by automated means.
Providing data in a non-machine-readable or uncommon/unstructured format contrary to the required "structured, commonly used and machine-readable format".
Imposing obstacles or friction that constitutes "hindrance" to transmission to another controller.
Failing to provide direct controller-to-controller transmission when it is technically feasible.
Providing portable data in a way that adversely affects the rights and freedoms of others.
best_practices: Standardize export formats that are structured and machine-readable and are commonly used in the relevant context.
Maintain a technical feasibility assessment method for direct transfers and revisit feasibility as systems evolve.
Implement checks to prevent inclusion of third-party data where it would adversely affect othersâ€™ rights and freedoms.
compliance_checklist: Portability request intake process exists and is operational.
Eligibility checks: consent (Art. 6(1)(a) / 9(2)(a)) or contract (Art. 6(1)(b)) confirmed.
Eligibility checks: processing is carried out by automated means.
Export output is structured, commonly used, and machine-readable.
Transmission to another controller can occur without hindrance.
Direct controller-to-controller transfer available where technically feasible.
Public interest/official authority processing is excluded from portability.
Safeguards in place to avoid adverse effects on othersâ€™ rights and freedoms.

key_definitions.personal data concerning him or her, whi: The subset of personal data about the data subject that the data subject has provided to the controller (as stated in the section).
key_definitions.structured, commonly used and machine-re: A format requirement for the portable data output; the data must be structured, commonly used, and machine-readable (as stated in the section).
key_definitions.without hindrance: A prohibition on obstacles imposed by the original controller that would impede transmission to another controller (as stated in the section).
key_definitions.carried out by automated means: A condition limiting the right to processing performed through automated processing (as stated in the section).
key_definitions.where technically feasible: A limitation on the right to direct controller-to-controller transmission; it applies only when technically feasible (as stated in the section).
key_definitions.without prejudice to Article 17: A limitation clarifying that exercising portability does not affect the application of the right to erasure under Article 17 (as stated in the section).

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 21 (Right to object)

applicable_regions: European Economic Area (as incorporated into EEA law)

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data (including public and private sector)

description.brief_summary: Establishes the data subjectâ€™s right to object to processing based on public task/official authority or legitimate interests (including related profiling), an unconditional right to object to direct marketing (including related profiling), controller duties to stop processing upon objection unless strict conditions apply, and an obligation to inform data subjects of this right clearly and separately by the first communication; also allows automated objection mechanisms for information society services and provides a qualified objection right for research/statistics processing subject to a public-interest necessity exception.
description.detailed_explanation: The section provides actionable rules governing when and how a data subject may object to processing and what the controller must do in response. For processing based on Article 6(1)(e) (task in the public interest/exercise of official authority) or Article 6(1)(f) (legitimate interests), the data subject may object at any time on grounds relating to their particular situation, including where the processing involves profiling based on those legal bases. Upon such objection, the controller must stop processing unless it can demonstrate either (i) compelling legitimate grounds overriding the data subjectâ€™s interests, rights and freedoms, or (ii) that processing is needed for the establishment, exercise, or defence of legal claims. Separately, where processing is for direct marketing, the data subject has a right to object at any time, including to profiling insofar as it relates to direct marketing; once the objection is made, the controller must cease processing for direct marketing purposes (no balancing test is stated in this section for direct marketing). The controller must also ensure the right to object (for both the general objection right and the direct marketing objection right) is explicitly brought to the data subjectâ€™s attention no later than the time of the first communication, and that it is presented clearly and separately from other information. For information society services, the data subject may exercise the right to object by automated means using technical specifications, notwithstanding Directive 2002/58/EC. Finally, for processing for scientific or historical research or statistical purposes under Article 89(1), the data subject has a right to object on grounds relating to their particular situation unless the processing is necessary for performing a task carried out for reasons of public interest.
description.purpose: To give individuals control over certain types of processingâ€”especially processing based on public task/official authority or legitimate interests, and direct marketingâ€”by enabling them to object and requiring controllers to stop processing unless specific overriding conditions apply.
description.legislative_intent: To strengthen data subject autonomy and fairness in processing by (i) enabling objections tied to the individualâ€™s circumstances for certain legal bases, (ii) providing an effective and unconditional opt-out from direct marketing, (iii) ensuring transparency by requiring prominent notice of the right, and (iv) balancing research/statistics processing with public interest needs.

what_it_covers: Objections to processing based on Article 6(1)(e) or Article 6(1)(f)
Objections to profiling when profiling is based on Article 6(1)(e) or (f)
Objections to processing for direct marketing purposes
Objections to profiling related to direct marketing
Controller obligations to cease processing following objections (with specified exceptions for certain bases)
Transparency obligation to explicitly inform data subjects of the right to object by first communication
Mechanisms for exercising objection rights via automated means for information society services
Objections to processing for scientific/historical research or statistical purposes under Article 89(1), subject to a public-interest necessity exception

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities subject to GDPR territorial scope (not specified in this section).

what_it_does_not_cover: Objections to processing based on legal bases other than Article 6(1)(e) or 6(1)(f) (not addressed here)
Detailed procedures for verifying identity or responding timeframes (not specified here)
Specific penalty amounts or enforcement procedures (not specified here)

mandatory_obligations: Controller must stop processing after an objection under paragraph 1 unless it demonstrates an applicable overriding justification. Quote: "The controller shall no longer process the personal data unless the controller demonstrates compelling legitimate grounds for the processing which override the interests, rights and freedoms of the data subject or for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims."

Controller must stop processing for direct marketing after an objection. Quote: "Where the data subject objects to processing for direct marketing purposes, the personal data shall no longer be processed for such purposes."

Controller must explicitly bring the right to object (paragraphs 1 and 2) to the data subjectâ€™s attention no later than the first communication. Quote: "At the latest at the time of the first communication with the data subject, the right referred to in paragraphs 1 and 2 shall be explicitly brought to the attention of the data subject".
Controller must present the right to object clearly and separately from any other information. Quote: "and shall be presented clearly and separately from any other information."
prohibited_actions: Controller must not continue processing after a paragraph 1 objection unless it can demonstrate compelling legitimate grounds overriding the data subjectâ€™s interests/rights/freedoms or necessity for legal claims (continuation without meeting these conditions is prohibited by the 'shall no longer process' rule).
Controller must not process personal data for direct marketing purposes after the data subject objects (absolute cessation requirement stated).
conditional_requirements: Paragraph 1 objection right applies only where processing is "based on point (e) or (f) of Article 6(1), including profiling based on those provisions."

Controller may continue processing after a paragraph 1 objection only if it demonstrates either: (i) "compelling legitimate grounds" overriding the data subjectâ€™s interests, rights and freedoms; or (ii) processing is necessary "for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims."
Direct marketing objection right applies where "personal data are processed for direct marketing purposes" and includes profiling "to the extent that it is related to such direct marketing."
Automated exercise of the right to object applies "In the context of the use of information society services" and is allowed "by automated means using technical specifications."

Research/statistics objection right applies where personal data are processed for "scientific or historical research purposes or statistical purposes pursuant to Article 89(1)"; the right is qualified by an exception where "the processing is necessary for the performance of a task carried out for reasons of public interest."
documentation_requirements: Demonstration requirement implies the controller must be able to evidence/justify "compelling legitimate grounds" or legal-claims necessity when continuing processing after an objection (specific record types not specified in this section).
reporting_requirements: Requirement to explicitly bring the right to object to the data subjectâ€™s attention by first communication functions as a mandatory notice/communication obligation (no external reporting to authorities specified).
timeline_requirements: Objection may be exercised "at any time" (paragraphs 1 and 2).
Notice of the right to object must be provided "At the latest at the time of the first communication with the data subject" (paragraph 4).
Upon objection, cessation is immediate in principle ("shall no longer process"), with no specific grace period stated.

general_restrictions: Processing based on Article 6(1)(e) or (f) is restricted upon objection unless the controller meets the stated override conditions.
Direct marketing processing is restricted upon objection with a mandatory stop.
data_restrictions: After a valid objection, the controller must cease processing of the personal data for the objected purpose(s), subject to the paragraph 1 override conditions or the research/public-interest necessity exception.
operational_restrictions: Controllers must implement operational processes to receive and act on objections at any time, including stopping relevant processing activities and ensuring marketing suppression.
Controllers must ensure first-contact communications include a clear, separate notice of the right to object.
technical_restrictions: For information society services, the right to object may be exercised "by automated means using technical specifications" (requires technical capability to accept automated objections where offered/implemented; exact specifications not provided).

individual_rights: Right to object, on grounds relating to the data subjectâ€™s particular situation, at any time to processing based on Article 6(1)(e) or (f), including profiling based on those provisions. Quote: "shall have the right to object, on grounds relating to his or her particular situation, at any time".

Right to object at any time to processing for direct marketing purposes, including related profiling. Quote: "shall have the right to object at any time" and "which includes profiling to the extent that it is related to such direct marketing."
Right to have processing stopped following an objection (subject to paragraph 1 override conditions; absolute for direct marketing).
Right to be explicitly informed of the right to object by the first communication, presented clearly and separately.
Right to exercise the right to object by automated means using technical specifications in the context of information society services.

Right to object to processing for scientific/historical research or statistical purposes under Article 89(1) on grounds relating to the data subjectâ€™s particular situation, unless a public-interest necessity applies.
organizational_rights: Controller right to continue processing after a paragraph 1 objection only if it can demonstrate overriding compelling legitimate grounds or necessity for legal claims.
how_to_exercise_rights: Data subject may object "at any time" (paragraphs 1 and 2).
In information society services contexts, the data subject may exercise the right "by automated means using technical specifications" (paragraph 5).
For paragraph 1 and paragraph 6 objections, the objection must be "on grounds relating to his or her particular situation".

general_exceptions: Controller may refuse to stop processing after a paragraph 1 objection if it demonstrates overriding compelling legitimate grounds or necessity for legal claims.
conditional_exemptions: Research/statistics objection does not apply where processing is necessary for a task carried out for reasons of public interest. Quote: "unless the processing is necessary for the performance of a task carried out for reasons of public interest."
legitimate_interest_exceptions: Continuation after objection permitted where controller demonstrates "compelling legitimate grounds" overriding the data subjectâ€™s interests, rights and freedoms (paragraph 1).
public_interest_exceptions: For Article 89(1) research/statistics processing, objection right is limited where processing is necessary for performance of a task carried out for reasons of public interest (paragraph 6).

technical_measures: Enable (where applicable in information society services) automated objection mechanisms "using technical specifications" (specifications not detailed in this section).
Implement systems to suppress/stop direct marketing processing upon objection, including suppression of related profiling for direct marketing.
organizational_measures: Establish procedures to receive, assess, and action objections at any time, including evaluating whether paragraph 1 override conditions apply.
Ensure first communication templates/processes include an explicit, clear, separate notice of the right to object (for paragraphs 1 and 2).
Implement decision-making governance to document and approve any decision to continue processing after a paragraph 1 objection based on compelling legitimate grounds or legal claims.

related_articles: Article 6(1)(e) (processing necessary for performance of a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority)
Article 89(1) (processing for archiving in the public interest, scientific or historical research purposes or statistical purposes, subject to safeguards)
complementary_regulations: Directive 2002/58/EC (ePrivacy Directive) â€” referenced as 'notwithstanding Directive 2002/58/EC' in relation to automated objection in information society services

implementation_steps: Identify processing activities relying on Article 6(1)(e) and 6(1)(f), including any profiling based on those bases, and ensure an objection-handling workflow exists.
Implement a mechanism to immediately cease direct marketing processing upon objection, including disabling marketing-related profiling for the objecting data subject.

Create a standard assessment template to determine whether 'compelling legitimate grounds' override the data subjectâ€™s interests/rights/freedoms or whether processing is necessary for legal claims when an objection is received under paragraph 1.

Update first-contact communications (e.g., first email, first letter, first in-app message) to explicitly highlight the right to object (paragraphs 1 and 2) clearly and separately from other information.

For information society services, provide an automated objection option using technical specifications (e.g., account settings toggle or standardized automated request channel), consistent with the sectionâ€™s allowance.

For research/statistics processing under Article 89(1), implement a process to evaluate objections based on the data subjectâ€™s particular situation and determine whether a public-interest necessity justifies continuing processing.
common_violations: Continuing legitimate-interests/public-task processing after an objection without being able to demonstrate overriding compelling legitimate grounds or legal-claims necessity.
Failing to stop direct marketing processing after an objection (including continuing marketing-related profiling).
Burying the right to object within general privacy information rather than presenting it 'clearly and separately' by the first communication.
Not providing a workable method to submit objections 'at any time' (e.g., only allowing objections through narrow channels).
best_practices: Maintain a suppression list for marketing objections and ensure it is honored across all marketing systems and vendors.
Use layered notices where the right to object is prominently displayed and separated from other disclosures at first contact.
Document the balancing/override rationale when relying on 'compelling legitimate grounds' to continue processing after an objection.
compliance_checklist: Is processing based on Article 6(1)(e) or (f) flagged so objections trigger the correct workflow?
Can data subjects object at any time, and are channels accessible?
Upon a paragraph 1 objection, does the controller stop processing unless it can demonstrate overriding compelling legitimate grounds or legal-claims necessity?
For direct marketing, does an objection result in cessation of marketing processing (including related profiling)?
Is the right to object explicitly brought to the data subjectâ€™s attention no later than the first communication, clearly and separately from other information?
For information society services, is an automated objection method available using technical specifications (where implemented)?
For Article 89(1) research/statistics processing, is there a process to handle objections and assess the public-interest necessity exception?

key_definitions.on grounds relating to his or her partic: A condition stated in this section for objections under paragraphs 1 and 6; the objection must be tied to the individualâ€™s specific circumstances (no further definition provided in this section).
key_definitions.direct marketing purposes: Processing for marketing directly to the individual; the section states this includes profiling to the extent related to such direct marketing (no further definition provided in this section).
key_definitions.profiling: Referenced as included within objection rights when based on Article 6(1)(e)/(f) and when related to direct marketing; no definition provided in this section.
key_definitions.compelling legitimate grounds: A controller justification that must override the interests, rights and freedoms of the data subject to continue processing after a paragraph 1 objection; no further definition provided in this section.
key_definitions.information society services: Context in which automated objection may be exercised; no definition provided in this section.
key_definitions.technical specifications: Means by which automated objections may be exercised; no specific standards or formats provided in this section.

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 22: Automated individual decision-making, including profiling

applicable_regions: European Economic Area (via incorporation into EEA law)

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data (public and private)

description.brief_summary: Establishes a right for individuals not to be subject to decisions based solely on automated processing (including profiling) that have legal or similarly significant effects, subject to limited exceptions and mandatory safeguards.
description.detailed_explanation: The section provides a general prohibition/right framework: individuals (data subjects) have a right not to be subject to decisions that (i) are based solely on automated processing, including profiling, and (ii) produce legal effects concerning them or similarly significantly affect them. It then enumerates three circumstances where this right/prohibition does not apply: where the decision is necessary for entering into or performing a contract with the data subject; where the decision is authorized by Union or Member State law applicable to the controller and that law also provides suitable safeguards; or where the decision is based on the data subjectâ€™s explicit consent. Where the controller relies on the contract-necessity or explicit-consent bases, the controller must implement suitable safeguards, at minimum ensuring the data subject can obtain human intervention, express their point of view, and contest the decision. Finally, it restricts the use of special categories of personal data as inputs/bases for such decisions unless specific Article 9(2) conditions apply (point (a) or (g)) and suitable safeguards are in place.
description.purpose: To protect individuals from potentially harmful, opaque, or unfair outcomes produced by solely automated decisions, ensuring meaningful human involvement and avenues for challenge where such decisions are permitted.
description.legislative_intent: To limit solely automated decision-making with significant effects to narrowly defined lawful bases and to require safeguards that preserve human oversight and contestability, particularly where sensitive data may be involved.

what_it_covers: Decisions about a data subject
Decisions based solely on automated processing
Automated processing that includes profiling
Decisions producing legal effects concerning the data subject
Decisions that similarly significantly affect the data subject
Use of special categories of personal data in such decisions (subject to conditions)

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Controllers subject to Union or Member State law (and, by GDPR territorial scope, controllers/processors in scope of GDPR).

what_it_does_not_cover: Decisions that are not based solely on automated processing (i.e., where there is non-token, meaningful human involvement)
Automated processing that does not produce legal effects or similarly significant effects (not specified further in this excerpt)
Cases falling within the listed exceptions (contract necessity; legal authorization with safeguards; explicit consent), subject to conditions

mandatory_obligations: Recognize and respect the data subjectâ€™s right not to be subject to a decision based solely on automated processing, including profiling, that produces legal effects or similarly significantly affects them. Quote: "The data subject shall have the right not to be subject to a decision based solely on automated processing, including profiling, which produces legal effects concerning him or her or similarly significantly affects him or her."

When relying on the contract necessity exception (paragraph 2(a)) or explicit consent exception (paragraph 2(c)), the controller must implement suitable measures to safeguard the data subjectâ€™s rights, freedoms, and legitimate interests. Quote: "the data controller shall implement suitable measures to safeguard the data subject's rights and freedoms and legitimate interests".

At minimum, in the paragraph 2(a) and 2(c) cases, safeguards must include: (i) the right to obtain human intervention on the part of the controller; (ii) the right to express his or her point of view; and (iii) the right to contest the decision. Quote: "at least the right to obtain human intervention on the part of the controller, to express his or her point of view and to contest the decision."

Ensure that decisions within paragraph 2 are not based on special categories of personal data (Article 9(1)) unless the specified Article 9(2) conditions apply and safeguards are in place. Quote: "Decisions referred to in paragraph 2 shall not be based on special categories of personal data referred to in Article 9(1), unless point (a) or (g) of Article 9(2) applies and suitable measures ... are in place."
prohibited_actions: Subjecting a data subject to a decision that is (i) based solely on automated processing (including profiling) and (ii) produces legal effects or similarly significantly affects them, unless an exception applies. (Derived from the stated right and the exception structure.)

Basing paragraph 2 decisions on special categories of personal data (Article 9(1)) unless Article 9(2)(a) or 9(2)(g) applies and suitable safeguards are in place. Quote: "shall not be based on special categories of personal data ... unless ... applies".
conditional_requirements: Exceptionâ€”Contract necessity: The paragraph 1 right does not apply if the decision "is necessary for entering into, or performance of, a contract between the data subject and a data controller" (paragraph 2(a)); however, if relying on this exception, the controller must implement suitable safeguards including human intervention, ability to express a view, and contestation (paragraph 3).

Exceptionâ€”Legal authorization: The paragraph 1 right does not apply if the decision "is authorised by Union or Member State law to which the controller is subject" AND that law "also lays down suitable measures to safeguard the data subject's rights and freedoms and legitimate interests" (paragraph 2(b)).

Exceptionâ€”Explicit consent: The paragraph 1 right does not apply if the decision "is based on the data subject's explicit consent" (paragraph 2(c)); however, if relying on this exception, the controller must implement suitable safeguards including human intervention, ability to express a view, and contestation (paragraph 3).
Special category data condition: For paragraph 2 decisions, special category data may only be used if Article 9(2)(a) or 9(2)(g) applies AND suitable safeguards are in place (paragraph 4).

general_restrictions: Solely automated decisions with legal or similarly significant effects are restricted by default due to the data subjectâ€™s right not to be subject to them, unless an exception applies.
data_restrictions: Restriction on using special categories of personal data (Article 9(1)) as a basis for paragraph 2 automated decisions unless Article 9(2)(a) or 9(2)(g) applies and safeguards are in place.
operational_restrictions: Where relying on contract necessity or explicit consent for solely automated decisions, operations must include a mechanism for human intervention, a channel for the data subject to express their view, and a process to contest the decision.
technical_restrictions: Automated decision systems must be designed/operated so that human intervention can be obtained and decisions can be contested (implied by the mandatory safeguards; no specific technical method is prescribed in the excerpt).
