geographic_restrictions: The legal-authorization exception depends on Union or Member State law applicable to the controller.

individual_rights: Right not to be subject to a decision based solely on automated processing, including profiling, that produces legal effects or similarly significantly affects the individual. Quote: "shall have the right not to be subject to a decision based solely on automated processing".
In contract-necessity and explicit-consent cases: right to obtain human intervention on the part of the controller. Quote: "the right to obtain human intervention on the part of the controller".
In contract-necessity and explicit-consent cases: right to express his or her point of view. Quote: "to express his or her point of view".
In contract-necessity and explicit-consent cases: right to contest the decision. Quote: "to contest the decision".
how_to_exercise_rights: Request human intervention from the controller for a solely automated decision made under the contract-necessity or explicit-consent exceptions (process details not specified in the excerpt).
Provide/submit the data subjectâ€™s point of view to the controller regarding the decision (mechanism not specified in the excerpt).
Contest/challenge the decision with the controller (procedure not specified in the excerpt).

general_exceptions: Contract necessity exception. Quote: "necessary for entering into, or performance of, a contract".
Legal authorization exception. Quote: "authorised by Union or Member State law ... and which also lays down suitable measures".
Explicit consent exception. Quote: "based on the data subject's explicit consent".
conditional_exemptions: Legal authorization exception is conditional on the authorizing law also laying down suitable safeguards for rights, freedoms, and legitimate interests.
public_interest_exceptions: Implicitly, Article 9(2)(g) referenced for special category data (substantial public interest) may enable use of special category data in paragraph 2 decisions, provided safeguards are in place (the excerpt references the point but does not define it).

technical_measures: Implement functionality/processes enabling human intervention in solely automated decisions made under paragraph 2(a) or 2(c) (no specific technical standard prescribed).
Implement mechanisms enabling the data subject to express their point of view and to contest the decision for paragraph 2(a) or 2(c) decisions (no specific technical standard prescribed).
organizational_measures: Adopt procedures to identify when a decision is "based solely on automated processing" and whether it produces "legal effects" or "similarly significantly affects" the data subject, to determine applicability of the right and exceptions (criteria not further defined in the excerpt).

Where relying on paragraph 2(a) or 2(c), establish and maintain a process for handling requests for human intervention, receiving the data subjectâ€™s viewpoint, and handling contests/challenges to decisions.

related_articles: GDPR Article 9(1) (special categories of personal data) (referenced)
complementary_regulations: Union or Member State law authorizing automated decisions under Article 22(2)(b) must also lay down suitable safeguards (specific laws not identified in the excerpt).

implementation_steps: Inventory decision processes to identify decisions that are solely automated and have legal or similarly significant effects.
For any such decision, determine whether one of the three exceptions applies: contract necessity, legal authorization with safeguards, or explicit consent.

If relying on contract necessity or explicit consent, implement safeguards ensuring: (1) human intervention is available; (2) the data subject can express their view; (3) the data subject can contest the decision.

Assess whether special category data (Article 9(1)) is used in the automated decision; if yes, ensure Article 9(2)(a) or 9(2)(g) applies and that suitable safeguards are in place; otherwise, do not base the decision on such data.
common_violations: Running solely automated decisions with significant effects without fitting within one of the listed exceptions.
Relying on contract necessity or explicit consent but failing to provide meaningful human intervention or a contestation process.
Using special category data in solely automated decisions without meeting Article 9(2)(a) or 9(2)(g) conditions and safeguards.
best_practices: Design decision workflows so that human review can be triggered upon request and is capable of changing the outcome (the excerpt requires human intervention but does not define its quality).
Provide clear channels for individuals to submit their viewpoint and to contest outcomes, and ensure internal procedures exist to evaluate and respond.
compliance_checklist: Is the decision based solely on automated processing (including profiling)?
Does the decision produce legal effects or similarly significantly affect the data subject?
If yes, which exception is relied upon: contract necessity, legal authorization with safeguards, or explicit consent?
If relying on contract necessity or explicit consent: are safeguards implemented, including human intervention, ability to express a view, and ability to contest?
Is special category data used as a basis for the decision? If yes, does Article 9(2)(a) or 9(2)(g) apply and are suitable safeguards in place?

key_definitions.Decision based solely on automated proce: A decision made without human involvement, based only on automated processing (the excerpt states the concept but does not define it further).
key_definitions.Profiling: Included within automated processing for purposes of this right; not defined in the excerpt.
key_definitions.Legal effects: A threshold for impact triggering the right; not defined in the excerpt.
key_definitions.Similarly significantly affects: A threshold for impact triggering the right; not defined in the excerpt.
key_definitions.Special categories of personal data: Those referred to in GDPR Article 9(1) (not enumerated in the excerpt).
key_definitions.Explicit consent: A condition allowing an exception; not defined in the excerpt.
key_definitions.Suitable measures to safeguard rights an: Measures that must be implemented by the controller in specified cases; minimum measures are listed (human intervention, express view, contest decision).

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 23 (Restrictions)

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data under GDPR
Law enforcement-adjacent processing (as a safeguarding objective, not a separate regime)

description.brief_summary: Allows Union or Member State law to restrict certain GDPR obligations and rights through legislative measures, subject to strict necessity/proportionality and fundamental-rights safeguards, and requires such measures to include specified minimum content where relevant.
description.detailed_explanation: The provision authorizes restrictions on the scope of specified GDPR obligations and rights when the controller or processor is subject to Union or Member State law that enacts a legislative measure imposing such restrictions. The restriction is only permissible if it (i) respects the essence of fundamental rights and freedoms and (ii) is a necessary and proportionate measure in a democratic society, and (iii) is aimed at safeguarding one or more enumerated objectives (national security, defence, public security, criminal law enforcement objectives, other important public interests including economic/financial interests, public health and social security, judicial independence/proceedings, ethics breaches for regulated professions, certain monitoring/inspection/regulatory functions, protection of othersâ€™ rights, and enforcement of civil law claims). Additionally, any such legislative measure must contain specific provisions at least, where relevant, addressing a minimum set of elements: processing purposes/categories, personal data categories, scope of restrictions, safeguards against abuse/unlawful access/transfer, controller specification, storage periods and safeguards, risks to data subjectsâ€™ rights/freedoms, and the right to be informed about the restriction unless informing would prejudice the restrictionâ€™s purpose.
description.purpose: To permit narrowly tailored legal restrictions on GDPR rights/obligations for specified public-interest and justice/security objectives while ensuring fundamental-rights protection and minimum legislative safeguards.
description.legislative_intent: To balance data protection rights with essential state and public interests by requiring that any restriction be legally grounded, necessary and proportionate, and accompanied by defined safeguards and transparency rules (subject to prejudice exceptions).

what_it_covers: Legislative measures under Union or Member State law that restrict GDPR obligations and rights
Restrictions affecting obligations and rights in GDPR Articles 12 to 22 and Article 34
Restrictions affecting GDPR Article 5 only insofar as its provisions correspond to rights/obligations in Articles 12 to 22
Mandatory content elements that must be included in such legislative measures (where relevant)

target_entities: Legislators/competent public authorities enacting legislative measures (as the mechanism for restriction)
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Controllers/processors subject to Union or Member State law.

what_it_does_not_cover: Non-legislative restrictions (e.g., internal policies) as a basis to restrict GDPR rights/obligations (not described as permissible here)
Restrictions that do not respect the essence of fundamental rights and freedoms
Restrictions that are not necessary and proportionate in a democratic society
Restrictions not aimed at safeguarding one of the listed objectives

mandatory_obligations: Any restriction must be imposed "by way of a legislative measure" under Union or Member State law. (Quote: "may restrict by way of a legislative measure")
Any restriction must "respect[] the essence of the fundamental rights and freedoms". (Quote: "when such a restriction respects the essence of the fundamental rights and freedoms")
Any restriction must be "a necessary and proportionate measure in a democratic society". (Quote: "and is a necessary and proportionate measure in a democratic society")

Any legislative measure referred to must contain "specific provisions at least, where relevant" addressing the listed items (a)â€“(h). (Quote: "shall contain specific provisions at least, where relevant, as to")
Where relevant, the legislative measure must specify: "the purposes of the processing or categories of processing".
Where relevant, the legislative measure must specify: "the categories of personal data".
Where relevant, the legislative measure must specify: "the scope of the restrictions introduced".
Where relevant, the legislative measure must specify: "the safeguards to prevent abuse or unlawful access or transfer".
Where relevant, the legislative measure must specify: "the specification of the controller or categories of controllers".

Where relevant, the legislative measure must specify: "the storage periods and the applicable safeguards taking into account the nature, scope and purposes of the processing or categories of processing".
Where relevant, the legislative measure must specify: "the risks to the rights and freedoms of data subjects".
Where relevant, the legislative measure must specify: "the right of data subjects to be informed about the restriction, unless that may be prejudicial to the purpose of the restriction".
prohibited_actions: Imposing restrictions on the covered GDPR obligations/rights without a legislative measure (implicit prohibition by conditioning permissibility on a legislative measure).
Imposing restrictions that do not respect the essence of fundamental rights and freedoms (implicit).
Imposing restrictions that are not necessary and proportionate in a democratic society (implicit).
Imposing restrictions for purposes outside the enumerated safeguarding objectives (implicit).
conditional_requirements: Union or Member State law may restrict the scope of obligations/rights in Articles 12â€“22 and Article 34, and Article 5 only insofar as it corresponds to Articles 12â€“22, only "when" the restriction meets the fundamental-rights essence test and necessity/proportionality test and is to safeguard one of the listed objectives. (Quote: "may restrict ... when such a restriction respects ... and is a necessary and proportionate measure ... to safeguard")

The legislative measure must include the listed specific provisions "at least, where relevant"â€”meaning inclusion is mandatory to the extent each item is relevant to the measure. (Quote: "shall contain specific provisions at least, where relevant")

Data subjectsâ€™ right to be informed about the restriction applies unless informing "may be prejudicial to the purpose of the restriction". (Quote: "unless that may be prejudicial to the purpose of the restriction")
documentation_requirements: The legislative measure must document/specify (where relevant) the items (a)â€“(h), including purposes/categories of processing, data categories, scope of restrictions, safeguards, controller specification, storage periods and safeguards, risks, and the right to be informed (with prejudice exception).
reporting_requirements: Provide for "the right of data subjects to be informed about the restriction" unless prejudicial (this functions as a transparency/notification requirement embedded in the legislative measure).
timeline_requirements: Where relevant, the legislative measure must specify "the storage periods" and applicable safeguards (retention-related requirement).

general_restrictions: Permits restricting "the scope of the obligations and rights provided for in Articles 12 to 22 and Article 34".
Permits restricting "Article 5 in so far as its provisions correspond to the rights and obligations provided for in Articles 12 to 22".
data_restrictions: Legislative measures must (where relevant) define "the categories of personal data" implicated by the restriction.
Legislative measures must (where relevant) define processing purposes or categories, which constrains/frames processing under the restriction.
operational_restrictions: Restrictions may limit operational handling of data subject requests and transparency obligations covered by Articles 12â€“22 and breach communication under Article 34, but only within the scope defined by the legislative measure and subject to safeguards.
technical_restrictions: Legislative measures must (where relevant) include "safeguards to prevent abuse or unlawful access or transfer" (may entail technical controls, though not enumerated here).
geographic_restrictions: Restrictions are grounded in "Union or Member State law" applicable to the controller/processor.

individual_rights: A right for data subjects "to be informed about the restriction" (subject to the prejudice exception).
organizational_rights: A legal ability for controllers/processors (through applicable Union/Member State legislative measures) to operate under restricted scopes of certain GDPR obligations/rights, provided conditions are met.
how_to_exercise_rights: The section requires that the legislative measure address the right to be informed; it does not specify a procedure for exercising it beyond that.

general_exceptions: Restrictions are only permissible for safeguarding the enumerated objectives (a)â€“(j).
conditional_exemptions: Data subjects may be denied information about the restriction where informing them "may be prejudicial to the purpose of the restriction".
public_interest_exceptions: Safeguarding objectives that justify restrictions include: "national security"; "defence"; "public security"; criminal offences/penalties and threats to public security; "other important objectives of general public interest" including important economic/financial interests ("monetary, budgetary and taxation" matters), "public health" and "social security"; "the protection of judicial independence and judicial proceedings"; ethics breaches for regulated professions; monitoring/inspection/regulatory functions connected to official authority; protection of the data subject or othersâ€™ rights/freedoms; and enforcement of civil law claims.

technical_measures: Implement (as reflected/required by the legislative measure where relevant) safeguards to prevent "unlawful access or transfer" (specific technical measures not detailed in this section).
organizational_measures: Ensure any restriction relied upon is grounded in an applicable legislative measure and that internal practices align with the measureâ€™s specified scope, purposes, data categories, retention periods, and safeguards.
security_measures: Safeguards to prevent "abuse or unlawful access or transfer" must be provided for in the legislative measure where relevant.

related_articles: GDPR Article 5 (limited linkage: only insofar as corresponding to Articles 12-22)

implementation_steps: Identify whether any Union or Member State legislative measure applies to the controller/processor that restricts GDPR Articles 12â€“22 and/or 34 (and Article 5 only to the extent linked).

Verify the measure explicitly meets the conditions: respects the essence of fundamental rights and freedoms; is necessary and proportionate in a democratic society; and is aimed at one or more listed safeguarding objectives (a)â€“(j).

Check the legislative measure includes (at least where relevant) explicit provisions covering items (a)â€“(h), including safeguards against abuse/unlawful access/transfer and retention/storage periods with safeguards.
Operationalize the measure internally: map which rights/obligations are restricted, for which processing purposes/categories, for which data categories, and for how long.
Implement and maintain safeguards described/required by the measure to prevent abuse and unlawful access/transfer.
Assess and document (as required by the measure where relevant) the risks to data subjectsâ€™ rights and freedoms associated with the restriction.

Implement a process to inform data subjects about the restriction where required, and a decision process to withhold such information only when informing would be prejudicial to the restrictionâ€™s purpose.
common_violations: Relying on internal policy or ad hoc decisions to restrict data subject rights without a legislative measure.
Applying restrictions beyond what is necessary/proportionate or beyond the listed safeguarding objectives.
Failing to include/ensure the legislative measure includes required specifics (e.g., missing safeguards, undefined scope, undefined retention/storage periods).
Automatically refusing to inform data subjects about restrictions without assessing whether informing would be prejudicial to the restrictionâ€™s purpose.
best_practices: Maintain a register of applicable legislative restriction measures and map them to affected GDPR rights/obligations.
Create a written necessity/proportionality rationale aligned to the measureâ€™s safeguarding objective(s).
Implement access controls and transfer controls aligned to the measureâ€™s required safeguards against unlawful access/transfer.
Define retention schedules consistent with the measureâ€™s specified storage periods and safeguards.
compliance_checklist: Restriction is based on a Union/Member State legislative measure applicable to the controller/processor.
Restriction targets only GDPR Articles 12â€“22 and/or 34 (and Article 5 only insofar as corresponding to 12â€“22).
Restriction respects the essence of fundamental rights and freedoms.
Restriction is necessary and proportionate in a democratic society.
Restriction safeguards at least one objective (a)â€“(j) listed in the section.
Legislative measure includes (where relevant): purposes/categories of processing.
Legislative measure includes (where relevant): categories of personal data.
Legislative measure includes (where relevant): scope of restrictions introduced.
Legislative measure includes (where relevant): safeguards to prevent abuse or unlawful access or transfer.
Legislative measure includes (where relevant): specification of controller/categories of controllers.
Legislative measure includes (where relevant): storage periods and applicable safeguards considering nature/scope/purposes.
Legislative measure includes (where relevant): risks to rights and freedoms of data subjects.
Legislative measure includes (where relevant): right to be informed about the restriction, with documented prejudice exception handling.

key_definitions.legislative measure: A restriction must be enacted through Union or Member State law; the section does not further define the term beyond requiring restrictions be made "by way of a legislative measure".
key_definitions.necessary and proportionate measure in a: A condition for any restriction; the section does not define the test but requires necessity and proportionality.
key_definitions.essence of the fundamental rights and fr: A non-derogable core that the restriction must respect; not further defined in the section.
key_definitions.prejudicial to the purpose of the restri: Condition under which informing data subjects about the restriction may be withheld; not further defined in the section.

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 24 (Responsibility of the controller)

applicable_regions: European Economic Area (as incorporated into EEA law)

description.brief_summary: Requires controllers to implement and maintain appropriate technical and organisational measures, based on a risk assessment and processing context, to ensure and demonstrate GDPR-compliant processing; encourages proportionate data protection policies; and allows use of approved codes of conduct/certification to demonstrate compliance.
description.detailed_explanation: The provision imposes an accountability duty on the controller. The controller must (i) assess processing in light of its nature, scope, context, purposes, and the risks to individualsâ€™ rights and freedoms (including varying likelihood and severity), and (ii) implement technical and organisational measures that both ensure compliance and enable the controller to demonstrate compliance. The measures are not static: they must be reviewed and updated when necessary. Where proportionate to the processing activities, the controllerâ€™s measures must include implementing appropriate data protection policies. Additionally, the controller may use adherence to approved codes of conduct (Article 40) or approved certification mechanisms (Article 42) as an element to demonstrate compliance with controller obligations.
description.purpose: To operationalize the GDPR accountability principle by requiring controllers to proactively implement, maintain, and evidence compliance measures tailored to processing risks and context.
description.legislative_intent: To ensure controllers take responsibility for GDPR compliance through a risk-based approach, embedding governance and demonstrability (evidence of compliance) into processing operations, and to promote harmonized compliance tools such as codes of conduct and certification.

what_it_covers: Implementation of technical measures for GDPR-compliant processing
Implementation of organisational measures for GDPR-compliant processing
Demonstrability of compliance (accountability evidence)
Ongoing review and updating of measures
Implementation of data protection policies where proportionate
Use of approved codes of conduct and certification mechanisms as compliance evidence

entity_types: Any entity acting as a controller
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies to controllers subject to GDPR territorial scope (not specified in this excerpt).

what_it_does_not_cover: Specific prescriptive lists of measures (the article requires appropriateness but does not enumerate exact controls in this excerpt)
Processor-specific obligations (this article is controller-focused)

mandatory_obligations: Implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to ensure processing is performed in accordance with the Regulation. Quote: "the controller shall implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to ensure ... that processing is performed in accordance with this Regulation."

Implement measures in a risk-based manner considering processing characteristics and risks. Quote: "Taking into account the nature, scope, context and purposes of processing as well as the risks of varying likelihood and severity for the rights and freedoms of natural persons".

Be able to demonstrate that processing is performed in accordance with the Regulation (accountability/demonstrability). Quote: "and to be able to demonstrate that processing is performed in accordance with this Regulation."
Review and update the measures where necessary. Quote: "Those measures shall be reviewed and updated where necessary."

Where proportionate in relation to processing activities, include implementation of appropriate data protection policies. Quote: "Where proportionate in relation to processing activities, the measures ... shall include the implementation of appropriate data protection policies by the controller."
prohibited_actions: Failing to implement appropriate technical and organisational measures (implicit prohibition via 'shall implement').
Failing to review and update measures where necessary (implicit prohibition via 'shall be reviewed and updated').
conditional_requirements: If proportionate in relation to processing activities, the controller must include appropriate data protection policies as part of the measures. Quote: "Where proportionate ... shall include the implementation of appropriate data protection policies".
documentation_requirements: Maintain evidence sufficient to demonstrate compliance (the article requires the controller "to be able to demonstrate" compliance; specific document types are not enumerated in this excerpt).
timeline_requirements: Measures must be "reviewed and updated where necessary" (no fixed interval specified; triggers are necessity/changes in context, processing, or risk).

general_restrictions: Measures must be 'appropriate' and determined by a risk-based assessment considering nature, scope, context, purposes, and risks to individualsâ€™ rights and freedoms.
operational_restrictions: Controllers must operate processing in a way that can be demonstrated as compliant (imposes an operational constraint to maintain demonstrability).
technical_restrictions: Technical measures must be implemented to ensure compliant processing; the specific technical controls are not specified in this excerpt.

organizational_rights: Controllers may use adherence to approved codes of conduct or approved certification mechanisms as an element to demonstrate compliance. Quote: "may be used as an element by which to demonstrate compliance".
how_to_exercise_rights: Adhere to an approved code of conduct under Article 40 and/or obtain/maintain an approved certification mechanism under Article 42, and use that adherence/certification as part of compliance evidence.

conditional_exemptions: Data protection policies are required only "where proportionate in relation to processing activities" (i.e., if not proportionate, the specific obligation to include policies does not apply).

technical_measures: Implement "appropriate technical" measures tailored to the processing and risk profile (specific measures not enumerated in this excerpt).
organizational_measures: Implement "appropriate organisational" measures tailored to the processing and risk profile.
Review and update measures where necessary.
Where proportionate, implement appropriate data protection policies.
security_measures: Not explicitly labeled as 'security' in this excerpt, but the requirement for technical and organisational measures based on risks to rights and freedoms can encompass security-related controls (no specific security controls specified here).
audit_requirements: Ongoing review of measures is required; formal audits are not explicitly mandated in this excerpt.
certification_requirements: Certification is not mandatory; however, "approved certification mechanisms as referred to in Article 42" may be used to demonstrate compliance.

implementation_steps: Assess processing activities by nature, scope, context, and purposes.
Perform a risk assessment focusing on risks to rights and freedoms of natural persons, considering likelihood and severity.
Select and implement technical measures appropriate to the assessed risks and processing context.
Select and implement organisational measures (governance, roles, procedures) appropriate to the assessed risks and processing context.
Establish evidence and artifacts that allow the controller to demonstrate compliance (e.g., documented measures, decision records, policies where proportionate).
Set up a process to review measures and update them when necessary (e.g., upon changes in processing, technology, threats, or incidents).
If proportionate, implement and maintain appropriate data protection policies.
Optionally, adopt an approved code of conduct and/or obtain an approved certification to support demonstrability of compliance.
common_violations: Implementing measures without considering the specific nature/scope/context/purposes of processing and the likelihood/severity of risks.
Inability to demonstrate compliance due to lack of evidence or documentation supporting implemented measures.
Failing to review and update measures when processing changes or risks evolve.
Omitting data protection policies in situations where they would be proportionate to the processing activities.
best_practices: Maintain a living compliance program that ties measures to documented risk assessments.
Define review triggers (e.g., new processing purposes, new categories of data subjects/data, new systems/vendors, incidents, regulatory changes).
Use approved codes of conduct/certification as supplementary evidence, not as the sole compliance mechanism.
compliance_checklist: Have we evaluated nature, scope, context, and purposes of each processing activity?
Have we assessed risks to rights and freedoms with likelihood and severity?
Are technical measures implemented and mapped to identified risks?
Are organisational measures implemented (governance, procedures) and mapped to identified risks?
Can we demonstrate compliance with evidence (records of measures, decisions, reviews)?
Do we review and update measures when necessary?
Where proportionate, do we have appropriate data protection policies in place?
Do we use approved codes of conduct and/or certification mechanisms as supporting compliance evidence (optional)?

regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2016/679) â€” Article 25 (Data protection by design and by default)

applicable_regions: European Economic Area (via incorporation into EEA law)

description.brief_summary: Imposes mandatory controller obligations to implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to embed data-protection principles and safeguards into processing (by design) and to ensure that, by default, only necessary personal data are processed for each purpose, including limiting accessibility and preventing default public exposure.
description.detailed_explanation: The provision requires controllers to proactively build compliance into processing operations. It mandates a risk- and context-based approach that considers (i) state of the art, (ii) cost of implementation, (iii) nature, scope, context and purposes of processing, and (iv) risks to rights and freedoms of natural persons (likelihood and severity). Controllers must implement appropriate technical and organisational measures at two points in time: when determining the means of processing (design/architecture stage) and during the processing itself (operational stage). Measures must be designed to implement data-protection principles (explicitly including data minimisation) effectively and to integrate necessary safeguards to meet the Regulationâ€™s requirements and protect data subjectsâ€™ rights. Separately, controllers must ensure privacy-by-default: default configurations and practices must ensure only personal data necessary for each specific purpose are processed, covering the amount collected, extent of processing, storage period, and accessibility. A specific default-accessibility safeguard is required: by default, personal data must not be made accessible to an indefinite number of natural persons without the individualâ€™s intervention. The section also provides that an approved certification mechanism under Article 42 may be used as an element to demonstrate compliance with these obligations.
description.purpose: To ensure data protection principles and safeguards are embedded into processing systems and practices from the outset and that default settings minimize personal data use and exposure, thereby protecting individualsâ€™ rights and freedoms.
description.legislative_intent: To shift compliance from reactive to proactive by requiring controllers to engineer privacy into systems and default configurations, reducing unnecessary processing and preventing broad default accessibility of personal data.

what_it_covers: Determination of the means for processing (design stage decisions about tools, systems, architecture, settings, workflows)
Processing operations themselves (runtime/operational processing activities)
Selection and implementation of technical measures (e.g., pseudonymisation) and organisational measures
Default settings and configurations governing collection, processing extent, storage duration, and access controls
Safeguards to meet GDPR requirements and protect data subject rights

entity_types: Any organization acting as a controller

what_it_does_not_cover: No explicit exclusions are stated in this section.

mandatory_obligations: Risk- and context-based assessment obligation: the controller must take into account "the state of the art, the cost of implementation and the nature, scope, context and purposes of processing" and "the risks of varying likelihood and severity for rights and freedoms of natural persons posed by the processing" when selecting measures. (Quote: "Taking into account the state of the art, the cost of implementation and the nature, scope, context and purposes of processing as well as the risks of varying likelihood and severity for rights and freedoms of natural persons posed by the processing")

Design-stage implementation obligation: the controller must implement appropriate technical and organisational measures "at the time of the determination of the means for processing". (Quote: "the controller shall, both at the time of the determination of the means for processing")

Operational-stage implementation obligation: the controller must implement appropriate technical and organisational measures "at the time of the processing itself". (Quote: "and at the time of the processing itself")

Appropriate measures must be designed to implement data-protection principles effectively, including data minimisation. (Quote: "implement appropriate technical and organisational measures, such as pseudonymisation, which are designed to implement data-protection principles, such as data minimisation, in an effective manner")

Safeguards integration obligation: measures must "integrate the necessary safeguards into the processing" to meet the Regulationâ€™s requirements and protect data subjectsâ€™ rights. (Quote: "and to integrate the necessary safeguards into the processing in order to meet the requirements of this Regulation and protect the rights of data subjects")

Privacy-by-default obligation: the controller must implement appropriate technical and organisational measures ensuring that "by default, only personal data which are necessary for each specific purpose of the processing are processed". (Quote: "The controller shall implement appropriate technical and organisational measures for ensuring that, by default, only personal data which are necessary for each specific purpose of the processing are processed")

Default limitation must apply across multiple dimensions: amount collected, extent of processing, storage period, and accessibility. (Quote: "That obligation applies to the amount of personal data collected, the extent of their processing, the period of their storage and their accessibility")

Default accessibility safeguard: measures must ensure that "by default personal data are not made accessible without the individual's intervention to an indefinite number of natural persons". (Quote: "In particular, such measures shall ensure that by default personal data are not made accessible without the individual's intervention to an indefinite number of natural persons")
prohibited_actions: By default making personal data accessible to an indefinite number of natural persons without the individual's intervention. (Derived from explicit requirement; Quote: "by default personal data are not made accessible without the individual's intervention to an indefinite number of natural persons")
conditional_requirements: Measures selection must be conditioned on contextual factors and risk: state of the art, cost of implementation, nature/scope/context/purposes, and risks (likelihood and severity) to rights and freedoms. (Quote: "Taking into account...")

Use of certification is optional and conditional on availability/approval: "An approved certification mechanism pursuant to Article 42 may be used as an element to demonstrate compliance". (Quote: "may be used as an element")
timeline_requirements: Measures must be implemented at two timepoints: (1) "at the time of the determination of the means for processing" and (2) "at the time of the processing itself". (Quote: "both at the time... and at the time...")

general_restrictions: Processing must be structured so that data-protection principles (e.g., data minimisation) are implemented effectively and safeguards are integrated into processing.
data_restrictions: Only personal data necessary for each specific purpose may be processed by default. (Quote: "by default, only personal data which are necessary for each specific purpose of the processing are processed")
Restriction on amount collected by default. (Quote: "applies to the amount of personal data collected")
Restriction on extent of processing by default. (Quote: "the extent of their processing")
Restriction on storage period by default. (Quote: "the period of their storage")
operational_restrictions: Controllers must embed safeguards into processing operations to meet GDPR requirements and protect rights.
technical_restrictions: Default configurations must prevent accessibility to an indefinite number of natural persons without the individual's intervention. (Quote: "not made accessible without the individual's intervention to an indefinite number of natural persons")
Implementation of technical measures may include pseudonymisation as an example. (Quote: "such as pseudonymisation")

individual_rights: This section does not enumerate specific procedural rights, but it explicitly frames the obligation to "protect the rights of data subjects" through safeguards. (Quote: "protect the rights of data subjects")
organizational_rights: Ability to use an approved certification mechanism under Article 42 as an element to demonstrate compliance. (Quote: "may be used as an element to demonstrate compliance")

technical_measures: Implement appropriate technical measures designed to implement data-protection principles effectively. (Quote: "implement appropriate technical... measures")
Pseudonymisation is explicitly provided as an example of such measures. (Quote: "such as pseudonymisation")
Implement default settings/controls ensuring only necessary data are processed for each purpose. (Quote: "by default, only personal data which are necessary...")

Implement access controls/default exposure controls so that personal data are not accessible to an indefinite number of natural persons without the individual's intervention. (Quote: "not made accessible... to an indefinite number of natural persons")
organizational_measures: Implement appropriate organisational measures at design and operational stages to integrate safeguards and meet GDPR requirements. (Quote: "technical and organisational measures")
Ensure organisational governance supports data minimisation and default limitation across collection, processing extent, storage period, and accessibility. (Quote: "That obligation applies to...")
security_measures: Integrate necessary safeguards into processing to protect rights and meet the Regulationâ€™s requirements (security may be part of safeguards, but the section does not specify particular security controls beyond pseudonymisation and access limitation). (Quote: "integrate the necessary safeguards")
certification_requirements: Certification is not mandatory; however, an approved certification mechanism pursuant to Article 42 may be used as an element to demonstrate compliance with Article 25(1) and (2). (Quote: "may be used as an element to demonstrate compliance")

related_articles: GDPR Article 42 (Certification) (referenced as: "An approved certification mechanism pursuant to Article 42")

implementation_steps: At design stage, assess processing context and risks (likelihood and severity) and select appropriate technical and organisational measures considering state of the art and cost. (Quote basis: "Taking into account...")

Embed data-protection principles (explicitly including data minimisation) into system design and processing workflows. (Quote: "designed to implement data-protection principles, such as data minimisation")
Integrate safeguards into processing operations to meet GDPR requirements and protect data subject rights. (Quote: "integrate the necessary safeguards into the processing")

Configure defaults so only necessary personal data are processed per specific purpose, limiting collection, processing extent, storage period, and accessibility. (Quote: "That obligation applies to...")
Implement default access controls preventing exposure to an indefinite number of persons without the individualâ€™s intervention. (Quote: "not made accessible without the individual's intervention")
Optionally pursue/use an approved Article 42 certification mechanism as supporting evidence of compliance with these obligations. (Quote: "may be used as an element")
common_violations: Collecting more personal data than necessary by default for a given purpose (violates default necessity requirement).
Default retention periods longer than necessary (violates default limitation on "period of their storage").
Default settings that make profiles/posts/directories publicly accessible to unlimited audiences without user action (violates default non-accessibility to an indefinite number without intervention).
Failing to implement design-stage measures and only adding controls after deployment (violates dual timepoint requirement).
best_practices: Use privacy engineering patterns (data minimisation, purpose-based access control, default-private settings).
Apply pseudonymisation where it supports principle implementation and risk reduction (explicitly cited example).
Document design decisions showing consideration of state of the art, cost, context, and risk (not required by this text, but supports demonstrating compliance).
Use certification (Article 42) as supplementary evidence where available.
compliance_checklist: Have technical and organisational measures been implemented both at design time and during processing operations?
Were state of the art, cost, nature/scope/context/purposes, and risk likelihood/severity considered when selecting measures?
Do measures effectively implement data-protection principles, including data minimisation?
Are safeguards integrated into processing to meet GDPR requirements and protect data subject rights?
By default, is processing limited to personal data necessary for each specific purpose?
Do defaults limit: (a) amount collected, (b) extent of processing, (c) storage period, and (d) accessibility?
By default, are personal data prevented from being accessible to an indefinite number of natural persons without the individualâ€™s intervention?
If used, is there an approved Article 42 certification mechanism supporting compliance demonstration?

key_definitions.controller: Not defined in this section; referenced as the obligated party ("the controller shall").
key_definitions.technical and organisational measures: Not defined in this section; measures the controller must implement to embed principles and safeguards.
key_definitions.pseudonymisation: Not defined in this section; provided as an example of a technical/organisational measure ("such as pseudonymisation").
key_definitions.data-protection principles: Not defined in this section; includes data minimisation as an example ("such as data minimisation").
key_definitions.data minimisation: Not defined in this section; cited as an example principle to be implemented effectively.
key_definitions.individual's intervention: Not defined in this section; used as the condition required before making data accessible to an indefinite number of persons by default.

regulations.source_section: ## Data protection by design and by default

regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2016/679) â€” Article 42 (Certification) (referenced for compliance demonstration)

applicable_regions: European Economic Area (via incorporation into EEA law)

description.brief_summary: This section states that an approved certification mechanism under GDPR Article 42 may be used as an element to demonstrate compliance with the data protection by design and by default obligations.
description.detailed_explanation: The only actionable content in this section regarding Article 42 is its permitted use as supporting evidence: "An approved certification mechanism pursuant to Article 42 may be used as an element to demonstrate compliance" with Article 25(1) and (2). The section does not specify how certification works, who approves it, or certification criteria; it only establishes the linkage that certification can support compliance demonstration for these obligations.
description.purpose: To provide a recognized means (certification) that can support demonstrating compliance with Article 25 obligations.
description.legislative_intent: To encourage use of approved certification mechanisms as part of accountability and compliance demonstration.

what_it_covers: Use of an approved certification mechanism as an element to demonstrate compliance with GDPR Article 25(1) and (2)

target_entities: Controllers (as the party demonstrating compliance with Article 25 obligations)
entity_types: Any organization acting as a controller

what_it_does_not_cover: This section does not provide Article 42â€™s certification requirements, procedures, or criteria.

conditional_requirements: If a controller uses certification for compliance demonstration, it must be an "approved certification mechanism" and it is used only "as an element" (i.e., supportive evidence) to demonstrate compliance with Article 25(1) and (2). (Quote: "An approved certification mechanism pursuant to Article 42 may be used as an element to demonstrate compliance")

general_restrictions: Only an "approved" certification mechanism qualifies for this compliance-demonstration use. (Quote: "approved certification mechanism")

organizational_rights: Permission to use an approved certification mechanism as an element to demonstrate compliance with Article 25(1) and (2). (Quote: "may be used as an element")

certification_requirements: Certification mechanism must be approved and pursuant to Article 42 to be used as an element of compliance demonstration for Article 25(1) and (2). (Quote: "An approved certification mechanism pursuant to Article 42")

implementation_steps: Identify whether an approved GDPR Article 42 certification mechanism exists that is relevant to the controllerâ€™s processing and can support demonstrating compliance with Article 25(1) and (2). (Quote basis: "may be used as an element")
Use certification as supplementary evidence rather than the sole control, consistent with "as an element" wording.
common_violations: Relying on non-approved or informal certifications as if they were Article 42 approved mechanisms for demonstrating compliance.
best_practices: Treat certification as supporting evidence within a broader accountability package demonstrating Article 25 compliance.
compliance_checklist: If certification is used, is it an approved certification mechanism pursuant to GDPR Article 42?
Is certification being used as an element (supporting evidence) to demonstrate compliance with Article 25(1) and (2)?

key_definitions.approved certification mechanism: Not defined in this section; referenced as the type of certification that may be used to demonstrate compliance.

regulations.source_section: ## Data protection by design and by default

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 26 (Joint controllers)

applicable_regions: EEA (via incorporation into EEA law, where applicable)

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data under GDPR

description.brief_summary: Defines when controllers are joint controllers and requires them to transparently allocate GDPR compliance responsibilities through an arrangement, ensure the arrangement reflects their roles vis-Ã -vis data subjects, make the essence available to data subjects, and preserve data subjectsâ€™ ability to exercise rights against any joint controller.
description.detailed_explanation: This provision applies where two or more controllers jointly determine both the purposes and the means of processing. In such cases, they are legally characterized as â€œjoint controllersâ€ and must establish, in a transparent manner, how they will allocate responsibilities for complying with GDPR obligations. The allocation must particularly address (i) how data subject rights will be exercised and handled and (ii) which controller(s) will provide the information required under Articles 13 and 14. The allocation must be set out â€œby means of an arrangement between themâ€ unless Union or Member State law already determines the respective responsibilities for the controllers. The arrangement must reflect the joint controllersâ€™ roles and relationships vis-Ã -vis data subjects, and the â€œessenceâ€ of the arrangement must be made available to data subjects. Importantly, regardless of what the arrangement says, data subjects retain the right to exercise their GDPR rights â€œin respect of and against each of the controllers.â€
description.purpose: To ensure clear accountability and transparency when multiple controllers jointly decide how and why personal data is processed, while safeguarding data subjectsâ€™ rights and access to responsible parties.
description.legislative_intent: To prevent gaps or confusion in compliance and rights handling in multi-party processing scenarios by mandating transparent allocation of responsibilities and ensuring data subjects can enforce rights against any joint controller.

what_it_covers: Situations where two or more controllers jointly determine the purposes of processing
Situations where two or more controllers jointly determine the means of processing
Allocation of GDPR compliance responsibilities among joint controllers
Arrangements governing data subject rights handling and Articles 13/14 information duties
Transparency to data subjects regarding the essence of the joint controller arrangement

entity_types: Any organization acting as a controller under GDPR
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Controllers subject to GDPR (including those subject via establishment in the EU/EEA or extraterritorial scope where applicable).

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing where parties do not jointly determine purposes and means (i.e., not joint controllers)
Processor-only relationships (where one party acts solely on behalf of a controller)

mandatory_obligations: Determine joint controllership status when the condition is met: "Where two or more controllers jointly determine the purposes and means of processing, they shall be joint controllers."
Allocate responsibilities transparently: joint controllers "shall in a transparent manner determine their respective responsibilities for compliance with the obligations under this Regulation".

Use an arrangement to set out responsibilities (unless responsibilities are determined by applicable Union/Member State law): allocation must be done "by means of an arrangement between them unless, and in so far as, the respective responsibilities of the controllers are determined by Union or Member State law to which the controllers are subject."
Ensure the allocation addresses, in particular: (a) "the exercising of the rights of the data subject" and (b) "their respective duties to provide the information referred to in Articles 13 and 14".

Ensure the arrangement reflects roles/relationships vis-Ã -vis data subjects: "The arrangement ... shall duly reflect the respective roles and relationships of the joint controllers vis-Ã -vis the data subjects."
Make the essence of the arrangement available to data subjects: "The essence of the arrangement shall be made available to the data subject."

Respect data subject ability to exercise rights against any controller regardless of arrangement: "Irrespective of the terms of the arrangement ... the data subject may exercise his or her rights under this Regulation in respect of and against each of the controllers."
prohibited_actions: Do not restrict or negate data subject rights through the arrangement (implied by: "Irrespective of the terms of the arrangement... the data subject may exercise... rights... against each of the controllers.")
conditional_requirements: If two or more controllers jointly determine purposes and means, they must treat themselves as joint controllers and comply with the joint controller obligations.

If Union or Member State law determines respective responsibilities for the controllers, the arrangement requirement applies only "unless, and in so far as" those responsibilities are already determined by such law.
The arrangement may (optional) designate a contact point: "The arrangement may designate a contact point for data subjects."
documentation_requirements: Maintain an "arrangement" between joint controllers allocating responsibilities (required unless responsibilities are determined by applicable Union/Member State law).
Ensure the arrangement content "duly reflect[s]" roles and relationships vis-Ã -vis data subjects.
Prepare an extract/summary sufficient to constitute the "essence of the arrangement" for disclosure to data subjects.
reporting_requirements: Provide to data subjects the "essence of the arrangement" (a disclosure obligation; not a regulator reporting obligation).
timeline_requirements: No explicit deadlines stated; obligations apply when joint controllership exists and must be in place to support compliance and data subject interactions.

general_restrictions: Joint controllers cannot rely on their internal arrangement to prevent a data subject from exercising rights against any of them ("Irrespective of the terms of the arrangement...").
operational_restrictions: Operational governance must include a transparent allocation of responsibilities and a mechanism to provide the essence of the arrangement to data subjects.
geographic_restrictions: Exception/variation where responsibilities are determined by Union or Member State law applicable to the controllers ("Union or Member State law to which the controllers are subject").

individual_rights: Right to exercise GDPR rights against any joint controller: "the data subject may exercise his or her rights under this Regulation in respect of and against each of the controllers."
Right to receive the essence of the joint controller arrangement: "The essence of the arrangement shall be made available to the data subject."
organizational_rights: Ability (not an obligation) for joint controllers to designate a contact point for data subjects: "The arrangement may designate a contact point for data subjects."
how_to_exercise_rights: Data subjects may direct rights requests to any of the joint controllers ("against each of the controllers").
Data subjects may request/access the essence of the arrangement, which must be made available to them.

general_exceptions: Arrangement requirement is displaced to the extent responsibilities are already determined by applicable Union or Member State law: "unless, and in so far as, the respective responsibilities ... are determined by Union or Member State law".
conditional_exemptions: Partial exemption from defining responsibilities via an arrangement applies only to the extent ("in so far as") the law already determines those responsibilities.

organizational_measures: Establish governance to identify joint controllership when purposes and means are jointly determined.
Create and maintain a transparent joint controller arrangement allocating GDPR compliance responsibilities.
Define operational procedures for handling data subject rights requests across joint controllers.
Define which controller(s) will provide Articles 13 and 14 information and how this will be coordinated.
Implement a process to provide the essence of the arrangement to data subjects (e.g., via privacy notice, portal, or upon request).
Optionally establish a designated contact point for data subjects and ensure it is communicated where used.

related_articles: GDPR Article 13 (Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject) â€” referenced for information duties allocation
GDPR Article 14 (Information to be provided where personal data have not been obtained from the data subject) â€” referenced for information duties allocation
complementary_regulations: Union or Member State law determining controllersâ€™ respective responsibilities (as referenced: "Union or Member State law to which the controllers are subject")

implementation_steps: Assess whether multiple parties jointly determine both purposes and means for the processing; if yes, treat as joint controllers.
Draft and execute a joint controller arrangement that transparently allocates GDPR compliance responsibilities.
Explicitly allocate responsibility for (a) handling/fulfilling data subject rights and (b) providing Articles 13/14 information.
Ensure the arrangement accurately reflects the partiesâ€™ roles and relationships as experienced by data subjects.
Publish or otherwise provide the essence of the arrangement to data subjects (e.g., in privacy notices).
Ensure internal processes allow data subjects to exercise rights against any joint controller, regardless of the arrangementâ€™s internal allocation.
Optionally designate a data subject contact point in the arrangement and operationalize it.
common_violations: Failing to recognize joint controllership when purposes and means are jointly determined.
Having no joint controller arrangement (where not otherwise determined by law).
Arrangements that are not transparent or do not clearly allocate responsibilities for rights handling and Articles 13/14 information duties.
Not making the essence of the arrangement available to data subjects.
Attempting to route or reject data subject requests based on the arrangement, rather than accepting requests against any controller.
best_practices: Include clear responsibility matrices for each data subject right and for Articles 13/14 disclosures.
Provide a concise public-facing summary (the â€œessenceâ€) aligned with the privacy notice.
Set up a coordinated intake and tracking process so any joint controller can receive and route rights requests without delay.
compliance_checklist: Joint controllership assessment completed and documented for relevant processing activities.
Joint controller arrangement exists (unless responsibilities are determined by applicable Union/Member State law).
Arrangement transparently allocates GDPR compliance responsibilities.
Arrangement explicitly covers data subject rights handling responsibilities.
Arrangement explicitly covers Articles 13 and 14 information provision responsibilities.
Arrangement reflects roles/relationships vis-Ã -vis data subjects.
Essence of arrangement is made available to data subjects.
Operational process allows data subjects to exercise rights against any joint controller.

key_definitions.Joint controllers: Controllers that "jointly determine the purposes and means of processing".
key_definitions.Arrangement: The required governance instrument between joint controllers used to determine "their respective responsibilities for compliance" (unless responsibilities are determined by applicable Union/Member State law).
key_definitions.Essence of the arrangement: The core elements of the joint controller arrangement that "shall be made available to the data subject".
key_definitions.Contact point: An optional designation in the arrangement that "may" be set for data subjects.

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 27 (Representatives of controllers or processors not established in the Union)

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data within GDPR scope

description.brief_summary: Requires certain non-EU controllers/processors subject to GDPRâ€™s extraterritorial scope to appoint an EU-based representative in writing, sets exemptions, defines where the representative must be located, and clarifies the representativeâ€™s mandate and the non-prejudicial effect on enforcement against the controller/processor.
description.detailed_explanation: Where GDPR Article 3(2) applies (i.e., the GDPR applies to a controller/processor not established in the Union due to certain activities involving EU data subjects), the controller or processor must "designate in writing a representative in the Union." The section then provides two explicit exemptions from this obligation: (a) certain low-risk, occasional processing meeting cumulative conditions (occasional; not large-scale special category data under Article 9(1) and not criminal conviction/offence data under Article 10; and unlikely to result in a risk to rights and freedoms considering nature/context/scope/purposes), and (b) where the controller/processor is a public authority or body. The representative must be "established in one of the Member States" where the relevant data subjects are located (those whose data are processed in relation to offering goods/services to them, or whose behaviour is monitored). The representative must be "mandated" so that supervisory authorities and data subjects may address the representative "in addition to or instead of" the controller/processor "on all issues related to processing" for compliance purposes. Finally, appointing a representative is "without prejudice to legal actions" against the controller/processor themselves, meaning the representative does not replace or shield the controller/processor from liability or proceedings.
description.purpose: To ensure an accessible EU-based point of contact for supervisory authorities and data subjects and to facilitate enforcement and compliance for non-EU entities subject to GDPR.
description.legislative_intent: To operationalize GDPRâ€™s extraterritorial reach by requiring a Union-based representative for certain non-EU controllers/processors, while carving out narrow exemptions for low-risk occasional processing and public authorities/bodies.

what_it_covers: Designation of an EU representative by non-EU controllers/processors when GDPR Article 3(2) applies
Exemptions from the representative designation obligation
Location/establishment requirement for the representative within the EU
Mandate and contact-point role of the representative for supervisory authorities and data subjects
Clarification that representative designation does not prevent legal actions against the controller/processor

target_entities: Controllers not established in the Union
Processors not established in the Union
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies to controllers/processors not established in the Union where GDPR Article 3(2) applies; requires a representative established in the Union.

what_it_does_not_cover: Controllers/processors for which GDPR Article 3(2) does not apply
Processing that meets the full exemption criteria in Article 27(2)(a) (as quoted below)
Public authorities or bodies (as quoted below)

mandatory_obligations: When GDPR Article 3(2) applies, the controller or the processor must appoint an EU representative: "the controller or the processor shall designate in writing a representative in the Union."

The representative must be established in an appropriate Member State: "The representative shall be established in one of the Member States where the data subjects, whose personal data are processed in relation to the offering of goods or services to them, or whose behaviour is monitored, are."

The controller/processor must mandate the representative to be a contact point: "The representative shall be mandated by the controller or processor to be addressed in addition to or instead of the controller or the processor by, in particular, supervisory authorities and data subjects, on all issues related to processing, for the purposes of ensuring compliance with this Regulation."
prohibited_actions: Treating the designation of a representative as preventing actions against the controller/processor: "The designation of a representative by the controller or processor shall be without prejudice to legal actions which could be initiated against the controller or the processor themselves."
conditional_requirements: Designation obligation is triggered only "Where Article 3(2) applies".

Exemption applies only if all conditions in point (a) are met: "processing which is occasional, does not include, on a large scale, processing of special categories of data as referred to in Article 9(1) or processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences referred to in Article 10, and is unlikely to result in a risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons, taking into account the nature, context, scope and purposes of the processing".
Exemption applies if the controller/processor is "a public authority or body."
documentation_requirements: Representative must be designated "in writing" (written designation required).

general_restrictions: Representative must be located/established in a Member State tied to the affected data subjects: "established in one of the Member States where the data subjects ... are."
data_restrictions: Exemption is restricted where processing includes, on a large scale, special categories of data (Article 9(1)) or criminal conviction/offence data (Article 10); such processing disqualifies the exemption in point (a) as stated: "does not include, on a large scale, processing of special categories of data ... or processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences..."
operational_restrictions: The representative must be empowered/mandated to be addressed by supervisory authorities and data subjects "in addition to or instead of" the controller/processor on processing issues for compliance.
geographic_restrictions: Representative must be "in the Union" and "established in one of the Member States" where relevant data subjects are located.

individual_rights: Data subjects may address the representative (as mandated) on processing issues for compliance purposes: representative may be addressed by "data subjects, on all issues related to processing, for the purposes of ensuring compliance with this Regulation."
how_to_exercise_rights: Data subjects may contact the mandated representative (who can be addressed "in addition to or instead of" the controller/processor) regarding processing-related issues for compliance.

general_exceptions: Public authority or body exemption: "The obligation laid down in paragraph 1 of this Article shall not apply to: ... (b) a public authority or body."
conditional_exemptions: Low-risk occasional processing exemption (all elements required): "processing which is occasional, does not include, on a large scale, processing of special categories of data as referred to in Article 9(1) or processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences referred to in Article 10, and is unlikely to result in a risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons, taking into account the nature, context, scope and purposes of the processing".
public_interest_exceptions: Public authority or body exemption (as above).

organizational_measures: Implement a governance step to appoint an EU representative when Article 3(2) applies.
Ensure the representative has a formal mandate to act as a contact point for supervisory authorities and data subjects on processing/compliance issues.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authorities (referenced as entities that may address the representative: "in particular, supervisory authorities")
enforcement_mechanisms: Supervisory authorities may address the representative on processing issues for compliance purposes.

Legal actions may be initiated against the controller/processor regardless of representative designation: "without prejudice to legal actions which could be initiated against the controller or the processor themselves."

related_articles: GDPR Article 3(2) (trigger for applicability referenced: "Where Article 3(2) applies")
GDPR Article 9(1) (special categories of data referenced in exemption condition)
GDPR Article 10 (criminal convictions and offences data referenced in exemption condition)

implementation_steps: Determine whether GDPR Article 3(2) applies to the non-EU controller/processor (offering goods/services to EU data subjects or monitoring their behaviour, as referenced by the representative location rule).

Assess whether an exemption applies by checking: (i) processing is occasional; (ii) no large-scale processing of Article 9(1) special categories; (iii) no processing of Article 10 criminal conviction/offence data; (iv) processing is unlikely to result in risk to rights and freedoms considering nature/context/scope/purposes.
If not exempt, designate an EU representative "in writing".
Select the Member State for establishment based on where the relevant data subjects are located (those targeted by goods/services or monitored).

Execute a mandate empowering the representative to be addressed by supervisory authorities and data subjects, in addition to or instead of the controller/processor, on all processing-related issues for compliance.
common_violations: Failing to appoint an EU representative despite being subject to Article 3(2).
Appointing a representative but not documenting the designation "in writing".
Choosing a representative established in a Member State not aligned with where the relevant data subjects are located.
Failing to properly mandate the representative to be addressed by supervisory authorities and data subjects on all processing-related issues.
Assuming the representative shields the controller/processor from legal actions (contrary to the "without prejudice" clause).
best_practices: Maintain a written appointment letter/contract clearly identifying the representative and scope of mandate.
Document the exemption analysis (occasional/large-scale/special category/criminal data/risk assessment) when relying on Article 27(2)(a).
Align representative location with the primary Member State(s) where affected data subjects are located.
compliance_checklist: Is the organization a controller/processor not established in the Union?
Does GDPR Article 3(2) apply to the processing?
Does an exemption apply (occasional + no large-scale Art 9(1) + no Art 10 + unlikely risk considering nature/context/scope/purposes) or is the entity a public authority/body?
If not exempt, is there a written designation of an EU representative?
Is the representative established in a Member State where the relevant data subjects are located?
Is the representative mandated to be addressed by supervisory authorities and data subjects (in addition to or instead of the controller/processor) on all processing issues for compliance?
Has the organization ensured it remains directly subject to legal actions notwithstanding the representative appointment?

key_definitions.Representative (in the Union): An entity designated in writing by a controller or processor not established in the Union (where Article 3(2) applies), established in a relevant Member State, and mandated to be addressed by supervisory authorities and data subjects on processing issues for compliance purposes.

regulations.source_section: ## Representatives of controllers or processors not established in the Union

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 28 (Processor)

applicable_regions: EEA (via incorporation into EEA law, where applicable)

description.brief_summary: Establishes conditions for using processors, mandatory contractual clauses for controller-processor relationships, rules for engaging sub-processors, and accountability/audit duties; also clarifies when a processor is treated as a controller.
description.detailed_explanation: The article requires controllers to select only processors that provide sufficient guarantees of appropriate technical and organisational measures to meet GDPR requirements and protect data subject rights. It prohibits processors from engaging sub-processors without the controllerâ€™s prior written authorization (specific or general), and requires notice of changes under general authorization to allow controller objection. It mandates that processing by a processor be governed by a binding contract or other legal act under Union/Member State law, specifying key processing parameters and including a minimum set of processor obligations: processing only on documented controller instructions (including for transfers), confidentiality commitments, implementation of Article 32 measures, compliance with sub-processing conditions, assistance with data subject rights requests, assistance with compliance with Articles 32â€“36, deletion/return of data at end of services (unless law requires storage), and making information available plus supporting audits/inspections. The processor must also immediately inform the controller if an instruction infringes GDPR or other Union/Member State data protection provisions. When a processor engages a sub-processor, it must impose the same data protection obligations via contract/legal act and ensure sufficient guarantees; the initial processor remains fully liable to the controller if the sub-processor fails. Adherence to approved codes of conduct (Art. 40) or approved certification mechanisms (Art. 42) may be used to demonstrate sufficient guarantees. Contracts may be based on standard contractual clauses adopted by the Commission or supervisory authorities, and must be in writing (including electronic). Finally, if a processor determines purposes and means, it is considered a controller for that processing (without prejudice to Articles 82â€“84).
description.purpose: To ensure processors provide adequate safeguards and are contractually bound to protect personal data, enabling controller accountability and consistent protection of data subject rights throughout processing chains, including sub-processing.
description.legislative_intent: To operationalize accountability by requiring enforceable controller-processor arrangements, ensure security and rights protections are implemented by processors, and prevent uncontrolled onward processing through sub-processors.

what_it_covers: Controller selection and use of processors
Processor engagement of sub-processors
Mandatory content of controller-processor contracts/legal acts
Processor duties during processing (instructions, confidentiality, security, assistance, audits)
End-of-service data return/deletion
Use of codes of conduct/certification to evidence guarantees
Use/adoption of standard contractual clauses
Form requirement for contracts (writing/electronic)
Re-characterization of processor as controller when determining purposes/means

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies where GDPR applies; includes processing on behalf of controllers subject to GDPR and processors subject to Union/Member State law as referenced.

what_it_does_not_cover: Does not itself specify the detailed technical measures of Article 32 (it references them).
Does not set specific fine amounts in this section (penalties are addressed elsewhere; referenced as 'Without prejudice to Articles 82, 83 and 84').

mandatory_obligations: Controller must use only processors providing sufficient guarantees to implement appropriate technical and organisational measures so that processing meets GDPR requirements and protects data subject rights. Quote: "the controller shall use only processors providing sufficient guarantees to implement appropriate technical and organisational measures..." (para. 1).

Processor must not engage another processor (sub-processor) without prior specific or general written authorisation of the controller. Quote: "The processor shall not engage another processor without prior specific or general written authorisation of the controller." (para. 2).

If general written authorisation is used, processor must inform controller of intended changes regarding addition/replacement of other processors, giving controller opportunity to object. Quote: "inform the controller of any intended changes... thereby giving the controller the opportunity to object" (para. 2).

Processing by a processor must be governed by a contract or other legal act under Union or Member State law, binding on the processor with regard to the controller, and setting out: subject-matter, duration, nature, purpose, type of personal data, categories of data subjects, and controller obligations/rights. Quote: "shall be governed by a contract or other legal act... that sets out the subject-matter and duration..." (para. 3).

Contract/legal act must stipulate that processor processes personal data only on documented instructions from controller, including regarding transfers to third countries/international organisations, unless required by Union/Member State law; if so required, processor must inform controller before processing unless prohibited on important public interest grounds. Quote: "only on documented instructions... unless required...; in such a case, the processor shall inform the controller... unless that law prohibits such information on important grounds of public interest" (para. 3(a)).

Processor must ensure persons authorised to process personal data have committed to confidentiality or are under appropriate statutory confidentiality obligation. Quote: "have committed themselves to confidentiality or are under an appropriate statutory obligation" (para. 3(b)).
Processor must take all measures required pursuant to Article 32. Quote: "takes all measures required pursuant to Article 32" (para. 3(c)).
