Processor must respect conditions for engaging another processor as in paragraphs 2 and 4. Quote: "respects the conditions referred to in paragraphs 2 and 4" (para. 3(d)).

Processor must assist controller (taking into account nature of processing) by appropriate technical and organisational measures, insofar as possible, to fulfil controller obligation to respond to data subject rights requests under Chapter III. Quote: "assists the controller... insofar as this is possible" (para. 3(e)).

Processor must assist controller in ensuring compliance with obligations pursuant to Articles 32 to 36, considering nature of processing and information available to processor. Quote: "assists the controller in ensuring compliance with the obligations pursuant to Articles 32 to 36" (para. 3(f)).

At controllerâ€™s choice, processor must delete or return all personal data after end of services relating to processing, and delete existing copies unless Union/Member State law requires storage. Quote: "at the choice of the controller, deletes or returns... and deletes existing copies unless... law requires storage" (para. 3(g)).

Processor must make available to controller all information necessary to demonstrate compliance with Article 28 obligations and allow for and contribute to audits, including inspections, conducted by controller or auditor mandated by controller. Quote: "makes available... and allow for and contribute to audits, including inspections" (para. 3(h)).

Processor must immediately inform controller if, in its opinion, an instruction infringes GDPR or other Union/Member State data protection provisions. Quote: "shall immediately inform the controller if, in its opinion, an instruction infringes" (following para. 3(h)).

When engaging a sub-processor for specific processing activities, processor must impose the same data protection obligations as in the controller-processor contract/legal act on the sub-processor via contract/legal act under Union/Member State law, including providing sufficient guarantees for appropriate technical and organisational measures to meet GDPR requirements. Quote: "the same data protection obligations... shall be imposed... in particular providing sufficient guarantees" (para. 4).
Initial processor remains fully liable to controller for performance of sub-processor obligations if sub-processor fails. Quote: "the initial processor shall remain fully liable" (para. 4).
Contract/legal act referred to in paragraphs 3 and 4 must be in writing, including electronic form. Quote: "shall be in writing, including in electronic form" (para. 9).

If a processor infringes GDPR by determining purposes and means of processing, the processor shall be considered a controller in respect of that processing. Quote: "shall be considered to be a controller in respect of that processing" (para. 10).
prohibited_actions: Processor must not engage another processor without prior written authorisation (specific or general) from controller. Quote: "shall not engage another processor without prior specific or general written authorisation" (para. 2).

Processor must not process personal data beyond documented controller instructions, except where required by Union/Member State law. Quote: "processes the personal data only on documented instructions... unless required" (para. 3(a)).
conditional_requirements: If general written authorisation for sub-processors is granted, processor must notify controller of intended additions/replacements to allow objection (para. 2).

If processor is required by Union/Member State law to process contrary to controller instructions (including transfers), processor must inform controller of that legal requirement before processing unless the law prohibits informing on important public interest grounds (para. 3(a)).
Assistance obligations are conditioned by: (i) nature of processing; (ii) feasibility ('insofar as this is possible'); and (iii) information available to processor (paras. 3(e), 3(f)).
End-of-service deletion/return is at controllerâ€™s choice; deletion of copies is required unless Union/Member State law requires storage (para. 3(g)).
Use of approved code of conduct (Art. 40) or approved certification mechanism (Art. 42) may be used as an element to demonstrate sufficient guarantees (para. 5).
Contract/legal act may be based in whole or part on standard contractual clauses (paras. 6â€“8), including when part of certification granted under Arts. 42 and 43 (para. 6).
Processor becomes considered a controller only if it determines purposes and means of processing (para. 10).
documentation_requirements: A binding contract or other legal act under Union/Member State law must exist and must set out: subject-matter, duration, nature, purpose, type of personal data, categories of data subjects, and controller obligations/rights (para. 3).
Controller instructions must be 'documented' (para. 3(a)).
Written authorisation (specific or general) from controller is required for engaging sub-processors (para. 2).
Contract/legal act must be in writing, including electronic form (para. 9).
Processor must make available information necessary to demonstrate compliance (para. 3(h)).
reporting_requirements: Under general authorisation for sub-processors, processor must inform controller of intended changes (addition/replacement) to enable objection (para. 2).

If processing is required by Union/Member State law contrary to controller instructions, processor must inform controller of the legal requirement before processing unless prohibited on important public interest grounds (para. 3(a)).
Processor must immediately inform controller if it believes an instruction infringes GDPR or other Union/Member State data protection provisions (post-para. 3(h)).
timeline_requirements: Processor must inform controller of legal requirement 'before processing' when relying on Union/Member State law exception (para. 3(a)).
Processor must 'immediately' inform controller if it believes an instruction infringes GDPR/other data protection provisions (post-para. 3(h)).
After end of provision of services relating to processing, processor must delete or return personal data (at controllerâ€™s choice) and delete copies unless storage required by law (para. 3(g)).
Under general authorisation, processor must inform controller of 'any intended changes' concerning addition/replacement of sub-processors (para. 2) (no specific minimum notice period stated).

general_restrictions: Controller restriction: may only use processors with 'sufficient guarantees' of appropriate technical and organisational measures (para. 1).
Processor restriction: may only process on documented controller instructions, subject to legal requirement exception (para. 3(a)).
Processor restriction: cannot appoint sub-processors without controllerâ€™s prior written authorisation (para. 2).
data_restrictions: Processing limited to controllerâ€™s documented instructions, including instructions about transfers to third countries/international organisations (para. 3(a)).
End-of-service requirement to delete/return all personal data and delete copies unless law requires storage (para. 3(g)).
operational_restrictions: Sub-processing chain must be controlled via authorisation and flow-down contractual obligations (paras. 2 and 4).
Processor must allow and contribute to audits/inspections by controller or mandated auditor (para. 3(h)).
technical_restrictions: Processor must implement measures required by Article 32 (para. 3(c)) (specific measures not enumerated here).
Processor must provide appropriate technical and organisational measures to assist with data subject rights requests (para. 3(e)).
geographic_restrictions: Transfers to third countries/international organisations are covered within the instruction limitation: processor may transfer only on documented controller instructions unless required by Union/Member State law (para. 3(a)).

individual_rights: Indirectly supports data subject rights in Chapter III by requiring processor assistance to controller in responding to requests to exercise those rights (para. 3(e)).
organizational_rights: Controller right to object to intended changes in sub-processors under general authorisation (para. 2).
Controller right to choose deletion or return of personal data at end of services (para. 3(g)).
Controller right to receive information necessary to demonstrate processor compliance and to conduct audits/inspections (para. 3(h)).
how_to_exercise_rights: Controller exercises objection right by receiving notice of intended sub-processor changes and objecting (procedure details not specified) (para. 2).
Controller exercises end-of-service choice by instructing processor to delete or return data (para. 3(g)).
Controller exercises audit right by conducting or mandating audits/inspections and requesting compliance information (para. 3(h)).

general_exceptions: Processor may process contrary to controller instructions where required by Union or Member State law to which the processor is subject (para. 3(a)).
conditional_exemptions: Processorâ€™s duty to inform controller of the legal requirement before processing does not apply where the law prohibits such information on important grounds of public interest (para. 3(a)).
Deletion of copies after end of services is not required where Union/Member State law requires storage of the personal data (para. 3(g)).
public_interest_exceptions: Law may prohibit informing the controller of the legal requirement on 'important grounds of public interest' (para. 3(a)).

technical_measures: Implement 'all measures required pursuant to Article 32' (para. 3(c)).
Provide 'appropriate technical and organisational measures' to assist controller with responding to data subject rights requests, insofar as possible (para. 3(e)).
organizational_measures: Ensure selection/engagement processes verify 'sufficient guarantees' from processors/sub-processors (paras. 1 and 4).
Maintain documented instruction handling and escalation where instructions may infringe GDPR/other data protection provisions (para. 3(a) and post-para. 3(h)).
Put in place sub-processor onboarding/change management with controller authorisation and objection handling (para. 2).
Establish end-of-service data return/deletion procedures aligned to controller choice and legal retention requirements (para. 3(g)).
Enable audit cooperation processes and information provision to controller (para. 3(h)).
security_measures: Article 32 measures are required (para. 3(c)) (not detailed in this section).
Confidentiality controls: ensure authorized persons are bound by confidentiality commitments or statutory obligations (para. 3(b)).
training_requirements: Implied need to ensure authorized persons understand and comply with confidentiality obligations (para. 3(b)); explicit training requirement not stated.
audit_requirements: Processor must 'allow for and contribute to audits, including inspections' by controller or mandated auditor (para. 3(h)).
Processor must provide information necessary to demonstrate compliance with Article 28 obligations (para. 3(h)).
certification_requirements: No mandatory certification; however, adherence to an approved code of conduct (Art. 40) or approved certification mechanism (Art. 42) may be used as an element to demonstrate sufficient guarantees (para. 5).

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authorities (implied by reference to supervisory authority adoption of standard contractual clauses in para. 8; enforcement details not specified in this section).
enforcement_mechanisms: Controller audits/inspections and information requests as accountability mechanism (para. 3(h)).
Liability allocation: initial processor remains fully liable for sub-processor failures (para. 4).
Role reclassification: processor treated as controller if it determines purposes and means (para. 10).

related_articles: Article 32 (Security of processing) (referenced in para. 3(c) and 3(f))
Chapter III (Data subject rights) (referenced in para. 3(e))
Article 82 (Right to compensation and liability) (referenced in para. 10)
Article 83 (General conditions for imposing administrative fines) (referenced in para. 10)
complementary_regulations: Union or Member State law governing binding legal acts/contracts (paras. 3 and 4)

implementation_steps: Controller: perform due diligence to verify processor 'sufficient guarantees' (para. 1), including security posture and organizational controls.

Execute a written (including electronic) controller-processor agreement/legal act containing all mandatory elements (paras. 3 and 9), including detailed processing description and required clauses (a)â€“(h).
Establish documented instruction procedures, including for international transfers, and a process for processor to flag potentially unlawful instructions immediately (para. 3(a) and post-para. 3(h)).

Implement sub-processor governance: obtain prior written authorisation; if general authorisation, implement change notification and objection workflow; ensure flow-down of identical obligations to sub-processors via contract/legal act (paras. 2 and 4).
Implement confidentiality controls for authorized personnel (para. 3(b)).
Implement Article 32 security measures and be prepared to evidence them (para. 3(c) and 3(h)).
Set up operational support to assist controller with data subject rights requests and compliance with Articles 32â€“36 (paras. 3(e) and 3(f)).
Define end-of-service data handling: deletion/return options, secure deletion, and lawful retention exceptions (para. 3(g)).
Prepare audit readiness: maintain compliance documentation and support audits/inspections (para. 3(h)).
Assess processing activities to ensure processor does not determine purposes/means; if it does, treat as controller for that processing and apply controller obligations accordingly (para. 10).
common_violations: Engaging sub-processors without prior written controller authorisation (para. 2).
Failing to notify controller of sub-processor changes under general authorisation, removing controllerâ€™s opportunity to object (para. 2).
Missing mandatory clauses in the processor contract/legal act (para. 3(a)â€“(h)).
Processing beyond documented controller instructions (para. 3(a)).
Not ensuring confidentiality commitments/statutory obligations for staff (para. 3(b)).
Not enabling or obstructing controller audits/inspections or failing to provide compliance information (para. 3(h)).
Failing to delete/return data at end of services or retaining copies without legal basis (para. 3(g)).
Failing to flow down equivalent obligations to sub-processors and/or not ensuring sufficient guarantees (para. 4).
best_practices: Maintain a sub-processor register and a formal change-notification process aligned to controller objection rights (para. 2).
Use standardized Article 28 addenda with clear annexes for processing details (subject-matter, duration, nature/purpose, data types, data subjects) (para. 3).
Implement an 'instruction challenge' procedure to promptly escalate suspected unlawful instructions and document communications (post-para. 3(h)).
Adopt audit support playbooks (evidence packs, security reports, policies) to satisfy information and audit cooperation duties (para. 3(h)).
Define data return/deletion SOPs with verification and legal hold/retention exception handling (para. 3(g)).
Consider approved codes of conduct/certification as supporting evidence of guarantees (para. 5), while still performing due diligence.
compliance_checklist: Controller has assessed and documented processor 'sufficient guarantees' (para. 1).
Written (including electronic) contract/legal act exists and includes all required processing descriptors (para. 3) and is in writing (para. 9).

Contract includes clauses (a)â€“(h), including instruction limitation, confidentiality, Article 32 measures, sub-processing conditions, assistance duties, deletion/return, and audit cooperation (para. 3).
Sub-processor engagement is covered by prior written authorisation; general authorisation includes change notification and objection opportunity (para. 2).
Sub-processor contracts flow down the same obligations and sufficient guarantees; liability understanding documented (para. 4).
Process exists to inform controller before processing when compelled by law (unless prohibited) (para. 3(a)).
Process exists to immediately inform controller of suspected infringing instructions (post-para. 3(h)).
End-of-service deletion/return process implemented with lawful retention exception handling (para. 3(g)).
Audit readiness: information provision and audit/inspection cooperation procedures in place (para. 3(h)).
Governance ensures processor does not determine purposes/means; if it does, controller obligations are triggered for that processing (para. 10).

key_definitions.sufficient guarantees: Not defined in this section; used as a standard requiring processors/sub-processors to be able to implement appropriate technical and organisational measures so processing meets GDPR requirements and protects data subject rights (paras. 1 and 4).
key_definitions.documented instructions: Instructions from the controller that are recorded in a documented form; processor must process only on such instructions, including for transfers (para. 3(a)).
key_definitions.general written authorisation: Controllerâ€™s written permission allowing the processor to engage sub-processors generally, subject to the processor informing the controller of intended changes and allowing objection (para. 2).
key_definitions.contract or other legal act: A binding instrument under Union or Member State law governing processor processing on behalf of controller and containing specified minimum terms (paras. 3 and 4).

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 29 (Processing under the authority of the controller or processor)

applicable_regions: EEA (via incorporation into EEA law, where applicable)

description.brief_summary: Persons with access to personal data who act under the authority of the controller or processor are prohibited from processing personal data except on the controllerâ€™s instructions, unless Union or Member State law requires the processing.
description.detailed_explanation: The provision establishes a default rule and a narrow exception. Default rule: the processor and any person acting under the authority of the controller or processor who has access to personal data may process that data only when acting on the controllerâ€™s instructions. This creates an instruction-bound processing model and restricts discretionary processing by staff, contractors, and other authorized persons. Exception: if a Union or Member State law requires processing, the instruction limitation does not apply to the extent of that legal requirement. The condition is tied to (1) access to personal data, (2) acting under the authority of the controller or processor, and (3) processing activity. The rule functions as an internal governance and access/authorization control requirement: access alone does not permit processing; processing must be instruction-based unless legally mandated otherwise.
description.purpose: To ensure that personal data is processed only under the controllerâ€™s direction and to prevent unauthorized or self-directed processing by processors or individuals acting under the controller/processorâ€™s authority, while allowing compliance with binding legal obligations under Union or Member State law.
description.legislative_intent: To reinforce accountability and control over processing operations by anchoring processing authority in the controllerâ€™s instructions and limiting the processorâ€™s and authorized personsâ€™ autonomy, thereby reducing unauthorized processing and ensuring lawful processing aligned with the controllerâ€™s determined purposes.

what_it_covers: Processing of personal data by the processor
Processing of personal data by any person acting under the authority of the controller
Processing of personal data by any person acting under the authority of the processor
Situations where such persons have access to personal data
Deviation from controller instructions when required by Union or Member State law

target_entities: Controllers (indirectly, as the source of instructions)
Individuals acting under the authority of the controller
Individuals acting under the authority of the processor
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies within the GDPRâ€™s territorial scope; the section itself specifies Union or Member State law as the legal sources for the exception.

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing by persons who do not have access to personal data
Processing by persons not acting under the authority of the controller or processor
Non-personal data processing

mandatory_obligations: Ensure that the processor does not process personal data except on instructions from the controller (quote: "shall not process those data except on instructions from the controller").

Ensure that any person acting under the authority of the controller who has access to personal data does not process personal data except on instructions from the controller (quote: "any person acting under the authority of the controller ... who has access to personal data, shall not process those data except on instructions from the controller").

Ensure that any person acting under the authority of the processor who has access to personal data does not process personal data except on instructions from the controller (quote: "any person acting under the authority ... of the processor, who has access to personal data, shall not process those data except on instructions from the controller").
prohibited_actions: Processing personal data by the processor without controller instructions, unless required by Union or Member State law (quote: "shall not process those data except on instructions from the controller").

Processing personal data by persons acting under the authority of the controller or processor without controller instructions, unless required by Union or Member State law (quote: "shall not process those data except on instructions from the controller").
conditional_requirements: If processing is required by Union or Member State law, the prohibition on processing without controller instructions does not apply to the extent of that legal requirement (quote: "unless required to do so by Union or Member State law").

general_restrictions: Instruction-only processing: processing is restricted to what the controller instructs, except where law requires otherwise.
data_restrictions: Restriction applies to "personal data" accessed by the processor or persons acting under authority.
operational_restrictions: Limits operational discretion of processors and authorized persons; they cannot independently determine or expand processing beyond controller instructions.
geographic_restrictions: Exception is limited to requirements imposed by "Union or Member State law" (not other non-EU legal sources, as stated).

organizational_rights: Controllerâ€™s right to have processing carried out only on its instructions, subject to overriding legal requirements.

general_exceptions: Processing without controller instructions is permitted when it is "required to do so by Union or Member State law" (quote: "unless required to do so by Union or Member State law").
conditional_exemptions: The instruction limitation is lifted only to the extent necessary to comply with the Union or Member State legal requirement.

organizational_measures: Establish and enforce an instruction-based processing governance model for processors and authorized persons with access to personal data, ensuring they process only on controller instructions except where Union/Member State law requires otherwise.

implementation_steps: Define and communicate controller instructions governing permitted processing activities for processors and authorized persons with access to personal data.
Restrict processing activities by authorized persons to those instructions; prevent discretionary processing outside instructions.
Identify scenarios where Union or Member State law requires processing and ensure processing aligns with that legal requirement even if not covered by controller instructions.
common_violations: Processor staff using accessible personal data for purposes not covered by controller instructions.
Authorized persons processing personal data based on internal convenience rather than controller instructions.
Treating access to personal data as permission to process without verifying controller instructions or legal mandate.
best_practices: Maintain clear, role-specific instructions for processing activities and ensure authorized persons understand that processing must follow controller instructions unless legally required otherwise.
compliance_checklist: Do all persons acting under controller/processor authority with access to personal data have clear controller instructions governing their processing?
Are there controls to prevent processing outside controller instructions?
Is there a process to identify and handle processing required by Union or Member State law?

keywords: Union or Member State law requirement
regulations.source_section: ## Processing under the authority of the controller or processor

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 30 (Records of processing activities)

applicable_regions: European Economic Area (as incorporated by EEA states, where applicable)

description.brief_summary: Requires controllers and processors (and where applicable their representatives) to keep written records of processing activities containing specified minimum information, and to provide those records to the supervisory authority on request, with a limited exemption for organizations under 250 persons unless certain conditions apply.
description.detailed_explanation: The provision imposes an accountability documentation duty. Controllers must maintain a record of processing activities under their responsibility containing a defined set of data points (identity/contact details, purposes, categories of data subjects and personal data, recipients including third-country/international organization recipients, transfer details and safeguards documentation in certain Article 49(1) cases, envisaged erasure time limits where possible, and a general description of Article 32(1) security measures where possible). Processors must maintain a record of all categories of processing carried out on behalf of each controller, including identity/contact details of processor(s) and each controller, categories of processing, transfer details and safeguards documentation in certain Article 49(1) cases, and a general description of Article 32(1) security measures where possible. Records must be in writing (including electronic form). Controllers/processors (and where applicable their representatives) must make the record available to the supervisory authority upon request. A size-based exemption applies to enterprises/organisations employing fewer than 250 persons, but the exemption is removed if processing is likely to result in a risk to rights and freedoms, is not occasional, or includes special categories of data (Article 9(1)) or criminal conviction/offence data (Article 10).
description.purpose: To operationalize the GDPR accountability principle by ensuring organizations can demonstrate and evidence their processing activities, including key risk-relevant attributes such as transfers, retention, recipients, and security measures.
description.legislative_intent: To create a standardized minimum documentation baseline enabling supervisory authorities to verify compliance and enabling organizations to map and manage processing, particularly where processing presents risks or involves sensitive/criminal data or non-occasional operations.

what_it_covers: Maintaining records of processing activities by controllers
Maintaining records of processing activities by processors on behalf of controllers
Minimum required contents of those records
Form of records (written, including electronic)
Obligation to provide records to supervisory authority upon request
Size-based exemption and its conditions

entity_types: Any organization acting as controller or processor
who_it_applies_to.size_thresholds: Exemption potentially applies to an enterprise or organisation employing fewer than 250 persons, unless specified conditions apply.
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies within GDPR territorial scope; includes representatives where applicable (implying applicability to certain non-EU entities required to appoint a representative).

what_it_does_not_cover: Penalties or fine amounts for non-compliance (not stated in this section)
Detailed content of Article 32(1) security measures (only requires a general description by reference)
Detailed rules for international transfer mechanisms beyond the requirement to document suitable safeguards in certain Article 49(1) cases

mandatory_obligations: Controllers must maintain a record of processing activities under their responsibility. Quote: "Each controller and, where applicable, the controller's representative, shall maintain a record of processing activities under its responsibility."

Processors must maintain a record of all categories of processing activities carried out on behalf of a controller. Quote: "Each processor and, where applicable, the processor's representative shall maintain a record of all categories of processing activities carried out on behalf of a controller"
Records must be in writing, including electronic form. Quote: "The records referred to in paragraphs 1 and 2 shall be in writing, including in electronic form."

Controllers/processors (and where applicable their representatives) must make the record available to the supervisory authority on request. Quote: "shall make the record available to the supervisory authority on request."
conditional_requirements: Controller record must include joint controller details where applicable. Quote: "the name and contact details of the controller and, where applicable, the joint controller"
Controller record must include controller representative details where applicable. Quote: "the controller's representative"
Controller record must include DPO details where applicable/where present. Quote: "and the data protection officer"

Controller record must include transfers to third countries/international organisations where applicable. Quote: "where applicable, transfers of personal data to a third country or an international organisation"

For certain Article 49(1) transfers (second subparagraph), controller/processor records must include documentation of suitable safeguards. Quote: "and, in the case of transfers referred to in the second subparagraph of Article 49(1), the documentation of suitable safeguards"
Controller record must include envisaged time limits for erasure where possible. Quote: "where possible, the envisaged time limits for erasure"

Controller and processor records must include a general description of technical and organisational security measures (Article 32(1)) where possible. Quote: "where possible, a general description of the technical and organisational security measures referred to in Article 32(1)."

Size-based exemption does not apply (i.e., obligations still apply) to <250-person enterprises/organisations if any of the listed conditions are met. Quote: "shall not apply ... unless" followed by conditions.
documentation_requirements: Controller ROPA must contain: (a) "the name and contact details of the controller and, where applicable, the joint controller, the controller's representative and the data protection officer"
Controller ROPA must contain: (b) "the purposes of the processing"
Controller ROPA must contain: (c) "a description of the categories of data subjects and of the categories of personal data"
Controller ROPA must contain: (d) "the categories of recipients to whom the personal data have been or will be disclosed including recipients in third countries or international organisations"

Controller ROPA must contain: (e) "where applicable, transfers of personal data to a third country or an international organisation, including the identification of that third country or international organisation and, in the case of transfers referred to in the second subparagraph of Article 49(1), the documentation of suitable safeguards"
Controller ROPA must contain: (f) "where possible, the envisaged time limits for erasure of the different categories of data"
Controller ROPA must contain: (g) "where possible, a general description of the technical and organisational security measures referred to in Article 32(1)."

Processor ROPA must contain: (a) "the name and contact details of the processor or processors and of each controller on behalf of which the processor is acting, and, where applicable, of the controller's or the processor's representative, and the data protection officer"
Processor ROPA must contain: (b) "the categories of processing carried out on behalf of each controller"

Processor ROPA must contain: (c) "where applicable, transfers of personal data to a third country or an international organisation, including the identification of that third country or international organisation and, in the case of transfers referred to in the second subparagraph of Article 49(1), the documentation of suitable safeguards"
Processor ROPA must contain: (d) "where possible, a general description of the technical and organisational security measures referred to in Article 32(1)."
Records must be maintained "in writing, including in electronic form" (format requirement).
reporting_requirements: Provide/make available the record to the supervisory authority upon request. Quote: "shall make the record available to the supervisory authority on request."
timeline_requirements: No explicit fixed deadlines are stated for creation/update; however, the obligation is ongoing to "maintain" records.
Controller record should include "envisaged time limits for erasure" where possible (retention/erasure planning requirement, but not a specific numeric deadline).

general_restrictions: Organizations cannot rely on the <250-person exemption if processing meets any of the specified conditions (risk, non-occasional, special category data, or criminal conviction/offence data).
data_restrictions: If processing includes special categories of data (Article 9(1)) or criminal conviction/offence data (Article 10), the <250-person exemption is unavailable, meaning record-keeping obligations apply.
operational_restrictions: Must be able to produce records to supervisory authority upon request (implies operational readiness to retrieve and provide records).
technical_restrictions: Records must be "in writing, including in electronic form" (i.e., must exist as documented artifacts; purely informal/undocumented knowledge is insufficient).
geographic_restrictions: Records must include recipients in third countries/international organisations and identify third countries/international organisations for transfers where applicable.

general_exceptions: Obligations in paragraphs 1 and 2 do not apply to an enterprise or an organisation employing fewer than 250 persons, subject to the listed conditions. Quote: "shall not apply to an enterprise or an organisation employing fewer than 250 persons unless..."
conditional_exemptions: The <250-person exemption is lost if: (i) "the processing it carries out is likely to result in a risk to the rights and freedoms of data subjects"; or (ii) "the processing is not occasional"; or (iii) "the processing includes special categories of data as referred to in Article 9(1)"; or (iv) includes "personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences referred to in Article 10."
size_based_exceptions: Enterprises/organisations employing fewer than 250 persons are exempt unless one of the specified conditions applies.

technical_measures: Maintain records in a durable written format, including electronic form (e.g., database, spreadsheet, GRC tool), sufficient to capture all required fields.
organizational_measures: Establish and operate a process to maintain (create, update, and govern) controller and/or processor records of processing activities.
Ensure role-based responsibility for record maintenance (controller/processor and where applicable representatives; include DPO contact details in the record).
Ensure capability to respond to supervisory authority requests by retrieving and providing the record.
security_measures: Include (where possible) a general description of technical and organisational security measures referred to in Article 32(1) within the record.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authority (as referenced in the section).
enforcement_mechanisms: Supervisory authority may request the record; organization must make it available "on request".

related_articles: GDPR Article 32(1) (security measures referenced for inclusion as a general description in the record)
GDPR Article 49(1) second subparagraph (transfers requiring documentation of suitable safeguards in the record)
GDPR Article 9(1) (special categories of data referenced for exemption condition)
GDPR Article 10 (criminal convictions and offences data referenced for exemption condition)

implementation_steps: Determine whether the organization acts as controller, processor, or both for each processing activity.

Create a controller ROPA template capturing items (a)â€“(g) exactly as required, including recipients (including third-country/international organisation recipients), transfer identification, and (where applicable) Article 49(1) safeguards documentation.
Create a processor ROPA template capturing items (a)â€“(d), ensuring it is organized per controller ("on behalf of each controller").
Ensure the record is maintained in writing (electronic acceptable) and is kept current as processing changes.
Assess whether the <250-person exemption is available; if any condition applies (risk, non-occasional, special category data, criminal data), implement full ROPA obligations.
Implement a procedure to provide the record to the supervisory authority promptly upon request.
common_violations: Failing to maintain any written/electronic ROPA.
Omitting required fields (e.g., categories of recipients, purposes, categories of data subjects/personal data).
Failing to identify third countries/international organisations for transfers where applicable.
Failing to document suitable safeguards for transfers referred to in the second subparagraph of Article 49(1) where applicable.
Relying on the <250-person exemption despite non-occasional processing or processing special category/criminal data.
Inability to produce the record to the supervisory authority upon request.
best_practices: Maintain separate but linked controller and processor records where the organization has dual roles.
Use standardized fields aligned to (a)â€“(g) and (a)â€“(d) to ensure completeness.
Maintain an index of processing activities and map each to recipients, transfers, retention/erasure timelines, and security measure summaries.
compliance_checklist: Controller: record exists for processing under its responsibility.

Controller record includes: identity/contact details (controller, joint controller where applicable, representative where applicable, DPO), purposes, categories of data subjects, categories of personal data, categories of recipients (including third-country/international organisation recipients), transfer details (where applicable) including identification and Article 49(1) safeguards documentation where applicable, envisaged erasure time limits where possible, general description of Article 32(1) measures where possible.
Processor: record exists for all categories of processing on behalf of controllers.

Processor record includes: identity/contact details (processor(s), each controller, representatives where applicable, DPO), categories of processing per controller, transfer details (where applicable) including identification and Article 49(1) safeguards documentation where applicable, general description of Article 32(1) measures where possible.
Records are in writing (electronic acceptable).
Process exists to provide records to supervisory authority on request.
If <250 persons: exemption assessed; if risk/non-occasional/special category/criminal data applies, ROPA maintained.

key_definitions.record of processing activities: A written (including electronic) record maintained by a controller (for processing under its responsibility) or by a processor (for processing carried out on behalf of controllers) containing the minimum information specified in this section.
key_definitions.categories of recipients: The types/classes of entities to whom personal data have been or will be disclosed, explicitly including recipients in third countries or international organisations.
key_definitions.envisaged time limits for erasure: Planned/anticipated retention/erasure periods for different categories of personal data, to be included where possible.
key_definitions.documentation of suitable safeguards: Recorded evidence of appropriate safeguards for certain transfers referenced in the second subparagraph of Article 49(1), required to be included in the record where applicable.

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 32 (Security of processing)

applicable_regions: European Economic Area (via incorporation into EEA law where applicable)

description.brief_summary: Requires controllers and processors to implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to ensure security of personal data processing proportionate to risk, and to control how authorized persons process personal data.
description.detailed_explanation: The provision mandates a risk-based approach to security of processing. Controllers and processors must consider (i) state of the art, (ii) implementation costs, (iii) nature/scope/context/purposes of processing, and (iv) risks to individualsâ€™ rights and freedoms (likelihood and severity). Based on this assessment, they must implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to ensure a security level appropriate to the risk. The article provides a non-exhaustive list of measures that may be appropriate: pseudonymisation and encryption; ensuring ongoing confidentiality, integrity, availability, and resilience of systems/services; ability to restore availability and access to personal data in a timely manner after incidents; and a process for regular testing/assessment/evaluation of measure effectiveness. It further specifies that security level assessment must particularly consider risks from accidental or unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorised disclosure of, or access to personal data (whether transmitted, stored, or otherwise processed). It allows adherence to an approved code of conduct (Art. 40) or approved certification mechanism (Art. 42) as an element to demonstrate compliance with paragraph 1. Finally, it requires controllers and processors to ensure that any natural person acting under their authority who has access to personal data processes it only on controller instructions, unless Union or Member State law requires otherwise.
description.purpose: To protect personal data against security risks and to reduce the likelihood and impact of harm to individualsâ€™ rights and freedoms arising from insecure processing.
description.legislative_intent: To impose a flexible, risk-based security obligation on both controllers and processors, ensuring security measures evolve with technology and risk, and to create accountability mechanisms (testing, evaluation, and optional assurance via codes/certification).

what_it_covers: Implementation of technical and organisational security measures for personal data processing
Risk assessment considerations for determining appropriate security level
Security properties to be maintained (confidentiality, integrity, availability, resilience)
Incident recovery capability (restoration of availability/access)
Ongoing assurance activities (regular testing, assessing, evaluating effectiveness)
Use of approved codes of conduct/certification as compliance evidence
Controls over processing by persons under authority with access to personal data (instruction-based processing)

target_entities: Natural persons acting under the authority of the controller or processor (as controlled actors)
entity_types: Any organization acting as controller or processor
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies within GDPR territorial scope; this section itself does not specify territorial criteria.

what_it_does_not_cover: This section does not specify exact technical standards, algorithms, or minimum control baselines; it requires appropriateness to risk.
This section does not set explicit breach notification duties or timelines (those are addressed elsewhere in GDPR).
This section does not define 'state of the art' or prescribe a specific risk assessment methodology.

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to ensure a level of security appropriate to the risk.
conditions_or_factors_to_consider: â€œTaking into account the state of the artâ€
â€œthe nature, scope, context and purposes of processingâ€
â€œthe risk of varying likelihood and severity for the rights and freedoms of natural personsâ€
mandatory_obligations.exact_quote: â€œthe controller and the processor shall implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to ensure a level of security appropriate to the riskâ€

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Where appropriate, include pseudonymisation and encryption of personal data as part of security measures.
mandatory_obligations.exact_quote: â€œincluding inter alia as appropriate: (a) the pseudonymisation and encryption of personal data;â€

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Ensure the ongoing confidentiality, integrity, availability and resilience of processing systems and services (where appropriate).
mandatory_obligations.exact_quote: â€œ(b) the ability to ensure the ongoing confidentiality, integrity, availability and resilience of processing systems and services;â€

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Ensure the ability to restore availability and access to personal data in a timely manner in the event of a physical or technical incident (where appropriate).
mandatory_obligations.exact_quote: â€œ(c) the ability to restore the availability and access to personal data in a timely manner in the event of a physical or technical incident;â€

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Maintain a process for regularly testing, assessing and evaluating the effectiveness of technical and organisational measures for ensuring security of processing (where appropriate).
mandatory_obligations.exact_quote: â€œ(d) a process for regularly testing, assessing and evaluating the effectiveness of technical and organisational measures for ensuring the security of the processing.â€

mandatory_obligations.obligation: When assessing appropriate security level, take account in particular of risks presented by processing, especially risks from accidental or unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorised disclosure of, or access to personal data (transmitted, stored or otherwise processed).
mandatory_obligations.exact_quote: â€œIn assessing the appropriate level of security account shall be taken in particular of the risks that are presented by processing, in particular from accidental or unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorised disclosure of, or access to personal data transmitted, stored or otherwise processed.â€

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Take steps to ensure that any natural person acting under their authority who has access to personal data does not process them except on instructions from the controller, unless required by Union or Member State law.
mandatory_obligations.exact_quote: â€œThe controller and processor shall take steps to ensure that any natural person acting under the authority of the controller or the processor who has access to personal data does not process them except on instructions from the controller, unless he or she is required to do so by Union or Member State law.â€

prohibited_actions.actor: Any natural person acting under the authority of the controller or processor who has access to personal data
prohibited_actions.prohibition: Must not process personal data except on instructions from the controller, unless required by Union or Member State law.
prohibited_actions.exact_quote: â€œdoes not process them except on instructions from the controller, unless he or she is required to do so by Union or Member State law.â€

conditional_requirements.condition: Determining appropriate measures is risk-based and must consider state of the art, costs, and processing context/purposes and risk likelihood/severity.
conditional_requirements.requirement: Select and implement measures appropriate to the risk; listed measures apply â€œas appropriateâ€.
conditional_requirements.exact_quote: â€œTaking into account the state of the art, the costs of implementation and the nature, scope, context and purposes of processing as well as the risk of varying likelihood and severityâ€¦â€; â€œincluding inter alia as appropriateâ€

conditional_requirements.condition: In the event of a physical or technical incident
conditional_requirements.requirement: Be able to restore availability and access to personal data in a timely manner.
conditional_requirements.exact_quote: â€œin the event of a physical or technical incidentâ€ and â€œin a timely mannerâ€

conditional_requirements.condition: Where an approved code of conduct (Art. 40) or approved certification mechanism (Art. 42) exists and is adhered to
conditional_requirements.requirement: May use adherence as an element to demonstrate compliance with paragraph 1.
conditional_requirements.exact_quote: â€œmay be used as an element by which to demonstrate compliance with the requirements set out in paragraph 1â€

conditional_requirements.condition: Where Union or Member State law requires processing by a person under authority
conditional_requirements.requirement: Processing may occur without controller instruction to the extent required by such law.
conditional_requirements.exact_quote: â€œunless he or she is required to do so by Union or Member State law.â€

timeline_requirements.requirement: Restoration must be â€œin a timely mannerâ€ after a physical or technical incident.

general_restrictions: Security measures must be appropriate to risk and determined considering state of the art, costs, and processing context/purposes and risk likelihood/severity.
data_restrictions: Personal data must be protected against accidental or unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorised disclosure, or unauthorised access (for data transmitted, stored, or otherwise processed).
operational_restrictions: Persons under authority with access to personal data are restricted to processing only on controller instructions unless legally required otherwise.
technical_restrictions: Where appropriate, implement pseudonymisation and encryption.
Maintain capabilities ensuring confidentiality, integrity, availability, resilience.
Maintain restoration capability after incidents.
Maintain regular testing/assessment/evaluation process.

organizational_rights.right: Ability to use adherence to an approved code of conduct (Art. 40) or approved certification mechanism (Art. 42) as an element to demonstrate compliance with Article 32(1).
organizational_rights.exact_quote: â€œmay be used as an element by which to demonstrate compliance with the requirements set out in paragraph 1â€

how_to_exercise_rights: Adhere to an approved code of conduct under Article 40 and/or obtain/adhere to an approved certification mechanism under Article 42, and use that adherence as evidence element for Article 32(1) compliance.

conditional_exemptions.exception: Processing by a person under authority without controller instruction is permitted when required by Union or Member State law.
conditional_exemptions.exact_quote: â€œunless he or she is required to do so by Union or Member State law.â€

technical_measures.exact_quote: â€œthe pseudonymisation â€¦ of personal dataâ€

technical_measures.measure: Capabilities to ensure ongoing confidentiality, integrity, availability, and resilience of processing systems and services (as appropriate).
technical_measures.exact_quote: â€œthe ability to ensure the ongoing confidentiality, integrity, availability and resilience of processing systems and servicesâ€

technical_measures.measure: Capabilities to restore availability and access to personal data in a timely manner after physical or technical incidents (as appropriate).
technical_measures.exact_quote: â€œthe ability to restore the availability and access to personal data in a timely manner in the event of a physical or technical incidentâ€

organizational_measures.measure: Risk-based selection of security measures considering state of the art, costs, and processing context/purposes and risk likelihood/severity.
organizational_measures.exact_quote: â€œTaking into account the state of the art, the costs of implementation and the nature, scope, context and purposes of processing as well as the riskâ€¦â€

organizational_measures.measure: Process to regularly test, assess, and evaluate effectiveness of technical and organisational measures.
organizational_measures.exact_quote: â€œa process for regularly testing, assessing and evaluating the effectivenessâ€¦â€

organizational_measures.measure: Steps to ensure persons under authority with access process only on controller instructions unless legally required otherwise.
organizational_measures.exact_quote: â€œshall take steps to ensure that any natural person acting under the authorityâ€¦ does not process them except on instructionsâ€¦â€

security_measures: Ensure a level of security appropriate to the risk.
Address risks including accidental/unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorised disclosure/access.

audit_requirements.requirement: Regular testing, assessing, and evaluating effectiveness of security measures (process-based assurance).
audit_requirements.exact_quote: â€œregularly testing, assessing and evaluating the effectivenessâ€

certification_requirements.requirement: Not mandatory; however, adherence to approved code of conduct (Art. 40) or approved certification mechanism (Art. 42) may be used to demonstrate compliance with Article 32(1).
certification_requirements.exact_quote: â€œmay be used as an element by which to demonstrate complianceâ€

related_articles: GDPR Article 40 (Codes of conduct) (referenced as demonstrating compliance element)
GDPR Article 42 (Certification) (referenced as demonstrating compliance element)

implementation_steps: Perform a security risk assessment considering: state of the art, implementation costs, nature/scope/context/purposes, and likelihood/severity of risks to individualsâ€™ rights and freedoms.
Select and implement appropriate technical and organisational measures aligned to identified risks.
Where appropriate, deploy pseudonymisation and encryption for personal data.
Implement controls to maintain ongoing confidentiality, integrity, availability, and resilience of processing systems/services.
Establish and maintain disaster recovery/business continuity capabilities to restore availability and access to personal data in a timely manner after physical/technical incidents.
Create a recurring assurance process to regularly test, assess, and evaluate the effectiveness of security measures.

Implement governance/access-control steps ensuring staff/authorized persons process personal data only on controller instructions, with a carve-out for legally required processing under Union/Member State law.
Optionally, adhere to an approved code of conduct (Art. 40) and/or approved certification mechanism (Art. 42) and use it as evidence supporting compliance with Article 32(1).
common_violations: Failing to implement risk-appropriate security measures (e.g., ignoring state of the art or processing risk profile).
No regular testing/assessment/evaluation of security controls.
Inability to restore availability/access to personal data in a timely manner after incidents.
Insufficient controls to ensure confidentiality/integrity/availability/resilience of systems and services.
Allowing personnel with access to personal data to process it without controller instructions and without a legal requirement.
best_practices: Document the risk-based rationale for chosen measures (even though documentation is not explicitly required in this section).
Implement layered security controls mapped to confidentiality, integrity, availability, and resilience objectives.
Test restoration procedures through exercises to validate â€œtimely mannerâ€ recovery capability.
Use independent assessments and continuous monitoring as part of the regular evaluation process.
Use approved codes of conduct/certifications as supporting evidence where available.
compliance_checklist: Have state-of-the-art and cost considerations been evaluated for security controls?
Have nature/scope/context/purposes and risk likelihood/severity been assessed for the processing?
Are appropriate technical and organisational measures implemented to achieve risk-appropriate security?
Are pseudonymisation and encryption implemented where appropriate?
Can the organization ensure ongoing confidentiality, integrity, availability, and resilience of processing systems/services?
Is there a tested capability to restore availability and access to personal data in a timely manner after physical/technical incidents?
Is there a defined process that regularly tests, assesses, and evaluates security measure effectiveness?
Are persons under authority with access restricted to processing only on controller instructions (unless legally required otherwise)?
If using codes of conduct/certification, are they approved under Art. 40/42 and is adherence maintained as evidence?

regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2016/679) â€” Article 33: Notification of a personal data breach to the supervisory authority

applicable_regions: European Economic Area (where GDPR applies via EEA incorporation)

description.brief_summary: Requires controllers to notify the competent supervisory authority of personal data breaches within strict timelines and with minimum prescribed content, imposes prompt breach escalation from processors to controllers, permits phased reporting where necessary, and mandates controller documentation of breaches to demonstrate compliance.
description.detailed_explanation: This section imposes a structured breach-notification regime. A controller must notify the competent supervisory authority of a personal data breach "without undue delay" and, where feasible, within 72 hours after becoming aware of the breach, unless the breach is unlikely to result in a risk to individuals' rights and freedoms. If notification is not made within 72 hours, the controller must provide reasons for the delay. Separately, a processor that becomes aware of a personal data breach must notify the controller without undue delay. The controllerâ€™s notification to the supervisory authority must include, at minimum, four categories of information: (a) a description of the nature of the breach including, where possible, categories and approximate numbers of affected data subjects and personal data records; (b) the name and contact details of the data protection officer (DPO) or other contact point; (c) the likely consequences of the breach; and (d) measures taken or proposed to address the breach, including mitigation measures where appropriate. Where it is not possible to provide all information at the same time, the controller may provide the information in phases, but must do so without undue further delay. Finally, the controller must document any personal data breaches, including the facts, effects, and remedial action taken, and the documentation must be sufficient to enable the supervisory authority to verify compliance with Article 33.
description.purpose: To ensure timely regulatory oversight of personal data breaches, enable supervisory authorities to assess risks and compliance, and promote accountability through documentation and structured incident handling.
description.legislative_intent: To create a harmonized EU-wide obligation for prompt breach reporting and recordkeeping, ensuring consistent supervisory authority awareness and enabling verification of compliance while focusing reporting on breaches that may pose risks to individuals.

what_it_covers: Notification of personal data breaches to the competent supervisory authority
Processor-to-controller breach notification escalation
Minimum content requirements for breach notifications
Phased provision of notification information when not immediately available
Controller documentation/recordkeeping of personal data breaches for compliance verification

entity_types: Any organization acting as controller or processor under GDPR
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies where GDPR applies; notification is to the supervisory authority competent in accordance with Article 55 (as referenced in the text).

what_it_does_not_cover: Breach notification to data subjects (not addressed in this section text)
Penalties and fine amounts (not stated in this section text)
Detailed criteria for determining supervisory authority competence beyond the reference to Article 55 (not detailed in this section text)

mandatory_obligations: Controller must notify the personal data breach to the competent supervisory authority "without undue delay" and, where feasible, "not later than 72 hours after having become aware of it" unless an exception applies. Quote: "the controller shall without undue delay and, where feasible, not later than 72 hours after having become aware of it, notify the personal data breach to the supervisory authority competent in accordance with Article 55".

If the controller does not notify within 72 hours, the notification must include reasons for the delay. Quote: "Where the notification to the supervisory authority is not made within 72 hours, it shall be accompanied by reasons for the delay."

Processor must notify the controller "without undue delay" after becoming aware of a personal data breach. Quote: "The processor shall notify the controller without undue delay after becoming aware of a personal data breach."
Controllerâ€™s notification must include at least the minimum content items (a)-(d). Quote: "The notification referred to in paragraph 1 shall at least:" followed by (a)-(d).

Controller must document any personal data breaches, including facts, effects, and remedial action taken. Quote: "The controller shall document any personal data breaches, comprising the facts relating to the personal data breach, its effects and the remedial action taken."
Documentation must enable supervisory authority to verify compliance. Quote: "That documentation shall enable the supervisory authority to verify compliance with this Article."
prohibited_actions: Failing to notify the supervisory authority within 72 hours where feasible and where the breach is not unlikely to result in risk to rights and freedoms (implied by mandatory obligation and exception structure).
Omitting required minimum notification content (a)-(d) (implied by "shall at least").
Failing to provide reasons for delay when notification is made after 72 hours (implied by "shall be accompanied").
Failing to document breaches with required elements sufficient for supervisory authority verification (implied by "shall document" and "shall enable").
conditional_requirements: Controller notification to supervisory authority is not required if the personal data breach is "unlikely to result in a risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons." Quote: "unless the personal data breach is unlikely to result in a risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons."

Where it is not possible to provide all required information at the same time, the information may be provided in phases, but must be provided "without undue further delay." Quote: "Where, and in so far as, it is not possible to provide the information at the same time, the information may be provided in phases without undue further delay."

In describing the nature of the breach, inclusion of categories and approximate numbers is required "where possible." Quote: "including where possible, the categories and approximate number of data subjects concerned and the categories and approximate number of personal data records concerned".
Measures to mitigate adverse effects are required "where appropriate." Quote: "including, where appropriate, measures to mitigate its possible adverse effects."
documentation_requirements: Controller must document any personal data breaches.
Documentation must comprise: (i) facts relating to the breach, (ii) its effects, and (iii) remedial action taken.
Documentation must be sufficient to enable supervisory authority verification of compliance with Article 33.
reporting_requirements: Controller must notify the competent supervisory authority of a personal data breach unless the 'unlikely to result in risk' exception applies.
Processor must notify the controller after becoming aware of a personal data breach.

Notification to supervisory authority must include at least: (a) nature of breach with categories/approximate numbers where possible; (b) DPO/other contact point name and contact details; (c) likely consequences; (d) measures taken/proposed including mitigation where appropriate.
If notification is late (beyond 72 hours), it must include reasons for delay.
If all information cannot be provided at once, provide in phases without undue further delay.
timeline_requirements: Controller: notify supervisory authority "without undue delay" and, where feasible, "not later than 72 hours" after becoming aware of the breach.
Controller: if not notified within 72 hours, include reasons for delay with the notification.
Processor: notify controller "without undue delay" after becoming aware of a personal data breach.
Phased information: provide remaining information "without undue further delay" when not possible to provide all at the same time.

general_restrictions: Notification obligation is conditioned by a risk threshold exception: notification is not required where the breach is unlikely to result in risk to rights and freedoms of natural persons.
data_restrictions: Notification content must include specific data-related descriptors: categories and approximate numbers of data subjects and records, where possible.
operational_restrictions: Incident response processes must support rapid awareness-to-notification workflows to meet the 72-hour feasibility requirement and 'without undue delay' standard.
geographic_restrictions: Notification must be made to the supervisory authority competent in accordance with Article 55 (competence determination referenced but not detailed here).

individual_rights: Indirect protection of individualsâ€™ rights and freedoms through risk-based supervisory authority notification (no direct individual exercise mechanism stated in this section).
organizational_rights: Ability for controller to provide notification information in phases when not possible to provide all information at the same time, subject to 'without undue further delay'.
how_to_exercise_rights: Controller may submit required notification information in phases where simultaneous provision is not possible, ensuring no undue further delay.

general_exceptions: Controller is not required to notify the supervisory authority if the personal data breach is unlikely to result in a risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons.
conditional_exemptions: Phased reporting permitted only "where, and in so far as" it is not possible to provide the information at the same time.

organizational_measures: Establish procedures to detect, assess, and escalate personal data breaches to ensure controller awareness triggers timely notification.
Implement internal workflows to compile mandatory notification content items (a)-(d) and to support phased updates when necessary.
Ensure processor-controller contractual/operational arrangements support 'without undue delay' breach notification from processor to controller.
Maintain a breach register/log capturing facts, effects, and remedial actions, retained in a manner that enables supervisory authority verification.
security_measures: Implement measures taken or proposed to address the breach, including mitigation measures where appropriate (the section requires description of such measures; it does not prescribe specific security controls).
audit_requirements: Maintain documentation such that the supervisory authority can verify compliance with Article 33 (implies readiness for supervisory authority review).

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authority competent in accordance with GDPR Article 55 (as referenced).
enforcement_mechanisms: Supervisory authority verification of compliance enabled through controller documentation. Quote: "That documentation shall enable the supervisory authority to verify compliance with this Article."

dates.compliance_deadline: Operational deadline per incident: where feasible, not later than 72 hours after the controller becomes aware of the personal data breach.

related_articles: GDPR Article 55 (competence of supervisory authority) (referenced but not detailed in this section)

implementation_steps: Define and document what constitutes 'awareness' of a personal data breach for internal triggering of the 72-hour clock.
Create an incident notification playbook that ensures supervisory authority notification is prepared and submitted without undue delay and, where feasible, within 72 hours.
Implement processor escalation procedures (and contractual SLAs where applicable) requiring processors to notify controllers without undue delay upon awareness.

Prepare notification templates capturing mandatory elements: (a) nature of breach + categories/approximate numbers (where possible), (b) DPO/contact point details, (c) likely consequences, (d) measures taken/proposed including mitigation where appropriate.
Set up a phased reporting mechanism to submit initial notification with available information and follow-up submissions without undue further delay when information becomes available.
Maintain a breach documentation repository/log including facts, effects, and remedial actions, organized to support supervisory authority verification.
common_violations: Not notifying the supervisory authority within 72 hours where feasible and where the risk exception does not apply.
Submitting a notification without reasons for delay when filed after 72 hours.
Failing to include one or more mandatory content elements (a)-(d).
Treating phased reporting as open-ended and not providing remaining information without undue further delay.
Failing to maintain adequate breach documentation (facts, effects, remedial actions) or maintaining it in a way that does not enable supervisory authority verification.
Processor delays in notifying the controller after becoming aware of a breach.
best_practices: Use a standardized breach assessment to determine whether the 'unlikely to result in risk' exception applies, and document the rationale.
Maintain up-to-date DPO/contact point details to include in notifications.
Track timelines from awareness to notification submission and record reasons for any delay beyond 72 hours.
Quantify affected data subjects and records as early as possible; where not possible, clearly indicate estimates and provide updates in phases.
compliance_checklist: Controller can demonstrate notification to competent supervisory authority without undue delay and, where feasible, within 72 hours of awareness.
If notification exceeded 72 hours, reasons for delay are included with the notification.
Processor-to-controller notification process exists and is demonstrably 'without undue delay'.

Notification includes: nature of breach; categories and approximate numbers of data subjects and records (where possible); DPO/contact point name and contact details; likely consequences; measures taken/proposed including mitigation where appropriate.
If all information was not available initially, phased updates were provided without undue further delay.
Controller maintains breach documentation including facts, effects, and remedial actions, sufficient for supervisory authority verification.

regulations.source_section: ## Notification of a personal data breach to the supervisory authority

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 34: Communication of a personal data breach to the data subject

applicable_regions: European Economic Area (via incorporation into EEA law where applicable)

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data (public and private)

description.brief_summary: Requires controllers to notify affected data subjects of a personal data breach when it is likely to result in a high risk to individualsâ€™ rights and freedoms, specifies minimum content requirements for that communication, provides exceptions, and empowers supervisory authorities to require communication.
description.detailed_explanation: This section imposes a direct obligation on the controller to communicate a personal data breach to the data subject when the breach is likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons. The communication must be made "without undue delay" and must be written in "clear and plain language" describing the nature of the breach. The communication must include at least the information and measures referenced from Article 33(3)(b), (c), and (d). The section also establishes three alternative conditions under which communication to data subjects is not required: (a) appropriate technical and organisational protection measures were implemented and applied to the affected data, particularly measures rendering the data unintelligible to unauthorized persons (example given: encryption); (b) subsequent measures were taken ensuring the high risk is no longer likely to materialise; or (c) communication would involve disproportionate effort, in which case the controller must instead use a public communication or similar measure that informs data subjects in an equally effective manner. Finally, if the controller has not already communicated, the supervisory authority may require the controller to do so after considering the likelihood of high risk, or may decide that one of the exceptions applies.
description.purpose: To ensure individuals are promptly informed of high-risk personal data breaches so they can take protective steps, while allowing limited exceptions where effective protections or mitigations exist or where direct communication is impractical but can be replaced with equally effective public notice.
description.legislative_intent: To operationalize transparency and risk-based breach response by mandating timely, understandable communication to affected individuals in high-risk scenarios, and to provide supervisory authorities with oversight to ensure communications occur unless a justified exception applies.

what_it_covers: Decision-making on whether a breach triggers communication to data subjects based on likelihood of high risk
Timing of communication to data subjects
Content and language requirements for breach communications
Conditions/exceptions where communication is not required
Alternative public communication where direct communication is disproportionate effort
Supervisory authority intervention regarding communication

entity_types: Any organization acting as a controller under GDPR
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies where GDPR applies to the controllerâ€™s processing (not specified in this excerpt).

what_it_does_not_cover: Processor obligations (not addressed in this excerpt)
Notification to supervisory authority (covered primarily by Article 33, referenced but not detailed here)
Specific penalty amounts (not included in this excerpt)

mandatory_obligations: Communicate the personal data breach to the data subject when the breach is likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons. Quote: "the controller shall communicate the personal data breach to the data subject".
Make the communication "without undue delay" when the high-risk threshold is met. Quote: "without undue delay".
Ensure the communication "shall describe in clear and plain language the nature of the personal data breach". Quote: "describe in clear and plain language the nature of the personal data breach".

Include in the communication "at least the information and measures referred to in points (b), (c) and (d) of Article 33(3)". Quote: "contain at least the information and measures referred to in points (b), (c) and (d) of Article 33(3)".

If relying on the disproportionate effort condition, provide "instead" a public communication or similar measure that informs data subjects "in an equally effective manner". Quote: "there shall instead be a public communication or similar measure whereby the data subjects are informed in an equally effective manner".
prohibited_actions: Failing to communicate a high-risk breach to data subjects without a valid condition under paragraph 3 (implicit prohibition derived from the mandatory obligation and limited exceptions).
conditional_requirements: Trigger condition for mandatory communication: applies "[w]hen the personal data breach is likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons".

Communication is not required if the controller "has implemented appropriate technical and organisational protection measures" and "those measures were applied to the personal data affected"; particularly measures rendering data "unintelligible" to unauthorized persons (example: encryption). Quote: "in particular those that render the personal data unintelligible to any person who is not authorised to access it, such as encryption".
Communication is not required if the controller "has taken subsequent measures" ensuring the high risk "is no longer likely to materialise".
Communication is not required if it "would involve disproportionate effort"; if so, the controller must use public communication or similar equally effective measure.

Supervisory authority intervention condition: "If the controller has not already communicated" the breach, the supervisory authority, after considering likelihood of high risk, "may require it to do so" or "may decide" that an exception applies.
reporting_requirements: Communication to data subjects is required under the high-risk condition (a form of external notification/communication).
Where disproportionate effort applies, a public communication or similar measure is required as an alternative notification mechanism.
timeline_requirements: Communication must occur "without undue delay" once the high-risk condition is met.

general_restrictions: Communication content must meet minimum content requirements by including at least the information/measures referenced from Article 33(3)(b)-(d).
