Communication must be in "clear and plain language".
data_restrictions: Exception based on protection measures focuses on rendering data "unintelligible" to unauthorized persons (e.g., encryption), implying a restriction/requirement on the state of compromised data for the exception to apply.
operational_restrictions: If direct communication would involve disproportionate effort, the controller is restricted from doing nothing and must instead use public communication or similar equally effective measure.
technical_restrictions: To qualify for the technical/organisational measures exception, measures must be both implemented and applied to the affected data, and must render the data unintelligible to unauthorized persons (example: encryption).

individual_rights: Right to be informed of a personal data breach when it is likely to result in a high risk to their rights and freedoms (implemented via controllerâ€™s duty to communicate).
organizational_rights: Controller may refrain from direct communication to data subjects if one of the specified conditions is met (encryption/unintelligibility measures applied; subsequent risk-mitigating measures; disproportionate effort with equally effective public communication).
Supervisory authority may decide that conditions for not communicating are met (affecting whether the controller must communicate).

general_exceptions: Communication to data subjects "shall not be required" if any of the paragraph 3 conditions are met.
conditional_exemptions: Implemented and applied appropriate technical and organisational protection measures to affected data, particularly those rendering data unintelligible to unauthorized persons (e.g., encryption).
Subsequent measures taken ensure the high risk is no longer likely to materialise.
Direct communication would involve disproportionate effort, provided that a public communication or similar equally effective measure is used instead.

technical_measures: Implement and apply technical protection measures to affected personal data that render it unintelligible to unauthorized persons (example explicitly provided: encryption). Quote: "render the personal data unintelligible ... such as encryption".
organizational_measures: Implement organisational protection measures (in addition to technical measures) and ensure they are applied to the affected data to qualify for the exception.
Establish procedures to assess whether a breach is likely to result in a high risk to rights and freedoms (implied by the trigger condition).
Establish procedures to prepare and deliver clear, plain-language breach communications to data subjects without undue delay.
Establish procedures for alternative public communication where direct communication would involve disproportionate effort, ensuring equal effectiveness.
security_measures: Protection measures that render data unintelligible to unauthorized persons (e.g., encryption) as a security measure relevant to breach communication obligations.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authority (as referenced in paragraph 4).

penalties.reputational_consequences: Potential public communication requirement where disproportionate effort applies; supervisory authority may require communication (could lead to public awareness).

enforcement_mechanisms: Supervisory authority may require the controller to communicate the breach to data subjects after considering the likelihood of high risk. Quote: "may require it to do so".
Supervisory authority may decide that an exception condition is met. Quote: "may decide that any of the conditions referred to in paragraph 3 are met".

amendment_history: Document excerpt includes publication context lines "4.5.2016" and "Official Journal of the European Union" but does not state an effective date within the provided text.

implementation_steps: Implement a breach risk assessment process to determine whether a breach is likely to result in a high risk to rights and freedoms.

Create a data subject communication template that: (i) uses clear and plain language; (ii) describes the nature of the breach; and (iii) includes at least the information/measures required by Article 33(3)(b)-(d) (as referenced).
Define internal SLAs to ensure communications occur "without undue delay" once the high-risk threshold is met.
Deploy and maintain technical and organisational measures (e.g., encryption) and ensure they are applied to relevant datasets so the exception can be relied upon where appropriate.
Maintain an incident response playbook for taking subsequent measures that reduce risk so that high risk is no longer likely to materialise (to potentially rely on the exception).
Prepare a public communication mechanism (website notice, press release, broad outreach) for cases where direct communication would involve disproportionate effort, ensuring it is equally effective.
common_violations: Delaying communication beyond what could be considered "without undue delay" in high-risk cases.
Providing breach notices that are not in clear and plain language.
Omitting required minimum content (at least the information/measures referenced from Article 33(3)(b)-(d)).
Claiming the encryption/unintelligibility exception where measures were not actually applied to the affected data.
Invoking disproportionate effort without providing an equally effective public communication or similar measure.
best_practices: Use layered communications: a plain-language summary plus a detailed FAQ, while ensuring the required minimum content is present.
Pre-identify channels for rapid outreach (email, in-app, postal) and criteria for when public communication is equally effective.
Ensure encryption and key management practices are robust so that compromised data is truly unintelligible to unauthorized parties.
compliance_checklist: Has the controller assessed whether the breach is likely to result in a high risk to rights and freedoms?
If yes, was the data subject communication sent without undue delay?
Does the communication describe the nature of the breach in clear and plain language?
Does the communication contain at least the information/measures referenced in Article 33(3)(b)-(d)?
If communication was not sent, does at least one paragraph 3 condition apply (and can it be substantiated)?
If relying on disproportionate effort, was a public communication or similar equally effective measure used?
Has the supervisory authority required communication or confirmed an exception applies (if engaged)?

key_definitions.high risk to the rights and freedoms of: Threshold condition triggering the duty to communicate; the text states: "likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons" (no further definition provided in the excerpt).
key_definitions.without undue delay: Timing standard requiring prompt communication; exact duration not specified in the excerpt.
key_definitions.appropriate technical and organisational: Measures implemented and applied to affected data; particularly those rendering data unintelligible to unauthorized persons (example: encryption).
key_definitions.disproportionate effort: Condition allowing substitution of direct communication with public communication or similar equally effective measure; not further defined in the excerpt.
key_definitions.unintelligible: State of personal data such that it cannot be understood by unauthorized persons; example measure: encryption.

regulations.source_section: ## Communication of a personal data breach to the data subject

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 35 (Data protection impact assessment)

applicable_regions: EEA (where GDPR is incorporated via EEA Agreement, if applicable)

sub_domains: Profiling and automated decision-making (as a DPIA trigger)
Special categories of data (as a DPIA trigger)
Criminal convictions and offences data (as a DPIA trigger)

description.brief_summary: Requires controllers to perform a DPIA before processing likely to result in high risk to individuals, specifies when a DPIA is particularly required, prescribes minimum DPIA content, and sets related obligations involving the DPO, supervisory authorities, and periodic review.
description.detailed_explanation: The provision obliges a controller to conduct, before starting certain processing, an assessment of the impact of the envisaged processing operations on the protection of personal data when the processing is likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons, particularly when using new technologies and considering the nature, scope, context, and purposes. It allows a single DPIA to cover a set of similar operations with similar high risks. It requires the controller to seek advice from the data protection officer (if designated) during the DPIA. It identifies three specific scenarios where a DPIA is in particular required: (a) systematic and extensive evaluation of personal aspects based on automated processing (including profiling) where decisions produce legal effects or similarly significantly affect individuals; (b) large-scale processing of special categories of data (Article 9(1)) or criminal convictions/offences data (Article 10); and (c) systematic monitoring of publicly accessible areas on a large scale. It mandates supervisory authorities to publish lists of processing operations requiring a DPIA and to communicate those lists to the European Data Protection Board (Article 68), and permits supervisory authorities to publish lists of operations not requiring a DPIA, also communicated to the Board. Before adopting such lists, the competent supervisory authority must apply the GDPR consistency mechanism (Article 63) where the lists involve cross-border-related processing (offering goods/services or monitoring behaviour in several Member States) or may substantially affect free movement of personal data within the Union. The DPIA must contain at least four elements: a systematic description of processing and purposes (including legitimate interest where applicable), an assessment of necessity and proportionality, an assessment of risks to rights and freedoms, and measures to address risks (including safeguards, security measures, and mechanisms to ensure protection and demonstrate compliance, considering rights and legitimate interests of data subjects and others). Compliance with approved codes of conduct (Article 40) must be taken into due account in assessing impact, particularly for DPIAs. Where appropriate, the controller must seek views of data subjects or their representatives on intended processing, without prejudice to protection of commercial/public interests or security of processing operations. An exemption applies where processing under Article 6(1)(c) or (e) has a legal basis in Union or Member State law that regulates the specific processing and a DPIA has already been carried out as part of a general impact assessment during adoption of that legal basis; in that case, paragraphs 1 to 7 do not apply unless Member States deem a DPIA necessary prior to processing. Finally, where necessary, the controller must review to assess whether processing is performed in accordance with the DPIA at least when there is a change in the risk represented by the processing operations.
description.purpose: To ensure high-risk processing is assessed and mitigated before it begins, embedding privacy/data protection by design through structured risk identification, proportionality analysis, and documented safeguards.
description.legislative_intent: To prevent or reduce harm to individualsâ€™ rights and freedoms from high-risk processing (especially new technologies, large-scale sensitive data, profiling, and monitoring) by requiring prior assessment, transparency of high-risk categories via supervisory authority lists, and ongoing review when risk changes.

what_it_covers: Processing operations likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons
Processing using new technologies (as a factor increasing likelihood of high risk)
Sets of similar processing operations presenting similar high risks (may be covered by a single DPIA)
Systematic and extensive automated evaluation/profiling leading to legal or similarly significant effects
Large-scale processing of special categories of data (GDPR Article 9(1))
Large-scale processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences (GDPR Article 10)
Systematic monitoring of publicly accessible areas on a large scale
Supervisory authority publication of DPIA-required and DPIA-not-required processing lists
Application of the GDPR consistency mechanism for certain cross-border or internal market-impacting lists
Minimum content elements required in a DPIA
Taking approved codes of conduct into account in DPIA assessment
Seeking data subject/representative views where appropriate
Exemption where a DPIA was already performed as part of a general impact assessment for certain legal bases
Reviewing processing against the DPIA when risk changes

target_entities: Data protection officers (advisory role where designated)
European Data Protection Board (recipient of lists via communication)
who_it_applies_to.size_thresholds: Not specified; however, triggers include 'large scale' processing and 'large scale' monitoring (threshold not defined in this excerpt).
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies to processing within GDPR territorial scope; cross-border relevance explicitly addressed for supervisory authority list adoption where activities relate to several Member States or may affect free movement of personal data within the Union.

what_it_does_not_cover: Paragraphs 1 to 7 do not apply in the specific exemption scenario described in paragraph 10 (unless Member States deem a DPIA necessary).

mandatory_obligations: Controller must conduct a DPIA prior to processing when the processing is likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons. Quote: "the controller shall, prior to the processing, carry out an assessment of the impact of the envisaged processing operations on the protection of personal data."

Controller must consider factors when determining likelihood of high risk, including: use of new technologies and "taking into account the nature, scope, context and purposes of the processing" (risk determination criteria).

Controller must seek advice of the DPO (where designated) when carrying out a DPIA. Quote: "The controller shall seek the advice of the data protection officer, where designated, when carrying out a data protection impact assessment."
DPIA must contain at least the specified minimum elements (a)-(d). Quote: "The assessment shall contain at least:" followed by items (a)-(d).

Supervisory authority must establish and make public a list of processing operations subject to the DPIA requirement and must communicate those lists to the Board (EDPB). Quote: "The supervisory authority shall establish and make public a list... The supervisory authority shall communicate those lists to the Board referred to in Article 68."

Before adopting the lists in paragraphs 4 and 5, the competent supervisory authority must apply the consistency mechanism (Article 63) where the lists involve certain cross-border-related processing or may substantially affect free movement of personal data. Quote: "Prior to the adoption of the lists... the competent supervisory authority shall apply the consistency mechanism..."
Controller must take compliance with approved codes of conduct (Article 40) into due account in assessing impact, in particular for DPIAs. Quote: "shall be taken into due account".

Where necessary, controller must review processing to assess if it is performed in accordance with the DPIA at least when there is a change of the risk represented by processing operations. Quote: "Where necessary, the controller shall carry out a review... at least when there is a change of the risk..."
prohibited_actions: No explicit 'must not' prohibitions are stated in this excerpt; obligations are framed as affirmative duties and conditional non-application.
conditional_requirements: A single DPIA may cover multiple similar processing operations if they present similar high risks. Quote: "A single assessment may address a set of similar processing operations that present similar high risks."
A DPIA is "in particular" required in the following cases (non-exhaustive triggers):

Trigger (a): Systematic and extensive evaluation of personal aspects relating to natural persons based on automated processing (including profiling) where decisions are based that produce legal effects or similarly significantly affect the person. Quote: "a systematic and extensive evaluation... based on automated processing, including profiling, and on which decisions are based that produce legal effects... or similarly significantly affect..."

Trigger (b): Large-scale processing of special categories of data (Article 9(1)) or personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences (Article 10). Quote: "processing on a large scale of special categories of data... or of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences..."
Trigger (c): Systematic monitoring of a publicly accessible area on a large scale. Quote: "a systematic monitoring of a publicly accessible area on a large scale."

Supervisory authority may (optional) establish and make public a list of processing operations for which no DPIA is required, and must communicate those lists to the Board. Quote: "may also establish and make public a list... The supervisory authority shall communicate those lists to the Board."

Controller should seek views of data subjects or their representatives where appropriate, subject to safeguards for commercial/public interests and security. Quote: "Where appropriate, the controller shall seek the views... without prejudice to the protection of commercial or public interests or the security of processing operations."

Exemption: If processing under Article 6(1)(c) or (e) has a legal basis in Union/Member State law, that law regulates the specific processing operation(s), and a DPIA has already been carried out as part of a general impact assessment during adoption of that legal basis, then paragraphs 1 to 7 do not apply unless Member States deem it necessary to carry out such an assessment prior to processing. Quote: "paragraphs 1 to 7 shall not apply unless Member States deem it to be necessary..."

Consistency mechanism condition: required where lists involve processing related to offering goods/services to data subjects or monitoring their behaviour in several Member States, or may substantially affect free movement of personal data within the Union. Quote: "where such lists involve processing activities... in several Member States, or may substantially affect the free movement of personal data within the Union."
documentation_requirements: DPIA must document: (a) systematic description of envisaged processing operations and purposes, including legitimate interest where applicable. Quote: "a systematic description... and the purposes... including, where applicable, the legitimate interest pursued by the controller;"
DPIA must document: (b) assessment of necessity and proportionality in relation to purposes. Quote: "an assessment of the necessity and proportionality..."
DPIA must document: (c) assessment of risks to rights and freedoms of data subjects. Quote: "an assessment of the risks to the rights and freedoms of data subjects..."

DPIA must document: (d) measures envisaged to address risks, including safeguards, security measures, and mechanisms to ensure protection and demonstrate compliance, taking into account rights and legitimate interests of data subjects and other persons concerned. Quote: "the measures envisaged to address the risks, including safeguards, security measures and mechanisms... and to demonstrate compliance..."
reporting_requirements: Supervisory authority must make public the list of processing operations requiring a DPIA. Quote: "shall establish and make public a list".
Supervisory authority must communicate DPIA-required lists to the Board (Article 68). Quote: "shall communicate those lists to the Board".
If supervisory authority establishes a list of processing operations for which no DPIA is required, it must communicate those lists to the Board. Quote: "shall communicate those lists to the Board."
timeline_requirements: DPIA must be carried out "prior to the processing" when high risk is likely. Quote: "prior to the processing".
Review obligation timing: "at least when there is a change of the risk represented by processing operations" (minimum trigger for review). Quote: "at least when there is a change of the risk".

Supervisory authority list adoption timing is not dated, but a procedural prerequisite is imposed: "Prior to the adoption of the lists... shall apply the consistency mechanism" under specified conditions.

general_restrictions: High-risk processing cannot proceed without a prior DPIA where Article 35(1) conditions are met (functional restriction via 'prior to the processing' obligation).
data_restrictions: Large-scale processing of special categories of data (Article 9(1)) and criminal convictions/offences data (Article 10) is singled out as a DPIA-triggering category, implying heightened scrutiny and required assessment before processing at scale.
operational_restrictions: Systematic and extensive automated evaluation/profiling with legal or similarly significant effects is restricted by requiring a DPIA (and associated safeguards) before such processing proceeds.
Systematic monitoring of publicly accessible areas on a large scale is restricted by requiring a DPIA before such monitoring proceeds.
technical_restrictions: No specific technical controls are mandated by name, but the DPIA must include "security measures" and "mechanisms to ensure the protection of personal data and to demonstrate compliance".
geographic_restrictions: Supervisory authority list-making is subject to EU-level consistency mechanism where processing relates to multiple Member States or may affect free movement of personal data within the Union.

individual_rights: Procedural participatory element: where appropriate, data subjects (or representatives) may be consulted for their views on intended processing. Quote: "shall seek the views of data subjects or their representatives" (conditional).
organizational_rights: Controller may rely on a single DPIA for a set of similar processing operations presenting similar high risks. Quote: "A single assessment may address a set of similar processing operations..."

Supervisory authority may establish a list of processing operations for which no DPIA is required. Quote: "may also establish and make public a list... for which no data protection impact assessment is required."
how_to_exercise_rights: Data subject views are sought by the controller "where appropriate" on the intended processing; the process is not further specified in this excerpt and is constrained by protection of commercial/public interests and processing security.

general_exceptions: Exemption from paragraphs 1 to 7 where a DPIA has already been carried out as part of a general impact assessment in the context of adopting the legal basis for processing under Article 6(1)(c) or (e), provided the law regulates the specific processing operation(s). Quote: "paragraphs 1 to 7 shall not apply" (subject to Member State override).
conditional_exemptions: The exemption in paragraph 10 is conditional on all of the following: (i) processing pursuant to Article 6(1)(c) or (e); (ii) legal basis in Union or Member State law applicable to the controller; (iii) that law regulates the specific processing operation(s); and (iv) a DPIA has already been carried out as part of a general impact assessment during adoption of that legal basis.
legitimate_interest_exceptions: None stated as an exception; legitimate interest is referenced only as an item to include in DPIA description "where applicable".
public_interest_exceptions: Consultation of data subjects is limited "without prejudice to the protection of commercial or public interests or the security of processing operations" (a constraint/exception to consultation scope).
size_based_exceptions: None stated; although 'large scale' is a trigger, no small-entity exemption is provided in this excerpt.

technical_measures: DPIA must specify "security measures" as part of measures envisaged to address risks. Quote: "including safeguards, security measures and mechanisms..."
DPIA must specify "mechanisms to ensure the protection of personal data and to demonstrate compliance". Quote: "mechanisms to ensure the protection of personal data and to demonstrate compliance".
organizational_measures: Perform a DPIA prior to high-risk processing (organizational process requirement).
Seek DPO advice where designated during DPIA (governance requirement).
Where appropriate, seek views of data subjects/representatives (stakeholder engagement requirement).
Take approved codes of conduct into due account when assessing impact (governance/assurance requirement).
Review processing against the DPIA when risk changes (continuous compliance requirement).
security_measures: DPIA must include planned security measures to address identified risks (specific measures not enumerated in this excerpt).
audit_requirements: Ongoing review obligation functions as an internal compliance check: controller must review to assess whether processing is performed in accordance with the DPIA at least when risk changes.
certification_requirements: No certification is required in this excerpt; however, approved codes of conduct (Article 40) must be taken into account.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Competent supervisory authority (national data protection authority) within the GDPR framework; European Data Protection Board involved for communicated lists and consistency mechanism context.
enforcement_mechanisms: Supervisory authority publication of DPIA-required processing lists (regulatory guidance/standard-setting).
Consistency mechanism application for certain lists (EU-level coordination).

dates.compliance_deadline: DPIA must be completed prior to the processing where Article 35(1) applies.
dates.review_date: Review required where necessary, at least when there is a change of the risk represented by processing operations.

related_articles: GDPR Article 6(1)(c) (legal obligation) (referenced for exemption condition)
GDPR Article 6(1)(e) (public interest/official authority) (referenced for exemption condition)
GDPR Article 9(1) (special categories of personal data) (referenced for DPIA trigger)
GDPR Article 10 (personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences) (referenced for DPIA trigger)
GDPR Article 40 (codes of conduct) (referenced for consideration in DPIA)
GDPR Article 63 (consistency mechanism) (procedural requirement for list adoption in certain cases)
GDPR Article 68 (European Data Protection Board) (recipient of supervisory authority lists)

implementation_steps: Determine whether envisaged processing is likely to result in high risk by evaluating nature, scope, context, purposes, and use of new technologies.

Check whether processing falls within the listed 'in particular' DPIA-required cases: (a) automated evaluation/profiling with legal/similarly significant effects; (b) large-scale special category or criminal convictions/offences data; (c) large-scale systematic monitoring of publicly accessible areas.
If high risk is likely, complete the DPIA before starting processing; consider whether one DPIA can cover multiple similar operations with similar high risks.
Engage the DPO (if designated) and document the advice sought/received as part of the DPIA process.

Prepare DPIA documentation including all minimum required elements (description/purposes/legitimate interest; necessity & proportionality; risk assessment; measures including safeguards/security/compliance mechanisms).
Consider and document how any approved code(s) of conduct (Article 40) applicable to the controller/processor were taken into account.
Where appropriate, consult data subjects or representatives and document outcomes, while protecting commercial/public interests and processing security.
Monitor supervisory authority published lists of processing requiring a DPIA and lists exempted from DPIA; align internal DPIA triggers accordingly.
Establish a review process to reassess alignment with the DPIA at least when the risk profile changes (e.g., new data types, new technology, expanded scale, new purposes).
common_violations: Starting high-risk processing without completing a DPIA beforehand (breach of 'prior to the processing').
Failing to include one or more of the minimum DPIA content elements (a)-(d).
Failing to seek DPO advice where a DPO is designated.
Ignoring supervisory authority lists indicating DPIA is required for a processing type.
Not reviewing the DPIA when processing changes increase or alter risk.
best_practices: Use a DPIA template that maps directly to the four minimum content elements and captures evidence for each.
Define internal criteria for 'large scale' and 'systematic monitoring' consistent with supervisory authority guidance and document the rationale.
Maintain a change-management trigger that forces DPIA review when scope/context/purpose/technology changes.
Record how codes of conduct were considered and whether adherence reduces residual risk.
compliance_checklist: Is the processing likely to result in high risk considering nature/scope/context/purposes and new technologies?
Does the processing match any 'in particular required' triggers (profiling with significant effects; large-scale special category/criminal data; large-scale public monitoring)?
Was the DPIA completed before processing began?
Was DPO advice sought (if a DPO is designated) and documented?

Does the DPIA include: (a) systematic description & purposes (and legitimate interest where applicable), (b) necessity/proportionality assessment, (c) risk assessment to rights/freedoms, (d) measures including safeguards/security/compliance mechanisms?
Were approved codes of conduct (if applicable) taken into due account and documented?
Were data subject/representative views sought where appropriate, with protections for commercial/public interests and security?
Is there a review mechanism to reassess compliance with the DPIA at least when risk changes?

key_definitions.Data protection impact assessment (DPIA): An assessment of the impact of envisaged processing operations on the protection of personal data, required prior to processing where the processing is likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons.
key_definitions.High risk (context of Article 35(1)): Not defined in this excerpt; the obligation is triggered where processing is 'likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons' considering nature, scope, context, purposes, and particularly use of new technologies.
key_definitions.Systematic and extensive evaluation (tri: Evaluation of personal aspects relating to natural persons based on automated processing (including profiling) where decisions produce legal effects or similarly significantly affect the person.
key_definitions.Large scale (trigger qualifier): Not defined in this excerpt; used to qualify processing of special categories/criminal data and monitoring of publicly accessible areas.
key_definitions.Systematic monitoring of a publicly acce: Monitoring that is systematic and conducted on a large scale in publicly accessible areas.

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 36 (Prior consultation)

applicable_regions: European Economic Area (via incorporation into EEA law where applicable)

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data (public and private)

description.brief_summary: Requires controllers to consult the supervisory authority before processing when a DPIA indicates high risk absent mitigation, prescribes what must be submitted, sets supervisory authority advice timelines (with extension and suspension rules), and provides for Member State consultation/authorization requirements in specific contexts.
description.detailed_explanation: This section establishes a mandatory pre-processing consultation mechanism with the competent supervisory authority when a controllerâ€™s DPIA (under Article 35) indicates that the intended processing would result in a high risk if the controller does not take measures to mitigate that risk. It also defines the supervisory authorityâ€™s procedural obligations (written advice within a defined period, possible extension, obligation to notify of extension and reasons, and ability to suspend the clock pending requested information) and empowers the authority to use its Article 58 powers where it believes the intended processing would infringe the GDPR, particularly where risks are insufficiently identified or mitigated. The controller must provide specified information (including roles/responsibilities, purposes/means, safeguards, DPO contact details where applicable, the DPIA, and any other information requested). Additionally, Member States must consult supervisory authorities when preparing certain legislative/regulatory measures relating to processing, and Member State law may impose consultation and prior authorization requirements for certain public-interest tasks (including social protection and public health).
description.purpose: To prevent unlawful or excessively risky processing by requiring regulatory oversight and guidance before processing begins when high residual risk is identified, and to ensure supervisory authorities can intervene early.
description.legislative_intent: To operationalize a risk-based approach by creating a structured, time-bound consultation process and ensuring supervisory authorities can provide binding or influential input (including use of enforcement powers) before high-risk processing proceeds.

what_it_covers: Prior consultation with a supervisory authority before commencing certain processing operations
Supervisory authority review of intended processing that may infringe the GDPR
Submission package/information required for consultation
Supervisory authority response timelines, extensions, and suspension of timelines
Member State consultation during preparation of legislative/regulatory measures relating to processing
Potential Member State requirements for prior authorization for certain public-interest processing

target_entities: Processors (as recipients of advice where applicable)
Joint controllers (as part of responsibility mapping where applicable)
entity_types: Government bodies involved in legislative/regulatory drafting (Member States)
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies within the GDPR territorial scope; consultation is with the competent supervisory authority.

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing that does not trigger a DPIA under Article 35 or does not indicate high risk absent mitigation (as described in paragraph 1)
Detailed penalty amounts for non-compliance (not stated in this section)
Detailed criteria for what constitutes 'high risk' (referenced via Article 35 but not defined here)

mandatory_obligations: Controller must consult the supervisory authority prior to processing when the trigger condition is met. Quote: "The controller shall consult the supervisory authority prior to processing where a data protection impact assessment under Article 35 indicates that the processing would result in a high risk in the absence of measures taken by the controller to mitigate the risk."

Supervisory authority must provide written advice within the specified period when it believes intended processing would infringe the GDPR. Quote: "the supervisory authority shall, within period of up to eight weeks of receipt of the request for consultation, provide written advice to the controller and, where applicable to the processor"

Supervisory authority must inform controller (and processor where applicable) of any extension within one month of receipt of the request, including reasons. Quote: "The supervisory authority shall inform the controller and, where applicable, the processor, of any such extension within one month of receipt of the request for consultation together with the reasons for the delay."

Controller must provide specified information to the supervisory authority when consulting. Quote: "When consulting the supervisory authority pursuant to paragraph 1, the controller shall provide the supervisory authority with:" followed by items (a)â€“(f).

Member States must consult the supervisory authority during preparation of certain legislative/regulatory measures relating to processing. Quote: "Member States shall consult the supervisory authority during the preparation of a proposal for a legislative measure... or of a regulatory measure... which relates to processing."
prohibited_actions: Implicit prohibition: commencing processing without prior consultation when paragraph 1 conditions are met (derived from 'shall consult ... prior to processing').

conditional_requirements.condition: A DPIA under Article 35 indicates high risk would result in the absence of mitigation measures
conditional_requirements.requirement: Controller must consult the supervisory authority prior to processing (pre-processing consultation obligation).
conditional_requirements.quote: â€œshall consult ... prior to processing where a data protection impact assessment under Article 35 indicates that the processing would result in a high risk in the absence of measures ... to mitigate the risk.â€

conditional_requirements.condition: Supervisory authority is of the opinion intended processing would infringe the GDPR, particularly where controller has insufficiently identified or mitigated risk
conditional_requirements.requirement: Supervisory authority must provide written advice within up to 8 weeks and may use Article 58 powers.
conditional_requirements.quote: â€œWhere the supervisory authority is of the opinion that the intended processing ... would infringe this Regulation, in particular where the controller has insufficiently identified or mitigated the risk, the supervisory authority shall ... provide written advice ... and may use any of its powers referred to in Article 58.â€

conditional_requirements.condition: Complexity of intended processing warrants more time
conditional_requirements.requirement: Supervisory authority may extend the 8-week period by 6 weeks.
conditional_requirements.quote: â€œThat period may be extended by six weeks, taking into account the complexity of the intended processing.â€

conditional_requirements.condition: Supervisory authority extends the period
conditional_requirements.requirement: Authority must inform controller (and processor where applicable) within one month of receipt of request, with reasons for delay.
conditional_requirements.quote: â€œshall inform ... within one month of receipt ... together with the reasons for the delay.â€

conditional_requirements.condition: Supervisory authority has requested information for consultation and has not yet obtained it
conditional_requirements.requirement: Consultation periods may be suspended until requested information is obtained.
conditional_requirements.quote: â€œThose periods may be suspended until the supervisory authority has obtained information it has requested for the purposes of the consultation.â€

conditional_requirements.condition: Joint controllers and/or processors are involved (especially within a group of undertakings)
conditional_requirements.requirement: Controller must provide respective responsibilities of controller, joint controllers, and processors.
conditional_requirements.quote: â€œwhere applicable, the respective responsibilities of the controller, joint controllers and processors involved in the processing, in particular for processing within a group of undertakings;â€

conditional_requirements.condition: A data protection officer exists/has been designated
conditional_requirements.requirement: Provide DPO contact details.
conditional_requirements.quote: â€œwhere applicable, the contact details of the data protection officer;â€

conditional_requirements.condition: Supervisory authority requests additional information
conditional_requirements.requirement: Controller must provide any other information requested.
conditional_requirements.quote: â€œany other information requested by the supervisory authority.â€

conditional_requirements.condition: Member State law imposes additional requirements for certain public-interest processing
conditional_requirements.requirement: Controllers may be required to consult with and obtain prior authorization from the supervisory authority for processing for performance of a task in the public interest, including social protection and public health.
conditional_requirements.quote: â€œMember State law may require controllers to consult with, and obtain prior authorisation from, the supervisory authority ... for the performance of a task ... in the public interest, including ... social protection and public health.â€

documentation_requirements.document: Data protection impact assessment (DPIA) under Article 35
documentation_requirements.requirement: Must be provided to the supervisory authority as part of consultation submission.
documentation_requirements.quote: â€œthe data protection impact assessment provided for in Article 35;â€

documentation_requirements.document: Description of responsibilities among controller/joint controllers/processors (where applicable)
documentation_requirements.quote: â€œthe respective responsibilities of the controller, joint controllers and processors involved in the processing...â€

documentation_requirements.document: Description of purposes and means of intended processing
documentation_requirements.quote: â€œthe purposes and means of the intended processing;â€

documentation_requirements.document: Measures and safeguards to protect rights and freedoms of data subjects
documentation_requirements.quote: â€œthe measures and safeguards provided to protect the rights and freedoms of data subjects pursuant to this Regulation;â€
â€œthe contact details of the data protection officer;â€

documentation_requirements.document: Any other information requested by the supervisory authority
documentation_requirements.quote: â€œany other information requested by the supervisory authority.â€

reporting_requirements.report_or_notification: Consultation request submission to supervisory authority prior to processing (when triggered)
reporting_requirements.content: Items (a)â€“(f) listed in paragraph 3, including DPIA and other requested information.
reporting_requirements.quote: â€œThe controller shall consult the supervisory authority prior to processing...â€ and â€œthe controller shall provide the supervisory authority with...â€

reporting_requirements.report_or_notification: Written advice issued by supervisory authority
reporting_requirements.content: Written advice regarding intended processing where authority believes it would infringe the GDPR.
reporting_requirements.quote: â€œprovide written advice to the controller and, where applicable to the processorâ€

reporting_requirements.content: Notice of extension within one month of receipt of consultation request, including reasons for delay.
reporting_requirements.quote: â€œshall inform ... within one month ... together with the reasons for the delay.â€

timeline_requirements.trigger: Receipt of the request for consultation
timeline_requirements.obligation: Supervisory authority must provide written advice within up to eight weeks (where it believes intended processing would infringe the GDPR).
timeline_requirements.quote: â€œwithin period of up to eight weeks of receipt of the request for consultationâ€

timeline_requirements.trigger: Taking into account complexity of intended processing
timeline_requirements.obligation: Supervisory authority may extend the period by six weeks.
timeline_requirements.quote: â€œThat period may be extended by six weeks, taking into account the complexity of the intended processing.â€

timeline_requirements.trigger: Receipt of the request for consultation and decision to extend
timeline_requirements.obligation: Supervisory authority must inform controller (and processor where applicable) of extension within one month, with reasons.
timeline_requirements.quote: â€œshall inform ... within one month of receipt of the request for consultation together with the reasons for the delay.â€

timeline_requirements.trigger: Until supervisory authority has obtained information it requested for consultation
timeline_requirements.obligation: The 8-week/extended periods may be suspended pending receipt of requested information.
timeline_requirements.quote: â€œThose periods may be suspended until the supervisory authority has obtained information it has requested...â€

timeline_requirements.trigger: DPIA indicates high risk absent mitigation
timeline_requirements.obligation: Consultation must occur before processing begins.
timeline_requirements.quote: â€œshall consult ... prior to processingâ€

general_restrictions: Processing that meets the paragraph 1 trigger is restricted from proceeding without prior consultation (pre-condition to processing).
operational_restrictions: Supervisory authority may intervene (including via Article 58 powers) where intended processing would infringe the GDPR, particularly if risks are insufficiently identified/mitigated.

individual_rights: No new standalone individual rights are granted in this section; it references protection of 'rights and freedoms of data subjects' as an objective of measures/safeguards to be provided.
organizational_rights: Controller receives written advice from the supervisory authority within the defined procedure/timelines (procedural entitlement where paragraph 2 applies).
how_to_exercise_rights: Controller initiates consultation by submitting a request and the required information package under paragraph 3.

general_exceptions: Consultation obligation is not stated to apply unless the DPIA indicates high risk absent mitigation (paragraph 1 condition).
public_interest_exceptions: Member State law may impose additional consultation and prior authorization requirements for controllers performing tasks in the public interest, including social protection and public health (this is not an exemption but a special public-interest-related rule).

organizational_measures: Establish an internal process to determine when a DPIA indicates high risk absent mitigation and to trigger prior consultation before processing begins.

Prepare and maintain consultation submission materials covering roles/responsibilities, purposes/means, safeguards, DPO contact details (where applicable), DPIA, and any additional information requested.
Implement a process to respond promptly to supervisory authority information requests to avoid suspension delays.
security_measures: Provide 'measures and safeguards' to protect data subjectsâ€™ rights and freedoms (specific measures are not enumerated here; requirement is to provide them and describe them).

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authority (data protection authority) competent under the GDPR

penalties.administrative_penalties: Not specified in this section; section states the supervisory authority 'may use any of its powers referred to in Article 58.'

enforcement_mechanisms: Issuance of written advice within the consultation procedure
Use of supervisory authority powers under GDPR Article 58 (powers not detailed in this section, only referenced)
Ability to request additional information and suspend consultation timelines until obtained

amendment_history.description: Date appears in the provided text as Official Journal formatting; no explicit legal amendment described in this section.

related_articles: GDPR Article 35 (Data protection impact assessment) â€” referenced as the DPIA basis for triggering consultation
GDPR Article 58 (Powers of the supervisory authority) â€” referenced as powers that may be used

implementation_steps: Run a DPIA under Article 35 for processing likely to result in high risk; determine whether residual high risk remains absent mitigation.
If paragraph 1 trigger is met, submit a prior consultation request before starting processing.

Include in the submission: (a) responsibilities of controller/joint controllers/processors (where applicable, especially within a group), (b) purposes and means, (c) measures and safeguards for data subject rights/freedoms, (d) DPO contact details (where applicable), (e) the DPIA, and (f) any other information requested.
Track supervisory authority timelines: expect written advice within up to 8 weeks; anticipate possible 6-week extension for complexity; monitor for extension notice within 1 month with reasons.
Respond quickly to any supervisory authority information requests to prevent suspension of the consultation period.
common_violations: Starting processing before consulting the supervisory authority when the DPIA indicates high risk absent mitigation
Submitting an incomplete consultation package (e.g., missing DPIA, missing safeguards description, missing responsibility allocation among parties)
Failing to provide additional information requested by the supervisory authority, causing delays and potential non-compliance
best_practices: Maintain a standardized prior consultation dossier template aligned to paragraph 3(a)â€“(f).
Document risk identification and mitigation decisions clearly to avoid a finding that risks were 'insufficiently identified or mitigated.'
Establish a regulatory engagement timeline and internal owners to manage supervisory authority correspondence and deadlines.
compliance_checklist: DPIA completed under Article 35 and indicates high risk absent mitigation (yes/no)
Consultation initiated prior to processing (yes/no)
Responsibilities of controller/joint controllers/processors provided where applicable (yes/no)
Purposes and means of intended processing provided (yes/no)
Measures and safeguards to protect data subject rights/freedoms provided (yes/no)
DPO contact details provided where applicable (yes/no)
DPIA document attached (yes/no)
All additional information requested by supervisory authority provided (yes/no)
Timeline tracking: 8-week period, any 6-week extension, extension notice within 1 month, and any suspension events recorded (yes/no)
If applicable under Member State law: prior authorization obtained for public-interest task processing (yes/no)

key_definitions.prior consultation: A pre-processing procedure where the controller consults the supervisory authority before commencing processing when a DPIA indicates high risk absent mitigation (as described in paragraph 1).
key_definitions.data protection impact assessment (DPIA): Referenced as the assessment 'under Article 35' and as a document that must be provided to the supervisory authority during consultation (paragraph 3(e)); detailed definition not provided in this section.
key_definitions.group of undertakings: Referenced contextually as a scenario where responsibilities among controller/joint controllers/processors should be provided; definition not provided in this section.
key_definitions.prior authorisation: An additional requirement that Member State law may impose, requiring controllers not only to consult but also to obtain authorization from the supervisory authority for certain public-interest processing (paragraph 5).

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 37 (Designation of the data protection officer)

applicable_regions: European Economic Area (via incorporation into EEA law)

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data (public and private)

description.brief_summary: Requires controllers and processors to designate a DPO in specified circumstances, defines permissible appointment structures (including group-wide and multi-authority DPOs), sets qualification and engagement options, and mandates publication and notification of DPO contact details.
description.detailed_explanation: This section imposes a duty on both controllers and processors to appoint a Data Protection Officer when certain triggers are met: (i) processing by a public authority/body (with an explicit carve-out for courts acting judicially), (ii) core activities requiring regular and systematic monitoring of data subjects on a large scale, or (iii) core activities involving large-scale processing of special categories of data (Article 9) or personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences (Article 10). It also permits organizational flexibility by allowing a single DPO for a group of undertakings if accessibility from each establishment is ensured, and allowing a single DPO for multiple public authorities/bodies considering organizational structure and size. Outside the mandatory triggers, it allows voluntary designation and requires designation where Union or Member State law so requires, including via associations representing categories of controllers/processors. The DPO must be selected based on professional qualities, especially expert knowledge of data protection law/practices and ability to perform tasks referenced in Article 39. The DPO may be internal staff or engaged under a service contract. Finally, controllers/processors must publish DPO contact details and communicate them to the supervisory authority.
description.purpose: To ensure independent, expert oversight and accountability for data protection compliance within organizations by requiring appointment of a qualified DPO in higher-risk or public-sector processing contexts and ensuring accessibility and regulator contactability.
description.legislative_intent: To operationalize GDPR accountability by embedding a designated expert function (DPO) within relevant organizations, ensuring consistent compliance support, monitoring, and a clear liaison point for supervisory authorities and data subjects.

what_it_covers: Designation/appointment of a Data Protection Officer
Mandatory triggers for DPO designation
Group-wide DPO appointment conditions
Multi-public-authority DPO appointment conditions
Voluntary/other legally required DPO designation pathways
DPO qualification criteria
DPO engagement model (employee vs service contract)
Publication and notification of DPO contact details

target_entities: Associations/other bodies representing categories of controllers or processors
who_it_applies_to.size_thresholds: Not numerically specified; uses qualitative thresholds such as "large scale" and "core activities".
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies within GDPR territorial scope; specific location requirements not stated in this excerpt.

what_it_does_not_cover: Courts acting in their judicial capacity (explicit exception to mandatory designation trigger for public authorities/bodies)

mandatory_obligations: Controllers and processors must designate a DPO when any of the paragraph 1 triggers apply. Quote: "The controller and the processor shall designate a data protection officer in any case where:"

Mandatory trigger (public authority/body): designate a DPO where "the processing is carried out by a public authority or body". Quote: "(a) the processing is carried out by a public authority or body"

Mandatory trigger (monitoring): designate a DPO where core activities require "regular and systematic monitoring of data subjects on a large scale". Quote: "(b) the core activities ... require regular and systematic monitoring of data subjects on a large scale"

Mandatory trigger (sensitive/criminal data): designate a DPO where core activities consist of "processing on a large scale of special categories of data pursuant to Article 9" and "personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences referred to in Article 10". Quote: "(c) the core activities ... consist of processing on a large scale of special categories of data pursuant to Article 9 and personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences referred to in Article 10."

Qualification-based designation: DPO must be designated based on professional qualities, especially expert knowledge and ability to fulfill Article 39 tasks. Quote: "The data protection officer shall be designated on the basis of professional qualities and, in particular, expert knowledge of data protection law and practices and the ability to fulfil the tasks referred to in Article 39."

Publication and regulator notification: controller/processor must publish DPO contact details and communicate them to the supervisory authority. Quote: "The controller or the processor shall publish the contact details of the data protection officer and communicate them to the supervisory authority."
prohibited_actions: Not explicitly stated as prohibitions; however, failure to designate a DPO when required would be non-compliance (implicit).
conditional_requirements: Exception to public authority trigger: courts acting in judicial capacity are excluded. Quote: "except for courts acting in their judicial capacity"

Group of undertakings may appoint a single DPO only if accessibility condition is met. Quote: "A group of undertakings may appoint a single data protection officer provided that a data protection officer is easily accessible from each establishment."

Public authorities/bodies may designate a single DPO for several authorities/bodies, taking account of organizational structure and size. Quote: "a single data protection officer may be designated for several such authorities or bodies, taking account of their organisational structure and size."

Outside paragraph 1 cases, controller/processor/associations may designate a DPO; and where required by Union or Member State law, they must designate one. Quote: "may or, where required by Union or Member State law shall, designate a data protection officer."

Association-representative DPO may act for associations/other bodies representing controllers/processors. Quote: "The data protection officer may act for such associations and other bodies representing controllers or processors."
Engagement model flexibility: DPO may be staff member or service contract. Quote: "may be a staff member ... or fulfil the tasks on the basis of a service contract."
documentation_requirements: Publication of DPO contact details (public-facing documentation/notice). Quote: "shall publish the contact details"
reporting_requirements: Communication of DPO contact details to the supervisory authority. Quote: "communicate them to the supervisory authority"
timeline_requirements: No explicit deadlines/timeframes stated in the excerpt; obligations apply when the triggering conditions exist.

general_restrictions: Mandatory designation is restricted to specified triggers in paragraph 1, unless otherwise required by Union/Member State law (paragraph 4).
data_restrictions: Designation is triggered by large-scale processing of special categories of data (Article 9) and criminal conviction/offence data (Article 10), but no direct data-handling restrictions are specified in this excerpt.
operational_restrictions: If appointing a single DPO for a group, the organization must ensure the DPO is "easily accessible from each establishment" (operational accessibility constraint).
If appointing a single DPO for multiple public authorities/bodies, the designation must take account of "organisational structure and size" (organizational constraint).
technical_restrictions: None specified.
geographic_restrictions: Accessibility requirement applies across each establishment in a group; no explicit geographic limitation stated.

individual_rights: None explicitly granted in this excerpt.
organizational_rights: Right/option for a group of undertakings to appoint a single DPO subject to accessibility condition. Quote: "may appoint a single data protection officer"
Right/option for public authorities/bodies to designate a single DPO for several authorities/bodies, considering structure and size. Quote: "may be designated for several such authorities or bodies"
Right/option for controllers/processors and representative associations to designate a DPO even when not mandatory under paragraph 1. Quote: "may ... designate a data protection officer"
Right/option to engage DPO as staff or via service contract. Quote: "may be a staff member ... or ... service contract"
how_to_exercise_rights: Exercise options by formally designating a DPO and ensuring conditions (e.g., accessibility) are met; publish and notify contact details as required.

general_exceptions: Courts acting in their judicial capacity are excluded from the public authority/body trigger. Quote: "except for courts acting in their judicial capacity"
conditional_exemptions: Outside paragraph 1 triggers, designation is not mandatory unless required by Union or Member State law. Quote: "In cases other than those referred to in paragraph 1 ... may or, where required by Union or Member State law shall, designate"
public_interest_exceptions: Public authority/body processing generally triggers mandatory DPO designation, but courts in judicial capacity are carved out (institutional exception).
size_based_exceptions: None explicitly; however, multi-authority DPO designation must take account of organizational structure and size (not an exemption, but a consideration).

technical_measures: None specified.
organizational_measures: Assess whether paragraph 1 triggers apply (public authority/body processing; core activities involving large-scale monitoring; core activities involving large-scale processing of Article 9/10 data).
If a group-wide DPO is appointed, implement organizational arrangements ensuring the DPO is "easily accessible from each establishment."
If a single DPO is designated for multiple public authorities/bodies, structure the arrangement taking account of "organisational structure and size."
Ensure DPO selection criteria include professional qualities and expert knowledge of data protection law and practices, and capability to perform Article 39 tasks.
Decide and document engagement model (internal staff vs service contract) consistent with the requirement that the DPO can fulfill tasks.
security_measures: None specified.
training_requirements: Not explicitly required; implied by requirement for "expert knowledge" but no training mandate stated.
audit_requirements: None specified.
certification_requirements: None specified.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Supervisory authority (as referenced: "communicate them to the supervisory authority")
enforcement_mechanisms: Regulator oversight facilitated by mandatory communication of DPO contact details to the supervisory authority.

related_articles: GDPR Article 9 (special categories of personal data) (referenced as trigger)
GDPR Article 10 (personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences) (referenced as trigger)
GDPR Article 39 (tasks of the DPO) (referenced for capability requirement)
complementary_regulations: Union or Member State law (unspecified) that may require DPO designation in additional cases (paragraph 4).

implementation_steps: Determine whether the organization is a controller and/or processor for the relevant processing operations.
Check if processing is carried out by a public authority/body; if yes, designate a DPO unless the entity is a court acting in a judicial capacity for that processing.
Identify the organizationâ€™s "core activities" and assess whether they require "regular and systematic monitoring of data subjects on a large scale"; if yes, designate a DPO.
Assess whether core activities involve "processing on a large scale" of (i) special categories of data (Article 9) or (ii) criminal conviction/offence data (Article 10); if yes, designate a DPO.
If part of a group of undertakings, decide whether to appoint a single DPO; if so, ensure the DPO is "easily accessible from each establishment."
If a public authority/body among several, consider designating a single DPO across authorities/bodies, ensuring the arrangement accounts for organizational structure and size.
Select the DPO based on professional qualities, expert knowledge of data protection law/practices, and ability to perform Article 39 tasks.
Choose engagement model: internal staff member or external service contract.
Publish DPO contact details and communicate them to the supervisory authority.
common_violations: Failing to designate a DPO despite meeting one of the paragraph 1 triggers.
Appointing a group-wide DPO without ensuring the DPO is "easily accessible from each establishment."
Designating a DPO without sufficient "expert knowledge of data protection law and practices" or without ensuring capability to fulfill Article 39 tasks.
Failing to publish DPO contact details and/or failing to communicate them to the supervisory authority.
best_practices: Document the assessment of whether paragraph 1 triggers apply (public authority status; core activities; large-scale monitoring; large-scale Article 9/10 processing).
Define and operationalize "easily accessible" (e.g., clear contact channels for each establishment) consistent with the requirement.
Maintain a role description and selection rationale evidencing professional qualities and expertise.
Ensure public-facing privacy notices or equivalent channels include DPO contact details and that regulator notification is completed and kept current.
compliance_checklist: Have we assessed whether we are a public authority/body and whether any processing is excluded as a court acting judicially?
Have we assessed whether our core activities require regular and systematic monitoring of data subjects on a large scale?
Have we assessed whether our core activities involve large-scale processing of Article 9 special categories or Article 10 criminal conviction/offence data?
If required, have we formally designated a DPO?
Was the DPO selected based on professional qualities and expert knowledge, and ability to perform Article 39 tasks?
Is the DPO a staff member or engaged under a service contract (and is this arrangement documented)?
If a single DPO is used across a group, is the DPO easily accessible from each establishment?
If a single DPO is used across multiple public authorities/bodies, does the arrangement account for organizational structure and size?
Have we published the DPOâ€™s contact details?
Have we communicated the DPOâ€™s contact details to the supervisory authority?

key_definitions.core activities: Not defined in this excerpt; used as a trigger criterion for mandatory DPO designation.
key_definitions.regular and systematic monitoring: Not defined in this excerpt; used as a trigger criterion when conducted on a large scale.
key_definitions.large scale: Not defined in this excerpt; used as a threshold for monitoring and for processing of Article 9/10 data.
key_definitions.special categories of data: Referenced as "special categories of data pursuant to Article 9" (definition not included in this excerpt).
key_definitions.personal data relating to criminal convi: Referenced as data "referred to in Article 10" (definition not included in this excerpt).
key_definitions.group of undertakings: Not defined in this excerpt; used to permit appointment of a single DPO subject to accessibility.
key_definitions.easily accessible: Not defined in this excerpt; stated condition: "a data protection officer is easily accessible from each establishment."

regulations.source_section: ## Designation of the data protection officer

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 38 (Position of the data protection officer)

applicable_regions: European Economic Area (via incorporation into EEA law where applicable)

description.brief_summary: Article 38 requires controllers and processors to ensure the DPO is timely involved in data protection matters, adequately supported with resources and access, independent from instructions and retaliation, directly reporting to top management, reachable by data subjects, bound by confidentiality, and free from conflicts of interest when performing other duties.
description.detailed_explanation: The provision imposes direct duties on both controllers and processors to operationalize the DPO function. It mandates (i) timely and proper involvement of the DPO in all personal data protection issues; (ii) provision of resources and access necessary for the DPO to perform tasks (explicitly referencing Article 39 tasks) and to maintain expert knowledge; (iii) independence safeguards, including a prohibition on instructions regarding task performance, protection from dismissal/penalization for performing tasks, and a requirement that the DPO reports directly to the highest management level; (iv) accessibility for data subjects to contact the DPO on all issues related to processing and exercising rights; (v) secrecy/confidentiality obligations for the DPO in accordance with Union or Member State law; and (vi) allowance for the DPO to perform other tasks provided the controller/processor ensures no conflict of interests results.
description.purpose: To ensure the DPO can effectively oversee and advise on compliance by being integrated into processing-related decision-making, adequately resourced, independent, accessible to individuals, and protected from conflicts and retaliation.
description.legislative_intent: To strengthen accountability and compliance by embedding an independent expert role within organizations, ensuring management-level visibility, and enabling data subjects to engage with a dedicated contact for rights and processing concerns.

what_it_covers: Involvement of the DPO in personal data protection issues
Support and resourcing of the DPO function
Independence of the DPO (no instructions; protection from dismissal/penalization)
DPO reporting line to highest management
Data subject communications with the DPO
DPO secrecy/confidentiality obligations
Managing conflicts of interest when DPO has other duties

target_entities: Data protection officer (role obligations and protections)
entity_types: Any organization acting as controller or processor under GDPR
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities subject to GDPR (not specified in this section).

what_it_does_not_cover: Criteria for when a DPO must be designated (not in this section)
Detailed list of DPO tasks (referenced as Article 39 but not enumerated here)
Specific resource quantities or staffing ratios
Specific procedures for handling data subject communications

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Ensure the DPO is involved properly and in a timely manner in all issues relating to the protection of personal data.
mandatory_obligations.exact_quote: â€œThe controller and the processor shall ensure that the data protection officer is involved, properly and in a timely manner, in all issues which relate to the protection of personal data.â€
mandatory_obligations.operational_detail: Organizations must integrate the DPO into relevant workflows and decision-making processes affecting personal data protection, ensuring early engagement rather than after-the-fact consultation.

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Support the DPO in performing tasks referred to in Article 39 by providing necessary resources to carry out those tasks.
mandatory_obligations.exact_quote: â€œThe controller and processor shall support the data protection officer in performing the tasks referred to in Article 39 by providing resources necessary to carry out those tasksâ€¦â€
mandatory_obligations.operational_detail: Must allocate sufficient resources (e.g., time, budget, staff support, tools) to enable performance of Article 39 tasks; the section does not quantify resources.

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Provide the DPO with access to personal data and processing operations.
mandatory_obligations.exact_quote: â€œâ€¦and access to personal data and processing operationsâ€¦â€
mandatory_obligations.operational_detail: Must ensure the DPO can review relevant data and observe/assess processing activities as needed for their tasks.

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Enable the DPO to maintain expert knowledge.
mandatory_obligations.exact_quote: â€œâ€¦and to maintain his or her expert knowledge.â€
mandatory_obligations.operational_detail: Must support ongoing professional development/knowledge maintenance (e.g., training, time for learning), though specific methods are not prescribed.

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Ensure the DPO does not receive instructions regarding the exercise of DPO tasks.
mandatory_obligations.exact_quote: â€œThe controller and processor shall ensure that the data protection officer does not receive any instructions regarding the exercise of those tasks.â€
mandatory_obligations.operational_detail: Must preserve functional independence; management cannot direct outcomes or methods of DPO task execution.

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Ensure the DPO is not dismissed or penalised for performing DPO tasks.
mandatory_obligations.exact_quote: â€œHe or she shall not be dismissed or penalised by the controller or the processor for performing his tasks.â€
mandatory_obligations.operational_detail: Must implement protections against retaliation linked to DPO task performance (employment/contractual safeguards).

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Ensure the DPO directly reports to the highest management level of the controller or processor.
mandatory_obligations.exact_quote: â€œThe data protection officer shall directly report to the highest management level of the controller or the processor.â€
mandatory_obligations.operational_detail: Must establish a reporting line enabling direct escalation to top management (e.g., board/executive level), not filtered through intermediate management.

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Allow data subjects to contact the DPO regarding all issues related to processing of their personal data and the exercise of their rights under the Regulation.
responsible_party: Processor (to the extent it provides interfaces/communications; the text states data subjects may contact the DPO without limiting to controller-only)
mandatory_obligations.exact_quote: â€œData subjects may contact the data protection officer with regard to all issues related to processing of their personal data and to the exercise of their rights under this Regulation.â€
mandatory_obligations.operational_detail: Must ensure practical reachability of the DPO (contact channels), covering both processing questions and rights exercise matters.

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Ensure the DPO is bound by secrecy or confidentiality concerning performance of tasks, in accordance with Union or Member State law.
mandatory_obligations.exact_quote: â€œThe data protection officer shall be bound by secrecy or confidentiality concerning the performance of his or her tasks, in accordance with Union or Member State law.â€
mandatory_obligations.operational_detail: Confidentiality is tied to applicable Union/Member State legal rules; organizations should align DPO engagement and disclosures accordingly.

mandatory_obligations.obligation: If the DPO fulfills other tasks and duties, ensure those do not result in a conflict of interests.
mandatory_obligations.exact_quote: â€œThe data protection officer may fulfil other tasks and duties. The controller or processor shall ensure that any such tasks and duties do not result in a conflict of interests.â€
mandatory_obligations.operational_detail: Must assess and manage role combinations to prevent conflicts (e.g., DPO should not determine purposes/means of processing if that creates conflict; specific examples not provided in this section).

prohibited_actions.prohibition: Do not give the DPO instructions regarding the exercise of DPO tasks.
prohibited_actions.exact_quote: â€œâ€¦does not receive any instructions regarding the exercise of those tasks.â€

prohibited_actions.prohibition: Do not dismiss the DPO for performing DPO tasks.
prohibited_actions.exact_quote: â€œHe or she shall not be dismissedâ€¦â€

prohibited_actions.prohibition: Do not penalise the DPO for performing DPO tasks.
prohibited_actions.exact_quote: â€œâ€¦or penalisedâ€¦ for performing his tasks.â€

prohibited_actions.prohibition: Do not assign other tasks/duties to the DPO that result in a conflict of interests.
prohibited_actions.exact_quote: â€œâ€¦shall ensure that any such tasks and duties do not result in a conflict of interests.â€

conditional_requirements.condition: Where the DPO performs tasks referred to in Article 39
conditional_requirements.requirement: Provide resources necessary to carry out those tasks and provide access to personal data and processing operations; support maintenance of expert knowledge.
conditional_requirements.exact_quote: â€œâ€¦support the data protection officer in performing the tasks referred to in Article 39 by providing resources necessary to carry out those tasks and access to personal data and processing operations, and to maintain his or her expert knowledge.â€

conditional_requirements.condition: Where the DPO fulfills other tasks and duties
conditional_requirements.requirement: Ensure those tasks/duties do not result in a conflict of interests.
conditional_requirements.exact_quote: â€œThe data protection officer may fulfil other tasks and duties. The controller or processor shall ensure that any such tasks and duties do not result in a conflict of interests.â€

conditional_requirements.condition: Confidentiality/secrecy obligations apply in accordance with Union or Member State law
conditional_requirements.requirement: DPO must be bound by secrecy/confidentiality as defined by applicable law.
conditional_requirements.exact_quote: â€œâ€¦in accordance with Union or Member State law.â€

reporting_requirements.requirement: DPO must directly report to the highest management level of the controller or processor.
reporting_requirements.exact_quote: â€œThe data protection officer shall directly report to the highest management levelâ€¦â€
reporting_requirements.recipient: Highest management level of the controller or the processor

timeline_requirements.deadline_or_timeframe: Not quantified; requires early/appropriate timing relative to issues relating to personal data protection.

general_restrictions: DPO independence must be preserved (no instructions regarding task exercise).
No retaliation (dismissal or penalization) for performing DPO tasks.
Role combination permitted only if no conflict of interests results.
data_restrictions: DPO confidentiality/secrecy applies to performance of tasks, subject to Union/Member State law.
operational_restrictions: Organizational reporting structure must allow direct reporting to highest management level.

individual_rights.right: Right/ability to contact the DPO regarding all issues related to processing of personal data and exercising rights under the Regulation.
individual_rights.exact_quote: â€œData subjects may contact the data protection officerâ€¦â€
individual_rights.scope: All issues related to processing and to the exercise of rights under the Regulation.

organizational_rights.right: Ability for the DPO to fulfill other tasks and duties (subject to conflict-of-interest safeguards).
organizational_rights.exact_quote: â€œThe data protection officer may fulfil other tasks and duties.â€
