implementation_steps: Adopt/maintain internal rules and safeguards ensuring supervisory authority decisions are made independently and without external influence.
Establish and enforce member conduct rules prohibiting seeking/taking instructions and preventing incompatible actions/occupations during term.
Allocate sufficient human, technical, and financial resources, premises, and infrastructure to the supervisory authority, including for cross-authority cooperation and Board participation.
Design staffing frameworks so the supervisory authority selects its own staff and staff report exclusively to the authorityâ€™s member(s).
Implement budgeting and financial oversight so budgets are separate and public annually, and any financial control/audit does not compromise independence.
common_violations: Government ministry or external body directing or influencing supervisory authority decisions (directly or indirectly).
Members accepting or requesting instructions from political leadership, regulated entities, or other third parties.
Members holding outside roles/occupations that are incompatible with supervisory duties (including unpaid positions).
Insufficient resourcing that prevents effective performance, especially for cooperation/mutual assistance/Board participation.
Staffing controlled by external civil service structures such that staff are not under exclusive direction of authority members.
Budgeting/financial control arrangements that constrain independence (e.g., conditional funding tied to decision outcomes) or lack separate/public annual budgets.
best_practices: Formal independence policy and code of conduct for members, including conflict-of-interest and outside-occupation assessment.
Documented procedures for handling attempted external influence and reporting/recording such attempts.
Ring-fenced budget lines and transparent publication of annual budgets.
Clear organizational chart and HR policies confirming exclusive direction of staff by authority leadership.
Resource planning that explicitly accounts for mutual assistance, cooperation, and Board participation workload.
compliance_checklist: Supervisory authority operates with complete independence in tasks/powers under the Regulation.
Members are demonstrably free from external influence (direct/indirect).
Members neither seek nor take instructions from any person/body.
Members refrain from incompatible actions and do not engage in incompatible occupations during term (paid or unpaid).
Member State provides adequate human, technical, and financial resources, premises, and infrastructure (including for mutual assistance/cooperation/Board participation).
Supervisory authority chooses and has its own staff.
Staff are subject to exclusive direction of authority member(s).
Financial control exists only in a form that does not affect independence.
Separate, public annual budgets exist (may be within overall state/national budget but remain separate and public).

key_definitions.complete independence: Not defined in this section; stated as a required standard for supervisory authority action.
key_definitions.external influence: Not defined in this section; includes both direct and indirect influence per the text.
key_definitions.incompatible occupation: Not defined in this section; includes any occupation incompatible with duties, whether gainful or not.
key_definitions.financial control which does not affect: Not defined in this section; requires financial oversight arrangements that do not compromise supervisory authority independence.
key_definitions.separate, public annual budgets: Not defined in this section; requires budgets that are distinct for the authority, publicly available, and prepared annually; may be included within overall state/national budget.

description.brief_summary: Imposes mandatory governance safeguards for members of national supervisory authorities, including transparent appointment routes, competence requirements, lawful end-of-term events, and limited grounds for dismissal.
description.detailed_explanation: This section mandates that each EU Member State must establish rules ensuring that every member of its supervisory authority is appointed through a transparent procedure and only by one of the enumerated appointing bodies (parliament, government, head of State, or an independent body empowered under national law). It further requires that each member possess adequate qualifications, experience, and skillsâ€”particularly in personal data protectionâ€”to perform duties and exercise powers. It specifies that a memberâ€™s duties end only upon expiry of term, resignation, or compulsory retirement, and only as provided by the law of the relevant Member State. Finally, it restricts dismissal to two exclusive grounds: serious misconduct or failure to continue meeting the conditions required to perform the duties, thereby limiting arbitrary removal.
description.purpose: To ensure competent, stable, and procedurally legitimate composition of supervisory authorities, supporting their effective functioning and safeguarding against arbitrary appointment or removal.
description.legislative_intent: To require Member States to implement transparent appointment mechanisms, ensure membersâ€™ expertise (especially in data protection), and protect membersâ€™ tenure by limiting dismissal grounds, thereby reinforcing the authorityâ€™s integrity and independence in practice.

what_it_covers: Appointment procedure for each member of a supervisory authority
Permissible appointing bodies for members
Minimum competence/qualification expectations for members
Circumstances in which a memberâ€™s duties end
Permissible grounds for dismissal of a member

target_entities: Supervisory authorities (as institutions implementing these rules)
Members of supervisory authorities (as subjects of appointment/tenure rules)
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies within each EU Member State to its supervisory authority/authorities.

what_it_does_not_cover: Specific term length for office (not stated)
Detailed definition of 'transparent procedure' (not stated)
Detailed definition of 'serious misconduct' (not stated)
Specific process for dismissal (not stated)
Specific process for resignation or compulsory retirement (not stated)
Number of members or internal structure of the supervisory authority (not stated)

mandatory_obligations: Member States must ensure that "each member of their supervisory authorities" is "appointed by means of a transparent procedure". (Quote: "Member States shall provide for each member of their supervisory authorities to be appointed by means of a transparent procedure")

Member States must ensure appointment is made by one of the permitted appointing bodies: parliament, government, head of State, or an independent body entrusted with appointment under Member State law. (Quote: "by: â€” their parliament; â€” their government; â€” their head of State; or â€” an independent body entrusted with the appointment under Member State law.")

Each member must have the qualifications, experience, and skills required to perform duties and exercise powers, with particular emphasis on personal data protection. (Quote: "Each member shall have the qualifications, experience and skills, in particular in the area of the protection of personal data, required to perform its duties and exercise its powers.")

Member States must ensure that end of duties occurs in accordance with national law when triggered by expiry of term, resignation, or compulsory retirement. (Quote: "The duties of a member shall end in the event of the expiry of the term of office, resignation or compulsory retirement, in accordance with the law of the Member State concerned.")

A member may be dismissed only on the limited grounds specified: serious misconduct or no longer fulfilling required conditions. (Quote: "A member shall be dismissed only in cases of serious misconduct or if the member no longer fulfils the conditions required for the performance of the duties.")
prohibited_actions: Member States (and relevant appointing/dismissing bodies) must not dismiss a member on grounds other than "serious misconduct" or the member no longer fulfilling required conditions. (Derived from: "dismissed only in cases of...")
Member States must not use a non-transparent appointment procedure for members. (Derived from: "appointed by means of a transparent procedure")

Member States must not appoint members through bodies other than those listed (parliament, government, head of State, or an independent body entrusted under national law). (Derived from the exhaustive list introduced by "by:")
conditional_requirements: If an "independent body" is used as the appointing body, it must be "entrusted with the appointment under Member State law". (Quote: "an independent body entrusted with the appointment under Member State law")

Dismissal is permissible only if either condition is met: (a) serious misconduct, or (b) member no longer fulfills conditions required for performance of duties. (Quote: "only in cases of serious misconduct or if the member no longer fulfils the conditions...")

End of duties occurs when one of the listed events occurs (expiry of term, resignation, compulsory retirement) and must be handled "in accordance with" national law. (Quote: "shall end in the event of... in accordance with the law...")
documentation_requirements: The appointment procedure must be transparent, implying the need for documented procedures and criteria sufficient to demonstrate transparency; however, no explicit document types are specified in the text.
timeline_requirements: Duties end upon "expiry of the term of office" (no duration specified).
Duties end upon "resignation" (no notice period specified).
Duties end upon "compulsory retirement" (timing governed by Member State law; no age/trigger specified).

general_restrictions: Appointment must be conducted via a "transparent procedure".
Appointment authority is restricted to the enumerated bodies.
Dismissal is restricted to the enumerated grounds only.
operational_restrictions: Member Statesâ€™ discretion in appointing members is constrained to the listed appointing bodies and transparency requirement.
Member Statesâ€™ discretion in removing members is constrained to the two listed grounds.
geographic_restrictions: Applies within the jurisdiction of each "Member State concerned".

individual_rights: Members of supervisory authorities have a protected tenure interest insofar as they "shall be dismissed only" on limited grounds (serious misconduct or no longer fulfilling required conditions).
how_to_exercise_rights: Not specified; procedures for challenging dismissal/appointment decisions are not described.

organizational_measures: Establish and maintain a transparent appointment procedure for each member.
Define, apply, and verify qualification/experience/skills criteria for members, with emphasis on personal data protection competence.
Ensure national legal framework specifies how duties end upon expiry of term, resignation, or compulsory retirement.
Implement dismissal rules limiting grounds to serious misconduct or failure to meet required conditions.

implementation_steps: Codify in national law a transparent appointment procedure for supervisory authority members, including publication of selection criteria and steps sufficient to evidence transparency.
Designate the appointing body (parliament, government, head of State, or qualifying independent body) and ensure legal authority is explicit if using an independent body.
Create competency frameworks and vetting processes to confirm candidatesâ€™ qualifications, experience, and skills, particularly in personal data protection.
Define term-of-office rules and lawful end-of-duty events (expiry, resignation, compulsory retirement) consistent with Member State law.
Adopt dismissal policies and procedures that restrict grounds to serious misconduct or failure to meet required conditions, and ensure decisions are documented against those grounds.
common_violations: Appointments made through opaque or undocumented processes that cannot be shown to be transparent.
Appointments made by bodies not listed (e.g., a ministry/agency without clear status as 'government' or without being an 'independent body entrusted under law').
Selecting members without demonstrable competence in personal data protection.
Removing members for reasons outside the two permitted grounds (e.g., political disagreement, restructuring without meeting the stated grounds).
best_practices: Publish appointment criteria, timelines, and decision-making steps to substantiate transparency.
Maintain written records evidencing how each appointee meets qualification/experience/skills requirements.

Define 'serious misconduct' and 'conditions required for performance of duties' in national law or internal rules consistent with overarching legal requirements, to reduce arbitrariness (not mandated but supports compliance).
Ensure dismissal decisions explicitly map facts to one of the permitted grounds and are supported by documented evidence.
compliance_checklist: Is there a documented, transparent appointment procedure for each member?
Is the appointing body one of: parliament, government, head of State, or an independent body entrusted under Member State law?
If an independent body appoints, is its entrustment clearly established in Member State law?
Do selection records show each member has qualifications, experience, and skills required, particularly in personal data protection?
Do national rules specify that duties end only upon expiry of term, resignation, or compulsory retirement, in accordance with Member State law?
Are dismissal grounds limited to serious misconduct or failure to meet required conditions, with no other grounds used in practice?

key_definitions.independent body entrusted with the appo: An independent body that has been granted legal authority under the relevant Member Stateâ€™s law to appoint members of the supervisory authority (the section does not define 'independent' or the entrustment mechanism).

regulations.source_section: ## General conditions for the members of the supervisory authority

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 54 (Rules on the establishment of the supervisory authority)

industry_sectors: All sectors (public and private) insofar as they interact with supervisory authorities under GDPR

description.brief_summary: Member States must legislate to establish supervisory authorities and define appointment, eligibility, term length, reappointment, incompatibilities, cessation rules, and professional secrecy obligations for members and staff.
description.detailed_explanation: The provision imposes a legislative duty on each EU Member State to enact national laws covering a defined set of institutional and governance elements for its supervisory authority/authorities. These elements include: (a) the legal establishment of each supervisory authority; (b) qualifications and eligibility conditions for appointment as a member; (c) appointment rules and procedures; (d) term duration of at least four years, with a specific exception for the first appointment after 24 May 2016 allowing a shorter term where necessary to protect independence via staggered appointments; (e) whether reappointment is permitted and, if so, the number of terms; and (f) conditions governing obligations of members and staff, prohibitions on incompatible actions/occupations/benefits during and after office, and rules on cessation of employment. Additionally, members and staff must be subject to a duty of professional secrecy under Union or Member State law during and after their term, covering confidential information learned in performing tasks or exercising powers; during office, this duty specifically includes reports by natural persons of infringements of the GDPR.
description.purpose: To ensure supervisory authorities are properly constituted in national law with safeguards for independence, integrity, continuity, and confidentiality in the performance of GDPR oversight functions.
description.legislative_intent: To harmonize minimum governance requirements across Member States for supervisory authorities, including minimum term stability and confidentiality protections, while allowing Member States to implement detailed national procedures consistent with EU law.

what_it_covers: National legal framework for establishing supervisory authorities
Member qualifications and eligibility criteria
Appointment procedures for supervisory authority members
Term length rules (including minimum duration and initial staggered appointment exception)
Reappointment eligibility and term limits (if any)
Obligations and incompatibility rules for members and staff during and after office
Cessation of employment rules for members and staff
Professional secrecy obligations for members and staff during and after office
Confidentiality of information obtained through tasks/powers, including reports of infringements by natural persons

target_entities: EU Member States (legislators / competent national authorities responsible for enacting laws)
entity_types: National legislatures / government bodies responsible for legal implementation
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies within each EU Member State for its supervisory authority/authorities.

what_it_does_not_cover: Specific enforcement powers, investigative procedures, or sanctioning rules (not detailed in this section)
Specific fine levels or penalties (not stated in this section)
Detailed definitions of 'confidential information' beyond the described context

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Member States must provide by law for the establishment of each supervisory authority.
mandatory_obligations.how_to_comply: Enact national legislation that legally establishes the supervisory authority/authorities.
mandatory_obligations.legal_text_quote: â€œEach Member State shall provide by law for all of the following: (a) the establishment of each supervisory authority;â€

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Member States must provide by law for the qualifications and eligibility conditions required to be appointed as member of each supervisory authority.
mandatory_obligations.how_to_comply: Define in national law the qualifications and eligibility conditions for appointment as a supervisory authority member.
mandatory_obligations.legal_text_quote: â€œ(b) the qualifications and eligibility conditions required to be appointed as member of each supervisory authority;â€

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Member States must provide by law for the rules and procedures for the appointment of the member or members of each supervisory authority.
mandatory_obligations.how_to_comply: Set out in national law the appointment rules and procedures for supervisory authority members.
mandatory_obligations.legal_text_quote: â€œ(c) the rules and procedures for the appointment of the member or members of each supervisory authority;â€

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Member States must provide by law for the duration of the term of supervisory authority member(s) of no less than four years, subject to a limited exception for first appointments after 24 May 2016.
mandatory_obligations.how_to_comply: Legislate a minimum term length of at least four years for members, and if using staggered appointments for initial post-24 May 2016 appointments, ensure any shorter term is only to the extent necessary to protect independence.
mandatory_obligations.legal_text_quote: â€œ(d) the duration of the term of the member or members of each supervisory authority of no less than four years, except for the first appointment after 24 May 2016, part of which may take place for a shorter period where that is necessary to protect the independence of the supervisory authority by means of a staggered appointment procedure;â€

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Member States must provide by law whether and, if so, for how many terms supervisory authority member(s) are eligible for reappointment.
mandatory_obligations.how_to_comply: Specify in national law whether reappointment is allowed and, if allowed, the maximum number of terms (or other term-limit structure).
mandatory_obligations.legal_text_quote: â€œ(e) whether and, if so, for how many terms the member or members of each supervisory authority is eligible for reappointment;â€

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Member States must provide by law for conditions governing obligations of members and staff, prohibitions on incompatible actions/occupations/benefits during and after office, and rules governing cessation of employment.
mandatory_obligations.how_to_comply: Enact national rules covering: (i) obligations of members and staff; (ii) prohibitions on actions, occupations, and benefits incompatible with their role during and after term; and (iii) cessation of employment rules.
mandatory_obligations.legal_text_quote: â€œ(f) the conditions governing the obligations of the member or members and staff of each supervisory authority, prohibitions on actions, occupations and benefits incompatible therewith during and after the term of office and rules governing the cessation of employment.â€

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Members and staff of each supervisory authority must be subject to a duty of professional secrecy during and after their term of office regarding confidential information learned through their tasks/powers, in accordance with Union or Member State law.
mandatory_obligations.how_to_comply: Maintain professional secrecy over confidential information obtained in the course of performing tasks or exercising powers, both during and after service, as required by applicable Union or Member State law.
mandatory_obligations.legal_text_quote: â€œThe member or members and the staff of each supervisory authority shall, in accordance with Union or Member State law, be subject to a duty of professional secrecy both during and after their term of office, with regard to any confidential information which has come to their knowledge in the course of the performance of their tasks or exercise of their powers.â€

mandatory_obligations.obligation: During their term of office, the duty of professional secrecy must in particular apply to reporting by natural persons of infringements of the GDPR.
mandatory_obligations.how_to_comply: Treat reports made by natural persons about infringements of the GDPR as covered by professional secrecy during the term of office.
mandatory_obligations.legal_text_quote: â€œDuring their term of office, that duty of professional secrecy shall in particular apply to reporting by natural persons of infringements of this Regulation.â€

prohibited_actions.prohibition: Actions, occupations, and benefits incompatible with the obligations of supervisory authority members and staff must be prohibited during and after the term of office (as defined by Member State law).
prohibited_actions.legal_text_quote: â€œprohibitions on actions, occupations and benefits incompatible therewith during and after the term of officeâ€
prohibited_actions.notes: The specific incompatible actions/occupations/benefits are not enumerated here; Member State law must define them.

prohibited_actions.prohibition: Disclosure of confidential information learned through tasks/powers is prohibited by the duty of professional secrecy during and after office (subject to Union/Member State law).
prohibited_actions.legal_text_quote: â€œbe subject to a duty of professional secrecy both during and after their term of office, with regard to any confidential information which has come to their knowledgeâ€¦â€

conditional_requirements.condition: Exception to minimum four-year term for first appointment after 24 May 2016.
conditional_requirements.requirement_if_condition_met: Part of the first appointment after 24 May 2016 may be for a shorter period only where necessary to protect independence via a staggered appointment procedure.
conditional_requirements.legal_text_quote: â€œexcept for the first appointment after 24 May 2016, part of which may take place for a shorter period where that is necessary to protect the independence of the supervisory authority by means of a staggered appointment procedure;â€

conditional_requirements.condition: Reappointment rules apply only if Member State law allows reappointment.
conditional_requirements.requirement_if_condition_met: If reappointment is allowed, Member State law must specify for how many terms reappointment is permitted.
conditional_requirements.legal_text_quote: â€œwhether and, if so, for how many termsâ€¦ is eligible for reappointment;â€

conditional_requirements.condition: Professional secrecy duty is applied 'in accordance with Union or Member State law'.
conditional_requirements.requirement_if_condition_met: The duty must be implemented and interpreted consistent with applicable Union or Member State legal provisions governing professional secrecy/confidentiality.
conditional_requirements.legal_text_quote: â€œshall, in accordance with Union or Member State law, be subject to a duty of professional secrecyâ€¦â€

documentation_requirements.document_or_record: National legal provisions establishing and governing the supervisory authority (covering items (a)â€“(f)).
documentation_requirements.legal_text_quote: â€œEach Member State shall provide by law for all of the followingâ€¦â€

reporting_requirements.requirement: Confidential handling (professional secrecy) must cover reports by natural persons of infringements during members'/staff term of office.
reporting_requirements.legal_text_quote: â€œshall in particular apply to reporting by natural persons of infringements of this Regulation.â€
reporting_requirements.notes: This is not a duty to report; it is a confidentiality requirement concerning such reports.

timeline_requirements.timeline: Minimum term length: no less than four years.
timeline_requirements.legal_text_quote: â€œthe duration of the termâ€¦ of no less than four yearsâ€

timeline_requirements.timeline: Exception applies to first appointment after 24 May 2016 (may include a shorter period if necessary for staggered appointments to protect independence).
timeline_requirements.legal_text_quote: â€œexcept for the first appointment after 24 May 2016â€¦â€

timeline_requirements.timeline: Professional secrecy applies both during and after term of office.
timeline_requirements.legal_text_quote: â€œboth during and after their term of officeâ€

general_restrictions: Member States must legislate governance safeguards including incompatibility prohibitions and cessation rules for supervisory authority members and staff.
Members and staff are restricted by professional secrecy obligations regarding confidential information obtained through official functions.
data_restrictions: Confidential information obtained in the course of tasks/powers must not be disclosed (professional secrecy), including information relating to reports by natural persons of infringements during term of office.
operational_restrictions: Members and staff must not engage in actions, occupations, or accept benefits incompatible with their obligations during and after office (details to be set by Member State law).

conditional_exemptions: Minimum four-year term requirement has a limited exception for the first appointment after 24 May 2016, allowing a shorter period only where necessary to protect independence via staggered appointments.

organizational_measures: Adopt/maintain national legal framework covering establishment, appointment, term, reappointment, obligations, incompatibilities, and cessation rules for supervisory authority members and staff.

Implement confidentiality/professional secrecy rules and internal practices ensuring confidential information (including infringement reports by natural persons) is protected during and after service.
security_measures: Ensure organizational controls to preserve confidentiality of information obtained through supervisory authority functions (implied by professional secrecy duty; specific measures not prescribed in this section).

implementation_steps: Draft/enact national legislation explicitly covering items (a)â€“(f) for each supervisory authority.
Set minimum member term length to at least four years; if implementing staggered initial appointments after 24 May 2016, document necessity linked to protecting independence.
Define qualification/eligibility criteria and appointment procedures in law.
Decide and codify reappointment permissibility and any term limits.
Codify obligations and incompatibility prohibitions for members and staff during and after office, and define cessation of employment rules.
Implement professional secrecy obligations for members and staff, including procedures to protect confidentiality of infringement reports by natural persons.
common_violations: National law omits one or more required elements (e.g., no clear appointment procedure or no reappointment rule).
Term length set below four years without fitting the narrow initial post-24 May 2016 staggered-appointment necessity.
Lack of clear incompatibility rules for members/staff or lack of post-term restrictions.
Inadequate confidentiality handling of information obtained through supervisory authority functions, including whistleblower-type reports.
best_practices: Use clear statutory language mapping directly to items (a)â€“(f).
Provide transparent, objective appointment procedures and eligibility criteria to support independence.
Define incompatibilities and cooling-off/post-employment restrictions proportionately and clearly.
Adopt strict confidentiality protocols and access controls for case files and infringement reports.
compliance_checklist: Law establishes each supervisory authority.
Law defines qualifications and eligibility conditions for members.
Law defines appointment rules and procedures.
Law sets term length >= 4 years, with any initial post-24 May 2016 shorter term justified solely for staggered appointments to protect independence.
Law states whether reappointment is allowed and, if allowed, maximum number of terms.
Law defines obligations of members and staff.
Law prohibits incompatible actions/occupations/benefits during and after term.
Law defines cessation of employment rules.
Members and staff are bound by professional secrecy during and after office for confidential information obtained through tasks/powers.
Professional secrecy during office explicitly covers reports by natural persons of GDPR infringements.

key_definitions.professional secrecy: A duty binding supervisory authority members and staff to keep confidential information learned through official tasks/powers secret during and after their term of office (as applicable under Union or Member State law).
key_definitions.staggered appointment procedure: An appointment approach where initial terms may be set to different lengths to avoid simultaneous turnover, used here as a mechanism to protect supervisory authority independence (explicitly referenced as justification for a limited shorter initial term after 24 May 2016).
key_definitions.confidential information: Information that has come to the knowledge of supervisory authority members/staff in the course of performing tasks or exercising powers and is subject to professional secrecy (not further defined in this section).

regulations.source_section: ## Rules on the establishment of the supervisory authority

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 55 (Competence)

sub_domains: Jurisdiction and territorial scope of enforcement
industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data in the EU

description.brief_summary: Allocates supervisory authority competence primarily by Member State territory, provides a special competence rule for processing by public authorities/private bodies acting under specific legal bases, and excludes supervisory authority competence over courts acting in a judicial capacity.
description.detailed_explanation: This section sets binding rules determining which supervisory authority has jurisdiction to carry out GDPR tasks and exercise GDPR powers. First, it establishes a default territorial rule: each supervisory authority is competent within its own Member State territory for tasks and powers assigned by the GDPR. Second, it creates a specific allocation rule for processing carried out by public authorities or private bodies acting on the basis of Article 6(1)(c) (legal obligation) or Article 6(1)(e) (task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority): in those cases, the supervisory authority of the Member State concerned is competent, and the GDPR one-stop-shop mechanism in Article 56 is explicitly disapplied. Third, it sets an explicit exclusion: supervisory authorities are not competent to supervise processing operations of courts when courts act in their judicial capacity.
description.purpose: To clarify supervisory authority jurisdiction and avoid conflicts or gaps in oversight, including special handling for public-authority/official-authority processing and protection of judicial independence for courts acting judicially.
description.legislative_intent: To ensure clear, predictable allocation of supervisory authority competence across Member States, to prevent the one-stop-shop mechanism from displacing local competence for certain public-interest/legal-obligation processing, and to exclude supervisory oversight of courtsâ€™ judicial processing operations.

what_it_covers: Determination of which supervisory authority is competent to perform GDPR tasks
Determination of which supervisory authority is competent to exercise GDPR powers
Competence allocation for processing by public authorities or private bodies acting under Article 6(1)(c) or Article 6(1)(e)
Exclusion of supervisory authority competence over courts acting in their judicial capacity

entity_types: Private bodies acting on the basis of Article 6(1)(c) or (e)
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies to supervisory authorities and processing on the territory of EU Member States.

what_it_does_not_cover: Supervision of processing operations of courts acting in their judicial capacity (explicitly excluded)
Any competence rules not stated here (e.g., detailed cross-border cooperation procedures), except the explicit disapplication of Article 56 in the specified cases

mandatory_obligations: Each supervisory authority must be competent to perform GDPR-assigned tasks and exercise GDPR-conferred powers on the territory of its own Member State. (Quote: "Each supervisory authority shall be competent for the performance of the tasks assigned to and the exercise of the powers conferred on it in accordance with this Regulation on the territory of its own Member State.")

Where processing is carried out by public authorities or private bodies acting on the basis of Article 6(1)(c) or (e), the supervisory authority of the Member State concerned must be competent. (Quote: "the supervisory authority of the Member State concerned shall be competent.")
prohibited_actions: Supervisory authorities must not supervise processing operations of courts acting in their judicial capacity, because they are not competent to do so. (Quote: "Supervisory authorities shall not be competent to supervise processing operations of courts acting in their judicial capacity.")
conditional_requirements: If processing is carried out by public authorities or private bodies acting on the basis of Article 6(1)(c) or (e), then Article 56 does not apply. (Quote: "In such cases Article 56 does not apply.")

general_restrictions: Competence of a supervisory authority is territorially limited to "the territory of its own Member State" for the default rule.

For processing under Article 6(1)(c) or (e) by public authorities or private bodies, competence is restricted to the supervisory authority of the "Member State concerned" and the Article 56 mechanism is restricted (disapplied).
Supervisory authorities are restricted from supervising courtsâ€™ processing when courts act in a judicial capacity.
operational_restrictions: Limits which supervisory authority may act (jurisdictional/competence limitation) depending on territory, legal basis, and actor type (public authority/private body acting under specified legal bases).
geographic_restrictions: Default competence is limited to the supervisory authorityâ€™s own Member State territory.
Special-case competence is tied to the "Member State concerned" for Article 6(1)(c)/(e) processing by public authorities/private bodies.

general_exceptions: Courts acting in their judicial capacity are excluded from supervisory authority competence for supervision of their processing operations. (Quote: "shall not be competent to supervise processing operations of courts acting in their judicial capacity")
conditional_exemptions: Article 56 is inapplicable (effectively an exception to the one-stop-shop competence approach) where processing is carried out by public authorities or private bodies acting on the basis of Article 6(1)(c) or (e). (Quote: "In such cases Article 56 does not apply.")
public_interest_exceptions: Processing based on Article 6(1)(e) (public interest/official authority) triggers the special competence rule and disapplication of Article 56.

organizational_measures: Supervisory authorities should structure internal case intake/triage to ensure matters are handled by the competent authority based on Member State territory, and to route Article 6(1)(c)/(e) public-authority/official-authority cases to the supervisory authority of the Member State concerned, without applying Article 56 in those cases.
Supervisory authorities should implement procedures to identify and exclude from supervision any processing operations of courts acting in their judicial capacity.
training_requirements: Train supervisory authority staff on competence allocation rules, including the Article 6(1)(c)/(e) special rule and the courts-in-judicial-capacity exclusion.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: EU Member State supervisory authorities (competence allocated by this article).
enforcement_mechanisms: Jurisdiction/competence allocation determines which supervisory authority may take regulatory actions (tasks/powers) in a given matter; this section itself does not specify investigative steps or sanctions.

implementation_steps: Determine the Member State territory where the supervisory authority is acting; apply default competence within that territory.

When a case involves processing by a public authority or a private body acting under GDPR Article 6(1)(c) or (e), assign competence to the supervisory authority of the Member State concerned and do not apply Article 56 for competence determination in that case.
Screen matters involving courts to determine whether the court is acting in its judicial capacity; if yes, exclude the matter from supervisory authority supervision due to lack of competence.
common_violations: Applying Article 56 (one-stop-shop) to processing by public authorities/private bodies acting under Article 6(1)(c) or (e) despite the explicit rule that Article 56 does not apply in such cases.
Attempting to supervise or investigate processing operations of courts when the courts are acting in their judicial capacity.
A supervisory authority acting outside its Member State territorial competence under the default rule.
best_practices: Maintain a competence decision log documenting the basis for competence (territory; Article 6(1)(c)/(e) special rule; court judicial-capacity exclusion) even though not explicitly required here, to support defensibility of jurisdictional decisions.

Use standardized intake questions to identify (i) whether the controller/processor is a public authority, (ii) whether the legal basis is Article 6(1)(c) or (e), and (iii) whether the processing relates to a court acting judicially.
compliance_checklist: Is the supervisory authority acting within the territory of its own Member State for default competence matters?

Is the processing carried out by a public authority or a private body acting on the basis of GDPR Article 6(1)(c) or (e)? If yes, is the supervisory authority of the Member State concerned handling it?
If the special rule applies, has Article 56 been excluded from the competence analysis?
Does the matter involve a court acting in its judicial capacity? If yes, has the supervisory authority refrained from supervision due to lack of competence?

key_definitions.competent: Having jurisdiction/authority to perform GDPR tasks and exercise GDPR powers in the circumstances described (territory-based default; special rule for Article 6(1)(c)/(e) public-authority/official-authority processing; exclusion for courts acting judicially).
key_definitions.Member State concerned: The Member State relevant to the processing described in the section (used to allocate competence for processing by public authorities or private bodies acting under Article 6(1)(c) or (e)); further specification is not provided in this section.
key_definitions.courts acting in their judicial capacity: Courts performing judicial functions; processing operations in that context are excluded from supervisory authority competence (no further definition provided in this section).

regulations.regulation_name: General Data Protection Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2016/679) â€” Article 56: Competence of the lead supervisory authority

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data within GDPR scope

description.brief_summary: Allocates competence between the lead supervisory authority and other supervisory authorities for cross-border processing, including a local-handling derogation for matters limited to or substantially affecting one Member State, with mandatory notification, a three-week decision window for the lead authority, and procedural consequences depending on whether the lead authority takes the case.
description.detailed_explanation: This section sets out a competence framework for supervisory authorities in cross-border processing scenarios. As a default rule, the supervisory authority of the controllerâ€™s or processorâ€™s main establishment (or single establishment) is competent to act as the lead supervisory authority for cross-border processing, using the cooperation procedure in Article 60. A derogation allows a non-lead supervisory authority to handle a complaint lodged with it or a possible infringement when the subject matter relates only to an establishment in its Member State or substantially affects data subjects only in its Member State. When that derogation applies, the local supervisory authority must inform the lead supervisory authority 'without delay'. The lead supervisory authority must then decide within three weeks whether it will handle the case under Article 60, considering whether the controller/processor has an establishment in the informing authorityâ€™s Member State. If the lead authority takes the case, Article 60 procedure applies; the informing authority may submit a draft decision, and the lead authority must take 'utmost account' of it when preparing the Article 60(3) draft decision. If the lead authority declines to handle the case, the informing authority handles it under Articles 61 and 62. Finally, the lead supervisory authority is designated as the 'sole interlocutor' of the controller/processor for the cross-border processing carried out by that controller/processor.
description.purpose: To ensure clear allocation of supervisory competence and a coordinated enforcement approach for cross-border processing, while preserving the ability of local supervisory authorities to address matters confined to or primarily impacting their Member State.
description.legislative_intent: To operationalize the one-stop-shop mechanism by centralizing primary regulatory interaction with a lead authority for cross-border processing, reduce duplicative proceedings, and provide a structured exception and cooperation workflow for local impacts.

what_it_covers: Determination of the competent lead supervisory authority for cross-border processing
Competence of non-lead supervisory authorities to handle certain complaints/infringements under a derogation
Mandatory inter-authority notification and decision timelines
Procedural routing to GDPR cooperation mechanisms (Articles 60, 61, 62)
Interlocutor role vis-Ã -vis controllers/processors for cross-border processing

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies where a controller or processor has a main establishment or single establishment in the EU and engages in cross-border processing; also applies to supervisory authorities in EU Member States involved in such matters.

what_it_does_not_cover: Matters explicitly reserved by Article 55 (referenced as 'Without prejudice to Article 55')â€”details not provided in this section
Non-cross-border processing competence rules beyond what is stated here

mandatory_obligations: Default competence rule: the supervisory authority of the controllerâ€™s or processorâ€™s main establishment or single establishment 'shall be competent to act as lead supervisory authority for the cross-border processing' and must do so 'in accordance with the procedure provided in Article 60'. Quote: "the supervisory authority of the main establishment or of the single establishment of the controller or processor shall be competent to act as lead supervisory authority for the cross-border processing ... in accordance with the procedure provided in Article 60."

Derogation competence: each supervisory authority 'shall be competent to handle a complaint lodged with it or a possible infringement' when the subject matter meets the local-only/substantially-affects-only criteria. Quote: "each supervisory authority shall be competent to handle a complaint lodged with it or a possible infringement of this Regulation" (subject to the stated condition).

Notification duty: in derogation cases, the supervisory authority 'shall inform the lead supervisory authority without delay on that matter.' Quote: "shall inform the lead supervisory authority without delay".

Lead authority decision deadline: 'Within a period of three weeks after being informed the lead supervisory authority shall decide whether or not it will handle the case' under Article 60, considering establishment presence. Quote: "Within a period of three weeks after being informed the lead supervisory authority shall decide whether or not it will handle the case".
If lead authority handles the case: Article 60 procedure 'shall apply'. Quote: "Where the lead supervisory authority decides to handle the case, the procedure provided in Article 60 shall apply."

Consideration of draft decision: if the informing authority submits a draft decision, the lead authority 'shall take utmost account of that draft' when preparing the Article 60(3) draft decision. Quote: "shall take utmost account of that draft".
If lead authority does not handle the case: the informing authority 'shall handle it according to Articles 61 and 62.' Quote: "shall handle it according to Articles 61 and 62."

Sole interlocutor rule: the lead supervisory authority 'shall be the sole interlocutor of the controller or processor' for the relevant cross-border processing. Quote: "shall be the sole interlocutor of the controller or processor".
prohibited_actions: Implied restriction: controllers/processors should not treat non-lead supervisory authorities as the primary/sole interlocutor for cross-border processing where the lead supervisory authority is designated as sole interlocutor (explicit prohibition not stated; obligation is stated on the lead authority role).
conditional_requirements: Derogation trigger condition: local supervisory authority competence applies only 'if the subject matter relates only to an establishment in its Member State or substantially affects data subjects only in its Member State.' Quote: "if the subject matter relates only to an establishment in its Member State or substantially affects data subjects only in its Member State."

Lead authority decision must take into account establishment presence: decision whether to handle the case must consider 'whether or not there is an establishment of the controller or processor in the Member State of which the supervisory authority informed it.' Quote: "taking into account whether or not there is an establishment ... in the Member State".
Submission of draft decision is optional: the informing authority 'may submit to the lead supervisory authority a draft for a decision.' Quote: "may submit ... a draft for a decision."
Utmost account duty is conditional on submission: the lead authority must take utmost account of the draft when preparing the Article 60(3) draft decision, if such draft is submitted.
documentation_requirements: Potential draft decision document: the informing supervisory authority may create and submit 'a draft for a decision' to the lead supervisory authority (optional).
reporting_requirements: Inter-authority notification: the supervisory authority handling a derogation case must notify the lead supervisory authority 'without delay' about the matter.
timeline_requirements: Lead supervisory authority must decide within 'three weeks after being informed' whether it will handle the case under Article 60.

general_restrictions: Competence limitation on non-lead supervisory authorities in cross-border matters: they may handle complaints/infringements only under the derogation conditions (local establishment-only or substantial effect only in that Member State).
Centralization of controller/processor interaction: the lead supervisory authority is the 'sole interlocutor' for the controller/processor for the cross-border processing.
operational_restrictions: Procedural routing restriction: when the lead authority handles the case, authorities must follow Article 60 procedure; when it does not, the informing authority must proceed under Articles 61 and 62.
geographic_restrictions: Derogation is geographically bounded: applies where the subject matter relates only to an establishment in the supervisory authorityâ€™s Member State or substantially affects data subjects only in that Member State.

individual_rights: Implied procedural access: a data subject may lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority (referenced as 'a complaint lodged with it'); the section allocates which authority is competent to handle it in certain cross-border contexts.
organizational_rights: Controllers/processors have a structured single point of contact: interaction for cross-border processing is through the lead supervisory authority as 'sole interlocutor'.
how_to_exercise_rights: Complaint lodging is referenced but not procedurally detailed in this section; competence outcomes depend on whether the matter is local-only/substantially affects only one Member State and on the lead authorityâ€™s three-week decision.

general_exceptions: Carve-out reference: 'Without prejudice to Article 55' indicates Article 55 may override/qualify competence in certain cases, but the specific exception content is not provided here.
conditional_exemptions: Derogation from the default lead authority competence: local supervisory authority competence applies when the subject matter relates only to an establishment in its Member State or substantially affects data subjects only in its Member State.

organizational_measures: Supervisory authorities must implement internal processes to (a) identify whether a complaint/infringement meets the derogation criteria, (b) notify the lead supervisory authority without delay, (c) track the three-week decision period, and (d) route the case to Article 60 or to Articles 61/62 depending on the lead authority decision.
Lead supervisory authority must implement procedures to decide within three weeks whether to handle notified derogation cases and to consider establishment presence in the notifying Member State.
Where applicable, lead supervisory authority must implement a process to receive and incorporate (take 'utmost account' of) draft decisions submitted by the notifying supervisory authority.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: EU Member State supervisory authorities (including the lead supervisory authority and other concerned supervisory authorities) acting within the GDPR cooperation framework referenced (Articles 60, 61, 62).
enforcement_mechanisms: Competence allocation and procedural cooperation mechanisms: lead authority handling via Article 60; if not handled by lead authority, cooperation/assistance mechanisms via Articles 61 and 62 (details not specified in this section).

related_articles: Article 60 (procedure for cooperation/consistency in cross-border cases; referenced multiple times including Article 60(3))
Article 61 (applies when lead authority does not handle the case)
Article 62 (applies when lead authority does not handle the case)

implementation_steps: Determine whether processing is 'cross-border processing' and identify the controller/processor main establishment or single establishment to identify the presumptive lead supervisory authority.

For a complaint received by a non-lead supervisory authority, assess whether the subject matter (a) relates only to an establishment in that Member State or (b) substantially affects data subjects only in that Member State.
If the derogation criteria are met, notify the lead supervisory authority 'without delay' and document the notification date to start the three-week decision clock.

Lead supervisory authority: decide within three weeks whether to handle the case under Article 60, explicitly considering whether the controller/processor has an establishment in the notifying Member State.

If lead authority handles: apply Article 60 procedure; if the notifying authority provides a draft decision, ensure the lead authority takes 'utmost account' of it when preparing the Article 60(3) draft decision.
If lead authority does not handle: the notifying authority proceeds under Articles 61 and 62.
Ensure external communications to the controller/processor for cross-border processing are routed through the lead supervisory authority as the 'sole interlocutor'.
common_violations: Failure by a supervisory authority to inform the lead supervisory authority 'without delay' in a derogation scenario.
Lead supervisory authority failing to decide within the three-week period after being informed.
Proceeding under the wrong procedure (e.g., not applying Article 60 when the lead authority handles the case, or not applying Articles 61/62 when it does not).
Lead supervisory authority not taking 'utmost account' of a submitted draft decision from the notifying authority.
best_practices: Maintain a standardized inter-authority notification template and escalation workflow to satisfy the 'without delay' requirement.
Use case management tooling to track the three-week decision deadline and procedural routing (Article 60 vs. Articles 61/62).
Document the lead authorityâ€™s consideration of establishment presence in the notifying Member State when deciding whether to take the case.
When a draft decision is submitted, record how it was incorporated to evidence 'utmost account'.
compliance_checklist: Is the processing cross-border and is the main/single establishment identified?
Has the correct lead supervisory authority been identified for the controller/processor?
If a non-lead authority is handling initially, do derogation criteria apply (local establishment-only or substantial effect only in that Member State)?
Was the lead supervisory authority informed without delay (date/time recorded)?
Did the lead supervisory authority decide within three weeks of being informed?
If lead authority handled: was Article 60 procedure followed and was any submitted draft decision given 'utmost account'?
If lead authority did not handle: was the case handled under Articles 61 and 62?
Are controller/processor communications for cross-border processing routed through the lead supervisory authority as sole interlocutor?

key_definitions.lead supervisory authority: Not defined in this section; functionally described as the supervisory authority competent to act for cross-border processing and as the 'sole interlocutor' for the controller/processor for that processing.
key_definitions.derogation (from paragraph 1): A departure from the default lead authority competence allowing each supervisory authority to handle a complaint/infringement when the subject matter relates only to an establishment in its Member State or substantially affects data subjects only in its Member State.
key_definitions.without delay: Not quantified in this section; indicates an immediate/expeditious notification obligation to the lead supervisory authority.
key_definitions.three-week period: A fixed deadline: 'Within a period of three weeks after being informed' the lead supervisory authority must decide whether it will handle the case.

regulations.source_section: ## Competence of the lead supervisory authority

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 57 (Tasks)

applicable_regions: EU/EEA Member States (each supervisory authority within its territory)

description.brief_summary: Defines the tasks that each supervisory authority must perform to ensure consistent application and enforcement of the GDPR, including complaint handling, cooperation, investigations, guidance, and oversight of codes/certification and certain transfer instruments.
description.detailed_explanation: The article imposes a comprehensive set of mandatory tasks on each supervisory authority within its territory. These tasks include monitoring and enforcing GDPR compliance; promoting public and organizational awareness; advising national institutions on legislative/administrative measures; responding to data subject requests for information about rights; handling and investigating complaints (including those brought via representative bodies under Article 80) and informing complainants of progress/outcome within a reasonable period; cooperating with other supervisory authorities through information sharing and mutual assistance to ensure consistent application; conducting investigations including based on information from other authorities; monitoring relevant technological and commercial developments affecting personal data protection; adopting standard contractual clauses for processor engagements and certain transfer mechanisms; maintaining a list of processing operations requiring a DPIA; advising on processing operations subject to prior consultation; encouraging and approving codes of conduct; encouraging certification mechanisms and approving certification criteria and periodically reviewing certifications; drafting/publishing accreditation criteria and conducting accreditation for code-monitoring bodies and certification bodies; authorising certain contractual clauses for transfers; approving binding corporate rules; contributing to the EDPB; keeping internal records of infringements and measures taken; and performing any other tasks related to personal data protection. The article also requires supervisory authorities to facilitate complaint submission (including via electronic forms), to perform tasks free of charge for data subjects (and where applicable DPOs), and allows charging a reasonable administrative-cost-based fee or refusing to act only where requests are manifestly unfounded or excessive (especially repetitive), with the burden on the authority to demonstrate that condition.
description.purpose: To ensure supervisory authorities have clear, enforceable duties to protect individualsâ€™ rights and ensure consistent GDPR application and enforcement.
description.legislative_intent: To operationalize GDPR oversight by mandating concrete supervisory authority functions (enforcement, guidance, cooperation, complaint handling, and governance of compliance tools like codes/certification and transfer instruments) and to ensure accessibility of supervisory authority services while preventing abuse through unfounded/excessive requests.

what_it_covers: Supervisory authority monitoring and enforcement of GDPR
Public awareness and education on processing risks/rules/safeguards/rights
Advisory role to national institutions on measures affecting data protection
Awareness-raising among controllers and processors
Information provision to data subjects on exercising GDPR rights
Complaint handling and investigation (including Article 80 representation)
Cooperation, information sharing, and mutual assistance among supervisory authorities
Investigations into GDPR application
Monitoring technological and commercial developments impacting personal data protection
Adoption/authorisation/approval of certain GDPR instruments (SCCs, contractual clauses, BCRs)
DPIA-related lists and prior consultation advice
Codes of conduct encouragement/opinion/approval
Certification mechanisms encouragement/criteria approval/periodic review
Accreditation criteria publication and accreditation activities
Contribution to EDPB activities
Internal records of infringements and measures taken
Complaint submission facilitation measures
Fee-free performance of tasks and conditions for fees/refusal

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies to each supervisory authority within its Member State territory

what_it_does_not_cover: Specific fine amounts or penalty tiers (not stated in this section)
Detailed procedures for mutual assistance/consistency mechanism (only referenced generally)
Detailed criteria for SCCs/BCRs/accreditation (only tasks to adopt/approve/authorise are stated)

mandatory_obligations: Each supervisory authority shall on its territory "monitor and enforce the application of this Regulation" (para 1(a)).

Each supervisory authority shall "promote public awareness and understanding of the risks, rules, safeguards and rights in relation to processing" and "Activities addressed specifically to children shall receive specific attention" (para 1(b)).

Each supervisory authority shall "advise, in accordance with Member State law, the national parliament, the government, and other institutions and bodies on legislative and administrative measures" relating to protection of natural personsâ€™ rights and freedoms regarding processing (para 1(c)).
Each supervisory authority shall "promote the awareness of controllers and processors of their obligations under this Regulation" (para 1(d)).

Each supervisory authority shall, "upon request, provide information to any data subject concerning the exercise of their rights under this Regulation" and, if appropriate, "cooperate with the supervisory authorities in other Member States to that end" (para 1(e)).

Each supervisory authority shall "handle complaints lodged by a data subject, or by a body, organisation or association in accordance with Article 80" and "investigate, to the extent appropriate, the subject matter of the complaint" and "inform the complainant of the progress and the outcome of the investigation within a reasonable period" (para 1(f)).

Each supervisory authority shall "cooperate with, including sharing information and provide mutual assistance to, other supervisory authorities" to ensure consistency of application and enforcement (para 1(g)).

Each supervisory authority shall "conduct investigations on the application of this Regulation, including on the basis of information received from another supervisory authority or other public authority" (para 1(h)).

Each supervisory authority shall "monitor relevant developments" impacting personal data protection, "in particular the development of information and communication technologies and commercial practices" (para 1(i)).
Each supervisory authority shall "adopt standard contractual clauses referred to in Article 28(8) and in point (d) of Article 46(2)" (para 1(j)).
Each supervisory authority shall "establish and maintain a list" relating to the DPIA requirement pursuant to Article 35(4) (para 1(k)).
Each supervisory authority shall "give advice on the processing operations referred to in Article 36(2)" (para 1(l)).

Each supervisory authority shall "encourage the drawing up of codes of conduct pursuant to Article 40(1)" and "provide an opinion and approve such codes of conduct which provide sufficient safeguards, pursuant to Article 40(5)" (para 1(m)).

Each supervisory authority shall "encourage the establishment of data protection certification mechanisms and of data protection seals and marks pursuant to Article 42(1)" and "approve the criteria of certification pursuant to Article 42(5)" (para 1(n)).
Where applicable, each supervisory authority shall "carry out a periodic review of certifications issued in accordance with Article 42(7)" (para 1(o)).

Each supervisory authority shall "draft and publish the criteria for accreditation of a body for monitoring codes of conduct pursuant to Article 41 and of a certification body pursuant to Article 43" (para 1(p)).
Each supervisory authority shall "conduct the accreditation of a body for monitoring codes of conduct pursuant to Article 41 and of a certification body pursuant to Article 43" (para 1(q)).
Each supervisory authority shall "authorise contractual clauses and provisions referred to in Article 46(3)" (para 1(r)).
Each supervisory authority shall "approve binding corporate rules pursuant to Article 47" (para 1(s)).
Each supervisory authority shall "contribute to the activities of the Board" (para 1(t)).
Each supervisory authority shall "keep internal records of infringements of this Regulation and of measures taken in accordance with Article 58(2)" (para 1(u)).
Each supervisory authority shall "fulfil any other tasks related to the protection of personal data" (para 1(v)).

Each supervisory authority shall "facilitate the submission of complaints" by measures such as "a complaint submission form which can also be completed electronically", without excluding other means of communication (para 2).
The performance of the tasks of each supervisory authority shall be "free of charge for the data subject" and, where applicable, "for the data protection officer" (para 3).
prohibited_actions: Supervisory authorities must not exclude non-electronic complaint submission methods when providing an electronic complaint form: facilitation measures must be provided "without excluding other means of communication" (para 2).
conditional_requirements: Complaint investigations must be conducted "to the extent appropriate" (para 1(f)).
Informing complainants must occur "within a reasonable period", particularly where further investigation or coordination is necessary (para 1(f)).
Cooperation with other Member State supervisory authorities is required "if appropriate" when providing information to a data subject about exercising rights (para 1(e)).
Periodic review of certifications is required "where applicable" (para 1(o)).
Fees/refusal are permitted only "where requests are manifestly unfounded or excessive, in particular because of their repetitive character" (para 4).
If charging a fee, it must be "reasonable" and "based on administrative costs" (para 4).
documentation_requirements: Supervisory authority must "establish and maintain a list" related to DPIA requirement pursuant to Article 35(4) (para 1(k)).
Supervisory authority must "keep internal records of infringements of this Regulation and of measures taken in accordance with Article 58(2)" (para 1(u)).
Supervisory authority must "draft and publish the criteria for accreditation" for code-monitoring bodies (Art 41) and certification bodies (Art 43) (para 1(p)).
reporting_requirements: Supervisory authority must "inform the complainant of the progress and the outcome of the investigation within a reasonable period" (para 1(f)).
Supervisory authority must "publish" accreditation criteria (para 1(p)).
timeline_requirements: Complaint handling: inform complainant of progress and outcome "within a reasonable period" (para 1(f)).
Periodic review: certifications must be reviewed "periodic[ally]" where applicable (para 1(o)).

general_restrictions: Tasks must be performed "free of charge" for the data subject and, where applicable, the DPO, subject only to the manifestly unfounded/excessive request exception (para 3 and 4).
Fee charging/refusal is restricted to cases where requests are "manifestly unfounded or excessive" (para 4).
Any fee must be "reasonable" and "based on administrative costs" (para 4).
The supervisory authority bears the burden of proof to demonstrate a request is manifestly unfounded or excessive (para 4).
operational_restrictions: Complaint submission facilitation measures must not exclude other communication means (para 2).
technical_restrictions: If a complaint submission form is used, it "can also be completed electronically" (para 2) (technical enablement requirement, not exclusive).
geographic_restrictions: Tasks are to be performed by each supervisory authority "on its territory" (para 1).

individual_rights: Right for a data subject to request and receive information from the supervisory authority concerning the exercise of their GDPR rights (para 1(e)).
Right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority (handled under para 1(f), with facilitation measures under para 2).
Right to be informed of complaint investigation progress and outcome within a reasonable period (para 1(f)).
Right to access supervisory authority task performance free of charge (para 3), subject to the manifestly unfounded/excessive request exception (para 4).
organizational_rights: Bodies/organisations/associations (per Article 80) may lodge complaints that the supervisory authority must handle (para 1(f)).
how_to_exercise_rights: Submit a complaint to the supervisory authority; the authority must facilitate submission via measures such as a form that can be completed electronically, without excluding other communication means (para 2).
Submit a request to the supervisory authority for information about exercising GDPR rights (para 1(e)).

general_exceptions: Supervisory authority may charge a fee or refuse to act only where requests are "manifestly unfounded or excessive" (para 4).
conditional_exemptions: Fee/refusal exception is particularly relevant where requests are repetitive: "in particular because of their repetitive character" (para 4).

technical_measures: Implement measures to facilitate complaint submission, including providing a complaint submission form that can be completed electronically (para 2).
organizational_measures: Maintain processes to monitor and enforce GDPR application within territory (para 1(a)).
Run public awareness activities, with specific attention to children-focused activities (para 1(b)).
Establish advisory processes to national parliament/government/other bodies on legislative/administrative measures (para 1(c)).
Conduct outreach to controllers/processors regarding their obligations (para 1(d)).
Operate a request-handling function to provide data subjects information on exercising rights, including cross-border cooperation where appropriate (para 1(e)).
Operate a complaint intake, investigation triage, investigation, and complainant communication process (para 1(f)).
Operate cooperation/mutual assistance mechanisms with other supervisory authorities (para 1(g)).
Operate investigation capability, including acting on information from other authorities (para 1(h)).
Monitor relevant developments (ICT and commercial practices) affecting data protection (para 1(i)).
Operate governance for adoption/approval/authorisation tasks (SCCs, clauses, BCRs, codes, certification, accreditation) (para 1(j)-(s)).
Maintain internal infringement and enforcement-measure records (para 1(u)).
Ensure services are free of charge by default and implement a policy/process for manifestly unfounded/excessive requests, including burden-of-proof handling (para 3-4).
audit_requirements: Periodic review of certifications where applicable (para 1(o)) (functions as an oversight/audit-like requirement for issued certifications).
certification_requirements: Encourage establishment of certification mechanisms/seals/marks and approve certification criteria (para 1(n)).
Carry out periodic review of certifications issued in accordance with Article 42(7) where applicable (para 1(o)).
Draft/publish accreditation criteria and conduct accreditation for certification bodies (Art 43) (para 1(p)-(q)).

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Each Member State supervisory authority (data protection authority) within its territory

penalties.administrative_penalties: This section references measures taken in accordance with Article 58(2) (para 1(u)) but does not specify the measures or sanctions here.

enforcement_mechanisms: Monitoring and enforcement activities (para 1(a)).
Handling and investigating complaints and communicating outcomes (para 1(f)).
Conducting investigations, including based on information from other authorities (para 1(h)).
Cooperation/mutual assistance and information sharing to ensure consistent enforcement (para 1(g)).
Keeping internal records of infringements and measures taken (para 1(u)).

related_articles: Article 28(8) (standard contractual clauses for controller-processor arrangements)
Article 46(2)(d) (standard data protection clauses as transfer safeguard)
Article 41 (monitoring of approved codes; accreditation criteria/bodies)
Article 46(3) (authorisation of contractual clauses/provisions for transfers)

implementation_steps: Establish enforcement and monitoring program for GDPR compliance within the authorityâ€™s territory (para 1(a)).
Create public awareness initiatives, ensuring child-focused outreach receives specific attention (para 1(b)).
Set up formal advisory channels to parliament/government/other bodies consistent with Member State law (para 1(c)).
Develop controller/processor outreach and guidance programs (para 1(d)).
Implement a data subject inquiry process for rights-exercise information, including cross-border cooperation workflows (para 1(e)).

Implement complaint intake and case management: receipt, investigation proportionality assessment (â€œto the extent appropriateâ€), progress updates, and outcome notification within a reasonable period (para 1(f)).
Implement cooperation and mutual assistance procedures with other supervisory authorities, including information sharing (para 1(g)).
Maintain investigation capability and intake channels for referrals from other authorities/public authorities (para 1(h)).
Maintain horizon-scanning for ICT and commercial practice developments affecting data protection (para 1(i)).
Maintain governance and legal drafting capacity for SCC adoption, clause authorisations, and BCR approvals (para 1(j), 1(r), 1(s)).
Maintain DPIA list publication/maintenance process (para 1(k)).
Maintain prior consultation advisory process (para 1(l)).
Operate code of conduct lifecycle: encourage drafting, assess safeguards, issue opinions and approvals (para 1(m)).
Operate certification ecosystem oversight: encourage mechanisms, approve criteria, and periodically review certifications where applicable (para 1(n)-(o)).
Publish accreditation criteria and run accreditation programs for code-monitoring bodies and certification bodies (para 1(p)-(q)).
Maintain internal infringement and corrective-measure records (para 1(u)).
Provide complaint submission form that can be completed electronically while preserving other communication channels (para 2).

Ensure services are free by default; implement a defensible process to identify manifestly unfounded/excessive requests, calculate reasonable administrative-cost-based fees if charged, or refuse to act, and document evidence because the authority bears the burden of proof (para 3-4).
common_violations: Failing to inform complainants of progress/outcome within a reasonable period (para 1(f)).
Not providing accessible complaint submission methods (e.g., no electronic option) or excluding other communication means (para 2).
Charging fees or refusing to act without demonstrating the request is manifestly unfounded or excessive (para 4).
Charging a fee not based on administrative costs or not reasonable (para 4).
Failing to maintain required lists/records (DPIA list; internal infringement records) (para 1(k), 1(u)).
best_practices: Maintain documented SLAs defining what constitutes a â€œreasonable periodâ€ for complaint updates/outcomes, with escalation for cross-border coordination cases (para 1(f)).
Use multi-channel complaint intake (web form, email, mail, in-person) to satisfy â€œwithout excluding other means of communicationâ€ (para 2).
Document decision-making and evidence when classifying requests as manifestly unfounded/excessive to meet the burden of proof (para 4).
Maintain transparent publication processes for accreditation criteria and DPIA lists (para 1(p), 1(k)).
compliance_checklist: Monitoring/enforcement function operational (para 1(a)).
Public awareness program includes child-focused attention (para 1(b)).
Advisory process to national institutions established per Member State law (para 1(c)).
Controller/processor awareness initiatives in place (para 1(d)).
Data subject rights information request process in place; cross-border cooperation workflow available (para 1(e)).
Complaint handling: intake, investigation proportionality, progress/outcome notifications within reasonable period (para 1(f)).
Cooperation/mutual assistance and information sharing procedures with other DPAs (para 1(g)).
Investigation capability including acting on referrals (para 1(h)).
Monitoring of ICT/commercial developments (para 1(i)).
SCC adoption capability (Art 28(8), Art 46(2)(d)) (para 1(j)).
DPIA list established and maintained (para 1(k)).
Prior consultation advice process (para 1(l)).
Codes of conduct encouragement/opinion/approval process (para 1(m)).
Certification encouragement/criteria approval and periodic review where applicable (para 1(n)-(o)).
Accreditation criteria published and accreditation conducted for relevant bodies (para 1(p)-(q)).
Contractual clause authorisation (Art 46(3)) and BCR approval (Art 47) processes (para 1(r)-(s)).
Contribution to EDPB activities (para 1(t)).
Internal records of infringements and measures taken maintained (para 1(u)).
Complaint submission facilitated with electronic form option and other channels preserved (para 2).
Tasks free of charge by default; fee/refusal policy limited to manifestly unfounded/excessive requests with burden of proof on authority (para 3-4).

key_definitions.reasonable period: Not defined in this section; used as the timeframe within which the supervisory authority must inform the complainant of progress and outcome of the investigation (para 1(f)).
key_definitions.manifestly unfounded or excessive: Not defined in this section; condition allowing the supervisory authority to charge a reasonable fee based on administrative costs or refuse to act, particularly for repetitive requests, with burden of proof on the authority (para 4).

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 58 (Powers)

description.brief_summary: Defines the minimum set of investigative, corrective, authorisation and advisory powers that each data protection supervisory authority must have, and requires procedural safeguards and Member State legal empowerment for court engagement.
