description.detailed_explanation: Article 58 mandates that each supervisory authority possess enumerated powers grouped into: (i) investigative powers enabling information gathering, audits, certification review, infringement notification, access to personal data and necessary information, and access to premises/equipment subject to procedural law; (ii) corrective powers enabling warnings, reprimands, orders to comply with data subject requests, orders to bring processing into compliance (including specifying manner and timeframe), orders to communicate breaches to data subjects, processing limitations/bans, rectification/erasure/restriction orders with downstream recipient notification, certification withdrawal or directions to certification bodies, administrative fines under Article 83, and suspension of international data flows; (iii) authorisation/advisory powers including prior consultation advice, issuing opinions to public bodies and the public, authorising certain processing where Member State law requires, approving codes of conduct, accrediting certification bodies, issuing certifications and approving certification criteria, adopting standard contractual clauses for certain contexts, authorising certain transfer clauses and administrative arrangements, and approving binding corporate rules. The exercise of these powers must be subject to safeguards including effective judicial remedy and due process under Union/Member State law consistent with the Charter. Member States must provide by law that supervisory authorities can bring infringements to judicial authorities and, where appropriate, commence or otherwise engage in legal proceedings to enforce the GDPR. Member States may also grant additional powers, but their exercise must not impair the effective operation of Chapter VII.
description.purpose: To ensure supervisory authorities have effective tools to monitor and enforce GDPR compliance, remedy infringements, and oversee mechanisms like certifications, codes of conduct, and international transfer instruments, while ensuring procedural fairness.
description.legislative_intent: To harmonize a baseline of enforcement capabilities across Member States, enabling consistent and effective GDPR enforcement and cooperation, while embedding rule-of-law safeguards (judicial remedy and due process).

what_it_covers: Supervisory authority investigative actions (information requests, audits, access rights)
Supervisory authority corrective measures (orders, bans, fines, breach communication orders)
Supervisory authority authorisation/advisory functions (opinions, approvals, accreditations, standard clauses, BCR approvals)
Procedural safeguards governing exercise of powers
Member State legislative duties to empower supervisory authorities for judicial engagement
Optional additional national powers and their constraint (must not impair Chapter VII)

target_entities: Certification bodies (in relation to withdrawal/non-issuance orders)
Member States (legislative obligation to provide certain powers by law)
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies within EU/Member State legal frameworks; includes cross-border contexts (e.g., suspension of data flows to third countries/international organisations).

what_it_does_not_cover: Specific fine amounts/tiers (handled by Article 83, only referenced here)
Detailed procedures for exercising powers (left to Union/Member State procedural law and safeguards)
Substantive conditions for rights like rectification/erasure/restriction (handled by Articles 16, 17, 18)

mandatory_obligations: Supervisory authority must have investigative powers listed in Article 58(1), including: "to order the controller and the processor, and, where applicable, the controller's or the processor's representative to provide any information it requires for the performance of its tasks"; "to carry out investigations in the form of data protection audits"; "to carry out a review on certifications issued pursuant to Article 42(7)"; "to notify the controller or the processor of an alleged infringement of this Regulation"; "to obtain, from the controller and the processor, access to all personal data and to all information necessary for the performance of its tasks"; and "to obtain access to any premises of the controller and the processor, including to any data processing equipment and means, in accordance with Union or Member State procedural law".

Supervisory authority must have corrective powers listed in Article 58(2), including: "to issue warnings"; "to issue reprimands"; "to order the controller or the processor to comply with the data subject's requests"; "to order the controller or processor to bring processing operations into compliance ... in a specified manner and within a specified period"; "to order the controller to communicate a personal data breach to the data subject"; "to impose a temporary or definitive limitation including a ban on processing"; "to order the rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing" and related recipient notification; "to withdraw a certification or to order the certification body to withdraw a certification" or not issue certification if requirements are not met; "to impose an administrative fine pursuant to Article 83"; and "to order the suspension of data flows to a recipient in a third country or to an international organisation".

Supervisory authority must have authorisation and advisory powers listed in Article 58(3), including: "to advise the controller in accordance with the prior consultation procedure referred to in Article 36"; "to issue ... opinions" to specified bodies and the public; "to authorise processing referred to in Article 36(5), if the law of the Member State requires such prior authorisation"; "to issue an opinion and approve draft codes of conduct pursuant to Article 40(5)"; "to accredit certification bodies pursuant to Article 43"; "to issue certifications and approve criteria of certification in accordance with Article 42(5)"; "to adopt standard data protection clauses" (Article 28(8) and Article 46(2)(d)); "to authorise contractual clauses" (Article 46(3)(a)); "to authorise administrative arrangements" (Article 46(3)(b)); and "to approve binding corporate rules pursuant to Article 47".

Exercise of supervisory authority powers under Article 58 must be subject to safeguards: "shall be subject to appropriate safeguards, including effective judicial remedy and due process, set out in Union and Member State law in accordance with the Charter."

Member States must legislate to ensure supervisory authority power to involve courts: "Each Member State shall provide by law that its supervisory authority shall have the power to bring infringements of this Regulation to the attention of the judicial authorities and where appropriate, to commence or engage otherwise in legal proceedings, in order to enforce the provisions of this Regulation."
prohibited_actions: Member State additional powers (if granted) must not be exercised in a way that undermines cooperation/consistency mechanisms: "The exercise of those powers shall not impair the effective operation of Chapter VII."
conditional_requirements: Information-order power extends to representatives only "where applicable" (Article 58(1)(a)).
Premises/equipment access must be exercised "in accordance with Union or Member State procedural law" (Article 58(1)(f)).
Corrective measure to impose administrative fines may be used "in addition to, or instead of" other measures "depending on the circumstances of each individual case" (Article 58(2)(i)).
Power to authorise processing under Article 36(5) applies only "if the law of the Member State requires such prior authorisation" (Article 58(3)(c)).
Member State court-proceedings power: supervisory authority may "where appropriate" commence or otherwise engage in legal proceedings (Article 58(5)).

Member States may grant additional powers: "Each Member State may provide by law that its supervisory authority shall have additional powers" (Article 58(6)), but constrained by Chapter VII effectiveness.
documentation_requirements: Controllers/processors must be able to provide "any information" required for supervisory authority tasks (Article 58(1)(a)); the article does not specify format/records, but creates an enforceable obligation to furnish information upon order.
reporting_requirements: Supervisory authority may order controller "to communicate a personal data breach to the data subject" (Article 58(2)(e)).

Supervisory authority may require notification to recipients after rectification/erasure/restriction: "and the notification of such actions to recipients to whom the personal data have been disclosed" (Article 58(2)(g)) referencing Articles 17(2) and 19.
timeline_requirements: Supervisory authority may set a deadline when ordering compliance: "within a specified period" (Article 58(2)(d)).

general_restrictions: Exercise of Article 58 powers must be subject to "appropriate safeguards, including effective judicial remedy and due process" under Union/Member State law consistent with the Charter (Article 58(4)).
Additional national powers (if any) must not "impair the effective operation of Chapter VII" (Article 58(6)).
data_restrictions: Supervisory authority may impose "a temporary or definitive limitation including a ban on processing" (Article 58(2)(f)).
Supervisory authority may order "restriction of processing" (Article 58(2)(g)).
Supervisory authority may order "suspension of data flows to a recipient in a third country or to an international organisation" (Article 58(2)(j)).
operational_restrictions: Orders to bring processing into compliance may require changes "in a specified manner" and "within a specified period" (Article 58(2)(d)).
Certification-related restrictions: authority may order certification body to withdraw certification or not issue certification if requirements are not met (Article 58(2)(h)).
technical_restrictions: Access to "any data processing equipment and means" may be obtained by supervisory authority, subject to procedural law (Article 58(1)(f)).
geographic_restrictions: Suspension of data flows to "a recipient in a third country or to an international organisation" (Article 58(2)(j)).

individual_rights: Indirectly supports data subject rights by empowering supervisory authorities "to order the controller or the processor to comply with the data subject's requests to exercise his or her rights" (Article 58(2)(c)).
May result in direct notification to data subjects when authority orders controller "to communicate a personal data breach to the data subject" (Article 58(2)(e)).
organizational_rights: Supervisory authority has the right/power to access information, personal data, and premises for task performance (Article 58(1)(a), (e), (f)).
Supervisory authority has the right/power to adopt standard clauses and approve transfer mechanisms (Article 58(3)(g)-(j)).
how_to_exercise_rights: Supervisory authority exercises powers through orders, audits, reviews, opinions, authorisations, approvals, accreditations, and sanctions as enumerated in Article 58(1)-(3), subject to safeguards in Article 58(4) and national procedural law where referenced.

general_exceptions: No explicit carve-outs from supervisory authority powers are stated; instead, exercise is constrained by procedural safeguards and applicable procedural law.
conditional_exemptions: Representative involvement only "where applicable" (Article 58(1)(a)).
Prior authorisation power only where Member State law requires it (Article 58(3)(c)).

technical_measures: Organizations must be able to provide supervisory authority access to "any data processing equipment and means" when lawful access is exercised (Article 58(1)(f)), implying readiness to facilitate lawful inspection consistent with procedural law.
organizational_measures: Controllers/processors must have processes to respond to supervisory authority orders for "any information" required (Article 58(1)(a)).
Controllers/processors must be able to facilitate audits and investigations (Article 58(1)(b)).
Controllers/processors must be able to comply with orders to bring processing into compliance in a specified manner and timeframe (Article 58(2)(d)).
Controllers must be able to communicate a personal data breach to data subjects when ordered (Article 58(2)(e)).
Controllers/processors must be able to implement processing limitations/bans and restrictions when ordered (Article 58(2)(f)-(g)).
Controllers/processors must be able to execute rectification/erasure/restriction and notify recipients as required by referenced provisions when ordered (Article 58(2)(g)).
security_measures: No specific security controls are prescribed in this article; it enables audits and access that may assess security.
audit_requirements: Supervisory authority power "to carry out investigations in the form of data protection audits" (Article 58(1)(b)); organizations should expect and support such audits.
certification_requirements: Supervisory authority may review certifications issued under Article 42(7) (Article 58(1)(c)).
Supervisory authority may withdraw certification or order certification body withdrawal / non-issuance if certification requirements are not or no longer met (Article 58(2)(h)).
Supervisory authority may accredit certification bodies (Article 58(3)(e)) and issue certifications/approve criteria (Article 58(3)(f)).

enforcement.regulatory_authority: Each Member State supervisory authority (data protection authority) established under the GDPR; judicial authorities are engaged as per Member State law (Article 58(5)).

penalties.financial_penalties: Administrative fines may be imposed: power "to impose an administrative fine pursuant to Article 83" (Article 58(2)(i)); specific amounts/tiers are not provided in this section.
penalties.administrative_penalties: Warnings, reprimands, compliance orders, breach communication orders, processing bans/limitations, rectification/erasure/restriction orders, certification withdrawal/non-issuance directions, suspension of international data flows (Article 58(2)(a)-(j)).
penalties.reputational_consequences: Not specified in this section (though reprimands/orders may have practical reputational impact; not stated).

enforcement_mechanisms: Information orders to controller/processor/representative (Article 58(1)(a))
Data protection audits (Article 58(1)(b))
Certification reviews (Article 58(1)(c))
Infringement notifications (Article 58(1)(d))
Access to personal data and necessary information (Article 58(1)(e))
Access to premises and equipment subject to procedural law (Article 58(1)(f))
Corrective measures and fines (Article 58(2))
Judicial engagement: bring infringements to courts and commence/engage in proceedings (Article 58(5))

related_articles: Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union (referenced as "the Charter")
complementary_regulations: Union and Member State procedural law (as referenced for premises access and safeguards)

implementation_steps: Establish an internal process to respond promptly and completely to supervisory authority information orders (Article 58(1)(a)).
Maintain audit readiness for supervisory authority data protection audits (Article 58(1)(b)).
Ensure ability to provide supervisory authority access to all personal data and necessary information for tasks (Article 58(1)(e)).
Prepare procedures to facilitate lawful on-site inspections/access to premises and processing equipment, aligned with applicable procedural law (Article 58(1)(f)).
Implement governance to execute supervisory authority corrective orders, including compliance remediation plans with timelines when specified (Article 58(2)(d)).
Maintain operational capability to halt/limit processing and to suspend international data flows if ordered (Article 58(2)(f), (j)).
Maintain mechanisms to rectify/erase/restrict data and notify recipients when ordered (Article 58(2)(g)).
If using certifications, monitor ongoing compliance with certification requirements to avoid withdrawal/non-issuance orders (Article 58(2)(h)).
Plan for potential administrative fines and integrate enforcement response procedures (Article 58(2)(i)).
common_violations: Failure or delay in providing requested information to the supervisory authority (contrary to the effect of Article 58(1)(a)).
Obstructing or failing to facilitate audits or access to data/premises when lawfully required (Article 58(1)(b), (e), (f)).
Non-compliance with supervisory authority orders to bring processing into compliance within the specified period (Article 58(2)(d)).
Failure to comply with an order to communicate a personal data breach to data subjects (Article 58(2)(e)).
Continuing processing despite an imposed limitation/ban or failing to suspend international data flows when ordered (Article 58(2)(f), (j)).
Failure to notify recipients of rectification/erasure/restriction actions when ordered (Article 58(2)(g)).
best_practices: Maintain a regulatory response playbook covering information requests, audits, and on-site inspections.
Keep data maps and records enabling rapid identification and provision of "all personal data" and related processing information.
Implement change-management controls to execute processing restrictions/bans and transfer suspensions quickly.
Maintain breach communication templates and decision logs to support rapid compliance if ordered.
compliance_checklist: Can we produce any information required by the supervisory authority for task performance (Article 58(1)(a))?
Are we prepared for data protection audits (Article 58(1)(b))?
Can we provide access to all personal data and necessary information (Article 58(1)(e))?
Do we have procedures to facilitate lawful access to premises/equipment consistent with procedural law (Article 58(1)(f))?
Can we implement compliance remediation in a specified manner and within a specified period if ordered (Article 58(2)(d))?
Can we communicate a personal data breach to data subjects if ordered (Article 58(2)(e))?
Can we impose/operate a processing limitation or ban if ordered (Article 58(2)(f))?
Can we rectify/erase/restrict processing and notify recipients if ordered (Article 58(2)(g))?
If certified, do we monitor ongoing certification compliance to avoid withdrawal/non-issuance (Article 58(2)(h))?
Can we suspend data flows to third countries/international organisations if ordered (Article 58(2)(j))?

key_definitions.investigative powers: Enumerated powers enabling the supervisory authority to gather information and evidence, including ordering information, conducting audits, reviewing certifications, notifying alleged infringements, accessing personal data/information, and accessing premises/equipment (Article 58(1)).
key_definitions.corrective powers: Enumerated powers enabling the supervisory authority to remedy or sanction infringements, including warnings, reprimands, orders, processing limitations/bans, rectification/erasure/restriction orders with recipient notification, certification withdrawal directions, fines, and suspension of international data flows (Article 58(2)).
key_definitions.authorisation and advisory powers: Enumerated powers enabling the supervisory authority to advise, opine, authorise, approve, accredit, adopt clauses, and approve BCRs (Article 58(3)).
key_definitions.appropriate safeguards: Constraints on exercising Article 58 powers, including "effective judicial remedy and due process" set out in Union and Member State law in accordance with the Charter (Article 58(4)).

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 59 (Activity reports)

industry_sectors: Public sector regulators (data protection supervisory authorities)

description.brief_summary: Requires each supervisory authority to prepare an annual report on its activities, transmit it to specified national bodies, and make it publicly available and available to EU institutions/bodies.
description.detailed_explanation: This provision imposes an annual reporting duty on each supervisory authority. The report must cover the authorityâ€™s activities for the year. The content may (optionally) include a list of (i) types of infringement notified and (ii) types of measures taken, with the measures referenced as those taken under Article 58(2). The completed reports must be transmitted to the national parliament, the government, and any other authorities designated by Member State law. In addition, the reports must be made available to the public and also made available to the European Commission and the European Data Protection Board.
description.purpose: To ensure accountability, transparency, and oversight of supervisory authoritiesâ€™ enforcement and regulatory activities through regular public and institutional reporting.
description.legislative_intent: To create a consistent EU-wide minimum obligation for supervisory authorities to report annually and to ensure both national democratic oversight (parliament/government) and EU-level visibility (Commission/Board), while allowing Member States to designate additional recipients.

what_it_covers: Preparation of an annual activity report by each supervisory authority
Optional inclusion of enforcement-related summaries (types of infringements notified; types of measures taken under Article 58(2))
Transmission/distribution of the report to specified national bodies and other designated authorities
Making the report available to the public, the European Commission, and the European Data Protection Board

entity_types: Public bodies (independent supervisory authorities established under GDPR)
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Supervisory authorities of EU Member States (and EEA authorities where GDPR applies via EEA arrangements).

what_it_does_not_cover: No requirements for private organizations/controllers/processors to produce these activity reports
No mandated specific format, template, or minimum content beyond the annual report obligation (content elements are optional except the existence of the report and its transmission/availability)
No explicit publication medium or language requirements stated in this section

mandatory_obligations: Each supervisory authority must "draw up an annual report on its activities" (quote: "Each supervisory authority shall draw up an annual report on its activities").
The annual report must be transmitted to the national parliament (quote: "Those reports shall be transmitted to the national parliament").
The annual report must be transmitted to the government (quote: "Those reports shall be transmitted to ... the government").
The annual report must be transmitted to other authorities as designated by Member State law (quote: "and other authorities as designated by Member State law").
The annual report must be made available to the public (quote: "They shall be made available to the public").
The annual report must be made available to the European Commission (quote: "to the Commission").
The annual report must be made available to the European Data Protection Board (quote: "and to the Board").
conditional_requirements: If Member State law designates additional authorities, the supervisory authority must transmit the report to those designated authorities (quote: "other authorities as designated by Member State law").
documentation_requirements: An annual report documenting the supervisory authorityâ€™s activities (quote: "an annual report on its activities").
reporting_requirements: Annual activity report prepared by each supervisory authority.
Transmission of the report to national parliament, government, and other designated authorities.
Availability/publication of the report to the public, the Commission, and the Board.
timeline_requirements: Frequency: annual (quote: "annual report").
No specific date within the year or deadline is provided in this section.

individual_rights: Public access/availability of supervisory authority annual activity reports (quote: "They shall be made available to the public").
organizational_rights: National parliament and government receive the reports (institutional access) (quote: "transmitted to the national parliament, the government").
European Commission access to the reports (quote: "made available ... to the Commission").
European Data Protection Board access to the reports (quote: "and to the Board").

organizational_measures: Establish an internal annual reporting process to compile and approve an annual activity report.
Establish distribution procedures to ensure transmission to required national recipients and availability to the public, Commission, and Board.

penalties.reputational_consequences: Implicit transparency/accountability impact due to public availability of reports; no explicit penalty stated in this section.

related_articles: GDPR Article 58(2) (types of measures taken) (referenced in quote: "measures taken in accordance with Article 58(2)")

implementation_steps: Create an annual reporting calendar and assign responsibility for drafting and approval.
Optionally compile a categorized list of (a) types of infringements notified and (b) types of measures taken under Article 58(2) for inclusion.
Transmit the finalized report to the national parliament and government, and identify any additional recipients designated by Member State law and transmit accordingly.
Publish/make the report available to the public and provide it to the European Commission and the European Data Protection Board.
common_violations: Failure to produce an annual activity report.
Failure to transmit the report to one or more required national recipients.
Failure to make the report publicly available or available to the Commission/Board.
Failure to identify and transmit to additional authorities designated by Member State law.
best_practices: Maintain a distribution list reflecting Member State law designations and update it periodically.
Document evidence of transmission and publication (e.g., dispatch records, publication links) to demonstrate compliance.
compliance_checklist: Annual activity report drafted and approved for the reporting year.
Report includes (optional) lists of types of infringements notified and measures taken under Article 58(2), if chosen.
Report transmitted to national parliament.
Report transmitted to government.
Report transmitted to any other authorities designated by Member State law.
Report made available to the public.
Report made available to the European Commission.
Report made available to the European Data Protection Board.

key_definitions.supervisory authority: Not defined in this section; refers to the independent public authority established by a Member State under the GDPR.
key_definitions.annual report on its activities: A yearly report prepared by a supervisory authority describing its activities; specific required contents are not mandated here beyond the report itself, though optional inclusions are identified.
key_definitions.measures taken in accordance with Articl: Not defined in this section; refers to the corrective powers/measures available to supervisory authorities under GDPR Article 58(2).
key_definitions.other authorities as designated by Membe: Authorities identified in national law to receive the supervisory authorityâ€™s annual activity report in addition to parliament and government.

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 60: Cooperation between the lead supervisory authority and the other supervisory authorities concerned

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data in the EU

description.brief_summary: Establishes binding procedural obligations for cooperation between the lead supervisory authority and other concerned supervisory authorities in cross-border GDPR matters, including information exchange, draft decision consultation, objection handling, escalation to the consistency mechanism, decision adoption/notification, and post-decision compliance reporting by controllers/processors.
description.detailed_explanation: The article mandates that the lead supervisory authority (LSA) and other supervisory authorities concerned (CSAs) cooperate to reach consensus and exchange all relevant information. It empowers the LSA to request mutual assistance and conduct joint operations for investigations/monitoring in other Member States. It requires the LSA to promptly share relevant information, circulate draft decisions for opinion, and consider CSA views. It defines a structured objection process: CSAs have four weeks to raise a 'relevant and reasoned objection'; if the LSA does not follow it or disputes its relevance/reasoning, the matter must be referred to the GDPR consistency mechanism. If the LSA intends to follow the objection, it must issue a revised draft decision, which is again subject to objection within two weeks. If no objection is raised within the applicable period, authorities are deemed in agreement and bound by the draft decision. The LSA must adopt and notify the decision to the controller/processorâ€™s main or single establishment and inform CSAs and the EDPB, including a summary of facts and grounds; the authority receiving the complaint must inform the complainant. A derogation applies where a complaint is dismissed/rejected: the complaint-receiving authority adopts and notifies that decision to the complainant and informs the controller. Where authorities agree to dismiss/reject parts and act on other parts, separate decisions must be adopted for each part, with allocation of adoption/notification duties between the LSA and the complainantâ€™s authority. After notification of the LSA decision, the controller/processor must take necessary measures to ensure compliance across all EU establishments and must notify the LSA of measures taken; the LSA informs CSAs. In exceptional circumstances where a CSA considers urgent action is needed to protect data subjects, the urgency procedure applies. Information exchange under the article must be by electronic means using a standardised format.
description.purpose: To ensure consistent, coordinated, and timely enforcement of GDPR in cross-border cases through structured cooperation, consensus-building, and escalation mechanisms.
description.legislative_intent: To prevent fragmented enforcement across Member States, ensure CSAs can influence outcomes affecting their jurisdictions, and provide predictable timelines and procedures for cross-border supervisory decisions.

what_it_covers: Cooperation between LSA and CSAs in cross-border GDPR matters
Exchange of relevant information between supervisory authorities
Requests for mutual assistance and joint operations for investigations/monitoring
Draft decision consultation and opinion process
Handling of relevant and reasoned objections
Referral to the consistency mechanism
Decision adoption, notification, and information duties (including to EDPB/Board)
Complaint handling communications and allocation of decision-making for dismissals/rejections and split outcomes
Controller/processor obligations to implement decisions across EU establishments and report measures taken
Urgency procedure trigger in exceptional circumstances
Electronic, standardised-format information exchange

target_entities: Supervisory authority with which a complaint has been lodged
European Data Protection Board (Board) (as recipient of information)
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies to controllers/processors with a main establishment or single establishment in the EU and processing activities in the context of establishments in the Union; applies to supervisory authorities of EU Member States involved as LSA/CSAs.

what_it_does_not_cover: Substantive GDPR compliance requirements for processing (this article focuses on supervisory cooperation and procedure)
Detailed criteria for what constitutes a 'relevant and reasoned objection' beyond requiring it be relevant and reasoned
Specific content requirements for the 'standardised format' (only that it must be standardised and electronic)

mandatory_obligations: LSA must cooperate with CSAs to reach consensus: "shall cooperate ... in an endeavour to reach consensus." (para 1)
LSA and CSAs must exchange all relevant information: "shall exchange all relevant information with each other." (para 1)

LSA must, without delay, communicate relevant information on the matter to CSAs: "shall, without delay, communicate the relevant information on the matter to the other supervisory authorities concerned." (para 3)
LSA must, without delay, submit a draft decision to CSAs for their opinion: "shall without delay submit a draft decision ... for their opinion" (para 3)
LSA must take due account of CSA views: "and take due account of their views." (para 3)

If a CSA expresses a relevant and reasoned objection within four weeks, and the LSA does not follow it or considers it not relevant/reasoned, the LSA must submit the matter to the consistency mechanism: "shall ... submit the matter to the consistency mechanism referred to in Article 63." (para 4)
If the LSA intends to follow the objection, it must submit a revised draft decision to CSAs for opinion: "it shall submit ... a revised draft decision for their opinion." (para 5)
If no CSA objects within the applicable period, LSA and CSAs are deemed in agreement and bound by the draft decision: "shall be deemed to be in agreement ... and shall be bound by it." (para 6)

LSA must adopt and notify the decision to the main establishment or single establishment of the controller/processor, as applicable: "shall adopt and notify the decision to the main establishment or single establishment of the controller or processor" (para 7)

LSA must inform CSAs and the Board of the decision, including a summary of relevant facts and grounds: "inform the other supervisory authorities concerned and the Board ... including a summary of the relevant facts and grounds." (para 7)
The supervisory authority with which a complaint has been lodged must inform the complainant on the decision: "shall inform the complainant on the decision." (para 7)

Derogationâ€”if a complaint is dismissed or rejected, the complaint-receiving authority must adopt the decision and notify it to the complainant and inform the controller: "shall adopt the decision and notify it to the complainant and shall inform the controller thereof." (para 8)
If parts of a complaint are dismissed/rejected and other parts acted upon, separate decisions must be adopted for each part: "a separate decision shall be adopted for each of those parts" (para 9)

In split decisions, LSA must adopt and notify the decision for the action part to the main/single establishment on its Member State territory and inform the complainant: "shall adopt the decision ... shall notify it ... and shall inform the complainant thereof" (para 9)

In split decisions, the complainantâ€™s supervisory authority must adopt and notify the dismissal/rejection part to the complainant and inform the controller/processor: "shall adopt the decision ... shall notify it ... and shall inform the controller or processor thereof." (para 9)

After being notified of the LSA decision (paras 7 and 9), the controller/processor must take necessary measures to ensure compliance across all EU establishments: "shall take the necessary measures to ensure compliance ... in the context of all its establishments in the Union." (para 10)
Controller/processor must notify the measures taken to the LSA: "shall notify the measures taken for complying with the decision to the lead supervisory authority" (para 10)
LSA must inform CSAs of the measures notified: "which shall inform the other supervisory authorities concerned." (para 10)
In exceptional circumstances where a CSA considers urgent need to act to protect data subjects, the urgency procedure applies: "the urgency procedure referred to in Article 66 shall apply." (para 11)

LSA and CSAs must supply information required under the article to each other electronically using a standardised format: "shall supply the information required under this Article to each other by electronic means, using a standardised format." (para 12)
prohibited_actions: Implicit prohibition on delaying required communications/submissions where the article mandates "without delay" (paras 3, 7) (no explicit 'must not' language).
conditional_requirements: LSA may request mutual assistance pursuant to Article 61 and may conduct joint operations pursuant to Article 62, particularly for investigations/monitoring in another Member State (para 2) (discretionary power, conditionally used as needed).
Objection handling is triggered only "[w]here" a CSA expresses a relevant and reasoned objection within four weeks after consultation (para 4).
Revised draft decision procedure applies only "[w]here the lead supervisory authority intends to follow" the objection (para 5).
Deemed agreement/binding effect applies only where none of the CSAs object within the relevant period (paras 4 and 5) (para 6).
Derogation for complaint dismissal/rejection applies only "where a complaint is dismissed or rejected" (para 8).
Split decision requirement applies only where authorities agree to dismiss/reject parts and act on other parts (para 9).
Controller/processor compliance-measures obligation applies "[a]fter being notified of the decision" pursuant to paras 7 and 9 (para 10).
Urgency procedure applies only "[w]here, in exceptional circumstances" a CSA has reasons to consider urgent need to act to protect data subjects (para 11).
documentation_requirements: LSA must provide to CSAs and the Board a decision notification that includes "a summary of the relevant facts and grounds" (para 7).
Controller/processor must provide notification to the LSA describing "the measures taken for complying with the decision" (para 10).
reporting_requirements: LSA must inform CSAs and the Board of the decision (para 7).
Complaint-receiving supervisory authority must inform the complainant of the decision (para 7).
If complaint dismissed/rejected: complaint-receiving authority must notify the complainant and inform the controller (para 8).
Split decisions: LSA informs complainant for action part; complainantâ€™s authority informs controller/processor for dismissal/rejection part (para 9).
Controller/processor must notify LSA of compliance measures; LSA informs CSAs (para 10).
timeline_requirements: LSA communications and draft decision submission must be "without delay" (para 3).
CSAs have "a period of four weeks" after being consulted to express a relevant and reasoned objection (para 4).
If LSA issues a revised draft decision, it is subject to the objection procedure "within a period of two weeks" (para 5).
LSA adoption/notification duties are not assigned a numeric deadline but are mandatory once the procedure concludes (paras 6â€“7).

general_restrictions: LSA must follow the structured cooperation/consultation process and cannot finalize cross-border decisions without giving CSAs opportunity to opine and object within set periods (paras 3â€“6).
Where objections are raised and not followed/accepted, LSA is constrained to refer the matter to the consistency mechanism (para 4).
Authorities are "bound" by the draft decision when no objection is raised within deadlines (para 6).
data_restrictions: Information exchanged must be "all relevant information" and "the information required under this Article" (paras 1 and 12); no further limits specified in this section.
operational_restrictions: Information exchange must be conducted "by electronic means" and "using a standardised format" (para 12).
Split complaints require separate decisions per part, restricting use of a single combined decision for mixed outcomes (para 9).
technical_restrictions: Mandatory use of electronic means and a standardised format for inter-authority information supply (para 12).
geographic_restrictions: LSA notification for action part in split decisions must be to the main/single establishment "on the territory of its Member State" (para 9).
Controller/processor compliance measures must ensure compliance "in the context of all its establishments in the Union" (para 10).

individual_rights: Complainant must be informed of the decision by the supervisory authority with which the complaint was lodged (para 7).
Where a complaint is dismissed or rejected, the complainant must be notified of that decision (para 8).

In split outcomes, the complainant must be informed by the LSA regarding the action part decision (para 9) and notified by the complainantâ€™s authority regarding the dismissal/rejection part (para 9).
organizational_rights: LSA may request mutual assistance (Article 61) and may conduct joint operations (Article 62) (para 2) (institutional powers).
CSAs have the procedural ability to issue a "relevant and reasoned objection" within four weeks (para 4).
how_to_exercise_rights: CSAs exercise objection rights by expressing a "relevant and reasoned objection" within four weeks after consultation on the draft decision (para 4).
Complainants receive information/notifications from the competent supervisory authority as specified in paras 7â€“9.

conditional_exemptions: Derogation from the general rule in paragraph 7: where a complaint is dismissed or rejected, the complaint-receiving authority (not the LSA) adopts and notifies the decision to the complainant and informs the controller (para 8).

technical_measures: Implement electronic information exchange mechanisms capable of using a standardised format for required inter-authority information (para 12) (applies to supervisory authorities).
organizational_measures: Establish internal procedures to ensure 'without delay' communications, draft decision circulation, and tracking of objection deadlines (paras 3â€“5).
Establish procedures for adopting separate decisions for split complaint outcomes and allocating responsibilities between LSA and complainantâ€™s authority (para 9).
Controllers/processors must implement governance to roll out compliance measures across all EU establishments after a decision and to report measures to the LSA (para 10).

enforcement.regulatory_authority: EU Member State supervisory authorities (lead supervisory authority and other supervisory authorities concerned); European Data Protection Board involved via information and consistency mechanism references.
enforcement_mechanisms: Cross-authority cooperation and information exchange (paras 1, 3, 12).
Mutual assistance and joint operations for investigations/monitoring (para 2).
Consistency mechanism escalation when objections are not followed/accepted (para 4).
Urgency procedure in exceptional urgent cases to protect data subjects (para 11).
Binding effect of unobjected draft decisions on authorities (para 6).
Controller/processor obligation to implement measures and report back to LSA (para 10).

implementation_steps: For supervisory authorities: implement workflows to (1) exchange all relevant information, (2) issue and circulate draft decisions promptly, (3) log consultation dates and calculate 4-week and 2-week objection windows, (4) evaluate objections for relevance/reasoning, (5) either revise draft decisions or refer to the consistency mechanism, (6) adopt and notify final decisions and inform CSAs/Board with summary of facts/grounds, and (7) use electronic standardised formats for all required exchanges (paras 1â€“7, 12).
For complaint-handling authorities: ensure complainants are informed/notified according to whether the outcome is action, dismissal/rejection, or split (paras 7â€“9).
For controllers/processors: upon notification of an LSA decision, deploy compliance measures across all EU establishments and notify the LSA of measures taken (para 10).
common_violations: Failure to communicate relevant information or submit draft decisions 'without delay' (para 3).
Missing the 4-week or 2-week objection windows due to poor deadline tracking (paras 4â€“5).
Finalizing decisions without properly considering CSA views or without following the objection/escalation procedure (paras 3â€“5).
Not informing the Board/CSAs with a summary of relevant facts and grounds (para 7).
Incorrect allocation of decision adoption/notification responsibilities for dismissed/rejected complaints or split complaints (paras 8â€“9).
Controller/processor failing to implement measures across all EU establishments or failing to notify the LSA of measures taken (para 10).
Not using electronic means/standardised format for required information exchange (para 12).
best_practices: Maintain a case management system that timestamps consultation and automatically calculates objection deadlines (4 weeks; 2 weeks for revised drafts).
Use templates that ensure decisions shared with CSAs/Board include the required 'summary of relevant facts and grounds'.
Define standard operating procedures for split-complaint outcomes to ensure separate decisions and correct notification routing.
For controllers/processors, maintain an EU-wide remediation rollout plan and a standardized compliance-measures report to the LSA.
compliance_checklist: LSA/CSAs exchange all relevant information (para 1).
LSA communicates relevant information and submits draft decision 'without delay' (para 3).
LSA takes due account of CSA views (para 3).
CSAs given 4 weeks to object; objections handled per para 4 (consistency mechanism referral if not followed/accepted).
If following objection: revised draft circulated; 2-week objection window applied (para 5).
If no objection: authorities deemed in agreement and bound (para 6).
LSA adopts and notifies decision to main/single establishment; informs CSAs and Board with summary of facts/grounds (para 7).
Complaint authority informs complainant (para 7); if dismissal/rejection, complaint authority adopts/notifies and informs controller (para 8).
If split: separate decisions adopted; correct authority adopts/notifies each part (para 9).
Controller/processor implements necessary measures across all EU establishments and notifies LSA; LSA informs CSAs (para 10).
Urgency procedure considered in exceptional urgent cases (para 11).
All required inter-authority information supplied electronically using a standardised format (para 12).

key_definitions.lead supervisory authority (LSA): Not defined in this section; referenced as the authority that coordinates cooperation and adopts the decision in cross-border cases.
key_definitions.supervisory authorities concerned (CSAs): Not defined in this section; referenced as other supervisory authorities involved in the matter and consulted on draft decisions.
key_definitions.relevant and reasoned objection: Not defined in this section; referenced as an objection that must be both relevant and reasoned and must be expressed within specified deadlines (para 4).
key_definitions.main establishment or single establishme: Not defined in this section; referenced as the entity location to which the LSA must notify the decision (para 7) and, in split decisions, on the territory of the LSAâ€™s Member State (para 9).
key_definitions.consistency mechanism: Not defined in this section; referenced as the mechanism in Article 63 to which matters must be submitted under conditions in para 4.
key_definitions.urgency procedure: Not defined in this section; referenced as the procedure in Article 66 that applies in exceptional urgent circumstances (para 11).

regulations.source_section: ## Cooperation between the lead supervisory authority and the other supervisory authorities concerned

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 61 (Mutual assistance)

industry_sectors: All sectors (applies to supervisory authorities overseeing all controllers/processors)

description.brief_summary: Imposes mandatory mutual assistance and information-sharing duties between supervisory authorities, including strict timelines, limited refusal grounds, electronic/standardised exchange expectations, cost rules, and escalation mechanisms when assistance is not provided.
description.detailed_explanation: The provision requires supervisory authorities to cooperate by providing each other relevant information and assistance necessary for consistent implementation and application of the GDPR. Mutual assistance explicitly includes handling information requests and taking supervisory measures upon request (including prior authorisations/consultations, inspections, and investigations). A requested authority must take all appropriate measures to respond without undue delay and at the latest within one month of receiving the request, potentially including transmitting information about an investigationâ€™s conduct. Requests must include all necessary information (including purpose and reasons), and any information exchanged is strictly limited to use for the purpose for which it was requested. Refusal is tightly constrained to two grounds: lack of competence for the subject matter/measures, or where compliance would infringe the GDPR or other applicable Union/Member State law. The requested authority must communicate results or progress and must justify any refusal. As a default, information should be supplied electronically using a standardised format. No fee may be charged for actions taken under mutual assistance, though authorities may agree indemnification rules for specific expenditure in exceptional circumstances. If the requested authority fails to provide the information referred to in the results/progress obligation within one month, the requesting authority may adopt a provisional measure in its territory under Article 55(1), and urgency under Article 66(1) is presumed, requiring an urgent binding decision from the Board under Article 66(2). The Commission is empowered to adopt implementing acts specifying formats/procedures and electronic exchange arrangements (including the standardised format), using the examination procedure under Article 93(2).
description.purpose: To ensure consistent application and enforcement of the GDPR across Member States through structured cooperation, timely assistance, and reliable information exchange between supervisory authorities.
description.legislative_intent: To prevent fragmented enforcement and delays in cross-border or multi-jurisdictional matters by mandating cooperation, limiting refusal grounds, standardising exchange methods, and enabling escalation where cooperation fails.

what_it_covers: Mutual assistance between supervisory authorities
Exchange of relevant information for GDPR implementation/application
Execution of supervisory measures upon request (e.g., prior authorisations/consultations, inspections, investigations)
Procedural requirements for assistance requests (content, purpose limitation)
Response timelines and progress/result reporting
Permitted refusal grounds and duty to provide reasons
Electronic exchange and standardised formats
Cost/fee rules and exceptional indemnification arrangements
Escalation to provisional measures and urgent Board decisions when assistance is not provided in time
Commission implementing acts on formats/procedures and electronic exchange arrangements

target_entities: Supervisory authorities (data protection authorities) in EU Member States
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies to supervisory authorities operating within EU Member States; cooperation is inherently cross-border within the EU framework.

what_it_does_not_cover: Direct obligations on controllers/processors (this article governs authority-to-authority cooperation rather than regulated entitiesâ€™ operational compliance)

mandatory_obligations: Supervisory authorities must provide each other with relevant information and mutual assistance to implement and apply the Regulation consistently. Quote: "Supervisory authorities shall provide each other with relevant information and mutual assistance..."
Supervisory authorities must put in place measures for effective cooperation with one another. Quote: "...and shall put in place measures for effective cooperation with one another."

Each requested supervisory authority must take all appropriate measures required to reply to another authorityâ€™s request without undue delay and no later than one month after receiving the request. Quote: "Each supervisory authority shall take all appropriate measures required to reply... without undue delay and no later than one month after receiving the request."

Requests for assistance must contain all necessary information, including the purpose and reasons for the request. Quote: "Requests for assistance shall contain all the necessary information, including the purpose of and reasons for the request."

The requested supervisory authority must inform the requesting authority of the results or, as the case may be, the progress of measures taken to respond. Quote: "The requested supervisory authority shall inform the requesting supervisory authority of the results or, as the case may be, of the progress of the measures taken..."
The requested supervisory authority must provide reasons for any refusal to comply. Quote: "The requested supervisory authority shall provide reasons for any refusal to comply..."

Requested supervisory authorities must, as a rule, supply requested information by electronic means using a standardised format. Quote: "Requested supervisory authorities shall, as a rule, supply the information requested... by electronic means, using a standardised format."

Requested supervisory authorities must not charge a fee for any action taken pursuant to a mutual assistance request. Quote: "Requested supervisory authorities shall not charge a fee for any action taken..."
prohibited_actions: Information exchanged must not be used for purposes other than the purpose for which it was requested. Quote: "Information exchanged shall be used only for the purpose for which it was requested."

Requested supervisory authorities must not refuse to comply except on the enumerated grounds. Quote: "The requested supervisory authority shall not refuse to comply with the request unless: (a)... or (b)..."
Requested supervisory authorities must not charge fees for actions taken under mutual assistance. Quote: "...shall not charge a fee for any action taken..."
conditional_requirements: Mutual assistance must cover, in particular, information requests and supervisory measures such as requests to carry out prior authorisations and consultations, inspections and investigations. Quote: "Mutual assistance shall cover, in particular, information requests and supervisory measures, such as requests to carry out prior authorisations and consultations, inspections and investigations."

Measures taken to reply may include transmitting relevant information on the conduct of an investigation. Quote: "Such measures may include, in particular, the transmission of relevant information on the conduct of an investigation."

Refusal is permitted only if: (a) the requested authority is not competent for the subject-matter or measures; or (b) compliance would infringe the GDPR or Union/Member State law applicable to the requested authority. Quote: "...unless: (a) it is not competent...; or (b) compliance... would infringe this Regulation or Union or Member State law..."

Supervisory authorities may agree on rules to indemnify each other for specific expenditure arising from mutual assistance in exceptional circumstances. Quote: "Supervisory authorities may agree on rules to indemnify each other for specific expenditure... in exceptional circumstances."

If the requested authority does not provide the information referred to in the results/progress obligation within one month, the requesting authority may adopt a provisional measure on its territory in accordance with Article 55(1). Quote: "Where a supervisory authority does not provide the information referred to in paragraph 5... within one month... the requesting supervisory authority may adopt a provisional measure... in accordance with Article 55(1)."

In the above non-response scenario, urgent need to act under Article 66(1) is presumed and requires an urgent binding decision from the Board under Article 66(2). Quote: "...the urgent need to act under Article 66(1) shall be presumed to be met and require an urgent binding decision from the Board pursuant to Article 66(2)."

The Commission may specify format/procedures and electronic exchange arrangements via implementing acts, adopted under the examination procedure in Article 93(2). Quote: "The Commission may, by means of implementing acts, specify the format and procedures... Those implementing acts shall be adopted in accordance with the examination procedure referred to in Article 93(2)."
documentation_requirements: Assistance requests must include necessary information, specifically including purpose and reasons (i.e., the request must document these elements). Quote: "Requests for assistance shall contain all the necessary information, including the purpose of and reasons for the request."
If refusing a request, the requested authority must provide reasons (i.e., document and communicate the rationale). Quote: "...shall provide reasons for any refusal..."
reporting_requirements: Requested authority must report results or progress of measures taken to respond to the request. Quote: "...shall inform... of the results or... of the progress..."
timeline_requirements: Response deadline: without undue delay and no later than one month after receiving the request. Quote: "...without undue delay and no later than one month after receiving the request."

Escalation trigger: if information referred to in the results/progress obligation is not provided within one month of receiving the request. Quote: "...does not provide the information referred to in paragraph 5... within one month of receiving the request..."

general_restrictions: Purpose limitation on exchanged information: use only for the purpose requested. Quote: "Information exchanged shall be used only for the purpose for which it was requested."
Refusal restriction: non-compliance is prohibited except for the two specified grounds (competence or legal infringement). Quote: "...shall not refuse... unless: (a)... or (b)..."
data_restrictions: Use limitation on exchanged information (functional equivalent of purpose limitation for shared information). Quote: "Information exchanged shall be used only for the purpose for which it was requested."
operational_restrictions: Default channel/format expectation: as a rule, supply information electronically using a standardised format. Quote: "...as a rule... by electronic means, using a standardised format."
Cost restriction: no fees may be charged for mutual assistance actions. Quote: "...shall not charge a fee..."
technical_restrictions: Electronic means and standardised format are the default method for supplying requested information. Quote: "...by electronic means, using a standardised format."

Commission may specify electronic exchange arrangements and standardised formats via implementing acts. Quote: "...specify the format and procedures... and the arrangements for the exchange of information by electronic means... in particular the standardised format..."
geographic_restrictions: Provisional measures (in the non-response scenario) are adopted "on the territory of its Member State" by the requesting authority. Quote: "...may adopt a provisional measure on the territory of its Member State..."

organizational_rights: Requesting supervisory authority may adopt a provisional measure on its territory if the requested authority does not provide the required information within one month (subject to Article 55(1)). Quote: "...may adopt a provisional measure..."

Requesting supervisory authority benefits from a presumption of urgency under Article 66(1) in the non-response scenario, enabling escalation to an urgent binding Board decision under Article 66(2). Quote: "...urgent need to act... shall be presumed... and require an urgent binding decision..."
how_to_exercise_rights: To exercise the provisional-measure right: (1) make a mutual assistance request; (2) if the requested authority does not provide the paragraph 5 information within one month of receipt, adopt a provisional measure within the requesting authorityâ€™s Member State territory in accordance with Article 55(1); (3) treat urgency under Article 66(1) as presumed and seek/trigger an urgent binding decision from the Board under Article 66(2).

general_exceptions: Refusal permitted where the requested authority is not competent for the subject-matter or measures requested. Quote: "(a) it is not competent for the subject-matter of the request or for the measures it is requested to execute"

Refusal permitted where compliance would infringe the GDPR or Union/Member State law applicable to the requested authority. Quote: "(b) compliance with the request would infringe this Regulation or Union or Member State law..."
conditional_exemptions: Electronic/standardised exchange is qualified by "as a rule" (implying possible deviation where justified/necessary, though no criteria are specified in this text). Quote: "...shall, as a rule, supply... by electronic means, using a standardised format."

No-fee rule is qualified by the possibility of agreed indemnification for specific expenditure in exceptional circumstances. Quote: "...may agree on rules to indemnify each other for specific expenditure... in exceptional circumstances."

technical_measures: Capability to exchange information electronically with other supervisory authorities (and, as relevant, with the Board) and to use a standardised format. Quote: "...by electronic means, using a standardised format."

Ability to implement Commission-specified formats/procedures and electronic exchange arrangements once adopted via implementing acts. Quote: "The Commission may... specify the format and procedures... and the arrangements for the exchange of information by electronic means..."
organizational_measures: Establish measures for effective cooperation with other supervisory authorities. Quote: "...shall put in place measures for effective cooperation..."
Internal process to ensure responses to mutual assistance requests are handled without undue delay and within one month.
Process to ensure assistance requests drafted by the authority include all necessary information, including purpose and reasons.
Process to track and communicate results/progress back to requesting authorities.
Process to assess and document refusal grounds limited to competence or legal infringement, and to provide reasons for refusal.
security_measures: Purpose limitation control for exchanged information (procedural/technical controls to ensure information is used only for the requested purpose). Quote: "Information exchanged shall be used only for the purpose for which it was requested."

enforcement.regulatory_authority: EU Member State supervisory authorities (mutual obligations) and, in escalation scenarios, the European Data Protection Board (Board) via urgent binding decisions under Article 66(2); Commission via implementing acts for procedures/formats.
enforcement_mechanisms: Inter-authority procedural enforcement through mandatory cooperation duties and limited refusal grounds.
Escalation mechanism: if required information is not provided within one month, the requesting authority may adopt provisional measures under Article 55(1).
Urgency presumption triggers need for an urgent binding decision from the Board under Article 66(2) when non-response occurs as described.

dates.compliance_deadline: Operational deadlines within the procedure: respond to requests without undue delay and no later than one month after receipt; provide results/progress information within one month to avoid escalation.

related_articles: Article 55(1) (referenced for provisional measures on the territory of the requesting authorityâ€™s Member State)
Article 66(1) (referenced for urgent need to act; presumed satisfied in the non-response scenario)
Article 66(2) (referenced for urgent binding decision from the Board)
Article 93(2) (referenced for the examination procedure for Commission implementing acts)

implementation_steps: Create and maintain a mutual assistance intake and tracking workflow to ensure the one-month deadline is met.
Define internal criteria and routing to determine competence quickly and identify potential legal conflicts (GDPR/Union/Member State law) that could justify refusal.
Standardise request templates to ensure inclusion of "purpose" and "reasons" and other necessary information.
Implement electronic exchange tooling and adopt/maintain the required standardised format for responses.
Establish a policy to enforce purpose-limited use of received information (access controls, case-based handling, and logging).
Adopt a cost policy reflecting the no-fee rule and define when/ how indemnification for specific expenditure may be agreed in exceptional circumstances.

Prepare escalation playbooks for requesting authorities: if no paragraph 5 information is received within one month, consider provisional measures under Article 55(1) and initiate urgent Board procedures under Article 66.
common_violations: Failing to respond within one month of receiving a mutual assistance request.
Sending or using exchanged information for purposes beyond the stated request purpose.
Refusing assistance for reasons outside the two permitted grounds or failing to provide reasons for refusal.
Not providing results/progress updates to the requesting authority.
Charging fees for mutual assistance actions contrary to the no-fee rule.
Not using electronic means/standardised format as the default without a justified alternative process.
best_practices: Use standardised electronic forms and structured data fields for requests/responses to meet the "standardised format" expectation.
Maintain SLA monitoring to ensure "without undue delay" handling and to avoid missing the one-month deadline.
Document refusal decisions with explicit mapping to ground (a) competence or (b) legal infringement, including legal citations where applicable.
Provide interim progress updates when full results cannot be delivered quickly, to satisfy the paragraph 5 obligation.
compliance_checklist: Cooperation measures exist and are operational between supervisory authorities.
Mutual assistance scope includes information requests and supervisory measures (prior authorisations/consultations, inspections, investigations).
Process ensures responses are sent without undue delay and within one month of receipt.
Request templates require purpose and reasons and other necessary information.
Controls ensure exchanged information is used only for the requested purpose.
Refusal decisions are limited to competence/legal infringement and include written reasons.
Results/progress updates are provided to requesting authorities.
Electronic exchange and standardised format are used as the default.
No fees are charged; any indemnification rules are limited to specific expenditure and exceptional circumstances.

Escalation procedure is understood: provisional measures under Article 55(1) and urgency presumption leading to Board action under Article 66(2) when paragraph 5 information is not provided within one month.

key_definitions.mutual assistance: Assistance between supervisory authorities covering, in particular, information requests and supervisory measures such as requests to carry out prior authorisations and consultations, inspections and investigations. Quote: "Mutual assistance shall cover, in particular, information requests and supervisory measures, such as requests to carry out prior authorisations and consultations, inspections and investigations."
key_definitions.purpose limitation (for exchanged inform: Exchanged information may be used only for the purpose for which it was requested. Quote: "Information exchanged shall be used only for the purpose for which it was requested."
key_definitions.permitted refusal grounds: A requested supervisory authority may refuse only if it is not competent for the subject-matter/measures, or if compliance would infringe the GDPR or applicable Union/Member State law. Quote: "...shall not refuse... unless: (a)... or (b)..."

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 62 (Joint operations of supervisory authorities)

sub_domains: Liability and damages in supervisory cooperation

description.brief_summary: Requires supervisory authorities to cooperate through joint operations (including investigations and enforcement), grants participation rights to concerned authorities in multi-Member-State cases, regulates cross-border secondment and exercise of investigative powers, allocates liability for seconded staff and reimbursement between Member States for damages, and provides an escalation mechanism enabling provisional measures if an authority fails to cooperate within one month, with presumed urgency under the GDPR urgency procedure.
description.detailed_explanation: This section imposes operational cooperation duties on EU data protection supervisory authorities when cross-border processing affects multiple Member States. It mandates that supervisory authorities conduct joint operations where appropriate, and ensures that each supervisory authority of Member States with relevant establishments or substantially affected data subjects has a right to participate. It places a procedural duty on the competent supervisory authority (as determined under GDPR Article 56(1) or (4)) to invite other concerned supervisory authorities and to respond without delay to participation requests. It further regulates how investigative powers may be conferred on or exercised by seconded staff from another Member State, subject to authorisation and the host Member Stateâ€™s law, and requires that such powers be exercised only under the guidance and in the presence of host authority staff. The section also establishes a liability framework: the host Member State assumes responsibility (including liability) for actions of seconded staff operating in its territory; the Member State where damage occurs must compensate under conditions applicable to its own staff; and the seconding Member State must reimburse the host Member State in full for sums paid to injured persons. Finally, it limits reimbursement claims between Member States (except as specified) and provides an enforcement backstop: if a supervisory authority does not comply within one month with the obligation to respond to participation requests for an intended joint operation, other supervisory authorities may adopt provisional measures in that authorityâ€™s territory under Article 55, with urgency presumed under Article 66(1), triggering the need for an EDPB opinion or urgent binding decision under Article 66(2).
description.purpose: To ensure effective, coordinated, and legally structured cross-border supervision and enforcement of data protection rules across the EU, including clear operational procedures and liability allocation for joint actions.
description.legislative_intent: To prevent fragmented enforcement in cross-border cases by enabling joint investigations/enforcement, guaranteeing participation of concerned authorities, and providing a rapid escalation path when cooperation fails, while clarifying legal responsibility for seconded staff actions.

what_it_covers: Joint operations between supervisory authorities
Joint investigations
Joint enforcement measures
Participation rights of supervisory authorities in multi-Member-State cases
Invitation and response procedures for participation
Secondment of members/staff across Member States for joint operations
Conferral and exercise of investigative powers by seconded staff
Guidance/presence requirements for exercising investigative powers
Applicable law to seconded staff during operations
Liability and compensation for damage caused by seconded staff
Inter-Member-State reimbursement rules for compensation paid
Restrictions on reimbursement requests between Member States
Escalation to provisional measures and urgency procedure when cooperation fails

target_entities: Members or staff of supervisory authorities (including seconded staff)
entity_types: EU Member States (as legal persons responsible for damages)
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies when supervisory authorities and/or seconded staff operate across EU Member State borders; triggered particularly by controllers/processors with establishments in several Member States or processing substantially affecting data subjects in more than one Member State.

what_it_does_not_cover: Substantive rules on controller/processor compliance (this section focuses on supervisory authority cooperation and procedures)
Non-EU jurisdictions

mandatory_obligations: Supervisory authorities must, where appropriate, conduct joint operations including joint investigations and joint enforcement measures involving members or staff of supervisory authorities of other Member States. (Quote: "The supervisory authorities shall, where appropriate, conduct joint operations including joint investigations and joint enforcement measures in which members or staff of the supervisory authorities of other Member States are involved.")

Where the controller or processor has establishments in several Member States OR where a significant number of data subjects in more than one Member State are likely to be substantially affected, a supervisory authority of each of those Member States has the right to participate in joint operations. (Quote: "shall have the right to participate in joint operations")
The supervisory authority competent under Article 56(1) or (4) must invite the supervisory authority of each of those Member States to take part in the joint operations. (Quote: "shall invite")
The competent supervisory authority must respond without delay to a request of a supervisory authority to participate. (Quote: "shall respond without delay")

If investigative powers are exercised by seconded staff, they may be exercised only under the guidance and in the presence of members or staff of the host supervisory authority. (Quote: "Such investigative powers may be exercised only under the guidance and in the presence of members or staff of the host supervisory authority.")

Seconding supervisory authority members or staff involved in joint operations are subject to the Member State law of the host supervisory authority. (Quote: "shall be subject to the Member State law of the host supervisory authority")

When seconded staff operate in another Member State, the host Member State must assume responsibility for their actions, including liability for any damage caused during operations, in accordance with the law of the territory where they operate. (Quote: "shall assume responsibility for their actions, including liability")
The Member State in whose territory the damage was caused must make good such damage under the conditions applicable to damage caused by its own staff. (Quote: "shall make good such damage")

The Member State of the seconding supervisory authority must reimburse the other Member State in full any sums it has paid to the persons entitled on their behalf. (Quote: "shall reimburse that other Member State in full any sums it has paid")

Each Member State must refrain from requesting reimbursement from another Member State in relation to damage referred to in paragraph 4, except as provided in paragraph 5 and without prejudice to rights vis-Ã -vis third parties. (Quote: "each Member State shall refrain ... from requesting reimbursement")
prohibited_actions: Member States must not request reimbursement from another Member State for damage referred to in paragraph 4, except as allowed by paragraph 5. (Derived from: "shall refrain ... with the exception of paragraph 5")

Seconded staff must not exercise investigative powers outside the conditions set (i.e., not without host guidance/presence; not contrary to applicable host law/authorisation constraints). (Derived from: "may be exercised only under the guidance and in the presence" and conditionality in paragraph 3)
conditional_requirements: Joint operations are required only "where appropriate" (discretionary trigger based on appropriateness).

Participation right applies when either: (a) controller/processor has establishments in several Member States; or (b) a significant number of data subjects in more than one Member State are likely to be substantially affected by processing operations.

Conferral of powers (including investigative powers) on seconded authority staff is permitted only: (i) in accordance with Member State law; and (ii) with the seconding supervisory authorityâ€™s authorisation. (Quote: "in accordance with Member State law, and with the seconding supervisory authority's authorisation")

Alternatively, seconded staff may be allowed to exercise their own investigative powers only insofar as the host Member State law permits, and then in accordance with the law of the Member State of the seconding supervisory authority. (Quote: "in so far as the law of the Member State of the host supervisory authority permits")
Host Member State responsibility/liability applies when, in accordance with paragraph 1, staff of a seconding supervisory authority operate in another Member State.

Escalation mechanism applies when: (a) a joint operation is intended; and (b) a supervisory authority does not, within one month, comply with the obligation in the second sentence of paragraph 2 (i.e., to respond without delay to a request to participate).
timeline_requirements: Competent supervisory authority must "respond without delay" to participation requests (no fixed number of days specified).
If a supervisory authority does not comply "within one month" with the obligation referenced (response obligation), other supervisory authorities may adopt provisional measures.

general_restrictions: Exercise of investigative powers by seconded staff is restricted to being under host authority guidance and in the presence of host authority members/staff.
Seconded staff are subject to host Member State law during joint operations in the host territory.
operational_restrictions: Conferral/exercise of powers is constrained by: host Member State law, seconding authority authorisation, and (where applicable) the seconding Member State law governing the investigative powers exercised.
geographic_restrictions: Liability and applicable law are tied to the Member State territory where seconded staff operate and where damage occurs.

organizational_rights: Each supervisory authority of Member States where the controller/processor has establishments, or where a significant number of data subjects are likely to be substantially affected, has the right to participate in joint operations. (Quote: "shall have the right to participate")

Other supervisory authorities may adopt a provisional measure on the territory of a non-cooperating supervisory authorityâ€™s Member State under Article 55 when the one-month non-compliance condition is met. (Quote: "may adopt a provisional measure on the territory of its Member State")
how_to_exercise_rights: Participation right is exercised by requesting to participate; the competent supervisory authority must respond without delay.
Provisional measure right is exercised by other supervisory authorities adopting a measure under Article 55 when the specified one-month non-compliance occurs.
