Member States must "take all measures necessary to ensure that they are implemented" (Quote: "and shall take all measures necessary to ensure that they are implemented").
Member States must ensure the penalties are "effective, proportionate and dissuasive" (Quote: "Such penalties shall be effective, proportionate and dissuasive").

Each Member State must notify the European Commission of the national legal provisions adopted pursuant to paragraph 1 by 25 May 2018 (Quote: "Each Member State shall notify to the Commission the provisions of its law which it adopts pursuant to paragraph 1, by 25 May 2018").
Each Member State must notify the Commission "without delay" of any subsequent amendment affecting those provisions (Quote: "and, without delay, any subsequent amendment affecting them").
prohibited_actions: Failure to establish national penalty rules for GDPR infringements not covered by Article 83 administrative fines (implied prohibition via mandatory 'shall').
Failure to take necessary measures to ensure implementation of such penalties (implied prohibition via mandatory 'shall').
Failure to notify the Commission by the deadline or failure to notify subsequent amendments without delay (implied prohibition via mandatory 'shall').
conditional_requirements: Penalty rules must apply "in particular" where infringements are not subject to administrative fines under Article 83; i.e., the obligation specifically targets the subset of infringements outside Article 83 (Quote: "in particular for infringements which are not subject to administrative fines pursuant to Article 83").
Notification of amendments is required when there is a "subsequent amendment affecting" the national provisions adopted under paragraph 1 (Quote: "any subsequent amendment affecting them").
documentation_requirements: Member States must have identifiable "provisions of its law" adopted pursuant to paragraph 1 that can be notified to the Commission (Quote: "the provisions of its law which it adopts pursuant to paragraph 1").
reporting_requirements: Notification to the European Commission of national penalty provisions adopted under paragraph 1 by 25 May 2018.
Notification to the European Commission of any subsequent amendments affecting those provisions without delay.
timeline_requirements: Deadline: notify the Commission of adopted national provisions "by 25 May 2018".
Ongoing obligation: notify the Commission "without delay" of any subsequent amendment affecting the notified provisions.

general_restrictions: Member State penalty regimes must satisfy qualitative constraints: penalties must be "effective, proportionate and dissuasive" (acts as a constraint on how Member States design penalties).
operational_restrictions: Member States must operationalize enforcement by taking "all measures necessary to ensure that they are implemented" (requires operational capability to apply penalties).
geographic_restrictions: Applies to EU Member States; national penalty rules are established within each Member Stateâ€™s legal system.

general_exceptions: This article does not govern infringements that are subject to administrative fines under Article 83; it is directed "in particular" at infringements not subject to Article 83 fines (functional carve-out).

organizational_measures: Adopt national legal rules establishing other penalties for GDPR infringements not covered by Article 83.
Establish and maintain processes/measures to ensure penalties are implemented/enforced.
Establish and maintain a process to notify the European Commission of the adopted provisions and to notify amendments without delay.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: EU Member States (for establishing and implementing penalties); European Commission (recipient of notifications).

penalties.administrative_penalties: This section concerns "other penalties" for infringements not subject to administrative fines under Article 83; the specific types/amounts are to be laid down by Member States and are not specified here.

enforcement_mechanisms: Member State adoption of national penalty rules.
Member State implementation measures to ensure penalties are applied.
Commission notification mechanism for national provisions and amendments.

dates.compliance_deadline: 25 May 2018 (deadline for Member States to notify the Commission of national provisions adopted pursuant to paragraph 1).

related_articles: GDPR Article 83 (Administrative fines) (referenced as the fine regime from which certain infringements may be excluded).

implementation_steps: Identify GDPR infringements under national law that are not subject to Article 83 administrative fines.
Draft/adopt national legislation or rules establishing penalties for those infringements.
Validate that the penalty framework meets the criteria "effective, proportionate and dissuasive".
Put in place enforcement/implementation measures (e.g., designation of competent bodies, procedures to apply penalties).
Notify the European Commission of the adopted national provisions by 25 May 2018 (historical deadline) and maintain a process to notify any amendments without delay.
common_violations: Not adopting national penalty rules for non-Article-83 infringements.
Adopting penalties that are not demonstrably effective, proportionate, and dissuasive.
Failure to notify the Commission of adopted provisions or later amendments within the required timelines.
best_practices: Maintain a legislative register mapping GDPR infringement categories to applicable sanction types (Article 83 fines vs. other penalties).
Document rationale/impact assessment supporting effectiveness, proportionality, and dissuasiveness of penalties.
Establish a formal notification workflow to the Commission for initial provisions and amendments.
compliance_checklist: National law includes penalty provisions for GDPR infringements not covered by Article 83 fines.
Penalty provisions meet the criteria: effective, proportionate, dissuasive.
Implementation measures exist and are operational to apply penalties.
Commission notification completed for adopted provisions (by 25 May 2018) and process exists for notifying amendments without delay.

key_definitions.other penalties: Penalties established by Member States for GDPR infringements, particularly those not subject to administrative fines under Article 83 (specific forms not defined in this section).
key_definitions.effective, proportionate and dissuasive: Qualitative criteria that Member State penalties must satisfy; not further defined in this section.
key_definitions.without delay: An obligation to notify subsequent amendments promptly; no specific number of days is defined in this section.

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 85 (Processing and freedom of expression and information)

applicable_regions: EEA Member States (via EEA incorporation where applicable)

sub_domains: Regulatory notification to the European Commission
industry_sectors: Online platforms (where engaged in journalistic/expressive processing)
Academia and research institutions (where processing is for academic expression)

description.brief_summary: Requires Member States to legislate a balance between GDPR data protection and freedom of expression/information, including by providing necessary exemptions/derogations for journalistic and certain expressive processing, and to notify the Commission of the national measures adopted and amendments.
description.detailed_explanation: The provision mandates national legislative action. First, Member States must enact laws that reconcile two fundamental interests: protection of personal data under the GDPR and the right to freedom of expression and information, explicitly including processing for journalistic purposes and for academic, artistic, or literary expression. Second, for processing carried out for those purposes, Member States must provide exemptions or derogations from a defined set of GDPR chapters (principles; data subject rights; controller/processor obligations; international transfers; supervisory authorities; cooperation/consistency; and specific processing situations), but only to the extent such exemptions/derogations are necessary to achieve reconciliation between data protection and freedom of expression/information. Third, Member States must notify the European Commission of the national legal provisions adopted under the second requirement and must also notify, without delay, any subsequent amendment law or amendment affecting those provisions.
description.purpose: To ensure that GDPR data protection rules do not unduly restrict freedom of expression and information, while still protecting personal data, by requiring Member States to implement tailored national balancing rules and necessary derogations for expressive activities.
description.legislative_intent: To operationalize a legally mandated balancing framework at Member State level, ensuring consistent recognition of expressive freedoms across the EU while allowing national legal systems to define necessary and proportionate derogations from GDPR obligations for journalistic and other expressive processing.

what_it_covers: National legislation by Member States reconciling GDPR data protection with freedom of expression and information
Processing of personal data for journalistic purposes
Processing of personal data for purposes of academic expression
Processing of personal data for purposes of artistic expression
Processing of personal data for purposes of literary expression
Creation of exemptions/derogations from specified GDPR chapters when necessary for reconciliation
Notification to the European Commission of national provisions and amendments adopted under the derogation/exemption framework

target_entities: EU Member States (legislators/national governments) as duty-bearers for enacting laws and notifications
Controllers/processors indirectly, insofar as they may rely on national exemptions/derogations for covered expressive processing
entity_types: Public authorities (national legislatures and competent ministries) for implementation and notification
Private and public organizations engaged in journalistic/academic/artistic/literary expression (as beneficiaries/subjects of national derogations)
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Member State jurisdiction; applies to national lawmaking and to processing within the scope of Member State law implementing Article 85.

what_it_does_not_cover: Any exemption/derogation beyond the listed GDPR chapters (not specified here)
Any automatic exemption: exemptions/derogations must be provided by Member State law and must be 'necessary' to reconcile rights
Specific criteria for what constitutes 'journalistic purposes' or 'academic artistic or literary expression' (not defined in this section)

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Member States must enact national law reconciling data protection with freedom of expression and information.
mandatory_obligations.legal_trigger_or_context: General obligation under this article; applies to reconciling rights under the GDPR with freedom of expression/information.
mandatory_obligations.exact_quote: â€œMember States shall by law reconcile the right to the protection of personal data pursuant to this Regulation with the right to freedom of expression and information, including processing for journalistic purposes and the purposes of academic, artistic or literary expression.â€

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Member States must provide exemptions or derogations for certain expressive processing from specified GDPR chapters, when necessary to reconcile rights.
mandatory_obligations.legal_trigger_or_context: Applies â€œFor processing carried out for journalistic purposes or the purpose of academic artistic or literary expressionâ€ and only â€œif they are necessaryâ€ to reconcile rights.
mandatory_obligations.exact_quote: â€œMember States shall provide for exemptions or derogations from Chapter II (principles), Chapter III (rights of the data subject), Chapter IV (controller and processor), Chapter V (transfer of personal data to third countries or international organisations), Chapter VI (independent supervisory authorities), Chapter VII (cooperation and consistency) and Chapter IX (specific data processing situations) if they are necessary to reconcile the right to the protection of personal data with the freedom of expression and information.â€

mandatory_obligations.obligation: Member States must notify the European Commission of national provisions adopted under the derogation/exemption requirement and notify amendments without delay.
mandatory_obligations.legal_trigger_or_context: Applies to provisions adopted pursuant to paragraph 2 and any subsequent amendments affecting them.
mandatory_obligations.exact_quote: â€œEach Member State shall notify to the Commission the provisions of its law which it has adopted pursuant to paragraph 2 and, without delay, any subsequent amendment law or amendment affecting them.â€

conditional_requirements.condition: Processing is carried out for journalistic purposes or for academic, artistic, or literary expression.
conditional_requirements.requirement: Member States must provide exemptions/derogations from the listed GDPR chapters.
conditional_requirements.necessity_test: Exemptions/derogations must be provided only â€œif they are necessary to reconcileâ€ data protection with freedom of expression and information.
conditional_requirements.exact_quote: â€œFor processing carried out for journalistic purposes or the purpose of academic artistic or literary expression, Member States shall provide for exemptions or derogations ... if they are necessary to reconcile ...â€

documentation_requirements.document_or_artifact: National legal provisions adopted pursuant to paragraph 2 (exemptions/derogations).
documentation_requirements.purpose: To establish the exemptions/derogations in law and enable notification to the Commission.
documentation_requirements.exact_quote: â€œthe provisions of its law which it has adopted pursuant to paragraph 2â€

reporting_requirements.reporting_action: Notify the European Commission of national legal provisions adopted pursuant to paragraph 2.
reporting_requirements.exact_quote: â€œEach Member State shall notify to the Commission the provisions of its law which it has adopted pursuant to paragraph 2â€

reporting_requirements.reporting_action: Notify the European Commission of any subsequent amendment law or amendment affecting those provisions.
reporting_requirements.exact_quote: â€œand, without delay, any subsequent amendment law or amendment affecting them.â€

timeline_requirements.applies_to: Notification to the Commission of subsequent amendment law or amendment affecting the provisions adopted pursuant to paragraph 2

general_restrictions.restriction: Exemptions/derogations are limited by a necessity standard tied to reconciling rights.
general_restrictions.details: Member States may not provide exemptions/derogations under this article unless they are necessary to reconcile the right to data protection with freedom of expression and information.
general_restrictions.exact_quote: â€œif they are necessary to reconcile the right to the protection of personal data with the freedom of expression and information.â€

organizational_rights.right_or_benefit: Ability (via Member State law) for controllers/processors engaged in journalistic/academic/artistic/literary expression to rely on exemptions/derogations from specified GDPR chapters where necessary for freedom of expression and information.
organizational_rights.how_it_arises: Through Member State laws enacted under paragraph 2.
organizational_rights.limitations: Only to the extent necessary to reconcile rights; scope depends on national implementation.

how_to_exercise_rights: Rely on applicable Member State legal provisions implementing Article 85(2) for the relevant expressive processing purpose (journalistic/academic/artistic/literary), subject to the necessity-based limits set by that national law.

conditional_exemptions.exemption_type: Exemptions or derogations from GDPR chapters
conditional_exemptions.beneficiaries_or_context: Processing carried out for journalistic purposes or for academic, artistic, or literary expression
chapters_subject_to_exemption_or_derogat: Chapter III (rights of the data subject)
Chapter V (transfer of personal data to third countries or international organisations)
conditional_exemptions.condition: Only â€œif they are necessary to reconcileâ€ data protection with freedom of expression and information.
conditional_exemptions.exact_quote: â€œMember States shall provide for exemptions or derogations from Chapter II ... Chapter IX ... if they are necessary to reconcile ...â€

organizational_measures.measure: Adopt national legal framework balancing data protection and freedom of expression/information.
Establish in national law the exemptions/derogations from specified GDPR chapters for covered expressive processing where necessary.
organizational_measures.evidence: Statutory provisions specifying exemptions/derogations and their necessity-based scope.

organizational_measures.measure: Implement a process to notify the European Commission of adopted provisions and amendments without delay.
organizational_measures.evidence: Notification records and correspondence to the Commission.

implementation_steps: Draft and enact Member State legislation that explicitly reconciles GDPR data protection with freedom of expression and information, covering journalistic and academic/artistic/literary expression processing.
In that legislation, specify exemptions/derogations from the listed GDPR chapters for the covered processing purposes, ensuring each exemption/derogation is justified as necessary for reconciliation.
Maintain an internal governmental process to notify the European Commission of the enacted provisions adopted under paragraph 2.
Notify the European Commission â€œwithout delayâ€ of any subsequent amendment law or amendment affecting those provisions.
common_violations: Failing to enact national reconciliation legislation addressing freedom of expression and information in relation to GDPR data protection.
Providing exemptions/derogations for expressive processing without tying them to the necessity standard (overbroad derogations).
Failing to notify the European Commission of the national provisions adopted under paragraph 2.
Delaying notification to the Commission of amendments affecting those provisions (breaching the â€œwithout delayâ€ requirement).
best_practices: Document the necessity rationale for each exemption/derogation in legislative materials to demonstrate alignment with the reconciliation requirement.
Create a centralized register of Article 85(2) national provisions and amendments to support timely Commission notifications.
compliance_checklist: National law exists reconciling GDPR data protection with freedom of expression and information (including journalistic and academic/artistic/literary expression).
National law provides exemptions/derogations for covered processing from the specified GDPR chapters.
Each exemption/derogation is limited to what is necessary to reconcile rights.
Commission has been notified of the provisions adopted under paragraph 2.
Commission is notified without delay of any amendments affecting those provisions.

key_definitions.reconcile: Not defined in this section; used as a legal requirement for Member States to balance the right to personal data protection with freedom of expression and information through national law.
key_definitions.exemptions or derogations: Not defined in this section; refers to Member State legal measures that disapply or modify the application of specified GDPR chapters for covered expressive processing where necessary.
key_definitions.journalistic purposes: Not defined in this section; referenced as a category of processing eligible for Member State exemptions/derogations where necessary.
key_definitions.academic, artistic or literary expressio: Not defined in this section; referenced as categories of processing eligible for Member State exemptions/derogations where necessary.
key_definitions.without delay: Not defined in this section; establishes an immediacy requirement for notifying the Commission of amendments affecting the national provisions adopted under paragraph 2.

regulations.source_section: ## Processing and freedom of expression and information

sub_domains: Public sector information / access to documents
industry_sectors: Private bodies performing public interest tasks

description.brief_summary: Permits disclosure of personal data in official documents held by certain bodies, but only where such disclosure is carried out in accordance with applicable Union or Member State law, to balance public access to documents with personal data protection under the Regulation.
description.detailed_explanation: The section establishes a conditional permission framework for disclosing personal data contained in "official documents". It applies where the documents are held by (i) a public authority, (ii) a public body, or (iii) a private body, but only when the private body holds the documents "for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest". In those circumstances, the authority/body "may" disclose the personal data, but the disclosure must be "in accordance with Union or Member State law to which the public authority or body is subject". The stated compliance objective is "to reconcile public access to official documents with the right to the protection of personal data pursuant to this Regulation." This creates (a) a legal-basis dependency on external EU/Member State access-to-documents rules applicable to the disclosing entity, and (b) a balancing requirement: disclosure should be structured to achieve reconciliation between transparency/public access and data protection rights under the Regulation. Exact operative text: "Personal data in official documents ... may be disclosed ... in accordance with Union or Member State law ... in order to reconcile public access to official documents with the right to the protection of personal data pursuant to this Regulation."
description.purpose: To allow transparency/public access regimes for official documents to operate while ensuring personal data protection is respected under the Regulation.
description.legislative_intent: To avoid an absolute bar on disclosure of personal data in official documents, while ensuring disclosures occur only under applicable access-to-documents laws and in a way that balances transparency with data protection.

what_it_covers: Disclosure of personal data contained in official documents
Processing/disclosure decisions by public authorities, public bodies, and certain private bodies
Situations involving public access to official documents and data protection rights

target_entities: Private body performing a task carried out in the public interest
entity_types: Private entities acting under a public interest mandate/task
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities subject to Union or Member State law governing them (i.e., within EU/Member State jurisdiction).

what_it_does_not_cover: Disclosures not involving "official documents"
Private bodies not holding documents for performance of a task carried out in the public interest (not explicitly included)
Disclosures not made in accordance with applicable Union/Member State law (not permitted under this section)

mandatory_obligations: If disclosing personal data in official documents under this permission, the authority/body must do so "in accordance with Union or Member State law to which the public authority or body is subject" (quote: "may be disclosed ... in accordance with Union or Member State law to which the public authority or body is subject").

Disclosure (where undertaken) must be oriented to the purpose of reconciling public access to official documents with the right to personal data protection under the Regulation (quote: "in order to reconcile public access to official documents with the right to the protection of personal data pursuant to this Regulation").
prohibited_actions: Disclosing personal data in official documents other than in accordance with the applicable Union or Member State law governing the authority/body (implied restriction from the condition attached to "may be disclosed").
conditional_requirements: The permission applies only where the personal data is "in official documents" and those documents are "held by" a qualifying entity (public authority/public body/private body performing a public interest task) (quote: "Personal data in official documents held by a public authority or a public body or a private body for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest").
A private body is within scope only when holding the official documents "for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest" (quote as above).

Disclosure is conditional on the existence and applicability of relevant Union or Member State law to which the authority/body is subject (quote: "in accordance with Union or Member State law to which the public authority or body is subject").

general_restrictions: Disclosure is not free-standing under this section; it is constrained by and must follow applicable Union or Member State law governing the disclosing authority/body (quote: "in accordance with Union or Member State law to which the public authority or body is subject").

Disclosure must be framed as a reconciliation/balancing between public access and data protection rights under the Regulation (quote: "in order to reconcile public access ... with the right to the protection of personal data pursuant to this Regulation").
data_restrictions: Only personal data contained in "official documents" is addressed; other personal data contexts are not covered by this section (quote: "Personal data in official documents").
operational_restrictions: Only entities holding documents in the specified capacities may rely on this permission (quote: "held by a public authority or a public body or a private body for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest").
geographic_restrictions: The governing constraint is the Union or Member State law to which the authority/body is subject, implying the restriction is tied to the entityâ€™s applicable EU/Member State legal regime (quote: "Union or Member State law to which the public authority or body is subject").

individual_rights: Recognizes the "right to the protection of personal data" under the Regulation as a right that must be reconciled with public access (quote: "the right to the protection of personal data pursuant to this Regulation").
organizational_rights: Permits (does not require) disclosure by the authority/body when conditions are met (quote: "may be disclosed").

general_exceptions: Where disclosure is not in accordance with applicable Union or Member State law, the permission in this section does not apply (derived from the condition attached to disclosure).
conditional_exemptions: Private bodies are only included when holding documents for performance of a public interest task; otherwise they are outside the described scope (quote: "a private body for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest").
public_interest_exceptions: The section is explicitly tied to tasks carried out in the public interest as a condition for private bodies (quote: "for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest").

organizational_measures: Implement a decision process to ensure any disclosure of personal data in official documents is made only under the applicable Union/Member State access-to-documents framework governing the entity (derived from: "in accordance with Union or Member State law to which the public authority or body is subject").

Implement a balancing/reconciliation assessment between public access and personal data protection for disclosures in this context (derived from: "in order to reconcile public access ... with the right to the protection of personal data").

related_regulations.parent_legislation: This Regulation (unnamed in the excerpt; referenced as "this Regulation")
complementary_regulations: Applicable Union law on public access to official documents (not specified in the excerpt)
Applicable Member State law on public access to official documents (not specified in the excerpt)

implementation_steps: Identify whether the requested/considered disclosure concerns "personal data in official documents".
Confirm the holder is a public authority/public body, or (if private) that it holds the documents for performance of a task carried out in the public interest.
Identify the specific Union or Member State law governing public access to official documents that the authority/body is subject to, and follow its conditions/procedures for disclosure.

Perform and document (if required by the applicable law/policies) a reconciliation/balancing analysis between public access and the right to personal data protection under the Regulation before disclosing.
common_violations: Disclosing personal data from official documents without grounding the disclosure in the applicable Union/Member State access-to-documents law.
Treating public access as automatically overriding data protection without performing a reconciliation/balancing exercise.
best_practices: Maintain a mapping of applicable access-to-documents laws and internal procedures for responding to public access requests involving personal data.
Use standardized balancing criteria aligned with the applicable access-to-documents regime and data protection obligations under the Regulation.
compliance_checklist: Is the information personal data contained in an official document?
Is the holder a public authority/public body, or a private body performing a public interest task?
What Union/Member State law governs disclosure for this entity, and have its conditions been met?
Has reconciliation between public access and data protection rights been assessed?

key_definitions.official documents: Not defined in the excerpt; referenced as documents held by a public authority/body (or certain private bodies) in the context of public access.
key_definitions.private body for the performance of a ta: A private entity holding official documents in connection with performing a task carried out in the public interest (phrase used as a scope condition; not further defined in the excerpt).
key_definitions.reconcile public access with the right t: A balancing objective requiring alignment between transparency/public access regimes and data protection rights under the Regulation (not further operationalized in the excerpt).

regulations.source_section: ## Processing and public access to official documents

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 87 (Processing of the national identification number)

description.brief_summary: Allows Member States to set specific conditions for processing national identification numbers (or similar general identifiers) and requires that any use of such identifiers occur only with appropriate safeguards for data subjectsâ€™ rights and freedoms under the GDPR.
description.detailed_explanation: This provision establishes (1) a permission for EU Member States to legislate additional, specific conditions governing the processing of a national identification number or any other identifier of general application, and (2) a mandatory safeguard requirement: when a national identification number or other general identifier is used, it must be used only under appropriate safeguards that protect the rights and freedoms of the data subject, consistent with the GDPR. The section does not enumerate what the safeguards must be, but it makes the existence of â€œappropriate safeguardsâ€ a condition of lawful/acceptable use of such identifiers when processed under the Regulation and/or under Member State-determined conditions.
description.purpose: To recognize the sensitivity and potential misuse risks of national identification numbers and similar universal identifiers, while allowing Member States to tailor specific processing conditions and ensuring protection of data subjects through safeguards.
description.legislative_intent: To balance harmonized EU data protection rules with Member State discretion over national identifiers, and to ensure that use of such identifiers is constrained by protective measures for individuals.

what_it_covers: Processing of a national identification number
Processing of any other identifier of general application
Member State specification of conditions for such processing
Use of such identifiers subject to safeguards for data subject rights and freedoms

target_entities: Member State legislators/competent national authorities (in setting conditions)
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Processing within EU Member States and/or processing subject to the GDPRâ€™s territorial scope

what_it_does_not_cover: Specific safeguard measures (not enumerated in this section)
Specific Member State conditions (not provided in this section)

mandatory_obligations: Ensure that the national identification number or any other identifier of general application is used only under appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of the data subject pursuant to the Regulation. (Quote: "shall be used only under appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of the data subject pursuant to this Regulation.")
prohibited_actions: Do not use a national identification number or other identifier of general application without appropriate safeguards for the data subjectâ€™s rights and freedoms. (Implied prohibition from "shall be used only under appropriate safeguards")
conditional_requirements: If a Member State determines specific conditions for processing a national identification number or other identifier of general application, processing must comply with those Member State-specific conditions. (Quote: "Member States may further determine the specific conditions for the processing...")

In that case (i.e., where Member States determine specific conditions), the identifier must be used only under appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of the data subject pursuant to the Regulation. (Quote: "In that case ... shall be used only under appropriate safeguards...")

general_restrictions: Use of national identification numbers and other general identifiers is restricted to contexts where appropriate safeguards for data subject rights and freedoms are in place. (Quote: "shall be used only under appropriate safeguards")
data_restrictions: Restricts the use/processing of national identification numbers and other identifiers of general application by conditioning their use on safeguards.
operational_restrictions: Organizations may need to limit or redesign processes involving national identification numbers to ensure safeguards are present and to meet any Member State-specific conditions.
geographic_restrictions: Member State discretion implies that conditions may vary by EU Member State.

individual_rights: Right to have rights and freedoms safeguarded when national identification numbers or other general identifiers are used. (Derived from the requirement for "appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of the data subject")
organizational_rights: Member States have the ability to determine specific conditions for processing national identification numbers or other general identifiers. (Quote: "Member States may further determine the specific conditions...")

organizational_measures: Implement and maintain â€œappropriate safeguardsâ€ for the rights and freedoms of the data subject when using national identification numbers or other identifiers of general application (specific measures not detailed in this section).

complementary_regulations: Member State laws setting specific conditions for processing national identification numbers or other identifiers of general application (not specified in this section)

implementation_steps: Identify whether the organization processes a national identification number or another identifier of general application.
Determine whether applicable Member State law sets specific conditions for such processing in the relevant Member State(s).

Ensure that use of the identifier occurs only with appropriate safeguards protecting data subject rights and freedoms under the GDPR (e.g., governance controls and risk-based safeguards; specific safeguards not enumerated in this section).
common_violations: Using national identification numbers as general-purpose identifiers across systems without implementing safeguards for data subject rights and freedoms.
Failing to check and comply with Member State-specific conditions governing national identification numbers.
best_practices: Apply a restrictive approach to collection and use of national identification numbers, ensuring safeguards are demonstrable and aligned with GDPR protections.
Track Member State-specific legal conditions where operations span multiple EU Member States.
compliance_checklist: Do we process a national identification number or other identifier of general application?
Which Member State(s) laws apply and do they set specific conditions for this processing?
Are appropriate safeguards in place to protect data subject rights and freedoms when the identifier is used?
Can we evidence the safeguards and their alignment with GDPR requirements (even though this section does not specify documentation duties)?

key_definitions.national identification number: Not defined in this section; referenced as a category of identifier subject to Member State conditions and safeguard requirements.
key_definitions.identifier of general application: Not defined in this section; referenced as any broadly applicable identifier treated similarly to a national identification number.
key_definitions.appropriate safeguards: Not defined in this section; required safeguards must protect the rights and freedoms of the data subject pursuant to the GDPR.

regulations.source_section: ## Processing of the national identification number

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 88 (Processing in the context of employment)

industry_sectors: All sectors employing staff in EU Member States

description.brief_summary: Allows Member States to create more specific employment-context data protection rules and requires those rules to include specific safeguards; also requires Member States to notify the Commission of such provisions by a set date and of later amendments without delay.
description.detailed_explanation: The provision establishes a mechanism for Member States to tailor data protection rules for employee personal data processing through national laws or collective agreements. It specifies the employment-related purposes for which such more specific rules may be created (e.g., recruitment, contract performance, workplace management, equality and diversity, health and safety, property protection, employment rights/benefits, and termination). It then mandates that any such national/collective-agreement rules include â€œsuitable and specific measuresâ€ safeguarding the data subjectâ€™s â€œhuman dignity, legitimate interests and fundamental rights,â€ with particular attention to transparency, intra-group transfers within corporate groups or joint economic activity groups, and workplace monitoring systems. Finally, it imposes a procedural obligation on each Member State to notify the European Commission of the adopted provisions by 25 May 2018 and to notify any subsequent amendments â€œwithout delay.â€
description.purpose: To enable employment-specific data protection rules while ensuring consistent protection of employeesâ€™ fundamental rights through mandatory safeguards and EU-level visibility via Commission notification.
description.legislative_intent: To balance flexibility for Member States and social partners (collective agreements) with minimum safeguard requirements for employee data processing, especially in sensitive areas like monitoring and intra-group transfers, and to ensure transparency to the Commission regarding national divergences.

what_it_covers: Member State adoption of more specific rules for processing employeesâ€™ personal data in the employment context
Employment-related processing purposes explicitly listed in the article
Mandatory safeguards that must be included in those more specific rules
Member State notification to the European Commission of adopted provisions and amendments

target_entities: Social partners negotiating collective agreements (where applicable under national law)
Employers and organizations processing employeesâ€™ personal data (indirectly, via national/collective rules adopted under this article)
Groups of undertakings / groups of enterprises engaged in a joint economic activity (in relation to intra-group transfers and safeguards)
entity_types: Other employing organizations (e.g., non-profits) subject to Member State rules
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies within EU Member States; cross-border relevance where transfers occur within a group of undertakings or joint economic activity group.

what_it_does_not_cover: Any employment processing rules not adopted by Member States â€œby law or by collective agreementsâ€ pursuant to paragraph 1 (not explicitly covered here)
Specific penalty amounts or enforcement procedures (not stated in this section)

mandatory_obligations: Member States may provide â€œmore specific rules to ensure the protection of the rights and freedoms in respect of the processing of employees' personal data in the employment contextâ€ (enabling provision; not mandatory to legislate, but establishes the permissible route). Quote: â€œMember States may, by law or by collective agreements, provide for more specific rules to ensure the protection of the rights and freedoms in respect of the processing of employees' personal data in the employment contextâ€.

If Member States adopt such rules, â€œThose rules shall include suitable and specific measures to safeguard the data subject's human dignity, legitimate interests and fundamental rightsâ€. Quote: â€œThose rules shall include suitable and specific measures to safeguard the data subject's human dignity, legitimate interests and fundamental rightsâ€.

Member States must notify the Commission of provisions adopted pursuant to paragraph 1 by a fixed deadline. Quote: â€œEach Member State shall notify to the Commission those provisions of its law which it adopts pursuant to paragraph 1, by 25 May 2018â€.
Member States must notify the Commission â€œwithout delayâ€ of any subsequent amendment affecting those provisions. Quote: â€œand, without delay, any subsequent amendment affecting them.â€
conditional_requirements: Where a Member State adopts more specific employment-context rules under paragraph 1, those rules must include safeguards described in paragraph 2 (condition: adoption of rules).

Safeguards must be designed â€œwith particular regard toâ€ certain risk areas: transparency of processing, intra-group transfers, and workplace monitoring (condition: designing/including safeguards). Quote: â€œwith particular regard to the transparency of processing, the transfer of personal data within a group of undertakings, or a group of enterprises engaged in a joint economic activity and monitoring systems at the work place.â€
documentation_requirements: Member State-level: the existence of â€œprovisions of its lawâ€ adopted pursuant to paragraph 1 that must be notified to the Commission (implies maintaining identifiable legal provisions for notification).
reporting_requirements: Member State notification to the European Commission of national legal provisions adopted under paragraph 1 by 25 May 2018.
Member State notification to the European Commission of any subsequent amendments affecting those provisions â€œwithout delay.â€
timeline_requirements: Notification deadline: â€œby 25 May 2018â€ for provisions adopted pursuant to paragraph 1.
Ongoing obligation: notify â€œwithout delayâ€ any subsequent amendment affecting those provisions.

general_restrictions: Any Member State-specific rules adopted under paragraph 1 are constrained by a mandatory safeguard requirement: they must include â€œsuitable and specific measuresâ€ protecting dignity, legitimate interests, and fundamental rights.
data_restrictions: The section does not set explicit data minimization/retention limits, but requires safeguards addressing transparency, intra-group transfers, and workplace monitoring, which function as constraints on how employee data may be processed under national/collective rules.
operational_restrictions: Where workplace monitoring systems are used/regulated under Member State rules, safeguards must be included with particular regard to such monitoring (imposing constraints on monitoring practices through required safeguards).
geographic_restrictions: Explicit focus on transfers â€œwithin a group of undertakings, or a group of enterprises engaged in a joint economic activityâ€ (intra-group context), requiring safeguards with particular regard to such transfers.

individual_rights: Protection of â€œrights and freedomsâ€ in respect of processing of employeesâ€™ personal data (general right-protection objective). Quote: â€œensure the protection of the rights and freedoms in respect of the processing of employees' personal dataâ€.

Safeguarding of â€œhuman dignity, legitimate interests and fundamental rightsâ€ through suitable and specific measures in Member State rules. Quote: â€œsafeguard the data subject's human dignity, legitimate interests and fundamental rightsâ€.
organizational_rights: Member States are permitted to legislate or enable collective agreements to set more specific rules for employment-context processing (regulatory competence/permission).

general_exceptions: No explicit exceptions are stated; paragraph 1 is permissive (â€œmayâ€) rather than mandatory to adopt national rules.

organizational_measures: Member State/collective agreement rules must include â€œsuitable and specific measuresâ€ safeguarding dignity, legitimate interests, and fundamental rights (organizational/legal safeguards).

Safeguards must be designed with particular regard to: (i) â€œthe transparency of processingâ€; (ii) â€œthe transfer of personal data within a group of undertakings, or a group of enterprises engaged in a joint economic activityâ€; and (iii) â€œmonitoring systems at the work place.â€

enforcement.regulatory_authority: European Commission (recipient of Member State notifications); national authorities enforce Member State laws/collective agreements (not specified in this section).
enforcement_mechanisms: Commission notification mechanism for adopted provisions and amendments (procedural oversight/visibility).

dates.compliance_deadline: 25 May 2018 (deadline for Member States to notify the Commission of provisions adopted pursuant to paragraph 1).

complementary_regulations: Member State laws and collective agreements adopted pursuant to GDPR Article 88(1) (as contemplated by this section)

implementation_steps: For Member States: if adopting employment-context processing rules, do so via â€œlaw or collective agreementsâ€ and ensure the rules are designed to protect employeesâ€™ rights and freedoms for the listed employment purposes.

For Member States: embed â€œsuitable and specific measuresâ€ safeguarding dignity, legitimate interests, and fundamental rights, explicitly addressing transparency, intra-group transfers, and workplace monitoring.
For Member States: notify the European Commission of adopted provisions by 25 May 2018 and notify subsequent amendments â€œwithout delay.â€

For employers (indirectly): identify applicable Member State employment-data rules/collective agreements adopted under Article 88 and ensure HR processing, intra-group transfers, and workplace monitoring align with the safeguards required by those rules.
common_violations: Adopting employment-context rules without including â€œsuitable and specific measuresâ€ safeguarding dignity, legitimate interests, and fundamental rights.
Failing to give particular regard to transparency, intra-group transfers, or workplace monitoring when designing safeguards in employment-context rules.
Failure by a Member State to notify the Commission by 25 May 2018 of provisions adopted under paragraph 1.
Failure by a Member State to notify the Commission â€œwithout delayâ€ of subsequent amendments affecting those provisions.
best_practices: When drafting/negotiating employment-context rules, explicitly map safeguards to the three highlighted areas: transparency, intra-group transfers, and workplace monitoring.
Maintain a formal process to track amendments to employment-data provisions and trigger Commission notification promptly.
compliance_checklist: If Member State rules/collective agreements exist under Article 88(1), do they cover the relevant employment purposes (e.g., recruitment, contract performance, management, equality/diversity, health & safety, property protection, rights/benefits, termination)?
Do those rules include â€œsuitable and specific measuresâ€ safeguarding human dignity, legitimate interests, and fundamental rights?
Do the safeguards explicitly address transparency of processing?
Do the safeguards address transfers of personal data within a group of undertakings or joint economic activity group?
Do the safeguards address workplace monitoring systems?
Has the Member State notified the Commission of the provisions by 25 May 2018 (historical compliance) and of amendments without delay (ongoing compliance)?

key_definitions.processing in the employment context: Processing of employeesâ€™ personal data related to employment activities and lifecycle events, including the purposes explicitly listed in paragraph 1 (as described in this section).
key_definitions.more specific rules: Member State rules adopted â€œby law or by collective agreementsâ€ to ensure protection of rights and freedoms in respect of employee personal data processing (as described in this section).
key_definitions.suitable and specific measures: Safeguards that must be included in Member State/collective-agreement rules to protect the data subjectâ€™s human dignity, legitimate interests, and fundamental rights, with particular regard to transparency, intra-group transfers, and workplace monitoring (as described in this section).
key_definitions.group of undertakings: Not defined in this section (term referenced as context for intra-group transfers).
key_definitions.group of enterprises engaged in a joint: Not defined in this section (term referenced as context for intra-group transfers).
key_definitions.monitoring systems at the work place: Not defined in this section (referenced as an area requiring particular safeguard attention).

regulations.source_section: ## Processing in the context of employment

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 89: Safeguards and derogations relating to processing for archiving purposes in the public interest, scientific or historical research purposes or statistical purposes

applicable_regions: EEA (via incorporation into EEA law where applicable)

industry_sectors: Private sector R&D performing scientific/historical research
Any controller/processor conducting statistical analysis involving personal data

description.brief_summary: Requires appropriate safeguards for processing personal data for archiving in the public interest, scientific/historical research, or statistical purposes, emphasizing data minimisation and allowing measures such as pseudonymisation. Permits Union/Member State law to provide derogations from specified data subject rights when necessary and when exercising those rights would make the purposes impossible or seriously impaired, and limits derogations to the qualifying purpose when processing is multi-purpose.
description.detailed_explanation: This section imposes a mandatory safeguard framework for certain special-purpose processing (archiving in the public interest, scientific or historical research, statistical purposes). Controllers must implement "appropriate safeguards" for data subjectsâ€™ rights and freedoms, specifically ensuring technical and organisational measures that respect data minimisation. The text explicitly recognizes pseudonymisation as a possible measure where the purposes can be fulfilled that way. It further requires that if the purposes can be fulfilled by further processing that does not permit (or no longer permits) identification of data subjects, then the purposes must be fulfilled in that non-identifying manner. Additionally, it authorizes (but does not itself create) derogations from certain data subject rights, but only where Union or Member State law provides them and only under strict conditions: the derogations must be subject to the safeguards in paragraph 1; the relevant rights must be likely to render impossible or seriously impair achievement of the specific purposes; and the derogations must be necessary for fulfilling those purposes. Finally, where the same processing serves another purpose, derogations apply only to the processing for the qualifying research/statistical/archiving purposes.
description.purpose: To enable socially valuable processing (archiving, research, statistics) while protecting individuals through safeguards and limiting any reduction of rights to what is necessary and proportionate for those purposes.
description.legislative_intent: To balance data subject rights with public interest and innovation needs by mandating safeguards (especially data minimisation and de-identification techniques) and by allowing narrowly tailored legal derogations only when rights would undermine the feasibility of the specific purposes.

what_it_covers: Processing of personal data for archiving purposes in the public interest
Processing of personal data for scientific research purposes
Processing of personal data for historical research purposes
Processing of personal data for statistical purposes
Implementation of safeguards (technical and organisational measures) for such processing
Use of pseudonymisation as a safeguard where feasible
Requirement to use non-identifying processing where feasible
Derogations from specified data subject rights when provided by Union/Member State law and conditions are met
Limitation of derogations in multi-purpose processing

target_entities: Processors (indirectly, via controller-implemented safeguards and measures)
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities subject to GDPR territorial scope when conducting covered processing.

what_it_does_not_cover: Derogations not provided by Union or Member State law (this section does not itself create a standalone derogation without such law)
Processing not for archiving in the public interest, scientific/historical research, or statistical purposes (unless another GDPR provision applies)

mandatory_obligations: Ensure processing for archiving in the public interest, scientific/historical research, or statistical purposes "shall be subject to appropriate safeguards" for the rights and freedoms of the data subject. (Quote: "shall be subject to appropriate safeguards")

Ensure safeguards "shall ensure that technical and organisational measures are in place" to respect data minimisation. (Quote: "shall ensure that technical and organisational measures are in place ... in order to ensure respect for the principle of data minimisation")

Where the purposes can be fulfilled by further processing that does not permit or no longer permits identification of data subjects, "those purposes shall be fulfilled in that manner." (Quote: "those purposes shall be fulfilled in that manner")
If derogations are used (where provided by Union/Member State law), they must be "subject to the conditions and safeguards referred to in paragraph 1".
prohibited_actions: Do not rely on derogations for non-qualifying purposes when processing serves multiple purposes. (Derived from Quote: "the derogations shall apply only to processing for the purposes referred to in those paragraphs")

Do not continue identifiable processing where the purposes can be fulfilled by processing that does not permit identification. (Derived from Quote: "Where those purposes can be fulfilled ... which does not permit or no longer permits the identification ... those purposes shall be fulfilled in that manner")
conditional_requirements: Safeguard measures "may include pseudonymisation provided that those purposes can be fulfilled in that manner." (Quote: "may include pseudonymisation provided that those purposes can be fulfilled in that manner")

Union or Member State law may provide derogations from rights in Articles 15, 16, 18 and 21 for scientific/historical research or statistical purposes only if: (i) subject to paragraph 1 safeguards; (ii) the rights are likely to render impossible or seriously impair achievement of the specific purposes; and (iii) derogations are necessary for fulfilment of those purposes. (Quote: "may provide for derogations ... subject to the conditions and safeguards ... in so far as such rights are likely to render impossible or seriously impair ... and such derogations are necessary")

Union or Member State law may provide derogations from rights in Articles 15, 16, 18, 19, 20 and 21 for archiving in the public interest only if: (i) subject to paragraph 1 safeguards; (ii) the rights are likely to render impossible or seriously impair achievement of the specific purposes; and (iii) derogations are necessary for fulfilment of those purposes. (Quote mirrors paragraph 3)

Where processing serves at the same time another purpose, derogations apply only to the qualifying processing purpose. (Quote: "the derogations shall apply only to processing for the purposes referred to in those paragraphs")

general_restrictions: Processing for the listed purposes is constrained by a mandatory safeguard requirement protecting data subject rights and freedoms.
Derogations are restricted to cases where rights would likely make the purpose impossible or seriously impaired and where derogations are necessary.
data_restrictions: Must respect the principle of data minimisation through technical and organisational measures. (Quote: "ensure respect for the principle of data minimisation")

Prefer processing that does not permit identification (or no longer permits identification) where feasible. (Quote: "Where those purposes can be fulfilled ... which does not permit or no longer permits the identification ... those purposes shall be fulfilled in that manner")
Pseudonymisation is contemplated as a measure where it still allows fulfilment of the purposes. (Quote: "may include pseudonymisation provided that those purposes can be fulfilled in that manner")
operational_restrictions: If relying on derogations, they must be limited to the specific qualifying purpose and not extended to other concurrent purposes. (Quote: "shall apply only to processing for the purposes referred to")
technical_restrictions: Technical measures must be in place to ensure data minimisation; pseudonymisation is an example measure where feasible.

individual_rights: This section references (and potentially limits via lawful derogations) the following data subject rights: Articles 15 (access), 16 (rectification), 18 (restriction of processing), 19 (notification regarding rectification/erasure/restriction), 20 (data portability), 21 (objection).
organizational_rights: Union or Member State lawmakers are permitted to create derogations from specified rights for the covered purposes, subject to conditions and safeguards. (Quote: "Union or Member State law may provide for derogations")

general_exceptions: Derogations are not automatic; they exist only where "Union or Member State law may provide" them.
conditional_exemptions: Derogations from Articles 15, 16, 18, 21 (research/statistics) only "in so far as" the rights are likely to render impossible or seriously impair the purposes and derogations are necessary, and only with paragraph 1 safeguards. (Quote: "in so far as such rights are likely to render impossible or seriously impair ... and such derogations are necessary")
Derogations from Articles 15, 16, 18, 19, 20, 21 (archiving in the public interest) under the same necessity/impairment and safeguard conditions.
public_interest_exceptions: Archiving purposes in the public interest is explicitly recognized as a context where Member State/Union law may provide derogations (subject to conditions and safeguards).

technical_measures: Implement technical measures to ensure respect for data minimisation for covered processing. (Quote: "technical ... measures ... to ensure respect for the principle of data minimisation")

Where feasible, implement processing that does not permit or no longer permits identification of data subjects (e.g., anonymisation or equivalent non-identifying processing), as the required manner of fulfilment when possible. (Quote: "does not permit or no longer permits the identification ... those purposes shall be fulfilled in that manner")
Consider pseudonymisation as a technical measure where the purposes can still be fulfilled. (Quote: "may include pseudonymisation")
organizational_measures: Implement organisational measures to ensure respect for data minimisation for covered processing. (Quote: "organisational measures ... to ensure respect for the principle of data minimisation")

Ensure safeguards are designed to protect "rights and freedoms of the data subject" in the covered processing contexts. (Quote: "appropriate safeguards ... for the rights and freedoms of the data subject")

If applying derogations (where provided by law), ensure internal governance limits the derogation strictly to the qualifying purpose when processing is multi-purpose. (Quote: "derogations shall apply only to processing for the purposes referred to")
security_measures: Safeguards must protect rights and freedoms; the section does not enumerate specific security controls beyond data minimisation and pseudonymisation/non-identification requirements.

related_articles: Article 5 (principle of data minimisation is referenced by name)
complementary_regulations: Union or Member State law provisions that establish specific derogations for research/statistics/archiving (not specified in the provided text)

implementation_steps: Identify whether the processing purpose qualifies as: archiving in the public interest, scientific research, historical research, or statistical purposes.
Design and implement appropriate safeguards focused on protecting data subject rights and freedoms.
Implement technical and organisational measures to ensure data minimisation for the processing.
Assess whether the purposes can be fulfilled using pseudonymised data; if yes, implement pseudonymisation.
Assess whether the purposes can be fulfilled using processing that does not permit (or no longer permits) identification; if yes, implement that approach and avoid identifiable processing.

If relying on derogations from data subject rights, verify there is a specific Union/Member State legal basis providing the derogation and document that the conditions are met: likely impossibility/serious impairment and necessity, with paragraph 1 safeguards.
If processing is multi-purpose, technically and procedurally segregate/limit the derogation to the qualifying purpose only.
common_violations: Failing to implement concrete technical/organisational measures to ensure data minimisation in research/statistics/archiving contexts.
Using identifiable data when non-identifying processing would suffice for the stated purpose.
Applying a derogation without a specific Union/Member State law providing it.
Applying derogations broadly to all processing activities rather than limiting them to the qualifying research/statistics/archiving purpose in multi-purpose processing.
best_practices: Use a structured feasibility assessment to justify why identification is necessary (or not) for the purpose, and revisit as methods evolve.
Adopt pseudonymisation by default for research/statistical datasets where direct identifiers are not required.
Implement purpose-based access controls and data segregation to ensure derogations are not inadvertently applied to other purposes.
Maintain a decision log mapping each derogated right to the legal basis, impairment rationale, necessity rationale, and safeguards applied (even though not explicitly required here).
compliance_checklist: Processing purpose qualifies (archiving in public interest / scientific or historical research / statistical).
Appropriate safeguards implemented for rights and freedoms of data subjects.
Technical and organisational measures implemented to ensure data minimisation.
Pseudonymisation implemented where purposes can be fulfilled that way.
Non-identifying processing used where purposes can be fulfilled without identification.
Any derogation is based on Union/Member State law and meets: safeguards + likely impossibility/serious impairment + necessity.
Derogations limited to qualifying purpose only when processing also serves another purpose.

key_definitions.appropriate safeguards: Not defined in the provided text; described functionally as safeguards "for the rights and freedoms of the data subject" ensuring technical and organisational measures to respect data minimisation.
key_definitions.technical and organisational measures: Measures that must be in place "in order to ensure respect for the principle of data minimisation" (specific measures not exhaustively listed).
key_definitions.pseudonymisation: Referenced as a possible measure: "may include pseudonymisation provided that those purposes can be fulfilled in that manner" (term itself not defined in the provided text).
key_definitions.derogations: Legally provided limitations on certain data subject rights that Union or Member State law may provide, subject to safeguards and necessity/impairment conditions.

regulations.source_section: ## Safeguards and derogations relating to processing for archiving purposes in the public interest, scientific or historical research purposes or statistical purposes

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 90 (Obligations of secrecy)

sub_domains: Regulatory notification to the European Commission
industry_sectors: Any sector where controllers/processors are subject to professional secrecy or equivalent secrecy obligations (e.g., legal, healthcare, banking/finance, telecommunications, public sector regulated professions)

description.brief_summary: Allows Member States to adopt specific rules governing how certain supervisory authority powers are exercised in relation to controllers/processors bound by professional secrecy or equivalent secrecy obligations, subject to necessity and proportionality and limited to data obtained in the secrecy-covered activity; requires Member States to notify the Commission of such rules and amendments.
description.detailed_explanation: This provision creates a Member State option to legislate specific national rules that tailor the exercise of supervisory authority powers referenced in GDPR Article 58(1)(e) and (f) when the supervised controller or processor is subject to professional secrecy or equivalent secrecy obligations under Union law, Member State law, or rules established by national competent bodies. The Member State rules are permitted only where they are "necessary and proportionate" to reconcile (balance) the right to protection of personal data with the secrecy obligation. The applicability of any such national rules is strictly limited: they "shall apply only" with regard to personal data that the controller or processor "has received as a result of or has obtained in an activity covered by that obligation of secrecy." Separately, the provision imposes a mandatory notification duty on each Member State to inform the European Commission of rules adopted under paragraph 1 by a fixed deadline (25 May 2018) and to notify any later amendments "without delay."
description.purpose: To enable reconciliation between GDPR supervisory enforcement powers and legally protected professional secrecy (or equivalent secrecy obligations), while ensuring transparency to the European Commission about national rules that affect supervisory authority powers.
description.legislative_intent: To preserve the effectiveness of data protection supervision while respecting established secrecy regimes (e.g., professional privilege/confidentiality) by allowing narrowly tailored national rules, constrained by necessity/proportionality and limited scope, and to ensure EU-level awareness via Commission notification.

what_it_covers: Adoption by Member States of specific national rules governing supervisory authority powers under GDPR Article 58(1)(e) and (f) in secrecy-bound contexts
Conditions for when such national rules may be adopted (necessity and proportionality to reconcile rights/interests)
Limitation of such rules to certain personal data (received/obtained through secrecy-covered activity)
Member State notification to the European Commission of adopted rules and subsequent amendments

target_entities: EU Member States (legislators/competent authorities responsible for adopting rules)
Supervisory authorities (whose powers may be set out/structured by such rules)
entity_types: Public bodies (Member State institutions and supervisory authorities)
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies within EU Member States; relevant to controllers/processors subject to Union/Member State secrecy obligations or rules established by national competent bodies.

what_it_does_not_cover: Personal data not received/obtained as a result of, or in, an activity covered by the relevant secrecy obligation (explicitly excluded by the 'shall apply only' limitation).
Supervisory authority powers other than those in GDPR Article 58(1)(e) and (f) (not addressed in this section).

mandatory_obligations: Member States that adopt rules under paragraph 1 must ensure those rules are "necessary and proportionate" to reconcile the right to protection of personal data with the obligation of secrecy. (Quote: "where this is necessary and proportionate to reconcile the right of the protection of personal data with the obligation of secrecy")

Any rules adopted under paragraph 1 must be limited in application to specific personal data. (Quote: "Those rules shall apply only with regard to personal data which the controller or processor has received as a result of or has obtained in an activity covered by that obligation of secrecy.")

Each Member State must notify the European Commission of rules adopted pursuant to paragraph 1 by 25 May 2018. (Quote: "Each Member State shall notify to the Commission the rules adopted pursuant to paragraph 1, by 25 May 2018")
Each Member State must notify the European Commission, without delay, of any subsequent amendment affecting the notified rules. (Quote: "and, without delay, any subsequent amendment affecting them.")
prohibited_actions: Member State rules adopted under paragraph 1 must not be applied beyond the specified data scope (i.e., must not apply to personal data outside the secrecy-covered activity). (Derived from: "shall apply only")
conditional_requirements: Member States may adopt specific rules only in relation to controllers/processors that are subject to professional secrecy or other equivalent obligations of secrecy under Union law, Member State law, or rules established by national competent bodies. (Quote: "in relation to controllers or processors that are subject, under Union or Member State law or rules established by national competent bodies, to an obligation of professional secrecy or other equivalent obligations of secrecy")
Member States may adopt such rules only where necessary and proportionate to reconcile data protection with secrecy. (Quote: "where this is necessary and proportionate")

The national rules may set out the powers of supervisory authorities laid down in points (e) and (f) of Article 58(1) only (i.e., the permission is limited to those powers). (Quote: "to set out the powers of the supervisory authorities laid down in points (e) and (f) of Article 58(1)")
documentation_requirements: Member State must have the adopted rules in a form capable of being notified to the Commission (implied by the notification obligation).
reporting_requirements: Notification to the European Commission of rules adopted under paragraph 1 by 25 May 2018.
Notification to the European Commission of any subsequent amendments affecting those rules without delay.
timeline_requirements: Deadline: 25 May 2018 for notifying the Commission of rules adopted pursuant to paragraph 1.
Ongoing: notify subsequent amendments "without delay" (no specific number of days provided).

general_restrictions: Member State rules are constrained by a necessity and proportionality requirement to reconcile competing interests (data protection vs secrecy).
Member State rules are limited to setting out supervisory authority powers in GDPR Article 58(1)(e) and (f) only.
data_restrictions: Rules adopted under paragraph 1 may apply only to personal data received/obtained as a result of, or in, an activity covered by the secrecy obligation. (Quote: "shall apply only with regard to personal data ... received ... or ... obtained in an activity covered by that obligation of secrecy")
operational_restrictions: Any tailoring of supervisory authority powers must be confined to secrecy-bound contexts and to the specified data scope.
geographic_restrictions: Applies at Member State level; notification obligation applies to each Member State vis-Ã -vis the European Commission.

organizational_rights: Member States are permitted (not required) to adopt specific rules to set out supervisory authority powers in secrecy-bound contexts. (Quote: "Member States may adopt specific rules")
how_to_exercise_rights: Member States exercise this permission by adopting national rules meeting the necessity/proportionality and scope limitations, and then notifying the Commission.

general_exceptions: If a controller/processor is not subject to professional secrecy or equivalent secrecy obligations under the specified legal bases, the paragraph 1 permission is not applicable.
conditional_exemptions: Even where secrecy obligations exist, Member States may only adopt rules if necessary and proportionate; otherwise the permission does not apply.

organizational_measures: Member States: establish internal processes to (a) identify whether rules have been adopted under paragraph 1, (b) notify the Commission by the deadline, and (c) notify amendments without delay.

enforcement.regulatory_authority: European Commission (recipient of notifications); Member State authorities responsible for adopting rules; supervisory authorities affected by such rules.
enforcement_mechanisms: Commission oversight via mandatory notification of national rules and amendments (mechanism specified; sanctions not specified in this section).

complementary_regulations: Union or Member State laws establishing professional secrecy or equivalent secrecy obligations (not specified in this section)
Rules established by national competent bodies imposing secrecy obligations (not specified in this section)

implementation_steps: Member State: determine whether national context requires specific rules to reconcile supervisory powers with professional secrecy/equivalent secrecy obligations.
Member State: if adopting rules, ensure a documented necessity and proportionality assessment supporting the reconciliation objective (as required by the text).
Member State: draft rules so they apply only to personal data received/obtained through secrecy-covered activities.

Member State: notify the European Commission of the adopted rules by 25 May 2018 (or, for later-adopted rules, ensure notification occurs consistent with the obligation to notify rules adopted pursuant to paragraph 1).
Member State: establish a change-management process to notify the Commission without delay of any amendments affecting the rules.
common_violations: Applying secrecy-related national limitations to supervisory authority interactions involving personal data not obtained through the secrecy-covered activity (breach of 'shall apply only' limitation).
Failing to notify the Commission of adopted rules by the deadline.
Failing to notify the Commission of amendments without delay.
Adopting rules without demonstrating necessity and proportionality to reconcile data protection with secrecy.
best_practices: Maintain a register of national rules adopted under GDPR Article 90(1) and their amendment history to support timely Commission notifications.
Define, in national rules, clear criteria for what constitutes an 'activity covered by' the secrecy obligation to avoid overbroad application (while staying within the 'shall apply only' constraint).
Implement governance to ensure supervisory authorities and secrecy-bound sectors understand the limited scope of any adopted rules.
compliance_checklist: If national rules exist under Article 90(1), do they explicitly address only Article 58(1)(e) and (f) powers?
Is there evidence the rules are necessary and proportionate to reconcile data protection with secrecy?
Do the rules limit application only to personal data received/obtained in secrecy-covered activities?
Has the Member State notified the Commission of the rules by 25 May 2018?
Are amendments notified to the Commission without delay?

key_definitions.professional secrecy: Not defined in this section; referenced as an obligation under Union or Member State law or rules established by national competent bodies.
key_definitions.equivalent obligations of secrecy: Not defined in this section; refers to secrecy obligations comparable to professional secrecy.
key_definitions.activity covered by that obligation of s: Not defined in this section; determines the boundary of the 'shall apply only' data-scope limitation.
key_definitions.notify to the Commission: A mandatory communication by each Member State to the European Commission of rules adopted under paragraph 1 and subsequent amendments.

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 91 (Existing data protection rules of churches and religious associations)

description.brief_summary: Allows churches and religious associations/communities in a Member State to continue applying comprehensive data protection rules that existed at the GDPRâ€™s entry into force, but only if those rules are brought into line with the GDPR; requires supervision by an independent supervisory authority meeting Chapter VI conditions, which may be a specific authority.
description.detailed_explanation: This provision creates a conditional continuity mechanism for certain religious bodies that already had their own comprehensive personal data protection rules when the GDPR entered into force. Continuation is not automatic: it is permitted only if those rules are updated so they are aligned with the GDPR. Additionally, where such comprehensive rules are applied, the churches/religious associations must be supervised by an independent supervisory authority.
