The supervisory authority can be a dedicated/specific authority for the religious regime, but it must satisfy the conditions set out in GDPR Chapter VI (i.e., the GDPRâ€™s requirements for supervisory authorities).
description.purpose: To accommodate pre-existing, comprehensive internal data protection regimes of churches and religious associations while ensuring GDPR-equivalent protection and independent oversight.
description.legislative_intent: To respect established church/religious community data protection frameworks in Member States, while preventing regulatory gaps by requiring GDPR alignment and independent supervision consistent with the GDPR supervisory authority model.

what_it_covers: Continuation of pre-existing comprehensive data protection rules of churches and religious associations/communities
Condition of alignment of those rules with the GDPR
Requirement for independent supervisory authority oversight for such rules
Possibility of a specific supervisory authority, subject to Chapter VI conditions

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Applies where, in a Member State, such entities apply comprehensive rules at the time of entry into force of the GDPR.

what_it_does_not_cover: Non-comprehensive rules (only 'comprehensive rules' are addressed)
Entities that did not apply such comprehensive rules at the time of entry into force
Detailed criteria for what constitutes 'comprehensive rules' (not defined in this section)
Detailed Chapter VI conditions (only referenced, not specified here)

mandatory_obligations: If churches/religious associations/communities continue to apply comprehensive rules that existed at the time of entry into force, those rules must be brought into line with the GDPR. Quote: "such rules may continue to apply, provided that they are brought into line with this Regulation."

Churches and religious associations applying comprehensive rules under paragraph 1 must be subject to supervision by an independent supervisory authority. Quote: "shall be subject to the supervision of an independent supervisory authority".

Any such supervisory authority (including a specific authority) must fulfil the conditions laid down in GDPR Chapter VI. Quote: "which may be specific, provided that it fulfils the conditions laid down in Chapter VI of this Regulation."
prohibited_actions: Continuing to apply pre-existing comprehensive rules without bringing them into line with the GDPR (implied prohibition via the condition 'provided that').
conditional_requirements: Continuation permission is conditional on two elements: (1) the rules were applied "at the time of entry into force" of the GDPR; and (2) they are "brought into line" with the GDPR.
The supervision requirement applies conditionally to churches/religious associations "which apply comprehensive rules in accordance with paragraph 1".
timeline_requirements: Temporal condition for eligibility: the comprehensive rules must be applied "at the time of entry into force of this Regulation."
No explicit deadline is stated in this section for when the rules must be brought into line; only that continuation is permitted provided alignment occurs.

general_restrictions: Continuation of church/religious comprehensive rules is restricted to those that are aligned with the GDPR.
Supervision must be by an independent supervisory authority meeting GDPR Chapter VI conditions.
operational_restrictions: Religious bodies cannot rely on internal comprehensive rules as a standalone regime unless those rules are GDPR-aligned and independently supervised.
geographic_restrictions: Applies only "where in a Member State" such entities apply comprehensive rules at the relevant time.

organizational_rights: Conditional right/permission for churches and religious associations/communities to continue applying their comprehensive data protection rules existing at the GDPRâ€™s entry into force, subject to alignment with the GDPR. Quote: "such rules may continue to apply".
how_to_exercise_rights: Maintain/continue the comprehensive rules only after bringing them into line with the GDPR and ensuring independent supervisory authority oversight meeting Chapter VI conditions.

general_exceptions: This section functions as a conditional carve-out/derogation allowing continuation of certain pre-existing comprehensive rules, rather than requiring immediate replacement, but only under the stated conditions.
conditional_exemptions: Continuation is permitted only for comprehensive rules already applied at the time of entry into force and only if aligned with the GDPR.

organizational_measures: Undertake a gap analysis and update the church/religious comprehensive rules to ensure they are "brought into line" with the GDPR (specific method not prescribed here).
Ensure governance arrangements place the regime under an "independent supervisory authority".
audit_requirements: Be subject to supervision by an independent supervisory authority (implies oversight/audit capability, but no specific audit cadence is stated here).

enforcement.regulatory_authority: An independent supervisory authority (which may be specific) that fulfils the conditions laid down in GDPR Chapter VI.
enforcement_mechanisms: Supervision by an independent supervisory authority (specific mechanisms not detailed in this section).

dates.effective_date: At the time of entry into force of this Regulation (exact date not stated in this section).

related_articles: GDPR Chapter VI (Supervisory authorities) (referenced; specific articles not identified in this section)

implementation_steps: Confirm whether the organization is a church/religious association/community applying "comprehensive rules" on data protection that were in place at the GDPRâ€™s entry into force.
Map existing comprehensive rules against GDPR requirements and update them to be "brought into line" with the GDPR.
Establish or designate an independent supervisory authority for the regime; if using a specific authority, verify it fulfils Chapter VI conditions.
Document governance and oversight arrangements demonstrating independence and Chapter VI compliance (documentation not explicitly required here, but practically necessary to evidence compliance).
common_violations: Continuing to apply legacy church/religious data protection rules without updating them to align with the GDPR.
Operating a church-specific supervisory body that is not independent or does not meet Chapter VI conditions.
best_practices: Perform periodic reviews to ensure ongoing alignment of the comprehensive rules with GDPR updates and interpretations.
Ensure structural and functional independence of the supervisory authority, consistent with Chapter VI expectations.
compliance_checklist: Are the rules 'comprehensive' and were they applied at GDPR entry into force?
Have the rules been brought into line with the GDPR (documented mapping/gap closure)?
Is there an independent supervisory authority overseeing the regime?
If the authority is specific to the church/religious regime, does it fulfil Chapter VI conditions?

key_definitions.comprehensive rules: Not defined in this section; refers to rules relating to the protection of natural persons with regard to processing that are described as 'comprehensive'.
key_definitions.brought into line with this Regulation: Not defined in this section; indicates the church/religious rules must be aligned/consistent with the GDPRâ€™s requirements.
key_definitions.independent supervisory authority: Not defined in this section; must meet the conditions laid down in GDPR Chapter VI.
key_definitions.specific supervisory authority: A supervisory authority that may be dedicated to churches/religious associations, permitted only if it fulfils Chapter VI conditions.

regulations.source_section: ## Existing data protection rules of churches and religious associations

regulations.regulation_id: EU Delegated Acts Procedure (Exercise of the delegation) â€” delegation under Article 12(8) and Article 43(8)
regulations.regulation_name: Exercise of the delegation (procedural conditions for Commission delegated acts under Article 12(8) and Article 43(8))

sub_domains: Legislative oversight (European Parliament/Council objection and revocation)
industry_sectors: All sectors affected by delegated acts adopted under Article 12(8) and Article 43(8)

description.brief_summary: Defines how the Commission may exercise delegated powers, including indefinite duration from a specified date, revocation rights of Parliament/Council, notification duties, and a three-month objection period (extendable) as a condition for entry into force.
description.detailed_explanation: This section imposes procedural and legal conditions on the Commissionâ€™s ability to adopt delegated acts under the delegations referenced in Article 12(8) and Article 43(8). It (i) states that the Commissionâ€™s power to adopt delegated acts exists only subject to the conditions in this section; (ii) grants the delegation for an indeterminate period starting 24 May 2016; (iii) allows the European Parliament or the Council to revoke the delegation at any time, with specified effects on timing and on the continued validity of already-in-force delegated acts; (iv) requires the Commission to notify adopted delegated acts simultaneously to both the European Parliament and the Council; and (v) makes entry into force conditional on the absence of objections within three months of notification (or earlier non-objection confirmations), with a possible three-month extension initiated by either the Parliament or the Council.
description.purpose: To ensure democratic oversight and control over the Commissionâ€™s exercise of delegated powers by establishing revocation rights, notification obligations, and an objection-based scrutiny period before delegated acts can take effect.
description.legislative_intent: To balance efficient rulemaking via delegation to the Commission with institutional checks by the European Parliament and the Council, ensuring transparency (notification) and accountability (revocation/objection mechanisms).

what_it_covers: Conferral of delegated power on the Commission under Article 12(8) and Article 43(8)
Duration of the delegation (indeterminate period from a fixed start date)
Revocation procedure and legal effects of revocation
Notification procedure for adopted delegated acts
Conditions and timelines for entry into force of delegated acts (objection period and extension)

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: EU institutional framework; applies to EU-level delegated acts with EU-wide effect

what_it_does_not_cover: Substantive content requirements of delegated acts under Article 12(8) and Article 43(8) (not specified here)
Procedures for implementing acts or ordinary legislative procedure (not addressed here)

mandatory_obligations: Commissionâ€™s delegated-act power is conditional: "The power to adopt delegated acts is conferred on the Commission subject to the conditions laid down in this Article."

Duration/commencement of delegation: "The delegation of power referred to in Article 12(8) and Article 43(8) shall be conferred on the Commission for an indeterminate period of time from 24 May 2016."
Notification duty upon adoption: "As soon as it adopts a delegated act, the Commission shall notify it simultaneously to the European Parliament and to the Council."

Entry-into-force condition (no objection): "A delegated act adopted pursuant to Article 12(8) and Article 43(8) shall enter into force only if no objection has been expressed by either the European Parliament or the Council within a period of three months of notification of that act to the European Parliament and the Council"
prohibited_actions: Commission must not treat a delegated act as entering into force if an objection is expressed within the applicable objection period (implied by: "shall enter into force only if no objection has been expressed...").
conditional_requirements: Revocation may occur at any time: "The delegation of power referred to in Article 12(8) and Article 43(8) may be revoked at any time by the European Parliament or by the Council."
Effect of revocation decision: "A decision of revocation shall put an end to the delegation of power specified in that decision."
Timing of revocation effectiveness: "It shall take effect the day following that of its publication in the Official Journal of the European Union or at a later date specified therein."
Non-retroactivity for acts already in force: "It shall not affect the validity of any delegated acts already in force."

Alternative to waiting full objection period: delegated act may enter into force if both institutions indicate non-objection before period ends: "or if, before the expiry of that period, the European Parliament and the Council have both informed the Commission that they will not object."
Extension of objection period: "That period shall be extended by three months at the initiative of the European Parliament or of the Council."
documentation_requirements: Revocation decision must be published in the Official Journal of the European Union to trigger default effectiveness timing: "publication in the Official Journal of the European Union" (publication is a procedural/documentation step for effectiveness).
reporting_requirements: Commission notification to European Parliament and Council upon adoption of a delegated act: "shall notify it simultaneously" (institutional reporting/communication requirement).
timeline_requirements: Delegation start date: "from 24 May 2016" (delegation effective from this date).
Revocation effective date default: "the day following" publication in the Official Journal, unless a later date is specified.
Objection period length: "within a period of three months of notification".
Objection period extension: "extended by three months" if initiated by Parliament or Council.
Notification timing: "As soon as it adopts a delegated act" (immediate/without undue delay).

general_restrictions: Commissionâ€™s delegated-act authority is constrained by the conditions in this section: "subject to the conditions laid down in this Article."
Delegated acts cannot enter into force unless the objection condition is satisfied: "shall enter into force only if no objection has been expressed..."
operational_restrictions: Delegation can be terminated by revocation at any time by Parliament or Council, limiting Commissionâ€™s ability to continue adopting delegated acts under the revoked delegation: "may be revoked at any time" and "shall put an end to the delegation of power specified in that decision."

organizational_rights: European Parliament right to revoke the delegation at any time: "may be revoked at any time by the European Parliament".
Council right to revoke the delegation at any time: "may be revoked at any time by ... the Council."
European Parliament right to object to a notified delegated act within the objection period (implied by the entry-into-force condition referencing objections by Parliament).
Council right to object to a notified delegated act within the objection period (implied by the entry-into-force condition referencing objections by Council).
European Parliament right to initiate a three-month extension of the objection period: "extended by three months at the initiative of the European Parliament".
Council right to initiate a three-month extension of the objection period: "extended by three months at the initiative of ... the Council."
how_to_exercise_rights: Revocation is exercised by adopting a "decision of revocation"; it becomes effective the day after publication in the Official Journal of the European Union or later if specified: "A decision of revocation... shall take effect the day following that of its publication... or at a later date specified therein."
Objection is exercised by expressing an objection within three months of notification: "within a period of three months of notification".

Non-objection acceleration is exercised by both Parliament and Council informing the Commission before the period expires that they will not object: "have both informed the Commission that they will not object."
Extension is exercised by either Parliament or Council taking the initiative to extend the period by three months: "at the initiative of the European Parliament or of the Council."

general_exceptions: Revocation does not invalidate delegated acts already in force: "It shall not affect the validity of any delegated acts already in force."
conditional_exemptions: Delegated act may enter into force before the end of the three-month period if both Parliament and Council inform the Commission they will not object: "if, before the expiry of that period... have both informed the Commission that they will not object."

organizational_measures: Commission must implement an internal process to ensure simultaneous notification to both the European Parliament and the Council immediately upon adoption: "shall notify it simultaneously" and "As soon as it adopts".

Commission must implement a process to track objection periods (three months, and possible extension) and ensure delegated acts are not treated as in force until conditions are met: "shall enter into force only if no objection... within... three months" and "extended by three months".

enforcement.regulatory_authority: European Parliament and Council of the European Union (institutional oversight via objection and revocation); publication in the Official Journal of the European Union is a legal effectiveness mechanism.

penalties.administrative_penalties: Institutional control mechanisms: revocation of delegation; prevention of entry into force through objection.

enforcement_mechanisms: Revocation of delegation by Parliament or Council: "may be revoked at any time".
Objection procedure preventing entry into force within the scrutiny period: "shall enter into force only if no objection has been expressed..."
Mandatory notification enabling scrutiny: "shall notify it simultaneously".

implementation_steps: Upon adopting any delegated act under Article 12(8) or Article 43(8), immediately send simultaneous notifications to the European Parliament and the Council.
Start the objection clock from the date of notification to both institutions; treat the act as not in force until the objection condition is satisfied.

Monitor for (a) objections from either institution within three months, (b) early non-objection confirmations from both institutions, and (c) any initiative by either institution extending the objection period by three months.

Track any revocation decisions; once effective (day after OJ publication unless later date specified), cease relying on the revoked delegation for future delegated acts, while maintaining validity of already-in-force delegated acts.
common_violations: Failing to notify both the European Parliament and the Council simultaneously.
Treating a delegated act as in force before the objection period expires (or before both institutions confirm non-objection).
Failing to account for a three-month extension initiated by Parliament or Council.
Continuing to act under a delegation after a revocation decision has taken effect.
best_practices: Maintain a formal notification log with timestamps and recipients (Parliament and Council) for each delegated act.
Implement a calendar-based control to prevent publication/operationalization as â€˜in forceâ€™ until the objection window closes or early non-objection is received from both institutions.
Monitor the Official Journal for publication of any revocation decision and record its effective date.
compliance_checklist: Delegation basis confirmed: act is pursuant to Article 12(8) or Article 43(8).
Notification sent simultaneously to Parliament and Council immediately after adoption.
Objection period tracked: 3 months from notification date.
Check whether Parliament or Council initiated a 3-month extension; if yes, update deadline.
Confirm no objection received from either institution within the applicable period OR confirm both institutions informed Commission they will not object before expiry.
Verify no revocation decision has taken effect that would end the relevant delegation for future acts.

keywords: Official Journal of the European Union

key_definitions.decision of revocation: A formal act by the European Parliament or the Council that ends the delegation of power specified in that decision; it takes effect the day after publication in the Official Journal of the European Union or later if specified, and does not affect the validity of delegated acts already in force.
key_definitions.objection period: A three-month period following notification of a delegated act to the European Parliament and the Council during which either institution may object; the period may be extended by three months at the initiative of either institution.

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 94 Repeal of Directive 95/46/EC

description.brief_summary: Repeals Directive 95/46/EC effective 25 May 2018 and mandates that references to the repealed Directive and its Article 29 Working Party be interpreted as references to the GDPR and the European Data Protection Board, respectively.
description.detailed_explanation: The section contains two operative rules. First, it repeals Directive 95/46/EC as of a fixed date, meaning the Directive ceases to apply from that date. Second, it provides a mandatory construction rule for legal references: (a) any reference to the repealed Directive must be read as a reference to the GDPR; and (b) any reference to the Article 29 Working Party established under the Directive must be read as a reference to the European Data Protection Board established by the GDPR. These rules are intended to ensure continuity and avoid ambiguity in legal instruments, contracts, policies, guidance, and other documents that still cite the Directive or the Article 29 Working Party after the repeal date.
description.purpose: To formally replace the prior EU data protection directive with the GDPR and ensure continuity of interpretation for existing references in legal and operational documentation.
description.legislative_intent: To eliminate legal uncertainty during the transition from Directive 95/46/EC to the GDPR by setting a clear repeal date and providing explicit interpretive substitutions for legacy references, including institutional references to the former Article 29 Working Party.

what_it_covers: Repeal of Directive 95/46/EC
Interpretation of references to Directive 95/46/EC after repeal
Interpretation of references to the Article 29 Working Party after repeal

target_entities: Contracting parties and policy owners maintaining documents referencing EU data protection law
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Entities operating within the EU legal framework or relying on EU data protection legal references in instruments applicable in the EU.

what_it_does_not_cover: No substantive data processing principles or operational controls are specified in this section beyond repeal and interpretive construction.

mandatory_obligations: Apply the repeal of Directive 95/46/EC as of the specified date. Exact quote: "Directive 95/46/EC is repealed with effect from 25 May 2018."
Construe references to the repealed Directive as references to the GDPR. Exact quote: "References to the repealed Directive shall be construed as references to this Regulation."

Construe references to the Article 29 Working Party as references to the European Data Protection Board. Exact quote: "References to the Working Party on the Protection of Individuals with regard to the Processing of Personal Data established by Article 29 of Directive 95/46/EC shall be construed as references to the European Data Protection Board established by this Regulation."
prohibited_actions: Treating references to Directive 95/46/EC as continuing to refer to an operative directive after 25 May 2018, where the construction rule applies (i.e., failing to construe them as references to the GDPR).
Treating references to the Article 29 Working Party as referring to that body rather than the European Data Protection Board, where the construction rule applies.
conditional_requirements: The construction rules apply when a document contains "References to the repealed Directive" or "References to the Working Party... established by Article 29 of Directive 95/46/EC"; in those cases, the references must be interpreted as specified.
documentation_requirements: No explicit documentation/recordkeeping requirement is stated; however, the section creates an interpretive requirement affecting how existing documentation is read.
timeline_requirements: Repeal effective date: 25 May 2018. Exact quote: "with effect from 25 May 2018."

general_restrictions: Post-repeal, legacy references are legally constrained to be interpreted as references to the GDPR and the EDPB as specified by the construction rules.
operational_restrictions: Limits interpretive discretion: stakeholders must apply the mandated construction rather than alternative interpretations for legacy references.
geographic_restrictions: Operates within the EU legal order and for instruments subject to EU law interpretation.

general_exceptions: No explicit exceptions are stated in this section.

organizational_measures: Ensure legal/compliance interpretation frameworks, templates, and reference mappings treat Directive 95/46/EC citations as GDPR citations after 25 May 2018, consistent with the construction rule.
Ensure institutional references to the Article 29 Working Party are treated as references to the European Data Protection Board for interpretive purposes, consistent with the construction rule.
training_requirements: No explicit training requirement is stated; however, compliance/legal teams may need awareness of the mandatory construction rules to avoid misinterpretation.

implementation_steps: Identify policies, contracts, notices, internal procedures, and legal analyses that reference "Directive 95/46/EC" and apply the mandated construction by treating those references as references to the GDPR.

Identify references to the "Working Party on the Protection of Individuals with regard to the Processing of Personal Data" / "Article 29 Working Party" and treat them as references to the European Data Protection Board for interpretive purposes.
Update internal legal citation guides and compliance mappings to reflect the repeal date and the construction rules to prevent inconsistent interpretation.
common_violations: Continuing to interpret legacy references to Directive 95/46/EC as if the Directive remains operative after 25 May 2018.
Continuing to treat Article 29 Working Party references as referring to that body rather than the EDPB in post-repeal interpretation.
best_practices: Maintain a controlled cross-reference table mapping Directive 95/46/EC references to GDPR equivalents for internal use.
Include a standard interpretive note in legacy documents that references to Directive 95/46/EC are to be read as references to the GDPR, consistent with the construction rule.
compliance_checklist: Directive 95/46/EC repeal date recognized as 25 May 2018 in compliance materials
Legacy references to Directive 95/46/EC are construed as GDPR references
Legacy references to the Article 29 Working Party are construed as EDPB references

key_definitions.Directive 95/46/EC: The EU Data Protection Directive repealed by this section effective 25 May 2018 (as stated: "Directive 95/46/EC is repealed with effect from 25 May 2018.").
key_definitions.Working Party on the Protection of Indiv: The body established by Article 29 of Directive 95/46/EC, references to which must be construed as references to the European Data Protection Board under this Regulation.
key_definitions.European Data Protection Board: The body established by this Regulation that replaces the Article 29 Working Party for purposes of construing references.

regulations.regulation_name: Relationship with Directive 2002/58/EC (non-duplication of obligations clause)

sub_domains: Processing of data in communications services
industry_sectors: Providers of publicly available electronic communications services

description.brief_summary: Prohibits this Regulation from imposing additional obligations on persons for certain processing activities when equivalent-objective obligations already exist under Directive 2002/58/EC.
description.detailed_explanation: The clause creates a limitation on the regulatory reach of "this Regulation" in a specific context. Where a natural or legal person is processing data "in connection with the provision of publicly available electronic communications services in public communication networks in the Union" and, for the relevant matters, that person is already "subject to specific obligations with the same objective" under Directive 2002/58/EC, then this Regulation must not add further obligations for those matters. The operative effect is a non-duplication / no-additional-burden rule tied to (i) the type of processing (connected to providing publicly available electronic communications services), (ii) the network context (public communication networks), (iii) the territorial scope (in the Union), and (iv) the existence of specific obligations under Directive 2002/58/EC that pursue the same objective for the same matters.
description.purpose: To avoid overlapping or duplicative compliance burdens and conflicting requirements between this Regulation and Directive 2002/58/EC for the same objective in the electronic communications context.
description.legislative_intent: To preserve the primacy/applicability of Directive 2002/58/EC-specific obligations for matters within its scope and prevent this Regulation from layering additional obligations where the objectives are already addressed.

what_it_covers: Processing in connection with the provision of publicly available electronic communications services
Processing occurring in the context of public communication networks
Matters for which entities are subject to specific obligations with the same objective set out in Directive 2002/58/EC

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: Provision of publicly available electronic communications services in public communication networks in the Union

what_it_does_not_cover: Processing not connected to the provision of publicly available electronic communications services
Processing not occurring in public communication networks
Matters where there are no specific obligations under Directive 2002/58/EC with the same objective

mandatory_obligations: This Regulation must not impose additional obligations on natural or legal persons for covered processing matters where Directive 2002/58/EC already imposes specific obligations with the same objective.
prohibited_actions: Imposing additional obligations under this Regulation on natural or legal persons "in relation to processing in connection with the provision of publicly available electronic communications services in public communication networks in the Union" for matters already subject to "specific obligations with the same objective" under Directive 2002/58/EC.
conditional_requirements: The non-imposition rule applies only where all of the following conditions are met: (1) the subject is a natural or legal person; (2) the processing is in connection with the provision of publicly available electronic communications services; (3) the services are provided in public communication networks; (4) the context is in the Union; and (5) for the relevant matters, the person is subject to specific obligations with the same objective set out in Directive 2002/58/EC.

general_restrictions: Regulatory limitation: this Regulation is restricted from adding obligations in the specified electronic communications context where Directive 2002/58/EC already sets specific obligations with the same objective.
operational_restrictions: Limits the ability of this Regulation to create additional compliance duties for providers/actors already regulated under Directive 2002/58/EC for the same objective.
geographic_restrictions: Applies to processing connected to services in public communication networks in the Union.

organizational_rights: Protection from additional obligations under this Regulation in the specified circumstances (non-duplication safeguard).
how_to_exercise_rights: Demonstrate that the processing is connected to publicly available electronic communications services in public communication networks in the Union and that specific obligations with the same objective apply under Directive 2002/58/EC for the matters at issue.

general_exceptions: Where Directive 2002/58/EC does not impose specific obligations with the same objective for the matter, this non-duplication limitation does not apply.
conditional_exemptions: If the obligations under Directive 2002/58/EC are not 'specific' or do not share the 'same objective' for the relevant matter, this Regulation may impose obligations (not restricted by this clause).

organizational_measures: Regulatory mapping to identify matters where Directive 2002/58/EC imposes specific obligations with the same objective, to ensure this Regulation is not applied to add additional obligations for those matters.

complementary_regulations: Directive 2002/58/EC

implementation_steps: Identify processing activities connected to the provision of publicly available electronic communications services in public communication networks in the EU.
For each relevant matter, determine whether Directive 2002/58/EC imposes specific obligations with the same objective.
Where such Directive 2002/58/EC obligations exist, ensure compliance programs do not treat this Regulation as adding extra obligations for those same matters (avoid duplicative controls).
common_violations: Applying additional compliance controls under this Regulation to matters already fully governed by specific Directive 2002/58/EC obligations with the same objective, creating unnecessary or conflicting requirements.
best_practices: Maintain a crosswalk between obligations under Directive 2002/58/EC and this Regulation to document where objectives overlap and prevent duplication.
compliance_checklist: Is the processing connected to publicly available electronic communications services?
Is the service provided in a public communication network?
Is the context within the EU?
For the matter at issue, are there specific obligations under Directive 2002/58/EC?
Do those obligations have the same objective as the obligations that would otherwise be imposed under this Regulation?
If yes, confirm no additional obligations are imposed under this Regulation for that matter.

industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data subject to EU data protection law

description.brief_summary: Legacy international agreements on personal data transfers concluded by Member States before 24 May 2016 remain in force if they complied with Union law applicable before that date, until they are amended, replaced, or revoked.
description.detailed_explanation: This clause creates a continuity rule for international agreements that involve transferring personal data to (i) third countries or (ii) international organisations. It applies only to agreements concluded by EU Member States before a fixed cut-off date ("prior to 24 May 2016"). Continuity is conditional: the agreement must "comply with Union law as applicable prior to that date". If the condition is met, the agreement "shall remain in force" and continues to have legal effect, but only until one of three terminating events occurs: the agreement is "amended, replaced or revoked". The clause does not prescribe how amendments/replacements/revocations must occur, nor does it specify any notification, approval, or documentation steps; it only sets the legal status of qualifying agreements over time.
description.purpose: To avoid automatic invalidation or disruption of pre-existing Member State international agreements governing personal data transfers, while ensuring only those consistent with pre-24 May 2016 Union law benefit from continued validity.
description.legislative_intent: To provide legal certainty and continuity for legacy transfer arrangements, while limiting that continuity to agreements that were lawful under the Union legal framework applicable at the time they were concluded.

what_it_covers: International agreements involving the transfer of personal data
Transfers of personal data to third countries
Transfers of personal data to international organisations
Agreements concluded by EU Member States before 24 May 2016
Ongoing validity of qualifying agreements until amendment, replacement, or revocation

target_entities: EU Member States (as parties concluding international agreements)
entity_types: Public authorities/governments of EU Member States
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: EU Member States; cross-border context involving third countries or international organisations

what_it_does_not_cover: Agreements concluded on or after 24 May 2016
Agreements not involving transfers of personal data
Agreements concluded by entities other than Member States (not specified as covered)
Agreements that did not comply with Union law applicable prior to 24 May 2016

mandatory_obligations: Qualifying agreements "shall remain in force" (continuity requirement/mandate).
conditional_requirements: Continuity applies only if the agreement was "concluded by Member States prior to 24 May 2016".
Continuity applies only if the agreement "compl[ies] with Union law as applicable prior to that date".
Continuity lasts only "until amended, replaced or revoked".
timeline_requirements: Cut-off date condition: agreements must be concluded "prior to 24 May 2016".
Duration condition: agreements remain in force "until amended, replaced or revoked" (no fixed end date).

general_restrictions: Only agreements meeting both the date condition and the compliance-with-prior-Union-law condition benefit from continued validity.
data_restrictions: Applies specifically to "transfer of personal data" to "third countries or international organisations".
operational_restrictions: The continued force of the agreement is limited temporally by amendment, replacement, or revocation.
geographic_restrictions: Transfers must be to "third countries" or "international organisations" (cross-border/international context).

organizational_rights: Member States retain the ability to keep qualifying pre-24 May 2016 agreements in effect until they choose to amend, replace, or revoke them (implicit continuity/validity effect).

general_exceptions: Agreements not compliant with "Union law as applicable prior to [24 May 2016]" do not benefit from the 'remain in force' rule.
conditional_exemptions: If an agreement is amended, replaced, or revoked, the continuity rule no longer applies to the agreement in its prior form.

dates.compliance_deadline: 24 May 2016 (eligibility cut-off for agreements concluded prior to this date)

related_regulations.parent_legislation: Union law (unspecified in the provided text) governing personal data transfers applicable prior to 24 May 2016

implementation_steps: Inventory international agreements involving transfers of personal data to third countries or international organisations.
Identify which agreements were concluded by the Member State prior to 24 May 2016.
Assess/document whether each such agreement complied with Union law applicable prior to 24 May 2016 (as the condition for continued force).
Track whether any qualifying agreement has been amended, replaced, or revoked, as this ends the continuity status for the prior agreement.
common_violations: Treating a pre-24 May 2016 agreement as automatically preserved without verifying it complied with Union law applicable prior to that date.
Assuming agreements concluded on/after 24 May 2016 are covered by this continuity rule.
best_practices: Maintain a dated register of relevant international agreements and their status (in force/amended/replaced/revoked).
Maintain a legal assessment memo evidencing compliance with Union law applicable prior to 24 May 2016 for each agreement relying on this clause.
compliance_checklist: Does the instrument qualify as an 'international agreement'?
Does it 'involv[e] the transfer of personal data'?
Is the recipient a 'third countr[y]' or 'international organisation'?
Was it 'concluded by Member States prior to 24 May 2016'?
Did it 'comply with Union law as applicable prior to that date'?
Has it been 'amended, replaced or revoked'?

key_definitions.International agreements: Agreements involving the transfer of personal data to third countries or international organisations concluded by Member States (no further definition provided in the text).
key_definitions.Third countries: Countries outside the relevant Union legal area (term used but not defined in the text).
key_definitions.International organisations: International bodies/organisations (term used but not defined in the text).
key_definitions.Remain in force: Continue to be legally effective until amended, replaced, or revoked (as stated in the text).

regulations.regulation_name: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation) â€” Article 97 Commission reports

sub_domains: Supervisory authority cooperation and consistency (review focus)
industry_sectors: All sectors processing personal data within GDPR scope

description.brief_summary: Requires the European Commission to submit and publish periodic evaluation and review reports on the Regulation, focusing on specified areas, with the ability to request information and an obligation to consider institutional positions and propose amendments if needed.
description.detailed_explanation: The provision establishes a recurring review mechanism. It mandates that the Commission produce an evaluation and review report by a fixed initial deadline and at a fixed recurring interval thereafter, submit it to the European Parliament and the Council, and make it public. It further specifies minimum subject-matter that must be examined during these evaluations/reviews, namely the application and functioning of Chapter V (international transfers) with particular attention to adequacy decisions under GDPR Article 45(3) and legacy adequacy decisions under Directive 95/46/EC Article 25(6), and Chapter VII (cooperation and consistency). To support the evaluation, the Commission is empowered to request information from Member States and supervisory authorities. When conducting the evaluation/review, the Commission must take into account positions and findings of the European Parliament, the Council, and other relevant bodies or sources. Finally, if necessary, the Commission must submit appropriate proposals to amend the Regulation, particularly considering developments in information technology and the state of progress in the information society.
description.purpose: To ensure ongoing oversight, accountability, and adaptability of the Regulation through periodic evaluation, transparency via publication, and a pathway to legislative amendment responsive to practical experience and technological/social developments.
description.legislative_intent: To institutionalize a structured, recurring review cycle led by the Commission, ensure democratic oversight by reporting to Parliament and Council, focus scrutiny on key operational areas (international transfers and consistency mechanisms), and enable timely updates to maintain effectiveness amid evolving technology and society.

what_it_covers: Commission evaluation and review of the Regulation
Submission of evaluation/review reports to the European Parliament and the Council
Public disclosure of the reports
Examination of application and functioning of specified GDPR chapters (Chapter V and Chapter VII)
Information-gathering from Member States and supervisory authorities for evaluation purposes
Consideration of positions/findings from EU institutions and other relevant bodies/sources
Submission of proposals to amend the Regulation when necessary

who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: European Union institutional competence

what_it_does_not_cover: No direct operational compliance duties for controllers/processors are specified in this section (it is an institutional reporting/review obligation).

mandatory_obligations: Commission must submit a report on the evaluation and review of the Regulation to the European Parliament and to the Council. Quote: "the Commission shall submit a report on the evaluation and review of this Regulation to the European Parliament and to the Council."
Commission must meet the initial deadline. Quote: "By 25 May 2020".
Commission must repeat reporting at the specified interval. Quote: "and every four years thereafter".
Commission must make the reports public. Quote: "The reports shall be made public."

In the context of the evaluations and reviews, Commission must examine specified areas. Quote: "the Commission shall examine, in particular, the application and functioning of" Chapter V and Chapter VII.

Commission must take into account specified inputs when carrying out evaluations and reviews. Quote: "the Commission shall take into account the positions and findings of the European Parliament, of the Council, and of other relevant bodies or sources."
Commission must submit proposals to amend the Regulation if necessary. Quote: "The Commission shall, if necessary, submit appropriate proposals to amend this Regulation".

When preparing amendment proposals, Commission must particularly take into account specified considerations. Quote: "in particular taking into account of developments in information technology and in the light of the state of progress in the information society."
conditional_requirements: If the Commission deems it necessary, it must submit appropriate proposals to amend the Regulation. Quote: "shall, if necessary, submit appropriate proposals to amend this Regulation".

When conducting evaluations/reviews, the Commission must in particular examine Chapter V with particular regard to certain decisions. Quote: "with particular regard to decisions adopted pursuant to Article 45(3) of this Regulation and decisions adopted on the basis of Article 25(6) of Directive 95/46/EC".
documentation_requirements: Preparation of an evaluation and review report (deliverable document). Quote: "submit a report on the evaluation and review".
reporting_requirements: Report submission recipients: European Parliament and Council. Quote: "to the European Parliament and to the Council".
Publication requirement: reports must be made public. Quote: "shall be made public".
timeline_requirements: Initial report deadline: 25 May 2020. Quote: "By 25 May 2020".
Recurring interval: every four years after the initial deadline. Quote: "every four years thereafter".

general_restrictions: The evaluation/review must include, at minimum, examination of specified chapters/areas (i.e., the Commissionâ€™s discretion is constrained by mandatory focus areas). Quote: "shall examine, in particular".
operational_restrictions: The Commissionâ€™s evaluation/review process must consider positions/findings of specified institutions and other sources, limiting unilateral assessment. Quote: "shall take into account".

organizational_rights: Commission may request information from Member States and supervisory authorities for evaluation purposes. Quote: "the Commission may request information from Member States and supervisory authorities."
how_to_exercise_rights: Not specified (the provision states the Commission 'may request' information but does not define procedure, format, or deadlines).

conditional_exemptions: Amendment proposals are required only "if necessary". Quote: "shall, if necessary".

organizational_measures: Establish an internal process/calendar to ensure the report is produced by 25 May 2020 and every four years thereafter.
Ensure mechanisms to publish the reports (public availability).

Ensure evaluation methodology includes mandatory examination areas: Chapter V (with particular regard to adequacy decisions under GDPR Article 45(3) and Directive 95/46/EC Article 25(6)) and Chapter VII.
Ensure evaluation process includes collection and consideration of positions/findings from European Parliament, Council, and other relevant bodies/sources.
audit_requirements: Periodic evaluation/review itself functions as a mandated assessment cycle (no separate audit standard specified).

penalties.reputational_consequences: Reports must be public, creating transparency and potential political/reputational accountability. Quote: "The reports shall be made public."

enforcement_mechanisms: Political/institutional oversight via mandatory submission to the European Parliament and the Council. Quote: "submit ... to the European Parliament and to the Council".
Transparency mechanism via mandatory publication. Quote: "shall be made public".

dates.compliance_deadline: 25 May 2020 (initial report submission deadline); every four years thereafter (recurring).
dates.review_date: Every four years after 25 May 2020 (recurring review/report cycle).

related_articles: GDPR Article 45(3) (decisions adopted pursuant to Article 45(3))
complementary_regulations: Directive 95/46/EC Article 25(6) (decisions adopted on the basis of Article 25(6))
superseded_regulations: Directive 95/46/EC (referenced for legacy adequacy decisions; not stated as superseded in this section)

implementation_steps: Create a four-year reporting cycle plan starting from 25 May 2020.

Define evaluation scope to include at least: (i) Chapter V functioning, emphasizing adequacy decisions under GDPR Article 45(3) and legacy decisions under Directive 95/46/EC Article 25(6); (ii) Chapter VII functioning.
Set up information request channels to Member States and supervisory authorities to support evaluation (as needed).
Collect and document positions/findings from European Parliament, Council, and other relevant bodies/sources and incorporate them into the evaluation.
Publish the final report to ensure it is publicly accessible.
If evaluation indicates need for changes, prepare and submit appropriate amendment proposals, explicitly considering IT developments and information society progress.
common_violations: Missing the four-year reporting cadence or initial deadline.
Failing to make the report public.
Conducting an evaluation that does not cover the mandated focus areas (Chapter V and Chapter VII) or does not give particular regard to the specified adequacy decisions.
Failing to take into account positions/findings of the European Parliament, Council, and other relevant bodies/sources.
best_practices: Maintain a standing evaluation framework with predefined data sources and stakeholder input channels.
Track adequacy decisions and cooperation/consistency outcomes continuously to reduce reporting burden at the four-year mark.
Document how institutional positions/findings were considered to evidence compliance with the 'take into account' requirement.
compliance_checklist: Report prepared and submitted to European Parliament and Council by required date.
Report made public.
Evaluation includes Chapter V functioning with particular regard to GDPR Article 45(3) decisions and Directive 95/46/EC Article 25(6) decisions.
Evaluation includes Chapter VII functioning.
Information requests to Member States/supervisory authorities made where needed and inputs incorporated.
Positions/findings of European Parliament, Council, and other relevant bodies/sources considered and documented.
If necessary, amendment proposals submitted, considering IT developments and information society progress.

key_definitions.evaluation and review report: A report the Commission must submit to the European Parliament and the Council assessing the Regulationâ€™s application and functioning, and which must be made public (no further definition provided in the section).
key_definitions.every four years thereafter: A recurring periodicity requiring the Commission to repeat the report submission at four-year intervals following 25 May 2020 (no further calculation method specified).
key_definitions.may request information: A discretionary power allowing the Commission to seek information from Member States and supervisory authorities for the purpose of the evaluation/review (no procedure specified).
key_definitions.shall take into account: A mandatory consideration requirement obliging the Commission to consider positions and findings of specified institutions and other relevant bodies/sources when conducting evaluations/reviews (no weighting specified).

regulations.regulation_name: This Regulation (unnamed in provided excerpt)

description.brief_summary: Establishes when the Regulation enters into force, when it applies, and confirms its binding and directly applicable nature across all EU Member States.
description.detailed_explanation: The section imposes a legally operative timeline and legal effect for the Regulation. It specifies (1) the entry-into-force rule tied to publication in the Official Journal of the European Union, (2) a fixed application date from which the Regulation applies, and (3) the Regulationâ€™s legal character as binding in its entirety and directly applicable in all Member States (i.e., it applies without national transposition). Exact operative text includes: "This Regulation shall enter into force on the twentieth day following that of its publication in the Official Journal of the European Union."; "It shall apply from 25 May 2018."; and "This Regulation shall be binding in its entirety and directly applicable in all Member States."
description.purpose: To define the temporal effect (entry into force and application) and the legal effect (binding and direct applicability) of the Regulation across the EU.
description.legislative_intent: To ensure uniform and simultaneous applicability across Member States by setting a clear application date and confirming direct applicability without transposition.

what_it_covers: Entry into force timing relative to Official Journal publication
Application start date
Binding force and direct applicability in Member States

target_entities: All persons and entities subject to EU law within Member States (not further specified in excerpt)
who_it_applies_to.geographic_presence: All EU Member States

what_it_does_not_cover: No substantive compliance duties, procedures, thresholds, or sector-specific obligations are specified in this excerpt beyond timing and legal effect.

mandatory_obligations: Entry into force must occur "on the twentieth day following" publication in the Official Journal of the European Union. (Quote: "This Regulation shall enter into force on the twentieth day following that of its publication in the Official Journal of the European Union.")
The Regulation must apply from the specified date. (Quote: "It shall apply from 25 May 2018.")

The Regulation must be treated as binding in its entirety and directly applicable in all Member States. (Quote: "This Regulation shall be binding in its entirety and directly applicable in all Member States.")
conditional_requirements: The entry-into-force date is conditional on the date of publication in the Official Journal of the European Union; it is calculated as the 20th day after publication. (Quote: "on the twentieth day following that of its publication")
timeline_requirements: Entry into force: 20 days after publication in the Official Journal of the European Union. (Quote: "enter into force on the twentieth day following that of its publication")
Application date: 25 May 2018. (Quote: "apply from 25 May 2018")

general_restrictions: Member States may not require transposition for applicability because the Regulation is "directly applicable" (legal effect stated; no further operational restriction specified in excerpt).
geographic_restrictions: Applies across "all Member States". (Quote: "directly applicable in all Member States")

dates.effective_date: 20 days after publication in the Official Journal of the European Union

implementation_steps: Determine the Official Journal publication date for the Regulation and calculate the entry-into-force date as publication date + 20 days.
Ensure compliance readiness by the application date: 25 May 2018.
Treat the Regulation as directly applicable across all Member States (no reliance on national transposition for applicability).
common_violations: Miscomputing the entry-into-force date by not using the Official Journal publication date as the reference point.
Assuming national implementing legislation is required before obligations apply, despite direct applicability.
best_practices: Record the Official Journal publication date and maintain an internal legal register with the calculated entry-into-force date and the fixed application date.
Align compliance program milestones to the application date rather than the entry-into-force date where substantive obligations begin at application.
compliance_checklist: Official Journal publication date identified and documented
Entry-into-force date calculated as +20 days and documented
Application date (25 May 2018) reflected in compliance timelines
Internal guidance reflects that the Regulation is binding in its entirety and directly applicable in all Member States

keywords: Official Journal of the European Union
